column10: not only did this game change my brain chemistry, it also changed my brain structure. you know how pokémon fans grow a new section of their brain dedicated just to pokémon? morrowind did that to me. and you know what? there's STILL things i keep finding out about this game after playing it multiple times and discussing it at length online. it is actually just that good. if there is one thing i hope for in this world, i hope that one day there will be a spiritual successor to morrowind. even if that never happens though, morrowind is forever.

The gameplay is terrible; the game-engine is simply not made with engaging gameplay in mind. But that was never what made The Elder Scrolls good. What has always made The Elder Scrolls games worth playing, at least starting with 3, is the amount of love poured in the crafting of the world and its lore, and you get to be a part of that lore. Few games match the feeling of immersion in exploring an alien world that has been molded by the history you read in its books, hear from its inhabitants, and see in its architecture and politics. This is an old game, so it asks more from your imagination than the latest installments. A few examples: point-blank hits on your opponents will sometimes not register if your skills are not high enough, npcs can't travel between interior and exterior loading zones, and there are many static npcs who never move from a single spot. But, if you can get past these shortfalls, there is something really special here that even the later installments have still not lived up to.

I'm conflicted about this, young me would have given a positive review to this game without a doubt, but back then gamers really didn't care much about good written stories, proper UX nor balanced gameplay mechanics.

The truth is Bethesda has always sucked at making games, but they sucked less that their competition, and they also were always ambitious in scope, so their games looked like ground breaking at the time when they were just the same McD combo but in a much larger size.

Now there are studios that are much better at making the kind of games they are known for (some of them were once subcontractors of theirs). And it doesn't seem fair but it's not really possible not to judge Bethesda's old content without current day realization that they have always been bad at so many things that we once shrugged off.

Morrowind's writing is atrocious. The many problems this game's story has is a foreshadowing of all the bad writing that Bethesda put us through in later games, which eventually culminated in the absolute garbage that is Starfield. It seems the financial success made the people involved just get bolder and bolder in their twisted sense of storytelling.

It's such a waste too, the original concept for the story has so much promise (prisoner conscripted to become a spy for the empire because they match the conditions for some obscure local prophecy, prophecy turns out to be real), but it just becomes a nauseating sequence of poorly written "fetch this" / "kill that" quests that never manage to drive the narrative tension anywhere, and resolves in the most boringly dull manner possible.

There's no need to go in depth about poorly balanced gameplay mechanics, it's just a staple of Bethesda's games that they need no introduction. You either have a really hard time or you just breeze through using stuff that feel like you are cheating. It's also very likely that you'll reach the endgame having totally broken the game, removing all challenge from it, as it's customary with Bethesda's games. You know... "it just works".

Honestly, the gameplay abusing meta-game is more fun than the actual game, as in it's actually more fun finding creative ways to break the game than actually playing the game.
Fortify and Fortify to Fortify my Fortifications which then Fortify the aforementioned Fortifications that Fortify my character. It's great!

Mechanics are hopelessly terrible as in all Bethesda RPG games, but you're not here for the mechanics - you're here for the best art direction and world building in TES franchise history (prior or subsequent).
I highly recommend playing this game because of the amazing story and worldbuilding, the gameplay mechanics are quite dated but can be learned with playing the game

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind é o último jogo da saga que leva a história de Tamriel suficientemente a sério. O fato de que esse jogo é de 2002, é entristecedor levando em conta a última afirmação, porque fazem mais de 21 anos que essa franquia não vê um jogo que pode equiparar-se com o terceiro, no quesito de importância e de responsabilidade com a história desse universo.

Eu digo importância, mas em todos os jogos, salvo alguns spin-offs, os eventos da história principal sempre são catastróficos, cataclismas que caem sobre os ombros do jogador, um prisioneiro sem nome, sem raça, sem rosto e sem relevância antes da história que se passa o jogo.

O jogador é como dito anteriormente, um zé ninguém, requisitados pelo próprio imperador Uriel para chegar até Seyda Neen, e receber um pacote para entregá-lo a um homem chamado Caius Cosades, na cidade de Balmora. A partir desse ponto, o jogador pode começar uma exploração sem fim, que pode culminar em dezenas de níveis e experiência em habilidades diversas. Pessoalmente, eu sigo uma regra pra jogos do gênero RPG de mundo aberto: Explorar um local novo, começar todas as sidequests, terminá-las, e avançar para a próxima área. 
Isso me mantém mais dedicado a observar cada parte de cada área do jogo, principalmente porque Morrowind é daqueles jogos que não seguram sua mão pra te dizer o que você tem que fazer, você tem um diário que resume o que um NPC disse sobre uma quest, e é isso. Sem bússola, sem um mini-mapa, sem um mapa muito detalhado (usando o OpenMW dá pra dar um zoom, que é uma ajuda legal, mas não é muita coisa). Tudo o que você tem pra te guiar é sua astúcia, e direções que os NPCS te dão que muitas vezes são vagas, e portanto, você vai com certeza passar uns bons minutos tentando achar uma porta no meio de um terreno baldio recheado de árvores secas, cinzas vulcânicas, e muito, muito, muito cliff racer.

Falando em Cliff Racer, um aspecto de design desse jogo é interessante. Você é um forasteiro, outlander, você não nasceu em Vvardenfell, ou Morrowind, e as pessoas sabem disso, e mesmo que você seja um dunmer assim como 90% da população dessa ilha, você ainda vai ser discriminado e esnobado. Das criaturas, com a exceção algumas, talvez menos que cinco, toda a fauna de Vvardenfell odeia você, sua aparência, e sua existência, e as criaturas malditas vão te perseguir até o inferno pra tentar expurgar você desse plano de existência, se brincar mesmo quando você morrer e aparecer em algum plano de Oblivion eles ainda vão querer te caçar.
Deu pra perceber que uma parte significativa desse jogo te odeia, só por você ser, e olha que eu nem falei dos Telvanni. E com esse contexto em mente, o aspecto que falei ser interessante é a respeito do vilão principal, Dagoth Ur. Quase tudo nesse jogo te odeia, menos o vilão. De todas as pessoas que poderiam te oferecer amizade, ou palavras gentis, quem faz isso é justamente aquele que você eventualmente vai enfrentar, e derrotar. Quando eu reparei nisso eu me senti muito mais ligado à atmosfera, à história que esse jogo queria contar.

E falando em história, que lore sensacional é a dos Dwemer. Todo o contexto dessa civilização, sua arquitetura, seus ideais, suas roupas, e criações, as grandes cidades subterrâneas, tudo é muito interessante, e culmina infinitamente em Kagrenac e seus artesãos, criando um deus, de metal e vapor. Boa parte dessas informações são reveladas a partir de uma quest que inicialmente você pode pensar ser apenas uma zoeira, mas lembrando de Edwinna da Guilda dos Magos de Ald-Ruhn, você decide levar um livro dwemer pensando se ela pode dizer algo sobre, e é a partir desse momento que você consegue ter pequenos vislumbres por meio dos diálogos dela e de outros NPCs de contos da força dos dwemer, e eventualmente, você acumula conhecimento por meio do que esses personagens dizem sobre livros como The Egg of Time, ou Divine Metaphysics.

Sobre a campanha, não são tantas quests, e nem tão interessantes, mas o Caius é daora. Até o ponto que você enfrenta um dos seguidores de Dagoth Ur, que te contamina com Corprus no último suspiro, te levando a conhecer Tel Fyr e o mago de quatro mil anos de idade, Divayth Fyr. No Corprusarium abaixo de sua torre, você se encontra com um dos seres mais importantes pra lore de Elder Scrolls. [spoiler]O último Dwemer vivo, Yagrum Bagarn[/spoiler]. Inclusive, na quest pra descobrir a resposta pro desaparecimento dos dwemer, você pode mostrar essa questão e os livros pra ele, e ele dirá o que sabe, que não é muito, mas ainda é entusiasmante ouvir o que ele tem a dizer. A partir dessa quest, a campanha fica bem mais interessante, por você finalmente começar a cumprir com as profecias do Nerevarine, Hortator Das Grandes Casas, Aquele Que Uniu As Tribos, portador da Lua-e-Estrela, o Encarnado. 
E por fim, temos a Montanha Vermelha, o lugar onde tudo vai terminar. A Ghostfence foi construída pelos Buyoant Armigers e Ordinators pra evitar que a tempestade de pragas, doenças e Corprus assolasse toda a ilha de Resdayn. E é por ela que você precisa passar pra visitar cada cidadela dos Dwemer que circunda a torre de fogo e encontrar os instrumentos de Kagrenac, [spoiler]Sunder[/spoiler] e [spoiler]Keening[/spoiler]. Das cidadelas a mais interessante pra mim com certeza foi [spoiler]a biblioteca de Kagrenac[/spoiler].  

Agora, não é como se esse jogo fosse perfeito (é sim), ele obviamente tem defeitos. Muitos deles porque é um jogo bem datado, de 21 anos atrás. A maioria desses defeitos é remediável por meio de mods, coisas como o MGE XE, o Code Patch, OpenMW, entre outros mods que dão uma nova vida pro jogo, deixando ele num padrão gráfico mais aceitável, principalmente quando o render distance é aumentado e aquela névoa que te impede de ver a mais de 30 metros de distância desaparece.
As mecânicas de gameplay também fazem o jogo ser muito intimidante e nenhum pouco beginner friendly, o fato do jogador precisar se atentar a mais de três valores diferentes pra saber se seu ataque vai acertar um alvo que está a menos de 30 centímetros de distância é frustrante pra quem não tem muita paciência ou vontade de aprender a jogar o jogo.
Eu poderia fazer um comentário elitista dizendo que adolescente que só joga cod, lol ou roblox, e nunca encostou num jogo que saiu antes de 2015 nunca conseguiria jogar Morrowind, o que é possivelmente verdade, mas eu estaria mentindo se eu dissesse que a mecânica de combate é agradável, principalmente quando você tem que lutar contra cliff racers a cada 2 minutos [spoiler](Ave São Jiub)[/spoiler]. Mas, longe de mim dizer que isso torna Morrowind injogável. É tipo café, com o tempo você acostuma a tomar.

The Elder Scrolls: Morrowind opened a lot of doors for me and I’m usually the action RPG player that has a short attention span for games. However, Morrowind grounded me and taught me a great deal of patience and to center myself in the world I’m in. That’s why I’m forever thankful for it and I can’t wait to delve deep into the next RPG universe the same way.

This game boasts perhaps the most captivating story and setting I've ever encountered in the gaming industry. I must add that I categorically dislike Oblivion and Skyrim for their flat plot, which can only be interesting to a three-year-old child.
The game is quite old and has many non-obvious mechanics and bugs. Unfortunately, even with unofficial patches available, you will have to resort to using the Internet to get further and fix some bugs.
As a starter pack I highly recommend:
1. Morrowind code patch - fixes a huge number of errors and bugs.
2. MGE XE – allows you to increase the draw distance and change the Menu UI scaling.

This game is 20 years old. 20. I have trouble playing even some newer games. I could never get into games like Halo: Reach, or Resident Evil 4. I had no issue playing Morrowind non-stop for a 4-5 days, and playing it for multiple hours the following days. 

Morrowind is undoubtedly the best Elder Scrolls, and if I may, one of; if not the best WRPGs of it's kind (I say WRPG because I think that OMORI is better, but OMORI is a JRPG, that is to say, nothing alike Morrowind).

I am not going to write an extensive review, because I think there are people who have done much better jobs than me at explaining every little feature and quest, but I can say this: If you like Tabletop RPGs or CRPGs, and you are okay with reading and outdated graphics, I think you will like Morrowind, and even if you don't like those things, I recommend you give Morrowind a shot anyway.

The best Elder Scrolls game. The world is dense, the dungeons aren't as artificially laid-out and can have actually real rewards, the NPCs are all mean to you, half of the map is literally an inhospitable wasteland of sulfurous wind and lava fields and lovecraftian monsters, there is a full in-game library's worth of relevant (and sometimes practically helpful) lore, many factions have goals that come in direct conflict with other factions, the game ultimately wants the player to limit-break with enchanting/spellmaking/alchemy and become enormously powerful, nobody is invulnerable, and cities are both much larger and contain many more quests that don't involve more dungeon-crawling. Except for Tribunal. If you don't like the combat then get rich and find a trainer to raise your skills for dirt cheap--there is no "just right" for Morrowind i.e. you can either be so weak that a rat can kill you or so strong that literally nothing can stop you and the moment that change happens is when the game's true greatness is revealed.

You'll know you've made it when you're casually leaping around Vvardenfell like it's Prototype, one-shotting literally anything that dares stand up against the flying fashion god that you've become.

Just remember to download OpenMW and go through the simple process of tweaking that before you start. Makes Morrowind feel almost like a modern game again and adds a number of QoL changes that are invaluable for a frustration-free playthrough. Your load times and your eyes will thank you later.

This game is an all-time classic. Some of the systems and oddities of this game can make it less appealing to newer audiences, but I got into this game for the first time in 2022 and can say that this is a game that needs to be experienced by those willing to learn the different mechanics and old systems. There is really nothing else out there like this game. While I love Oblivion, Skyrim, Souls games, and other more modern takes on these kinds of games, this game still holds its place as a great of the genre that will be looked back upon fondly for the rest of human history.

This is the most brutal yet rewarding "modern" Elder Scrolls game. No convenient fast travel is a pain, until you become a strong enough sorcerer to make your own travels go fast. The game keeps its dice roll attack system from Daggerfall, so you keep missing 8/10 attacks, which is pretty lame until you can kill the local god-king in a single sweep of the blade. This game has no level scaling unlike the future games, which is kind of...no no, level scaling sucks this is objectively better. Kind of hard to think that this was made by the same Todd Howard that made Starfield.

With it's dated graphics, dated combat system, almost no voice lines for the NPC's, it is still my favourite Elder Scrolls Game.

The lore of Morrowind is amazing. The odd architecture made up of mushrooms and crab shells, the wilderness and it's animals is all so damn good.

The world is very well built and there's always new stuff to find and explore. If you can get past the graphics, no voice lines and the combat system, this is a phenomenal game.

I do recommend modding the game to take care of some bugs and eventually trying Tamriel Rebuilt. The modding community has been working on this game for so long, there's a mod for everything.

My home away from reality.

My introduction to the Elder Scrolls series was Oblivion, which I really enjoyed, spending many hours adventuring in the province of Cyrodiil.  More recently, I read about Morrowind, and how many people thought it was better than Oblivion and even Skyrim, which I'd also played, so I had to try it out.

I did a lot of research on mods, as I wanted to play through the original game, but with improved graphics and some of the rough edges smoothed off.  After much fiddling, I finally settled on a mod list that I was happy with and embarked on another 100+ hours adventure!

Morrowind is a strange, unearthly place, with bizarre landscapes and architecture.  It's very different to Oblivion, which is very much cast in the medieval fantasy RPG mold.  As this is a game from 2002, beware that it does not hold your hand.  For example, there are no quest markers, so you need to pay attention to directions given by the quest giver!  The combat is also somewhat clunky, although there are mods for improving that and making it more similar to Oblivion and Skyrim.  Same story for the UI.

Once you have your mods sorted out you can immerse yourself in the world and enjoy a really good story, with an interesting main quest and many, many side quests to distract you.

I'm looking forward to playing it all over again when the Skywind remake comes out!
Better story and rpg aspect than Skyrim, a bit more difficult to get into but once it clicks its easily better. Im flying across morrowind as a mage. Cant do that in skyrim!

If your first Elder Scrolls game was Skyrim and you decide to go back in the series for lore I highly recommend Oblivion (come for the lock picking, stay for Sean Bean).
If you decide to hop further back to Morrowind for the same reason, I urge caution.
I believe there is only so far back someone is willing to play and I think this is a solid tar pit for me.
While some features are charming like using a lockpick to stab someone or the dark elf voice, there is so much that this older game lacks compared to the future games that I have been spoiled with.
You will have to draw your weapon before attacking, instead of attacking to draw your weapon. Or lack of auto save (I kept forgetting before turning off for the night and had to start over five times lol).

The speed of all the characters sucks but you can fix that in the first 30 minutes of your playthrough by getting the right pair of boots.

I previously played Morrowind and Oblivion on Series X, and was looking forward to be able to play them on the go on my Steam Deck. Unfortunately I had to give up on the idea since the controls of the Steam versions were made for the PC version first and not for regular controllers, and in turn, not for the Steam Deck.

Being perfectly honest, I don't know how easy or difficult it is to enable an option to use the same control settings as the Xbox versions, though seeing how later games like Fallout 3 & Skyrim do have proper controller settings and I'm able to play those perfectly fine on my Steam Deck, I'm hoping these can also be added to Morrowind and Oblivion, in which case I will gladly change my reviews.

About 2-3 years ago, I thought I could never beat an older game, especially this game, old games are tough and hard and especially his game where you don't have a quest marker and have to rely completely on your skills to navigate around the world (unless if you look it up online lol). But there is a certain charm to this game that makes you wanna try and go back from time to time. You keep going back and making new characters, constantly restarting and you slowly start to feel like that you're going insane (and rightfully so). But if you truly have the determination and motivation to keep going, you'll see a pattern. In Morrowind the landscape is very mountainous and the way your character moves, it's extremely hard sometimes to get to where you need to go, or the journey's to get from point A to point B can take literally hours, which is fine because after all this is an adventure game, but if you're trying to just get a quest done at the end of the day, As the old saying goes: if you can't go over it, go around it, and that leads to my point that with this game and many other games, whether if they are new or modern, there is always an easier way, always, and no, I'm not talking about cheating either. In total I have spent hundreds of hours grinding on this game, but in all those hours, it took me and the person I also play with that there are much easier ways then just simply following what the game wants. Exploits aren't cheating, because if anything, you know the rules better than anyone if you don't break the rules but make yourself completely OP with not too much effort. So, whoever is out there and is in the same boat I just was, just know that you must go around that big, ugly, red mountain. 

Edit: Still dope

Best of luck my fellow adventurers!

One of my favorite games of all times, but it has various aspects that may be hard to like in 2024 without nostalgia goggles.

Cities/towns are copy paste of similar buildings that are kind of boring, combat mechanics will feel weird to newcomers and a lot of quests are not really interesting. I like the UI as opposed to the console oriented modern UIs but a lot of people disagree with me on this.

The world and the main story are alright and like most Bethesda games there's a lot of lore and stuff to discover and enjoy. The land of Morrowind is breathtaking, it does not feel like the "standard European fantasy setting" which still stands out from other entries in the Elder Scroll series.

When I was younger I loved keeping a notebook and pen with me, taking notes, writing down directions to the cave I have to find to retrieve the random artifact, names of people and how they relate to each other, how I can take advantage of all this information. I don't know If I can dedicate myself at this level to a game released in 2024. These things no longer charm me, but when it comes to Morrowind I still enjoy it.

I'd still recommend people to try it out with Open MW or something similar and decide for themselves.

[h1] Review of TESIII: Morrowind [/h1]

The third part, Morrowind, is a pleasant transition from the previous two parts, featuring more modern graphics and the ability to switch to a third-person perspective. For the first time, the game introduces the concept of "Offline/online-RPG." This means that the game offers a vast number of quests and the freedom to explore a meticulously modeled 3D world, departing from the randomly generated worlds of TESI and II. Morrowind is also easily moddable, extending the playtime of the game.

[h2] Story [/h2]

The story revolves around a prisoner (typical for this game series) from The Imperial City, deported to the Vvardenfell Island in Morrowind. This area may be familiar from Skyrim, where it is mentioned in connection with the eruption of the Red Mountain volcano. Granting mercy, Uriel Septim VII orders the player to join the Blades, where tasks are assigned by the Blade's commander, Caius Cosades. As the story unfolds, the player discovers that their arrival aligns with the prophecies of the native people about the reincarnation of the warrior and warlord Nerevar. After completing several trials, the player is recognized as Nerevar by the Daedric Princess Azura herself. The main goal becomes defeating the demigod Dagoth Ur and his cult.

[h2] Ratings [/h2]

Coming directly from the second part, I was relatively excited about the graphical improvement. The game, despite its age, still looks good, with engaging gameplay and a well-thought-out story. I am more than convinced that it is worth playing even today. So, I can recommend it to everyone with a clear conscience.

[h3] Graphics 6/10 [/h3]
[h3] Story 8.5/10 [/h3]
[h3] Gameplay 8/10 [/h3]
[h3] Overall Rating 8/10 [/h3]

[h1] Recenze TESIII: Morrowind [/h1]

Třetí díl, Morrowind, je příjemný přechod z předchozích dvou dílů, kde je už modernější grafika, lze se přepnout do pohledu třetí osoby. Poprvé se zde vyskytuje koncept hry "Offline/online-RPG". 
To znamená, že hra obsahuje obrovské množství questů a možnost se volně pohybovat ve vymodelovaném 3D světě, takže zde se svět již náhodně negeneruje, jak tomu bylo v TESI a II. Morrowind šel i příjemně módovat, což také prodlouží dobu hraní této hry.

[h2] Příběh [/h2]

Příběh je o vězni (Jak typické pro tuto herní sérii) z The Imperial City, který je deportován na Ostrov Vvardenfell v Morrowindu. Tuto oblast můžete znát ze Skyrimu, kde se zmiňuje v souvislosti s výbuchem sopky Rudé hory. Zde mu milost udělí Samotný Uriel Septim VII, Hráč pak dostane rozkazy připojit se k Čepelím, kde mu úkoly zadává velitel Čepelí Caius Cosad. Postupem příběhu hráč zjistí, že jeho příchod zapadá do proroctví původních obyvatel o znovuzrození bojovníka a vojevůdce Nerevara. Po splnění několika zkoušek bude uznán za Nerevara i samotnou Deadrickou Princeznou Azurou. Jeho hlavním cílem bude zabít poloboha Dagoth Ura a jeho kult.

[h2] Hodnocení [/h2]

Jelikož jsem přešel rovnou z druhého dílu, byl jsem relativně nadšen ze grafického skoku. Ta hra na svůj věk vypadá stále dobře i včetně její hratelnosti a promyšleného příběhu. A jsem více než přesvědčen, že stojí za to si zahrát i dnes. Takže ji všem mohu doporučit s čistým svědomím.

[h3] Grafika 6/10 [/h3]
[h3] Příběh 8.5/10 [/h3]
[h3] Hratelnost 8/10 [/h3]
[h3] Celkové hodnocení 8/10 [/h3]

EDIT: On a more serious note, this is still my favorite of the ES series.  Whether intentionally or not, ESIII Morrowind provides the tools and environment for "game breaking" extremes, which grants those players driven to make ridiculous things occur the licence and reward to do so. It is steeped in alien culture, loaded with witty, flavorful dialogue and prose, and brought to life with a rich aural banquet; from it's atmospheric musical masterpieces to it's expertly expressed voice acting and engrossing sound effects. I have no doubt that the lens of nostalgia alters my view of this games many features and flaws, but I feel that the traits mentioned prior would likely be as true today as a novel experience as it was when it was first released so many years ago. 

All in all, an impactful confluence of passion, obsession, effort, and creativity.

Hands down, this is the absolute best RPG game, in my opinion. Grand in scope and scale, no other game since has managed to match the epic odyssey that is "Morrowind". Hundreds of quests, a huge game world, amazing amount of lore, creatures, and secrets. Although the graphics are dated, this game manages to beat modern games in almost every other aspect. The UI is fully customizable, allowing you to move the various windows, scale them to different sizes, pin them to your game screen, etc. The sounds (both ambient and music) are very excellent and both do a great job of helping to immerse you into the truly alien world of Morrowind. 

This game has features such as spellcrafting and alchemy that let you create and modify spells and potions, which I find to be awesome in that you can "break" the game by creating certain overpowered spells and/or potions that make you superhuman. But, hey, if that's your playstyle then go for it!

While the game contains "some" voice acting, the majority of the game, in terms of talking to NPCs, is text. You must read what they say and click on highlighted words in their speech to learn more about that subject. Some people, mostly modern games, wouldn't touch a game with hardly any voice acting. But, I feel that reading the text adds a bit more immersion and, too, allows you to proceed much faster since you don't have to wait for NPCs to finish talking when you can just quickly read what they're saying and move on. Having to listen to a long monologue is torture. Reading through it quickly is painless.

You can play almost any type of character you can think of in Morrowind. There are some default classes that you can choose from, but you can also create your own custom class and level up whatever skills you'd like. 

Bottom line: If you enjoy adventure games that don't hold your hand and can look past the dated graphics, you will find that Morrowind will spoil you for any other adventure games. Have fun, outlander!

Any form of build is viable in this game, however playing as an argonian or khajit is a bad move for beginners due to the lack of shoes. Also never use a premade class the game offers. Custom classes are king in this game. Select 1 type of armor, 1 type of melee weapon, and one form of ranged damage such as destruction or the marksmen skill. I've been playing this game ever since it debuted, during my childhood. It's a classic. I don't play with mods though if I could I would. The vanilla version is great in every way! Believe it or not, I actually beat the main quest a few weeks ago, and it's taken me that long to do so because I always get sidetracked with quests and the sheer amount of lore, books, storytelling, side quests, characters, etc. This is my nostalgia game. Graphics are of course not nearly as good as today's but I think that's part of what makes this game so special. I prefer the graphics this way as it makes the game unique in it's own way. My first memory of this game was the load screen starting this game, with Azura speaking, and then the initialization and seeing all of the cool monsters you'd be fighting. The first one I saw was a nix-hound and I thought "What the heck is that?!?". 

For people like me, this kind of game will be a 10/10. Future generations won't understand why I love this game so much, but if you dig deeper and looks at how they crafted this game, you will see all of the reasons why. I hope this review encourages you to give the vanilla version a try. Learn how to play this game and you will have endless fun!

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Use OpenMW and crank up the view distance; you honestly don't need a single mod otherwise because it does live up to the hype. It's the kind of 500 hour game that gets there by encouraging multiple playthroughs.

I recommend your first run be a very basic melee character; Orc speccing into axes, Redguard into Long Blades, something like that, because that'll let you learn what the game has to offer. This is not a "master everything on one character" game like Oblivion or Skyrim, and that's okay.

Don't mind the 1.2 hours of playtime: I grew up with this gem, and it's honestly of the best games I've ever played. 

The visuals, graphics and character designs are visibly dated, but what mainly makes this final Elder Scrolls-entry so compelling are its sound design, it's storytelling, its world-building and its timeless art-direction; all four of which make for an incredibly immersive atmosphere that draws you in and won't let you go. And while I still feel that relegating the entire game to two Islands apart from the massive Morrowind mainland (Vvardenfel and Solstheim) was a massive mistake on Bethesda's part, I also get that the company was teetering dangerously close to bankruptcy back then, and only had a small team to develop it.

And one more thing: the villain. Morrowind does a terrific job of embracing the concept of 'tell; don't show' with its main antagonist, and making it work. As you progress through the main story, the game passively builds up Dagoth Ur as a devil. The ''Sharmat'' (as ES lore goes). The embodiment of all that is evil and profane to the Dunmer people. But the closer the time comes to confront him, the more you come to realize that there is something very 'off' about the Tribunal; that they're not telling you everything. And this ultimately leads to an expertly-crafted plot twist.

But now, we get into the meat of the matter: 'why' I call this the final entry in the series, and it's for a very simple, overall reason:

Morrowind is the last Elder Scrolls game that remains true to the lore and spirit of its predecessors. While it 'did' make some questionable decisions (removal of fast travel and player mounts, and the ham-fisted removal of over half of the useful skills in Daggerfall), it at least didn't 'break' anything that had been previously established.

Oblivion and Skyrim, on the other hand, are not worthy of being called Elder Scrolls games, and I'll prove it below:

Oblivion warped the previously-established concept of the Dragonborn Emperors for the sake of suiting its Lord Of The Rings knockoff narrative. It removed the most interesting and compelling concepts and lore-established aspects of the land of Cyrodil (endless jungles and traditional Southeast-Asian/Roman-Mediterranean overall culture, dress and architecture) for the sake of making it look more medieval European, and therefore making it more 'safe' to market to western audiences. Not to mention the inexplicable absence of about 90% of the interesting lesser Daedric princes (though Morrowind shares some guilt in this as well), and the weird, amalgamated bastardization of the previously loosely-connected Temples of the various Divines into a single religious order that flies in the face of what had been portrayed in Daggerfall. And don't get me started about the complete lack of Knightly orders and the baffling removal of 'spears', medium armor, and all throwing weapons. All in all, Oblivion 'is' a decent RPG, but an unworthy successor to Daggerfall and Morrowind.

Skyrim... broke everything else. With the exception of leveled enemies, It took what all Oblivion did wrong, and multiplied it times ten. Don't get me wrong: I got a lot of enjoyment out of the mindlessly-wandering experience that is Skyrim, but at the end of the day I wouldn't be a true fan if I didn't roast this turd to Oblivion and back. 99% of the Skyrim-based vampire clans spoken of in previously established lore are simply non-existent, and not even mentioned in-game. The ruins of ancient Falmer (snow elf) architecture said to dot Skyrim's landscape are nowhere to be found, and none of the unique ancient Falmer weapons and armor exist, save for a light armor set that breaks lore, as the snow elves of old are said to have worn 'heavy' armor and wielded spears. Speaking of which: spears are 'still' absent, and so are throwing weapons. The aloof relationship between the mortal races and Dragons has been utterly bastardized for the sake of giving emphasis to the sudden shift in direction from 'slow character buildup to effective godhood', to 'Grade-school-esque power fantasy tripe from the get-go.'. 'None' of the minor Daedric princes are present, and now only a tiny, tiny handful of the Divines even have Temples dedicated to them. And whereas not being able to join the Imperial Legion in Oblivion was, frankly, a stupid decision on Bethesda's part, the way Skyrim handles 'joining' the Legion feels almost insulting, as you are not treated as a soldier by a disciplined commander like you were in Morrowind's IL faction arc: you are treated like a mercenary by a seemingly uninterested half-wit who doesn't care how you dress or how you talk to him (not that you have any real or meaningful dialogue choices in Skyrim). To top it off: the main quest is utterly forgettable, and the supposed main antagonist is just a bog-standard, stereotypical 'evil' black dragon... that we've all seen a million times since fantasy first became widespread in the 1980's. As such; Skyrim cannot and 'should' not be called an Elder Scrolls game... because it isn't, and couldn't ever possibly be, by virtue of its own design as a shallow, vapid, lore-bastardizing mockery of the series' founding. 

Case and point: Morrowind is not subjectively but 'objectively' the last game in the series.

BEST GAME

This game is a masterpiece. For its time, it pushed the boundaries of RPGs with a broad scope and excellent graphics. But bigger games, better-looking games, have come and gone in the 20+ years since Morrowind's release. Yet this game still has staying power. It still draws players in. Why? Because it is rich and unique in so many wonderful ways. The setting is a mix of the familiar (cottages, guards, prophesies) with the enticingly unfamiliar (giant mushrooms, tangible gods, bonemold buildings). It was written by people who truly cared about history and anthropology such that the people, places and myths of Morrowind's setting feel textured and believable. Most other games fall short in comparison. And of course, the music of this game is excellent. Jeremy Soule gives us his iconic themes that lift this game into something truly special. Finally, there's the modding community that continue to generate new or updated content for a fresher look and smoother experience even after more than two decades since its release.

Easily one of my favorite games of all time. Never have I seen a game with this unparalleled level of immersion, where it's so incredibly easy to completely lose yourself in its world, which is accomplished due to a mixture of a sublime sense of progression and pacing, rewarding exploration, inventive lore, a great soundtrack, absorbing mechanics that make you pay attention to dialogue and use your wits to traverse the map and complete your objectives instead of mindlessly following a quest marker, and beautifully creative alien landscapes and architecture that give the game a unique identity and atmosphere.

The game has a fascinatingly weird world, and it does a superb job of fleshing out the lore, politics, conflicts, and culture of the Dunmer people. It is by far the best game in the series in terms of worldbuilding, and it has the best main questline in any TES game. Everything about its universe is very experimental, surreal, and "out-there", and it's a shame that Bethesda abandoned this philosophy in later titles, since this is one of the best things about the game, and all of it really helps to immerse the player in the amazingly interesting and strange place that is Morrowind.

The game can be quite unforgiving and doesn't do a lot of hand-holding, but that's part of what makes it so special. Its mechanics have a lot of depth to them, and allow for a lot of experimentation and player freedom (I think [url=https://youtu.be/27iaPhD6Nt0][u]this video[/u][/url] does a great job of exemplifying this). I absolutely love the RPG elements, which I think are the perfect balance between complexity/depth and not being too unwieldy like Daggerfall when it comes to the stats, skills, attributes and so on, alongside the layered clothing system, which all make building and progressing your character one of the most engaging things about the game. I also love the amazing systems in place with almost infinite possibilities like Enchanting and Spellmaking, as overpowered as those can be.

Now, despite all the great things about it, it's far from perfect. The game hasn't aged well, both graphically and gameplay wise. If you're coming from Skyrim or Oblivion, it's almost certain you're gonna have a hard time learning the game's ropes, especially the archaic combat system. The leveling system can be quite tedious and grindy if you're looking to min/max and build your character in the most optimal way. The game is REALLY unbalanced and some aspects of it can be really frustrating while others are far too easy, since there are many exploits that the player can abuse to break the game. Also, even though the soundtrack is one of the game's strongest aspects, it can sometimes be fairly repetitive due to a relatively small quantity of tracks.

Most NPCs in the game are fairly generic due to copy-pasted lines, and basically just serve as lore vending machines. The wiki-style dialogue system makes it nearly impossible to role-play your character through dialogue choices in the same way that you would in other RPGs, so you shouldn't go in looking for that experience. You play a game like Morrowind to feel completely immersed in it's rich fantasy world, learning about its history, exploring and adventuring, joining different guilds, building your character, experimenting with the mechanics, becoming more and more powerful, etc. Just like any of the other TES games, you shouldn't really go in looking for a story with lots of different moral choices and branching paths, since that's just not the point of the game.

Let me also just take a moment to give potential new players two important tips to avoid frustration. First, make sure to only use weapons that your character specializes in, in other words, don't try to use the crappy Iron Dagger that you get at the start if you didn't pick Short Blade as a skill when creating your character. Instead, do some quests in Seyda Neen to get some gold since they usually don't involve any combat, talk to Caius Cosades in Balmora to get some more starter money, and then use that cash to buy some decent gear that your character can actually use. Second, you need to keep in mind that, unlike Skyrim, Fatigue is an important mechanic in this game. If your Fatigue is low when you enter combat, your character is much more likely to miss their attacks, and running and jumping everywhere will quickly deplete it. So, try to carry some Restore Fatigue potions with you, and if you see an enemy ahead try to either start walking slowly to regenerate a bit, or just rest for an hour in-game, which will completely refill your bar.

I would also definitely recommend installing [url=https://openmw.org/][u]OpenMW[/u][/url] and following [url=https://modding-openmw.com/lists/i-heart-vanilla/][u]this guide[/u][/url] to enjoy an enhanced, stable, and mostly bug-free version of the vanilla game on modern systems.

With all of that said, Morrowind is a masterpiece, albeit a very flawed one. If you persevere through all of its problems, what awaits you is one of the most incredibly engrossing and rewarding experiences you will ever have in an RPG. [b]8/10.[/b]

Ah, Morrowind.  An incredible experience from a time that may now be lost.

I played this back when it came out (2002) and the janky graphics we see now were actually quite laudable then. I preface this because visuals are very important to getting invested in a world and MAN was I invested in the land of Vvardinfell. The first time I went through the game it was hours and hours and [i]hours[/i] before I did anything of note. Simply walking about the towns with NPCs and the 3D rendered open world, at the time a much more novel concept, gripped me like no game had. The sky at night, with its double moons; the rain falling near the swamps full with little noises; the ash storms rushing across the wasteland near Ald Ruhn all made the world feel realized, like i was fully there.

Morrowind has so many pieces that get you to believe in its world, alien as it is. Libraries of books and poems; stories of oral and real history give this place depth. Politics both grandscale between empires, and small and local among houses or indivdiual city-dwellers make this place seem true. The guilds and their advancement, or your ability to buy property and increase its value, or even your own increase in power just from [i]doing[/i] gives the player a sense that they, themselves are increasing in scope and ability. Its hard to describe just how this game makes one feel involved in its place and people.  

There is just so much meat to chew on here. Immersive quests that the player must figure out, rather than hand-fed via markers or illuminated paths. Dialogue and investigations into minutiae, world building, or complete triviality for the sake of coloring in edges or people; making the world seem whole.  A narrative with characters having a sense of agency and motives and depth. 

However, in 2024 you won't get the same feeling from Morrowind I did.  Its combat is borderline unusable when you start, and outright broken by the end. The menus and inventory system and sorting are tedious, as is the process of persuasion and general conversation.  There is little voice acting and what there is you will hear often. Its just so....dated.  I don't think even were I to go back I'd find it as powerful.

So here it is then; Morrowind is a flawed gem. A masterpiece from a bygone age. It can shock you, mesmerize you, give you an experience you cant find anywhere else, but only if you let it and can freely look past its myriad issues. One should try this game, but I understand if they immediately bounce off.  For those that stay they will be rewarded.

I have very mixed feelings towards Morrowind. It's generally one of those games where you're either going to fall in love with it or you're going to hate every minute, but I kind of fell in the middle.

On one hand, Morrowind has one of the most unique and interesting settings in video game history, paired with some of the best writing and storytelling to come out of Bethesda. The world design is amazing and still holds up today. Morrowinds magic system is one of the all time greats, and you can break the game in so many fun ways. There is also still a very active mod community that has created some really impressive projects, most notably OpenMW (a complete engine rewrite) and Tamriel Rebuilt (a mod that adds most of mainland Morrowind to the game).

On the other hand, Morrowind has some real questionable design choices that feel weird even for RPG veterans, and would make it VERY hard for someone coming in from Oblivion/Skyrim/ESO. It feels archaic and clunky even compared to RPGs that released around it. Morrowind comes from a time when Bethesda were still refining the TES formula. Instead of being a vast, procedurally generated dungeon crawler like Daggerfall, they opted to make it a more focused, simplified and story based experience, and that's part of why it's so rough around the edges.

The vast majority of Morrowinds quests are very simple fetch quests or escort quests, and Morrowinds dungeons on average are much smaller and simpler than what you'd find in any other TES title. There is no natural mana regen. The fatigue system is terrible and poorly explained. The combat is based on dice rolls despite handling like an action RPG, and unlike other dice based games that released around the time (NWN) there is no animations or logs to show that your attack missed.  

There is no sprint, and your base movement speed is ridiculously slow given the sheer size and scale of the world, and "running" drains fatigue so you don't want to be doing it too often. There are no quest markers, which usually isn't a problem as most old school RPGs don't have them, but there are a handful of quests where the game doesn't give you sufficient information to find the objective (see: Dwemer Puzzle Cube) or they don't let you ask local NPCs where the guy you're supposed to talk to is, or where a nearby place is located. 

Nowadays there are mods that can fix a lot of Morrowinds design issues (shoutout to Fair Magicka Regen and Alex's Running Without Fatigue) but it's still worth bringing up. 

Overall, Morrowind is a gem that is worth playing if you're a fan of old school RPGs or the TES series in general. It can be a bit hard to get into due to it's design choices that are very uncommon and strange even by old school RPG standards, but if you can stick with it you will be rewarded. The games lore and world are so interesting and very easy to be immersed into despite the dated graphics, and the magic system and gameplay will make you feel more powerful than you have ever felt before in a TES game once you get a few levels in.

If you're coming in from Skyrim or Oblivion and are having trouble sticking with it, then make note of all the things you don't like about Morrowind, and see if there are any mods that can fix it (there probably is). Ignore all the purist gatekeeping and do whatever you need to do to stick with the game. It will be worth it.

..is what I would say if the steam release of this game wasn't an broken, buggy unplayable mess. I have installed countless patches, mods, ran the game on multiple different computers but no matter what I do, after around 15 seconds - 2 minutes after loading my save, the game freezes to a halt without any warnings or errors (not even a "morrowind.exe is not responding") and lock my pc, forcing me to sign out or restart. 

But surprisingly, this game functions perfectly fine on every other platform I've played it on. Original Xbox, and even the unofficial android port run fine with no crashes and give you the complete experience, letting you experience this wonderful game in all it's glory. However I cannot recommend buying this game on steam, as despite being the way most people play Morrowind, Bethesda has neglected their PC audience for the last 20 years leaving this game in an unplayable state. 

If you want to enjoy morrowind without all the bugs and crashes, I suggest trying either OpenMW, an unofficial source port of the game that provides additional engine features and keeps most of the base game intact (the original water shader is gone though, a damn shame) or the official Xbox port which you can play using backwards compatibility mode on any xbox console. The xbox port is probably the best if you want the "pure" TES 3 experience but if you don't own an Xbox and don't want to bother emulating then OpenMW is the main way to get the game functioning on PC. 

tl;dr: Great game, but don't play the steam version. Use openmw or emulation.

Allow me to expound upon the opus that is "The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind." A veritable tapestry of intricate design and audacious ambition, this seminal entry into the annals of gaming history is not to be trifled with lightly. A magnum opus, it stands as a testament to the industry's capacity for transcendent creativity, yet, dear reader, I must humbly submit that despite its undeniable merits, it falls short in the shadow of its predecessor, the magisterial "Daggerfall."

Morrowind, with its sprawling landscapes and labyrinthine lore, beckons the intrepid adventurer into a world teeming with mystique. The vibrant tapestry of the island of Vvardenfell unfolds before the player like an ancient manuscript, laden with intrigue and beguilement. The labyrinthine narrative, woven with the threads of prophecies and arcane mysteries, is an opulent banquet for the intellectual palate, albeit one tinged with the pangs of inconsistency and convolution.

However, let us not overlook the insurmountable shadow cast by the colossus that is Daggerfall. A sprawling continent, a vast expanse of provinces, Daggerfall is the epitome of a grandiose vision brought to fruition. The sheer scale of its ambition dwarfs Morrowind's confined island setting, rendering the latter's attempt at world-building akin to a mere sonnet in the grand symphony of Daggerfall's epic saga.

Furthermore, one cannot escape the palpable sense of nostalgia that permeates Daggerfall's every pixel. A pioneer in the realm of open-world exploration, Daggerfall's labyrinthine dungeons and procedurally generated landscapes remain unparalleled, underscoring Morrowind's regrettable inability to ascend to the same celestial heights.

In matters of depth and complexity, Morrowind may be praised for its intricate web of political machinations and rich tapestry of cultures, but, dear reader, let us not lose sight of Daggerfall's sheer audacity in granting players an empire to traverse. Morrowind's bespoke intricacies may seduce the discerning intellect, but Daggerfall's audacious sprawl remains unmatched.

In conclusion, as one contemplates the multifaceted brilliance of Morrowind, one cannot help but discern the looming specter of Daggerfall, an awe-inspiring testament to Bethesda's unbridled ambition. Morrowind, though a masterpiece in its own right, merely grazes the surface of the immersive odyssey that is Daggerfall, casting a perpetual shadow upon its magisterial predecessor. Thus, while Morrowind may sparkle as a gem of its time, it behooves us to acknowledge the superior grandeur of Daggerfall, an exemplar that transcends the mere confines of gaming antiquity.

The first Elder Scrolls game I played first was Skyrim, but this is becoming my favorite very quickly.

This game is so dumb. You can do so many hilarious, amazing, stupid things. Want to fly across the island in minutes? There's a potion for that. Want to space jump between your destinations? Visit the spellmaker and make it so. Want to sell your goods to an alcoholic merchant living on a deserted island? There's a crab for that.

This is also a really well-written game. The voice acting is pretty limited, but the amount of actual, juicy, coda makes this a really satisfying lore dive, if that's your wheelhouse.

Yes, the gameplay is pretty dated. It's clunky, and buggy in classic Bethesda fashion. Moreover, nearly everything you attempt to do requires a dice roll to succeed. Swinging your sword, casting spells, enchanting, arrows hitting their marks; these are all taken for granted in later titles. Here in Morrowind though, there's always a thin veneer of rng between you and lethal comedy. 

Also, the movement speed kind of sucks at first (though there are ways around this). If you can get past that, Vvardenfell is your oyster. You're presented with an incredible repertoire of magic and skills to get over obstacles and create mischief.

The world is handcrafted, and there's plenty to explore. Prepare to be surprised by environmental storytelling and excellent loot as you plumb the depths of this tightly designed, yet profoundly unbalanced role playing adventure.

Also, the speedrunning community is also hilarious. Since all items are always in the same place every new playthrough, you can get amazingly overpowered quickly and early, and can punch the endgame boss in the face at level 1 if you really wanted to. Lots of options here. Lots of love from the devs. It's a joy to play, even if its age is painfully obvious.

Overall would recommend.

A lot of you kids grew up playing Skyrim. I was in my 20s when Skyrim came out. This was the Elder Scrolls that I played in my teen years. It's not for everyone. This game is a lot more complex than Skyrim, and it is very unforgiving to players who don't learn how it works. Having said that, it is an amazing game and a prime example of the fact that they just don't make things like they used to. If you are having trouble with combat, try this: 1. Start a new character. 2. Build this character with your entire playstyle in mind. Don't major or even MINOR in skills that you won't be using all the time, especially ones you use from the get go. Don't specialize in more than one weapon and armor skill, and only use that type throughout the game. Make sure your Agility, Luck, Strength, and Endurance are at decent levels at the start. Don't pick a birthsign that just gives you a spell. You can get any and all spells during gameplay. Pick a sign like the Lady or the Mage, which gives you a stat bonus with no drawbacks. 3. Don't waste your fatigue running everywhere. This is a slow paced RPG, and you should be walking most of the time. If you find yourself in combat with low fatigue, you most likely will end up the losing party. Fatigue affects many many things, including your chance to hit, chance to successfully cast a spell, and even your chance to craft potions or persuade people. Only run when absolutely necessary.  4. Don't sleep on enchantments. They can be immeasurably powerful assets in your arsenal if you use them right. For example, a 1 pt slowfall enchantment on a piece of gear set as a constant effect, will completely negate all fall damage. If you use dispel magic while wearing the Boots of Blinding Speed, you essentially get the massive speed bonus without being blinded. Constant effects are basically godmode. 1 pt Levitate may be slow, but it's infinite. Meaning you can basically get around the entire map without coming into contact with most enemies. Find yourself running out of health too quickly in combat? Enchant your weapon with "Restore Health on Self" and set it to cast when the weapon strikes. This may not be as good as Absorb Health, but it is easily accessible early on, and can be a total game changer against more powerful enemies. There are so many tricks and such to make this game a breeze, and while many of them are basically broken, most of them are relatively balanced and super super fun to use! Morrowind may have its flaws, but it has so much going for it that they for some reason decided to gradually phase out of the Elder Scrolls games, starting with Oblivion, and continuing in Skyrim. You can craft spells in Oblivion, but Morrowind has twice as many effects to use. Skyrim completely did away with spellmaking. In Morrowind, you can use a mortar and pestle to craft potions, instead of trying to find a stupid alchemy table. I find the skills system in Morrowind to be far superior to any other RPG, let alone Skyrim. And it doesn't hold your hand and always magically point the way for your quests, meaning you are looking around the world for things instead of staring at a compass the entire time. I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the Elder Scrolls series, and I urge you to not look at it with Skyrim colored glasses. This game is an absolute gem and the main reason why the Elder Scrolls has had so much success. If it weren't for Morrowind, Skyrim would have never existed. Morrowind goes back to what is in my opinion the glory days of Bethesda, and will never not bring a smile to my face when I hear that in-game music.

I first rented Morrowind from Blockbuster 893 years ago. It quickly became the only reason I kept my original Xbox alive, though it begged for the sweet release of the red ring of death. Years later, I finally got a gaming pc and reunited with Morrowind all over again as an adult. Nothing will ever surpass my love for this game. To call it special is an understatement. It's a second home. Clearly made with care and a respect for its audience that I no longer see from the latest Bethesda releases. I'd like to say more, but the Silt Strider is calling. I'll end with this- you need nothing but Morrowind. Morrowind is all you need. There is no Oblivion, Skyrim, or Starfield. There is only Jobasha and his Rare Books.

As a fan of The Elder Scrolls series, I approached Morrowind with high expectations, only to be disappointed by its glaring lack of diversity and inclusion.

Morrowind's world is expansive and immersive, but it feels like a missed opportunity to create a truly inclusive and representative fantasy realm. The character designs and racial options are limited, with a lack of diverse ethnicities and body types. In a gaming landscape that's increasingly valuing diversity, Morrowind's stagnant approach is out of touch.

The game's narrative, while epic, could have been greatly enriched by incorporating a broader range of perspectives and backgrounds. The lack of diverse characters and cultures within the game's universe is a letdown, making it difficult for players from various walks of life to fully connect with the story.

In an era where players are seeking meaningful and diverse experiences, Morrowind falls short. The character creation options feel outdated, and the lack of representation can make the game feel exclusionary to many players. It's disheartening to see a beloved title miss the opportunity to grow and adapt to the changing expectations of the gaming community.

This game has the absolute worst saving and loading features in the history of games as I know them. Your hard-saves will become corrupted. Your autosave will become corrupted. Finally your quicksave will become irreversably corrupted, leaving you to wonder if its worth backtracking 20 fucking missions to your most recent uncorrupted hard-save. At which point you will be like "you know what? maybe its better to stick with games that fucking FUNCTION." My god. I've played buggy games before, theyre a hilarious blast. But this game is unsavably infested with bugs. If this game was person, you would euthanize it to end it's pain. If this game was a building, you would condemn it and quarantine the area. If this game was a planet, you would nuke it from orbit. This game is probably 20% bugs by weight. No joke, I have 142 hours of play time on this game. A good 20% of those hours, are hours lost to corrupted saves. The story and yes, even the Dagoth Ur memes urge you on at every step - and the packaging tells you to turn back with every other breath. Abandon hope, player. It's not worth your time. It might be if the game didn't do this to me, but I'm to the point where I want a refund and I'm never going to be able to touch this game again. It just hurts too much.

EDIT: I did eventually find a way to make it work and finish to the end. Can't remember how, but i know it created other issues along the way - like how i had to reset the controls every time i started. I fixed that now, and i do remember how i did it, but now the music is glitching out. I have a fix for that too now, but its a pain in the butt and i forget to do it every time i open the game. 

This is still, BAR NONE, *THE* absolute buggiest game i have ever played.

This game is fantastic.  Classic D&D like features in an RPG with a story worth talking about.  Start off your journey getting dunked on, and you'll be doing the dunking by the end.  There is so much to this game.  Every time I play it, I'm blown away by the sheer amount of items, quests, and spells that it has to offer.  It has a learning curve, and I'm confident you'll figure it out through trial and error.  Remember to manual save frequently (Before, after, and during each quest).  Happy gaming.

If you are a TRUE RPG lover, buy this game immediately. I've never played a game quite like this- proves they don't quite make them like they used to. Morrowind is my top favorite game of all time- the ultimate RPG, in my opinion, and definitely the best Elder Scrolls game to date.

Graphics and Gameplay Feel/Fluidity-
While Arena and Daggerfall are great in their own right, they're clunky, old, and dated. Morrowind is as well, don't get me wrong- but it's just new enough that it's perfectly playable if you don't mind older graphics. 
The gameplay is nothing short of perfect for any RPG lover- if you were ever into Dungeons & Dragons or old tabletop RPGs of that nature, then you will love Morrowind. If you are carved-in-stone no-exceptions used to Skyrim's gameplay- maybe stay away from Morrowind, as it's much more complex and can be intimidating for those who are used to Skyrim's (for lack of a better word) dumbed down systems.
When you start, by creating your character, you will choose a race (This determines some starting abilities, skills, and attributes (to a larger extent than the other two)), class (This determines what you're good at! You have 5 major and 5 minor skills, to which you recieve bonuses that add on to previous racial bonuses, and these are the only skills that can get you points to level up- Pick ones you know you'll use), and a birth sign (This will give you a unqiue special ability or power. Choose wisely- there are better and worse ones to pick). You can also create a completely custom class, complete with a custom description that you can write (I like to write a backstory for my character here).
It's the perfect video game adaptation of a tabletop RPG, with complex calculations automatically being taken every time you perform an action. You will fail to cast your spells, you will have to run, teleport away, regroup and return when you're stronger. You will even completely fail to hit many enemies when you first start out- I found it incredibly frustrating, even redundant at first, as someone who started on Skyrim and the like- but after spending some time on the game, I realized it's all part of the amazing journey that your character goes on. 
You will NOTICE your progression- the devs made sure of that. The game's difficulty doesn't scale with the player, it depends on the region and the type of enemy. This means that you WILL be able to surpass enemies eventually: those pesky Ashlander outcasts who once tore you to shreds in a matter of seconds will become mere pests that you can flick away without much effort. Eventually, you will never miss, and the skills that you decided to capitalize on WILL pay off, immensely.
The role-playing aspect of this game is one of the ways it shines the most- where in Skyrim, you are handed god-like abilities and the title of "Chosen One" (Dragonborn) from almost the very beginning, in Morrowind you must earn them. This also means that if you don't want your character to "save the world" or be a household name in Morrowind, you can choose to forego the main story and live out a "normal" life. There is an enormous abundance of other quest lines to pursue, and you will find many ways to create a unique character that the world reacts to accordingly.
You can kill literally anybody you wish, everyone is kill-able and being "essential" in the game merely means that upon killing that character, you will be notified that unless you revert to an earlier save, you won't be able to complete the main quest or DLC main quests. And if you decide after the quests that you want to kill them, go ahead- They're not "essential" anymore.
There's so many incredible things about Morrowind's gameplay- this review would be a novel's length if I listed even half of them- but to sum up some of the most exciting ones, you can do the following things in Morrowind:
-Custom spell creation and spell engineering
-Custom potions from complex alchemy systems involving multiple pieces of apparatus
-Powerful custom enchantments on almost any equipment
-Kill anyone (Literally ANYONE, I cannot stress this enough)
-Interact with/kill literal gods
-Become famous
-Become an outlaw
-Become a vampire/werewolf (With ACTUAL drawbacks- vampires and werewolves are hated in Tamriel, and this game makes you pay for the power of being undead, or a shape-shifter)
AND SO MUCH MORE! You will spend countless hours exploring all the features of this game.
Now, onto the next part.

Atmosphere/Immersion-
Morrowind, out of all Elder Scrolls games, is definitely the most atmospherically impressive and immersive. Like I said earlier, I started on Skyrim (Which has a much bigger map) and I didn't think anything could top that level of immersion. Morrowind's map, albeit smaller, is incredibly dense and much more interesting- every step is handcrafted and beautifully designed for maximum immersion- you feel like you're in this world. You will find hidden locations and secrets, sometimes (actually more often than not) containing useful equipment and tools, or even powerful one-of-a-kind artifacts.
There's no "fast travel" in Morrowind. Either you can pay at one of the silt-strider ports to be instantly taken to neighboring cities (You will spend a lot of gold on this), you can use spells Mark and Recall to teleport yourself to any location you have previously chosen, you can use Intervention scrolls to be teleported to religious locations, and there are about two items in game that allow for VERY LIMITED fast travel through magical capabilities. Other than that, you have to walk and explore- Trust me, this is better. Enjoy the view, Vvardenfell is a beautiful, diverse place. 
There's also no quest markers. Whaaaaaat? That's right- none whatsoever. NPCs, book pages, and subtle clues will give you accurate and descriptive directions to where the quest objective is, and your character records everything of that nature in their journal. You can access any part of your journal at any time, because of the alphabetized sorting system that can take you to any category or quest record instantly. 
The attention to detail in the game is also immaculate. Argonians and Khajiit have snouts- and in Morrowind, digitigrade (multi-jointed and animalistic, think of a cat's or a dog's hind legs) legs as well. These two races can't wear boots, and they also can't wear full-faced helmets. Why would they be able to? Argonians, lore-wise, are semi-aquatic as well- and the developers showed that, not only through their ability to breathe water, but also their unique swimming animation that only they use. Instead of pushing their arms like wings through the water like a human, they swim more like crocodiles or monitor lizards- pinning their arms to their sides, and using their tail to propel them forward. This is just one small example of attention to detail- it makes sense, so they put it in the game. You will find that there are many facets of the game that adhere to this rule. All of these small details add up to a bigger picture that creates a huge amount of immersion.

Story-
I won't spoil anything about the story, but it is amazing- once again, it shines in the Elder Scrolls series as an example of great storytelling. You will meet many characters, all with different personalities, likes, dislikes, inclinations, talents, and skills. You will fight, you will make diplomatic agreements, you will bribe and persuade, make alliances and enemies, and so much more. It's something you really need to experience for yourself to get the full idea.

The DLCs are also incredible- both adding content comparable in quantity AND quality to the base game itself.

What more can I say? This is an incredible game, and the best RPG video game ever created. Try it.

I played Morrowind as a kid but never finished it because I was like 6 and was too busy playing Halo instead. I finally decided to come back and actually play it properly after almost 20 years. The hit chance mechanic is not a problem unless you go out of your way to make it a problem. Power attacks actually do enough damage to warrant spending the extra stamina to use them. Magic is fun and viable. Alchemy is absurdly powerful and is actually worth using. Enchanting is more than "[INSERT MAGIC DAMAGE TYPE] on hit for [INSERT ARBITRARILY LOW NUMBER] damage." Every skill has an absurd amount of trainers who can train you as much as you want, with the only restrictions being your attributes, their skill, and how much gold you have. It might also be the single most stable Bethesda game I have ever played, with my only crashes being from drinking potions until I had over 100,000 in an attribute.

Morrowind is not a better game than Skyrim, but it is extremely well written. The gameplay is slow at first and always monotonous and janky. It's well worth spending the time to explore the world, interact with its citizens, and participate in some of the most wonderful lore ever written for fantasy. The main game, with almost all faction quests, took me 150 or so hours to complete. The Tribunal DLC is even better than the main game, with really impressive environments, and it directly builds on the end of the main story (takes about 15 hours). I highly recommend it. I haven't played the Bloodmoon DLC yet.

[h2]MORROWIND'S PROBLEMS[/h2]
Many people will claim that Morrowind is better than Skyrim, and that its many complex systems are part of what makes it a masterpiece. Despite all the praise, anyone can see as soon as they play the game what the core problems of Morrowind are: the initial hours are extremely slow, and the combat is not immersive. 

[b]The game starts slow.[/b] Your movement is slow, combat is slow, questing is slow, leveling up is slow. Many people claim that this is fine because it means you are forced to leave a difficult dungeon/quest and level up elsewhere before returning, and that this sets it apart from other RPGs. That is true, but that doesn't make it an inherently good system. It means that you have to try to make any progress anywhere you can. This doesn't always mean you're more immersed in the role of early adventuring. It just means that you will take any non-combat job you can get until the questline presents you with a fight you can't handle. Returning to that initial challenge you couldn't take earlier isn't particularly satisfying to me. Once you're capable of taking on the combat missions that once gave you issues, you can complete almost any quest in the game. Level/combat/wealth progression reaches a plateau after about 40 hours that removes impossible challenges and equalizes quests into somewhat monotonous chores. There are a handful of interesting combat challenges after this point, but since you are now capable of quickly reaching any destination and quickly dealing with quest objectives, that slow early game grind loses its meaning, because it's just a regular RPG now.

[b]The combat is not immersive.[/b] It is very clear that you're looking at an abstraction of a probability calculation playing out on screen. Because your level, gear, and wealth play such a large part in your progression, your skill at controlling your character doesn't matter. You walk up to enemies and click until they die. If something goes wrong, you quickly scroll through your long list of spells and run backwards until you take care of it. The difficulty of a fight is determined by how quickly you can kill an enemy and how much damage they can do to you in that time. The wealth of unique spells you can create are methods of cheating probabilities into your favor in particular situations. They don't meaningfully change gameplay. Combat isn't fun. It's not bad, it's just boring. To claim this is better than Skyrim's combat is, in my opinion, clearly contrarian. 

[h2]WHY YOU SHOULD PLAY MORROWIND[/h2]
Despite its problems, I still think Morrowind is a good game. Well, maybe it's not a good "game," but it is an immersive interface with the Elder Scrolls lore in a way that no Elder Scrolls game has gotten as well besides Elder Scrolls Online. And the Elder Scrolls lore, a lot of which was greatly expanded/explored for the first time in Morrowind, is an artistic treat. The stories, spirituality, culture, and art on display is masterful. The first time you see a sunrise/sunset against the water, you realize that there is something deeper to this game. Maybe the act of swinging a sword at a nix-hound isn't immersive, but them showing up across the countryside and their disgusting mannerisms certainly are. The transition between biomes is poorly done, but the biomes themselves are gorgeous and heavily varied. The characters you meet are important. They contribute to the lore at large or have already contributed to the lore, but they feel like characters still living in the world when you come across them. 

Quests in Morrowind break down into three main categories: the main quest, faction quests, and miscellaneous quests. You will spend the bulk of your time doing faction quests for the large number of factions in the game. These are mostly fetch quests and combat chores with no engaging gameplay. All that to say, once the character writing that differentiates the NPCs beyond the preset dialogue options becomes apparent in quest-givers, chores become framed around exploring guild intrigue and progression through their ranks. You might feel morally apprehensive about taking on a quest in a guild you want to advance through, only to learn that there is better alternative. The guilds have histories, and the guild members have histories that all interact to make your otherwise chore-filled experience a lot more rewarding. There's even inter-guild interactions that help connect your progress.

Miscellaneous quests usually have the most interesting gameplay, having to solve unusual problems, but they rarely have good rewards or solutions clear enough to feel worth doing. Plenty are just as boring as the faction quests, or even duplicate themselves, just in a different location. There are Daedric quests here in order to retrieve some artifacts, but they aren't especially complicated quests, nor are the rewards always better than something you'd receive during a faction quest.

The main quest really is the gem of the game. Yes, there's great dialogue writing everywhere in the game, but nowhere is it more consistent than in the main quest line. The level of the Elder Scrolls lore weirdness it explores is phenomenal. There's no other fantasy story like it. Unfortunately it becomes less writing and more a sprint to the finish in the final stage of the story, but Dagoth Ur and the Nerevarine's story is good, even by literary standards.

An enormous game, and a big time commitment, but by far the best in the series - a smarter, deeper story and a more interesting world than the more recent titles. Also has full-size in-game libraries!

These days, play via OpenMW - much better quality of life experience.  The game definitely holds up over 20 years later.
