Title: A Journey Through Vvardenfell's Rich Tapestry - The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind Review

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, released in 2002, stands as a monumental achievement in the realm of open-world RPGs, setting the stage for its successors in the renowned Elder Scrolls series. Stepping into the shoes of the Nerevarine, players find themselves on the island of Vvardenfell, a sprawling and mysterious land filled with intrigue, danger, and a depth of lore that remains unmatched.

The first thing that strikes players about Morrowind is its vivid and unique setting. Vvardenfell is a fantastical world teeming with diverse landscapes, from mushroom-filled forests to ashy volcanic plains. The attention to detail is exceptional, making exploration a captivating experience. Every corner of the world feels deliberate, each region telling its own story through environmental design.

The narrative is another high point of Morrowind. The game boasts a complex and engaging main questline that revolves around the player fulfilling a prophecy as the Nerevarine. The depth of the lore and the political intrigue surrounding the Great Houses and the Tribunal add layers of complexity to the overarching story. The freedom given to players in their approach to the main quest and the numerous side quests creates a sense of agency and personalization in the storytelling.

Character customization is one of Morrowind's strengths, offering a wide array of races, classes, and skills. The intricate character creation system allows players to craft a truly unique protagonist. However, the combat mechanics can be a point of contention. The dice-roll combat system, while a staple of classic RPGs, can feel clunky to modern gamers. It requires a degree of patience and adaptation, but those who persevere will find a satisfying sense of progression as their character becomes more skilled and powerful.

The modding community has played a significant role in Morrowind's enduring popularity. Even years after its release, a plethora of user-created content is available, ranging from graphical enhancements to extensive quest mods that expand the already vast world of Vvardenfell.

Despite its many merits, Morrowind is not without its flaws. The aging graphics may deter some modern players, and the absence of voice acting for most NPCs might be a hurdle for those accustomed to more contemporary RPGs. Additionally, the lack of a quest marker system means players must rely on directions given in the dialogue, which can be confusing at times.

In conclusion, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind remains a landmark title in the RPG genre. Its expansive world, rich lore, and unparalleled sense of freedom set the standard for open-world games. While some aspects may feel dated by today's standards, the game's enduring legacy is a testament to its lasting impact on the gaming industry. For those willing to immerse themselves in a meticulously crafted world and embrace the challenges of classic RPG mechanics, Morrowind is a journey well worth taking.

Oldie but goodie.

Though I only recently bought the Steam version of this game, I had a few hundred hours into it on its original CD-ROM version.

Let's be honest: People my age are too nostalgic, and we say that our old pixelated games are better than the new stuff. BUT younger people have the exact opposite problem where you insist that anything newer and shinier is automatically better. If we both set aside our biases and just judge this game based on its gameplay, I maintain that it is ten times the game that Skyrim is. I'll give 3 examples.

First, Morrowind truly lets you go anywhere and do anything from the very beginning. If you want to wander into a high-level area and get yourself beaten up, or if you want to kill a character that is crucial for the main story, then Morrowind will let you do this. It's your playthrough--you can enjoy it however you want to. By contrast, Skyrim is full of unpickable locked doors and unkillable main story characters because the devs want to force you to play the game a certain way and only interact with certain content at certain times. If I want to overthrow the crime family that runs Riften, the game won't let me. If i stumble across the Thalmor Embassy, I can't get inside (without a glitch or mod) even if my locking level is 100.  What incentive do I have for exploring, if I won't be allowed to access half of what I find?

Second, Morrowind never bothers you with the main story. You can pursue or ignore the main quest however you'd like. By contrast, after you fight the first dragon in Skyrim, the game will constantly send dragons after you. The main story will hunt you down, find you, and make you pay attention to it. This is yet another example of how the devs want to force players to play the game a certain way, instead of giving players the true freedom to interact with and enjoy the open world in any way that the players choose.

Lastly, many of the so-called achievements in Skyrim are actually obstacles or caps. For example, in many towns/cities, high-level quests are off-limits to you until you own land in that city. So you have to spend a lot of money buying houses in every city. This process is probably done to prevent players from becoming game-breakingly rich early in the game. But it's still a very obnoxious scenario, where the game is pretending to reward you by actually forcing you to spend a lot of money in order to progress. By contrast, you can only ("only") buy 2 houses in Morrowind, but they're wonderful houses and they are ACTUALLY rewards for having completed a long questline.

In conclusion, Morrowind gives players far more genuine freedom to explore a brilliantly immersive world.

Morrowind is a masterpiece, plain and simple.  When I first played it, upon it's release in 2003, my old computer was barely able to keep up with the graphics, and in fact the cut scenes were clipped and stuttered. Fortunately, they were few and far between.  The only thing that I really disliked about the game, was the facial graphics, which were absolutely horrid. Otherwise, the game was a treat, made me a fan of the Elder Scrolls series, and led me to purchase and play to death first Oblivion, and then Skyrim.  

It was not until just recently, some 20 years after playing the original, that I purchased the Morrowind Game of the Year Edition on Steam, and have just completed my first playthrough.  I did download several mods, with the most important being (for me):  MGE XE, Better Heads, Better Dialogue Font, Morrowind Enhanced Textures and Graphic Herbalism.  The other mods were all good, but I think those 5 contributed most to my enjoyment of the gameplay.  It was so nice to not have to deal with that original facial art, and Graphic Herbalism made harvesting components so much simpler than trying to guess which plants you had already harvested, and which you hadn't.   

Having been a big fan of both Oblivion and Skyrim, it was amazing to go back and play Morrowind once again, and find that it not only held up to those two later games, but actually surpassed it in almost every regard.  The depth of the main quest was awesome, and really pulled me in.  For my first character I made a custom built Nord melee specialist, specializing primarily in Axes, and it was a joy to have him swinging and slicing his way through the wilderness of Vvardenfell.  By this end of this playthrough, which I admit I spent a lot of time on, he was at 100 at all his stats except INT and WIL, and those were both over 80.  All of his Major and Minor skill were maxed or getting close to it, except for Armorer, which seems to go up very slowly, Alteration, which is limited by INT, and a couple of others.  Granted, he was very, very overpowered by the end of the game, but I had finished the main quest with him still around level 40, so it was still somewhat of a challenge.  

As to the expansions, which of course are included in the GOTYE, I really enjoyed Tribunal ... I mean really enjoyed it! ... but found Bloodmoon very tedious, and the only really unsatisfying part of the game for me.  The packs of mobs, attacking you around every hill, was just a pain, and contributed nothing to the enjoyment of the game.  Why the designers made such a radical departure from previous gameplay is beyond me.  These mobs meant nothing to Bloodmoon's questlines, dropped no meaningful gear, and seemed to be put into the game just to slow the player down.  

Conclusion:  For those who have never played Morrowind, or like me have not played it for the past 20 years, it is well worth picking up and enjoying.  It remains one of the best games ever released.

I'd never played Morrowind before buying it on sale a few days ago - I spent a lot of my childhood playing Oblivion though, so take this from someone who doesn't have any nostalgia for this game:

Does the combat suck ass? Yes
Is the quest design bland? Yes, and the lack of quest markers goes between allowing for immersion and interaction with the world and annoyingly obtuse
Is it unstable and buggy? Yes, but honestly no more than other Bethesda RPGs - it's honestly become part of their charm at this point
Is this one of the most alive, rich worlds I've ever had the pleasure of playing in? You bet.

For all the static NPCs, the jagged early '00s graphics, and clunky mechanics, Morrowind's world genuinely feels alive. There's not just a feeling of standing in one place and knowing there's a world around you to explore - it's also that that world has history, and those histories have their own histories, everyone has their own place in the world, and they have their own opinion about that place and where they want to go from there - it's a similar sort of feeling to Fallout New Vegas' world design, in that you're a big part of a small part of a big world.

It's okay if the jank drives you off - it's an acquired taste. Once you start to get the hang of things though, there's a definite feeling of satisfaction, of progression, and when you find those things that absolutely break the game, it's reticent to that. There's a lot to be found here, but the game isn't just going to give it to you - you have to engage with it, and that is, of course, not for everyone.

Get it on sale, try it out. If it's not for you, it's more than okay - it might just take you in one day when you decide to give it another go, and once the ball gets rolling, it *will* reward you for giving it your attention.

TES 3 Morrowind is in my opinion the best Elder Scrolls game and one of the greatest games of all time. This game has one of the most compelling narratives I've played, and it does far more with the lore far better than any TES entry before or after. The gameplay itself is also truly spectacular. The dialogue system is the best of any entry in the series, and it's a shame the depth it offered had to be put aside due to voiced line hardware constraints. The magic and fighting systems are done really well, and the leveling system works especially with the lack of leveled enemies.
Admittedly the graphics are a little dated, but I still personally find vanilla graphics enjoyable and at times breathtaking. The other big complaint often posed is how often attacks miss, but it is an intentional game design that wouldn't be egregious if you used a weapon you're actually proficient in. The bugs are admittedly bad at times, and I'd recommend you play with the unofficial code patch by default.
Overall the amount of player freedom and agency are astounding, and there is a significant amount of content packed into the game. For any TES fan, RPG player, or anyone even interested, this game is a must.
Ignore wonky graphics, drool over lore, world building and freeform exploration.
If you've played Skyrim and Oblivion, and liked Oblivion more, this is the next step.

As a younger gamer delving into the realm of classic RPGs, Morrowind felt like stepping into a time capsule of unparalleled creativity and depth. Despite its age, this game continues to astound with its intricate storytelling, vast world, and immersive gameplay.

The first thing that struck me was the sheer size and diversity of Morrowind's world. The land of Vvardenfell is a breathtaking mix of alien landscapes, from verdant forests to ash-covered plains and mushroom-filled swamps. Exploring these diverse regions was a true adventure, with surprises lurking around every corner.

What truly sets Morrowind apart is its dedication to immersion. The game doesn't hold your hand; instead, it trusts you to uncover its mysteries and lore on your own. This level of freedom, though daunting at first, soon became the game's greatest strength. The ability to choose my path, make decisions that shaped the story, and engage with various factions felt empowering and rewarding.

The depth of Morrowind's lore is astounding. The world feels alive, teeming with history, politics, and cultures. The conversations with NPCs, each with their distinct personalities and stories, added layers to the rich tapestry of this game. Unraveling the prophecies, uncovering ancient secrets, and navigating the intricate web of political intrigue kept me thoroughly engaged throughout my playthrough.

Combat and character progression might feel a bit dated by today's standards, but once I embraced Morrowind's unique mechanics, they added to the game's charm. The complex spellcasting system and diverse skill sets allowed for diverse playstyles, making each character truly unique.

Despite its age, Morrowind's visuals hold up remarkably well, especially considering the era it was released in. The art style, coupled with a hauntingly beautiful musical score, contributes significantly to the game's immersive atmosphere.

That said, Morrowind isn't without flaws. Some might find the outdated graphics or the occasional bugs a hurdle. Yet, for those willing to look past these minor issues, the game rewards with an unforgettable experience.

In conclusion, my first venture into Morrowind was nothing short of mesmerising. This game has aged like fine wine, proving that true greatness transcends time. For any gamer seeking a deep, immersive RPG experience, Morrowind stands as a testament to the genre's timeless brilliance.

I came into this game as someone who had only played Skyrim in the Elder Scrolls series previously. I say that to specify that I am not an OG Morrowind player viewing the game through nostalgia goggles. That said, I would HIGHLY recommend this game. You can really feel the love and effort that the developers put into Morrowind back in the day, and I found myself extremely engrossed in the various stories and characters present within the game. (Vivec may very well be one of the most interesting characters I've ever encountered in a video game and certainly within the Elder Scrolls series) In terms of gameplay, I really appreciated the level requirements present in order to rank up within factions (Thieves Guild, Mages Guild, etc.), which makes exponentially more sense than the Skyrim model that allows you to become the Wizard's College Archmaster with only a basic knowledge of destruction. However, even though I liked that system, I did find myself cheesing level-ups a lot, particularly on magic skills, by casting spells near a bed until I ran out of magika, going to sleep to refill, and repeating, which is not terribly immersive. 

Mechanically, there are some issues with the game that I could see preventing someone from enjoying the game. First, movement and attacking (at least with melee weapons) in the early game is ridiculously slow. It takes an obscene amount of time to walk from one point to another, and attacking enemies can be a slog when only 1 out of 10 attacks actually hit your target. Second, it IS possible to lock yourself out of pieces of the main story quest by exploring the world and stumbling on another side quest.  In my playthrough, I would've been completely unable to complete the main quest without console commands, and I ended up missing a very lore-important conversation with a high-level enemy. These issues aside, I do still highly recommend this game as long as you're willing to put up with some old-game jank. In return, you'll find hours of adventure, mystery, and some of the most colorful and interesting characters and lands in the Elder Scrolls.

It's a very interesting fantasy Western RPG with decent mod support if you know where to look and how to activate certain applications like the Morrowind Code Patch and MWSE.

I've heard Morrowind described as an immersive sim first and a curated experience second, somewhat like an inverse of Skyrim (which was crafted as a linear power fantasy with a deliberate aversion towards standard classes and builds when you can easily become a master swordsman/mage/archer/thief/blacksmith/alchemist/enchanter/etc without many role playing opportunities aside from mod support, and the only vanilla role-playing option is minor variations with character race).

The gameplay mechanics of The Elder Scrolls III are somewhat hardcore. Much like Daggerfall / Elder Scrolls II, Melee attacks have a significant chance to miss at low skill levels and spells have a high chance to fail, which increases greatly if your Fatigue gets low from sprinting... but you have the options of toughing it out or installing Magika/Fatigue mods for a smoother gameplay experience. I highly recommend the latter as someone who died to a tiny worm when playing Xbox Morrowind as a kid before moving on to Xbox 360 Oblivion and modded PC Oblivion and PC Skyrim SE with mods.

The setting of Morrowind is very unique and interesting and diverse with alien landscapes, cool architecture, fascinating transport options and exotic semi-hostile wildlife, the homeland the land of the Dummer, an ethnocentric, slave-owning elven culture with a very dim view of foreigners that they call 'outlanders.'

Still, it's an interesting change of pace from the pretty but standardized, puzzle-infested and linear frozen mountain dungeon caves of Skyrim, the standard fantasy woods of Oblivion, and it's more expressive and artistic than Starfield. I'd say it's worth the investment with mod support, especially at a discount for being such an old PC game.

Good stuff.
Lore is deep, although it is fed to you forcefully, since the main quest is heavily political.
Dialogue windows having more than three options are a breath of fresh air after Skyrim.
Power scaling is incredible - you start fighting for your life with mudcrabs and you end up killing incredible creatures.
Disposition as a mechanic is rather good.
Geography is what makes this a true fantasy: people eat eggs mined underground and take leather from flying land-borne jellyfish.
Atmosphere is pretty weak but well, you don't need a thousand mods to enjoy the game as is.
Levelling up is extremely confusing but once you get to know it, allows for fun stat management.
Magic is, unlike pretty much all other games in the series, actually fun and properly implemented. More meaningful spells than in Hogwarts Legacy, many more than in Skyrim. Magic is not required for playing, but it makes everything more fun. Spellmaking is just creme of the crop.

There's also bad stuff.
There is no way to organise your Journal, so it's best to keep a second one on you just in case.
Aggro mechanics are as annoying as it gets - a creature can spot you from a mile and get stuck while trying to approach you - this means no resting and healing within 100 metres of the spot, until you noclip and find the poor soul.
Most quests are "a naked guy is cursed by a witch" or "they stole my guar skins"
Inventory is just a mess, even more than in Skyrim (unbelievable).
Game crashes are... more common than I would like to admit. Happened to me probably 40-50 times, so like every 2-3 hours.
Bland melee and range combat (excluding fists and magic), once you come to an enemy, you just click faster than it does. Although, considering Weapon Condition, three strike types and weapon class diversity, I guess it's not as bad as in Skyrim.

Overall - worth it

Ah....Morrowind. I hope our ongoing relationship (over 20 years now!) never ends. I remember our first meeting. I went to GameStop in 2002 with a little extra Christmas money. I was holding you and another game, Shenmue 2, and having a hard time deciding which to take home to my Xbox. I ultimately decided on you and I'm a better person for it.

I still think about the first time I stepped off the boat onto Vvardenfell and I had absolutely no idea what I was doing. No quest arrow pointers, no direction. I was just supposed to do whatever I felt like. The very idea was mind-boggling and so hardcore. My first trip down the road toward Pelagiad, then on to Balmora, Caldera, and Ald-Ruhn. It was days before I even started the main quest. I rolled a few characters and we had a lot of fun times, but then you changed. Yes you changed, for the better, when you decided to show me so much more with your Game of the Year release on Xbox. 
 
The game I had already spent hundreds, possibly thousands, of hours in had nearly doubled in size. I still hadn't even done everything there was to do in the base game, but I knew I would come back evetually, so I moved on the expansions. We had so much fun together. I never imagined it could get any better.

But then, I got a PC. Oh, how I never even dreamed of the possibilities. Mods. Mods everywhere. The Unofficial Patch. Better Bodies. Morrowind Graphics Extender. I was never very shallow and didn't mind how you looked, but these and hundreds of other mods, no thousands, showed your true potential.

We've had our ups-and-downs. There's been times I have looked through old saves and realized I haven't spent time with you in over a year, but I know you'll always be there waiting. I'll admit I've cheated on you with your younger siblings. I know I'm a terrible person. 

I fell victim to the sway and promises of Oblivion, but it was too easy. It showed where to go and what to do. It gave me less armor and weapon choices. It tried to limit my experience. It was cold-hearted. While it was fun, it was really just a fling.

I went back to you for awhile, but then Skyrim released. Sure it was new and flashy, it looked gorgeous, but that's not what it's about. It was even easier than Oblivion. So after another fling and another lesson learned, I went back to you yet again.

I've purchased you 4 times over now (Xbox vanilla, Xbox GOTY, PC GOTY, Steam GOTY) and I've still never experienced all you have to offer.

----------

Environment: 10 - From the shores of Dagon Fel to the sprawling city of Vivec. From the streets of Mournhold to the Clockwork City. Very few words can describe the magnitude of the environment - sprawling is the first that comes to mind. Go anywhere you want. The sky's the limit. No really, it's the only limit.

Controls: 7 - Look up, look down. Strafe left, strafe right. Pretty basic setup. Combat may be clunky, but mods exist to make it better if you want. It's an action RPG, but an RPG none the less. Stat based combat means not everything willl hit every time.

Gameplay: 10 - Essentially, Morrowind allows you to do what you want, when you want. Play the game however you feel like. Don't feel like ever completing the main quest line? No problem. You might even forget it's there like I did. Want to kill off an important NPC that's part of the main quest line? No worries there either. There's even a work-around quest line that will still allow you to finish the main quest line if you prefer.

Entertainment: 10 - Become a member of the Thieve's Guild and steal your way to the top. Rise through the ranks of the Fighter's Guild and earn your place. Join one of the three political houses for some intrigue. Go on a walk-about and see what there is to see.  You might run into a naked Nord that has been bewitched or you could possibly encounter a group of bandits. There is so much going on in this game, you just have to explore to experience some of the random and crazy things out there.

Replayability: 10 - I've spent many, many hours in this game, and have only played a total of four characters. I still want to start a new character at some point. I hope that explains the score well enough.

Graphics: 7 - At release, it was gorgeous. Compared to modern games, it's not much to look at. If you're a shallow Hal, there's plenty of mods available to spruce things up a bit.

----------

If you've never played an Elder Scrolls game before, you have no idea what you're missing. If you started with either Oblivion or Skyrim, you have no idea what you're missing. A lot of gamers agree (no source) that Morrowind is the pinnacle of the Elder Scrolls series and I agree. Do yourself a favor and get the game.

Most important is give it some time. After the short intro scene, you're on your own. You decide where to go and what to do. You decide how to play the game. The learning curve can seem a bit steep, but believe when I say very simply, it's worth it.

-----------

It makes your character actually have weaknesses instead of the modern approach of RPGs where you are completely overpowered in every aspect right from the rip, and never fail. In Morrowind if you are not skilled in something then it will be difficult to perform the action, especially in combat when you are rolling against anothers skills.

By far and large the best old-school RPG game to date (in my personal opinion).

What makes Morrowind truly unique is the ability to craft any spell and potion one desires, plus its alien landscape which modern-day fantasy  RPGs have failed to replicate and its fantastic lore which makes the player feel as if they have stumbled into a Lovecraftian-inspired fantasy world.

And who could forget the story? Compared to the likes of Oblivion and Skyrim, Morrowind's main plot is simply out of this world, as it involves a resurrected warrior from the old days on a quest to overthrow those who betrayed and killed him while also dealing with a monstrous madman who seeks to enslave all of Morrowind's inhabitants using something similar to a Blight.

Last but not least, it is worth pointing out that while the combat is not the best, it gets progressively better depending on how many skill points one invests as one levels up.

Do yourself a favour and give this last old-school RPG a shot. Oblivion and Skyrim as well as any other RPGs that followed them (which includes Witcher 3) may seem more refined in aesthetics, combat, open-world exploration and transportation but story-wise and in terms of uniqueness, they unfortunately fall short of Morrowind's greatness.

Just an amazing game and when it came out in 2002 there was nothing like it. Even though the graphics are very dated now I still have lots of fun with this game; the factions, quests, setting, the world are wonderful. I highly suggest! This game is why I bought an original Xbox.

You start playing Morrowind. You pick a race, class, go through the tutorial and dive right in. The controls are a bit clunky and you feel a bit awkward swinging around the first dagger you get. Well screw it, let’s see what this game has to offer. So you go up to the first enemy you see, a mudcrab. You start hacking away at it, only to find that you miss almost 90% of the time. Finally after getting hit a few times you dispatch it. Well, that didn’t go as well as you expected. Then you realize that even when running you are moving at a snail's pace and you are constantly very low on fatigue. You get your hands on better weapons and armour, but you still miss often and take more damage than you expect. Despite all  this, you play on. You get your first side quest, and then you realize that objectives aren’t marked on your map nor are you notified when they are completed. Then you find other tedious things, your magic doesn’t regenerate, there isn’t a fast travel system*, spells can fail, equipment can break, etc. At long last you snap. You run around cursing the day you ever thought it was a good idea to purchase this game in a blood-curdling scream. But for whatever reason you play on, maybe you want to see if you can get the slightest satisfaction out of the money you’ve invested, maybe a small part of you likes the game, or maybe you want to add more play time so your multi-paragraph rant about why you shouldn’t play this game will be taken more seriously.

	Then something magical happens, you get a few level ups and your skills improve. You start figuring out how to keep your health up without constantly purchasing potions. You start paying close attention to the quest instructions and find that they aren’t so difficult to follow. You finally start hitting more than you miss and with every hit you land and every creature you slay you get a burst of adrenaline. You grow stronger and start making short work of enemies that once made mincemeat out of you, laughing triumphantly in your sweet revenge. You start moving much faster than you ever thought you would. But that was just the beginning. You then find yourself paying close attention to the side quests and the people of Morrowind and suddenly you’ve completely immersed yourself in a game that has graphics optimized from the N64 era, but that no longer matters. The controls that once baffled you become completely second-nature. The combat that once was infuriating becomes so great you will charge at every enemy you spot.** The magic system that once seemed impossible suddenly seems like the only way a magic system should work. Even the most trivial interactions become satisfying, and at long last all the troubles you had in the past with this game make complete sense.

	Unfortunately Morrowind isn’t for everyone, and that’s okay. It’s no exaggeration that this game takes a LOT of patience to get into. You begin with selecting races you’re not familiar with and making choices for your character without any knowledge about all they ways they will affect you throughout the game. Then, you are put through a brief tutorial and are thrust right into the game with only an item for the first main quest and a dagger. The rest you will have to look up online or learn through experience. But don’t be discouraged, as this game get’s extremely enjoyable once you get out of the ‘rut’ of the first chunk of the game. Once you finally get a good understanding of how everything works you finally start to see that things that once frustrated you are there for good reason. The customization level of this game is extensive, more extensive than Oblivion or Skyrim. Not that those are bad games, but Morrowind offers a deeper and more challenging experience. You have plenty of classes to choose from, you can make your own class, and you choose a birthsign which can augment your stats or grant you new abilities, further increasing the amount of character builds to experiment with. Overall, if you’ve got a lot of free time on your hands and want to play through an deep and immersive RPG, I cannot recommend Morrowind enough. 

Pros:
	+Very immersive open world
	+Plenty of ways to build your character
	+Background Music is subtle yet very catchy
	+Deep Stat/skill development 
	+Rock Solid Gameplay, takes some getting used to

Cons:
	-Takes a large amount of time to get used to gameplay and controls
        -Outdated Graphics (Can be fixed with the right mods) 
        -Sound Effects are a bit lacking (Fixed with Mods)
        -Enchanting is the worst

* There is a Fast travel system of sorts. (As Nerf mentioned earlier) The Mage’s guild allows you to warp to any other Mage’s guild building. The Silt Striders (Giant mountable insects) let you ride to almost any town. Also you can use intervention spells to warp you to the nearest temple, fortress, etc. When you get further in the game you can use exotic means of transportation such as jumping/levitating across the entire island. Bottom line is, just because there’s no fast travel doesn’t mean you can’t conveniently get places

** Morrowind is often criticized as having a “God-awful” combat system. I have yet to figure out why but the complaint I hear a lot is the fact that you can miss, and early game you will miss a lot. I actually loved this. The higher your agility stat and weapon skill the more often you will hit. This motivated me to try and improve my weapon skills so that I could hit more often. Plus I feel like the health of enemies was lowered to compensate for this. Most of the early enemies will go down in a few hits so long as you're using your most effective attacks. So even early game when you miss a lot fights don’t last too much longer than they would in Skyrim where you hit every time. Point is, the combat system is something I love, but you might not enjoy it.

The story was probably good but I was too frustrated at the level design choices to care. Every hallway looks the same. There is very little freedom. You MUST complete the linear questline to do much of anything. It drove me nuts. Meanwhile in the base game you could wander around, completing segments of the main quest in any order or ignoring large swathes altogether and just doing the back door approach.

Solstheim feels a lot like Skyrim if it only had one town and one or two tiny villages. Wander around and you'll find some draugr tombs. The Skaal. Some werewolves. It feels like its somewhere between the openness of the the base game and the restrictiveness of Tribunal. Tribunal is literally summarized with a flowchart on the wiki. Bloodmoon is not nearly as linear but to move things forward you still need to complete specific sets of quests. So to me Bloodmoon felt like a pretty big downgrade. Not nearly as bad as Tribunal felt to play through though.

[h1] The Ultimate RPG Experience [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is an absolute gem that has stood the test of time. As a long-time fan of the franchise, I can confidently say that this game is a must-play for any RPG enthusiast.

Right from the start, Morrowind immerses you in its incredibly detailed and richly crafted world. The depth of lore and the intricate history of Vvardenfell, the island on which the game takes place, is truly remarkable. From the moment you step off the boat, you feel like you're part of an authentic living, breathing world.

What sets Morrowind apart from its successors, Oblivion and Skyrim, is its sheer complexity and depth. The game doesn't hold your hand, and you're left to explore and discover things on your own. This can be initially challenging for newcomers, but once you get the hang of it, you'll appreciate the freedom it offers.

The character creation and progression system is incredibly robust, allowing you to customize your character to an astonishing degree. You can choose from various races, classes, and birth signs, each influencing your gameplay in unique ways. Leveling up requires careful planning and decision-making, making each choice feel meaningful.

The quest design in Morrowind is superb, filled with multi-layered stories and interesting characters. The main questline is captivating, but the true joy lies in engaging with the numerous side quests and guilds. The writers have done an excellent job of creating a diverse range of scenarios that keep you engaged throughout your adventure.

The combat mechanics may feel a little rigid compared to modern games, but they are functional and still enjoyable. Spellcasting, weapon skills, and stealth gameplay are all well-implemented, providing various playstyles to suit your preferences.

While the graphics may seem outdated by today's standards, the artistic design and attention to detail make up for it. The environments are stunning, giving you a sense of awe and wonder as you explore the unique landscapes of Vvardenfell.

Furthermore, Morrowind has one of the best soundtracks in gaming history. The haunting melodies perfectly capture the atmosphere and elevate the overall experience.

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind® Game of the Year Edition includes Morrowind plus all of the content from the Bloodmoon and Tribunal expansions. The original Mod Construction Set is not included in this package.
An epic, open-ended single-player RPG, Morrowind allows you to create and play any kind of character imaginable. You can choose to follow the main storyline and find the source of the evil blight that plagues the land, or set off on your own to explore strange locations and develop your character based on their actions throughout the game. Featuring stunning 3D graphics, open-ended gameplay, and an incredible level of detail and interactivity, Morrowind offers a gameplay experience like no other.
In Tribunal, you journey to the capital city of Morrowind, called Mournhold, to meet the other two god-kings of Morrowind, Almalexia and Sotha Sil. Your journey will lead you to the Clockwork City of Sotha Sil and massive, epic-sized dungeons, where strange and deadly creatures await you, including goblins, lich lords, and the mysterious Fabricants.
Bloodmoon takes you to the frozen Island of Solstheim where you'll experience snow, blizzards, and new creatures, including frost trolls, ice minions, and wolves... just to name a few. You'll have a choice of stories to follow and have the opportunity to defend the colony, take control over how the colony is built up, and eliminate the werewolves. Or, you can decide to join the werewolves and become one of them, opening up a whole new style of gameplay.
Key features:
Players can take their existing Morrowind characters and save games and continue their adventures in the Morrowind GotY edition
Adds up to 80 hours of new gameplay and quests for current Morrowind players
Explore the forests, caves, and snow-covered wastelands of the island of Solstheim
Delve into new, epic-sized dungeons and visit the Capital City of Mournhold and the Clockwork City of Sotha Sil
Fight new creatures including bears and wolves, lich lords and goblins, ice minions and spriggans
Direct the construction of a mining colony and face the threat of savage werewolves
Become a werewolf and indulge your thirst for the hunt
New armor and weapons including Nordic Mail and Ice blades

Easy recommendation, the best Elder Scrolls game ever. What you should rather know is that the game runs on 1024*768 max, and requires modding for higher resolutions. You should download (from Nexusmods)
1- Morrowind Code Patch (MCP) 
2- Morrowind Graphic Extender (MGE XE). 
From MGEXE you can also adjust the UI size to fit your new resolution. MGE XE includes various graphic improvements, but you need to fiddle with some of them. (It's optional, you do not need to.) Getting another mod called "Better Dialogue Font" is also recommended. You can use the Nexus Mod Manager to install these, but do not need to. Actually, NMM did not properly install the mods (in the right folder) for me and I had to do it manually. Mods do a great job and include lots of options if you are into making QOL adjustments. It took me a while to figure things out, but it all looks better now and it's playable again. Yay!

5. Develop a crippling addiction to alchemy and enchanting
6. Spend your evenings thinking about how you're going to become a god with the next soul you trap
7. Run into unexplored territory, hopeful that you'll find a powerful enemy capable of powering your weapon
8. Get distracted in a random crypt miles away from your intended destination
9. Develop a crippling addiction to exploring random mines and dungeons
10. Become so powerful you can one-shot the toughest enemies in the main game.
11. Remember there is a main quest.
12. Forget the main quest.
13. Die to a werewolf or goblin.
14. Reaffirm your commitment to alchemy and enchanting.
15. Disrupt an entire religion by killing its god, trapping his soul, and using it to boost your strength.
16. Drink enough Sujamma to one-shot the luckiest little punk in Tamriel
17. Realize you haven't slept in weeks because you're obsessed with a game that's now old enough to drink.
18. Read about Tamriel Rebuilt
19. Roleplay a character in your head that's so good, you install it and start all over
20. Arrive in Vvardenfell a new person.
21. Immediately leave because now you have a whole new game that's better than the original DLC.

I loved Morrowind when it first came out, and I loved it again 20 years later. You step off your prison-ship, run through your character generation, and then - the world's your oyster. Want to play like a cozy gamer? There's potion-making and enchanting and ingredient-gathering / hunting to do. Like caves? Me neither - and Morrowind's caves are so rewarding / interesting that even someone who speedruns caves b/c they'd rather be cozy in their home - will still enjoy them, or at least like the reward/story. Like boss fights? Morrowind has a few of those. Want to do a quest that tells you what to do, but stops short of holding your hand? That's Morrowind, main quest and all. Don't care to do the main quest? That's fine. There's no mechanic or bug going to stop you from just... being in this strange world and getting to know it because it's different from so many others in its genre (or in Bethesda's titles I spose).

I run around for a few hours filling my pockets with low quality loot and running away from battles. I then find my way back to the closest town and head back to Balmora to sell my stuff. This game sucks

For the time I can see why this is so revered. Large map (artificially), pure freedom, unique scenery that feels otherworldly, and a magic system that is epic. The main takeaway I have from this game is that Bethesda screwed up streamlining the magic, because nothing is funnier than levitating over enemies and poking at them with spears. The combat is actually fine, it makes sense that you suck shit at fighting at first. Even if I don't like this game, I still can see why others might TO AN EXTENT. When I hear people rave about how insane the decrease in quality is from Oblivion, I kinda roll my eyes and feel like the nostalgia glasses have been on tight. But this isn't about the other games, so back to Morrowind. 

Now for the bad.

The dialogue system SUCKS. It's like if they continued Daggerfall's system, but for some reason thought to make it more Wikipedia like. The hyperlink system was bad in Daggerfall, and it's bad here. I know they couldn't have added fully voiced, hyper interactive dialogue I know the story behind the development of this game. But even then, this is the best we could've got? Fallout 1 didn't have a lot of voice acting either, yet in that game you feel like you're speaking to not just characters but actual people. Here, everytime I meet a person it's like I'm reading the Wiki. 

The world is not that interesting. Yes it's alien, yes it has some pretty sights, and yeah it's by far the most unique map Bethesda ever had. But it's uniqueness isn't enough to make me like it even half as much as Oblivion or Skyrim. Let alone something like Fallout 3 which is one of my favorite game worlds. Vivec is a confusing mess. Balmora is fine. I actually really like the one with Skarr, even with those storms. But they're just cities, I don't really care about them. What I do really care about is every dungeon being the same exact thing. I know people hate Daggerfall's dungeons, but at least you actually felt like you was dungeon crawling. These ones are just boring, and I already know people would see this and say "but realism, daggerfall made no sense at least in Morrowind they're realistic" and to that I think it's fair. But this is the elder scrolls, not real life. The giant mushrooms, alien swamps, and ash mountains are kinda cool but again I'm not that crazy over them. 

The quests are really, really bad. This is actually a criticism I share with Daggerfall as well, in that game the quests were generally the same and you could actually get screwed over by bugs and not be able to finish it. But here, they work and all but it's just boring. They're fetch quests, but usually have you fetching items from places in the cities. And when you do get a dungeon, it'll be just another confusing Dwemer ruin that looks just like the other ones. The main quest though is way cooler than I thought it'd be, you're basically an agent which is cool. But the Mages Guild, Thieves Guild, and Fighters Guild SUCKS. I joined one of the Great Houses because I heard they're usually great, but it's the same shit there too. Imperial Legion? Same shit. Cults? Same shit. Cool assassin group? Same shit. This is one of those things that Oblivion wipes Morrowind on, at least in that game I can remember more than like 2 quests because they're usually interesting. And yeah I know there's hidden plots and more than meets the eye in a lot of these guilds, particular with some of the Great Houses and the cults. But that isn't enough to make me even remotely care.

There's more I could talk about, but really every single problem I've mentioned seemingly carries on to whatever else you'd want to discuss about the game. And since this is one of those Reddit games (not that being a reddit game means it sucks, just that the fandom is insane) I've seen people with any criticism be labeled as casuals or tik tok zoomers or whatever. And to that I say fine lol, I'll be a casual if it means I don't have to walk another 30 fucking minutes just to grab a Dwemer tube. Or make my way through Vivec's bullshit interior layout. As someone who wants to go through each of these games and rank them, I'd put this in the same boat as Skyrim but for different reasons. Play Daggerfall instead, it's free so you won't be giving any money to Zenimax and Todd Howard.

This review's goal is not to say this game is worthless. It was one of the first open world games, but it certainly is to counter the claim that this is Bethesda's masterpiece.

Combat
It isn't good. You spam click with either magic or melee, then rest when you can. I rarely needed to buff myself, or even could as the inventory menu requires you to read 90% of the potions in your inventory to even know what you have. Some people say the attribute system is superior to Skyrim, it's not. Skyrim had a perk system that made you feel like you were getting stronger. This is spamming actions in order to increase skills. The main attributes feel like nothing, simplifying it into the Skyrim level up system was a major improvement.

Quest design
I never expected for the gameplay to be good, but I sure as hell got hyped up for the quests in this game. People say it's this and it's that, yada yada about old game design. Let me walk you through what every single Morrowind quest is like.
Go to quest giver - > find fetch item location from journal directions - > either the fetch item is in a dungeon (go clear it) or it's an NPC at which, that NPC will give you a dungeon or you can talk to them - > go back to quest giver
I have yet, in my 35 hours been given any meaningful decisions in quest. The closest I've gotten, is being able to rat on NPCs for doing crime. Which the only consequence is losing that NPC as a vendor if you rat on them. In these 35 hours I have laughed once at dialogue.

World design
The open areas are barren hell scapes in which you hold W for hours, inter sliced with clicking on random enemies with the worst AI I have seen. The cities are copy and paste hell scapes in which there are few quests, only centered around the main 'factions'. I put factions in airquotes because they hardly interact with eachother, in reality they are large fetch quest handout lines that at the end, you finally get access to a vendor that's identical to the one across the street.

Dialogue
Spam the blue highlighted buttons so the NPC exposits the quest in the most bland way ever, with zero stakes because again you are literally just a errandboy. You don't even have to read ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of what they say because you can just press j and know everything you need to. The Bethesda fanboy will claim that this is an improvement to quest markers, not realizing both are the same mindlessly uncritically following directions slop injected into RPGs for more playtime. Except, this is more of a time investment. You get use to it and it becomes braindead easy. It's not that the journal is harder, it's that it's a substantial increase in time investment for F tier quests.

This game isn't hard, it's incredibly easy. It's just that because of the era, they weren't able to fill the world so they added hours of mindless tedium. The Bethesda fanboys will of course say no, it's actually incredibly riveting gameplay doing the 30th mindless fetch quest so you can get a meaningless title in a faction. No your brain is just rotten if you don't enjoy doing 30 hrs of these fetch quests. Well if that's the case, guess I'll be going back to skibidi fortnite battle royale amongus imposter sus edition game of the year edition preorder

Morrowind's outdated combat and graphics might frighten modern gamers, but it's a game that stands tall on it's own merits with it's classic uniqueness.

The world of Vvvardenfall is absolutely beautiful, the charm from the game comes from exploring a wondrous and odd land full of weird creatures and a landscape that just screams fantasy.

If the lore behind the Elder Scrolls is something you are interested in this is a must-play, with my favourite main story and setting in the series I can definitely recommend this game to those who love classic rpgs and Bethesda titles.  The lore behind the Nerevar and Dagoth Ur solidified my love for this game and settled Dagoth Ur at the top of my list of favourite video game antagonists.

The only other game I want to get a remake close to as much as this would be Fable 2, I believe Morrowind is a game I would absolutely love to revisit in the future, not that the games current state has aged badly but I would love for a modern audience to explore the world of Morrowind and its landscape.

Vvardenfell, also called the Black Isle,[1] is a large island located inside the bay-like Inner Sea, and is surrounded by mainland Morrowind with the exception of its northern coast, which meets the Sea of Ghosts. The island is dominated by the great volcano, Red Mountain. The island itself is named after the original Dwemeri name of Red Mountain, literally translating to "City of the Strong Shield".[2] It is characterized by arid wastes, rocky highlands and coastal wetlands filled with unusual and unique flora and fauna. Red Mountain’s lava flows, eruptions, and ash-fall cause Vvardenfell’s landscape to undergo a constant cycle of death and rebirth. The soil becomes greatly fertilized thanks to the volcanic activity, and new plants and fungi emerge from the cooling ashes. It also causes the island to expand as the lava hardens.[3]

Vvardenfell was initially inhabited by House Dagoth, the only Chimer clan to have their capital (Kogoruhn) on the island, as well as a kingdom of the Dwemer.[2][4] The corruption of Dagoth Ur’s Ash Blight would have a dramatic effect on the environment and its inhabitants. By the late Third Era, Vvardenfell was noticeably less vibrant, and Cliff Striders, Nix-Oxen, and Vvardvarks were wiped out.[5] During the Red Year of 4E 5, Vvardenfell was devastated after the Ministry of Truth crashed into the city of Vivec, causing Red Mountain to erupt. Most of the island was covered in ash, forcing much of the population to evacuate.[6]

[h1] Preface [/h1]

I am not a Morrowboomer My first introduction to The Elder Scrolls was Skyrim, then Oblivion, then Morrowind. I plan to review the game in a critical fashion and lay out its strengths and flaws Also, I use minimal mods to enjoy a mostly vanilla experience. [url=https://modding-openmw.com/lists/i-heart-vanilla/] I Heart Vanilla [/url]

Morrowind is a game from another era in gaming. Its graphics are not what you would call realistic, but it was a huge step up from Daggerfall. It processes most things through dice rolls like a real TTRPG, like whether or not your sword swing lands, or if you cast your spells properly. These of course get better later on as you level up, but in the beginning it can be INFURIATING. The GUIs are very unique: even looting can be tedious. Leveling up is something you have to get used to. You get points and depending on how you use your skills, you get multipliers for those points to be spent in attributes. 

[h2] Vvardenfell [/h2]

Vvardenfell is an island filled to the brim with mystery, weirdness, monstrosities, and side quests. There is an incredible amount of content packed into this game. There are so many guilds and organizations the player can join, each with their own unique questline, plenty of random sidequests you simply find out on the road, and places to explore like Dwemer ruins and Daedric Shrines. Truth is, you'll never run out of things to do, including the main quest.

[h2] Different [/h2]

I did use the [url=https://en.uesp.net/wiki/Morrowind:Morrowind] uesp [/url] just to learn how to play this game and to help with a few quest, because it does not help you one bit. You're dropped off in Seyda Neen and that is it. But once you get the hang of how the game functions and keep in mind that things will get better as you increase your stats, you'll find that Morrowind is truly one of the best RPGs ever made.

[h2] Magic [/h2]

Magic in Morrowind, I think, is one of its strong suits. There are tons of different spells you can learn. But the best part is once you buy a spell, you can then make spells at certain vendors who will give you a host of options to choose from. You can make Self spells (they affect you), Target spells (aim and fire!) or Touch spells (get up close and personal!), and then you can select how long the spell lasts, and how effective it is. The game then generates the price for the spell, how much Magicka it consumes, and your chances of casting it properly. 

[h2] Melee Combat [/h2]

Once you have increased your stats, you'll find that stabbing in someone’s face with an ebony spear can be quite... relaxing. Just push through the tedium in the beginning. The melee combat is not the best by any means, but it is still fun and there are many different types of weapons. Something Skyrim did not do so well at. Including Long Blades, Short Blades, Blunt Weapons, Axes, Spears, Bows, and even Crossbows. Most of these have to be leveled up individually, so it's best to pick one or two of them in character creation.

[h2] Character Creation [/h2]

Another highpoint for Morrowind. If you fill out the papers in the beginning yourself, you can become a truly unique individual. By selecting skills to put in the Major category, you gain a ton of points in the beginning for those skills. The same goes for Minor skills, but to a lesser extent. Everything you don't pick is tossed into Misc. with only a paltry 5 points. Good thing Morrowind is good at this part, because it falls flat on player appearance. You pick a race, but you only have a few different heads, hairstyles, and faces to choose from. Sure this is not Skyrim or Oblivion with its sliders for infinite customization.  

[h3] Other [/h3]
[list]
    [*]Levitation, Water Walking and Water Breathing spells.
    [*]Vvardenfell is gigantic. There are so many things to explore outside of the cities, and quests to go on. 
    [*]The main quest is completely separate from everything else. You are not required to complete it outright. 
    [*]The game is very slow-paced. This can be a good or bad thing depending on your playstyle. If you love really digging into a game this is perfect. If you are looking for some instant gratification, this might not  be for you
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Morrowind is truly is a diamond in the modern rough. It is a labor of love, and you will, with patience, have a fantastic and memorable experience in this legendary title. I’ve avoided making too many comparisons to TES IV and V because it is a little unfair to do so as far as graphics go, but I believe Morrowind is the better RPG of all of them, while Skyrim is a more polished lite RPG. If you are a hardcore RPG lover, Morrowind is an ideal choice.

There was this one quest that initially appeared to have a game-breaking glitch. This was because I had eliminated the cave rat found in the bedroom, and there was only one rat. However, the quest giver behaved as if I hadn't accomplished anything.

Upon inspecting my journal more thoroughly, I later unearthed that there were more rats lurking in a separate room that was supposed to be located higher in the building.

In my experience, Oblivion and Skyrim quests of this nature would be completed in less than a minute. This is primarily because my strategy always involved sprinting towards the quest-marker or the NPC below the quest-marker.

Contrary to Morrowind, I believe it's impractical to play Skyrim with the quest-marker disabled. The reason being, game designers anticipate that players will have it enabled anyway, thus they don't bother incorporating written or verbal directions like those found in Morrowind.

...

For the record, I earnestly hope that The Elder Scrolls 6 will not merely be an extension of Skyrim, either in spirit or in scope. Furthermore, I anticipate its prompt release as the intervening time since Skyrim's debut has already doubled the period between the launches of Oblivion and Skyrim!

The worlds of Fallout and its less-than-stellar, Spore-themed spinoff have ceased to captivate me.

In my opinion, Bethesda should have prioritized the development of The Elder Scrolls 6 over Starfield. Even if The Elder Scrolls 6 ends up being a reimagining of Fallout 4 set in Tamriel, it would still offer a worthwhile experience, justifying the wait.

However, it is disheartening to acknowledge that Bethesda Game Studios and Bethesda Softworks have both long recognized the financial viability of producing 'blank slate' games over crafting more intricate experiences akin to Daggerfall or even Morrowind. It's concerning how much they rely on their fanbase to rectify game issues, particularly those of their own making.

On a side note, I am apprehensive that they might now focus on creating games that necessitate DLC to feel complete.

If TES6's release extends beyond the year 2030, then it would signify an unusually prolonged development period.

Should the base game prove to be merely a high-definition version of Skyrim with lesser scope than Starfield, and another lackluster storyline, it would indeed be a disappointment, especially for an ardent fan like myself.

Bethesda needs to seriously consider upgrading their infamous Creation Engine. It's about time it became stable enough to realistically render an entire city, rather than a mere microcosm of one. They are long past the point where excuses are acceptable!

Even if Bethesda's performance falls short, there will be modders who will adapt to their shortcomings. However, it's regrettable that Bethesda seems content with simply meeting the minimum standard by leaning on the efforts of modders, rather than striving for excellence.

This game is a gem. I love Skyrim and Oblivion, but you don't realize how lackluster their writing is until you play this game. Morrowind reminds me a lot of Fallout: New Vegas- it feels like you're existing in a real world and talking to real people in a way that is difficult to capture in a lot of RPGs.

I'm a fan of hoarding equipment, especially when there are many options to cosmetically alter the character with it. Morrowind has equipment and customization to spare, which makes the exploration gameplay fun for me, and exploration is the majority of the game. Most open world games without blatant leveled equipment also meet my criteria. What sets Morrowind apart (and what I didn't know I'd care about) is its method of world building and immersion. The slice of life dialogue/quests, player actions and world events affecting reputations and quests, and finding quest locations via detailed directions rather than a magical waypoint put this game a cut above the rest, even with its dated mechanics.

I mean, how do I even start to review Morrowind?  When this came out on Xbox, it was THE game, it has set the bar for so many games of this type it shouldn't need a review.  But if I MUST:

Pros:
- One of the first truly open world games that were good
- SO many games have ripped it off,should speak volumes
- Once you know, storing stuff at the one house that's not yours is cool, unless ya have the expansion, then ya get ya own house in skald village
- Voice acting and story, lots of time put into that
- Runs GREAT on steam, I've had less crashes than when I played it on xbox for sure
- Again, this set the bar, I wont keep going with the pros, play this game if you haven't, if you have, play it again

Cons:
- No controller support
- Missions can be a bit vague, side quests are very trivial
- Cliff racers, constantly, wherever you go not near a town, get used to THAT annoyance
- 95,000 dollar items, we'll give ya 2000.  Best fill up that room with glass junk

This is one of the greatest games of all time. To not like it is fine, but people who say this game is bad are people who hate having to think while playing a video game. They create a character who isn't skilled in short blade, take the dagger from the census office, and then complain online that their character isn't killing anything with a weapon they have no skill in. If you saw someone playing Guitar Hero, and they were only pressing the fret buttons without strumming, and they complained that they kept failing the song, you would rightfully mock them for not playing the game right. This is directly analogous to Morrowind. Combat is extremely easy if you equip your character with a weapon they actually know how to use, you actually charge up your swings like you're supposed to, and you keep your character's fatigue up. If you refuse to engage with the game's systems though, of course you're going to fail. Simply learn how to play the game correctly, and the experience that will be opened to you is one that you'll never forget.

Skill issue sermon aside, there's not much I can say about the base game that hasn't already been said better than I could by dozens of other people (I highly recommend PatricianTV's brief retrospective), so instead I just wanna talk about the expansions for a second. If you've never played this game before, let me give you some very important information up front: Tribunal's main quest won't make sense if you haven't finished the main quest yet, and the enemies in both expansions will rip you a new butthole if your character isn't at least level 25-30. As for the actual content of these expansions, one of them is extremely mid and the other is one of the best expansions of all time. 

Tribunal seems cool on the surface; you go to the mainland of Morrowind and meet returning characters from Daggerfall, plus the two members of the titular trio of gods which are missing from the island of Vvardenfell. The city of Mournhold is beautiful, and there's some fun side quests on offer, such as the one where you join a stage production as an actor. You can also buy a pet scrib, which is an incredible feature which should be standard for every video game. However, the main quest of this expansion reeks. Literally. You'll spend 90% of it delving into the same sewer over and over. That sewer is the "epic sized dungeon" that the game's store page is talking about. Todd was real proud of that sewer. The finale of the main quest is cool though, I really really like Sotha Sil's design. It's a shame he plays such a small role in the story, though.

Now Bloodmoon, on the other hand, kicks ass. If you've played Skyrim you're likely already acquainted with the isle of Solstheim, and it's super cozy to visit in Morrowind. I love the alien landscape of Vvardenfell, but after more than 100 hours, it was bliss to see snow, pine trees, and wolves. Having played so much Skyrim myself, it felt like returning home, which is very appropriate since my character was a nord. What about the actual content on the island though? It's great. You actually have two main quests to play through in Bloodmoon. In one of them, you meet the Skaal tribe, you have a chance to either become a werewolf or join the fight against them, and you eventually come face to face with a daedric prince. In the other questline, you join the East Empire Company, and help steer the development of the brand new colony of Raven Rock. That would already be really cool when the game came out in 2003, but it's awesome when you've already played Skyrim and seen the colony still thriving 200+ years later. I can't speak highly enough about Bloodmoon.

I am a diehard fan of this game out of all the Elder Scrolls games. I actually got into Morrowind just a few years after its initial release thanks to being allowed to watch over my fathers shoulder while he was playing the game and owned the CD version of it ever since I got my first computer.

It's no modern game by any means and it's complex on a mechanical level. It will look ugly compared to modern game aesthetics and will give you a rough start if you don't know what you're doing. But.

It's one of the few games where you really feel like you've earned your win at the end. No quest-markers, no scaling difficulty(for the most part). Just you, your journal and quest log and the world to explore, learn from and conquer. 

The setting is alien enough to get you interested, but not alien enough for you to feel really lost in it unless you are spoon-fed explanations. Unraveling any mysteries is more fun than chore. 

The music is fitting, immersive and calming to a degree that can make you actually want to roleplay your character. They even reused it later in the series in 2012 DLC. That's how good it is.

8/10. Even after nearly 20 years I still keep coming back every now and then. ESO's version had the looks, but nothing can replace the original old grandpa Morrowind for me.

my favorite game. this and deus ex represent a wonderful point in time where first person games were simulations, with dice rolls just like their isometric counterparts.. something is lost when that system is removed. the world building in this game is fucking excellent, and i could explore the various swamps and deserts forever, let alone adding in extra content via mods (Tamriel Rebuilt). A true masterpiece, jagged, but brilliant, as all real diamonds are.

Back when TES was mainly for the PC. It's a good game, but a bit dated and rough here and there. 
One plays this game for the world and exploration, and these are executed just fine. Dialogues are almost all text, and navigating blocks of description and simple dialogue trees is par the course. Most of the writing is interesting, with humor and heart to it. 
Skyrim did combat better, but Morrowind wins at atmosphere and world building. The story is a bit scattershot, but the real fun is in some of the guilds, and the side quests. This game has solid expansions with plenty of content. 
Graphics are decent for the time, and the world is very large with plenty to discover. The graphics don't hold up that well, but I like the visual style. It is very alien and out there. 

I recommend modding the game, to bring it closer to expected QoL in 202X. 
Morrowind remains a solid RPG. I for one appreciate the PC-ish, blocks of dialogue text as well as the weapon attack and spell-failure chance tied to character statistics. It's a transitional Western RPG, which many of us 2000's PC gamers remember fondly.

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind (2002)

I'll start off by saying if you went back down the pipeline from Skyrim to Morrowind and you never played Morrowind before, you might have a bad experience with this game. Morrowind is old, like really old by the standards of today. The combat is clunky, characters walk funny and you actually have to read the dialog. But if you can look past all of this, this game is a great experience. I used a program called OpenMW to update the game a bit, to be able to play in 1980 x 1080 resolution and to stop the game from crashing when you alt tab out of the game. A must get program for the game, highly recommended.

Morrowind is a game I tried to play back in high school, this was around 2007. The graphics does not bother me, but the journal in this game is very annoying. It kinda tells you where to go and you literally have to keep notes on a piece of paper with you as you play, as its easier than bothering with the journal. Back then we did not really had internet to just do a Google search, you had the play the game the old way. I got far with the game but never finished it. I have now finally finished the game last month and I regret not doing it sooner. Once your combat skill get to around 50 and you can actually reliably hit enemies, the game feels exactly like Oblivion or Skyrim. The story is really fun and there is plenty to see and explore. Another old school thing is the fast travel in this game is not like Oblivion or Skyrim, here you have to rely on smaller transport across Morrowind and just walk around on foot to get to places. I'll admit I followed a guide as it is easier then fumbling around with the journal. Exploring cities was really great for me to do, new people to meet and places to experience. Except the City of Vivec - screw that place. You gonna spend many hours there trying to find your way, let alone find the correct person you need to talk to.

This is an extremely fun game to play. Sure there are mods out there to improve the graphics and make the game feel more like a modern experience, but that really takes away from Morrowind if you do so in my opinion. Give this game a try, a real good and honest try and do not quit if you die to a mudcrab in the first city. The experience across the barren lands of Morrowind is one you should experience if you love the Elder Scrolls game. This is a game from a different time, always remember that when you play it.

Finally completed it, after 374 hours (first walkthrough), almost took an year. No major cut-scenes, no major graphics (for a 2002 graphics, they are certainly above level), no major fights, even during the endgame, I played it on hardest difficulty yet it didn't bother me. However, there are a huge number of things that make this game loved without even containing the major things like cut-scenes and graphics that majority of gamers (in 2023) aspire for:

[b]Morrowind[/b]
[list]
[*]A huge-gigantic world to explore, all sorts of places to visit, starting with major cities like Balmora, Vivec, Ald-Ruhn, Sadrith Mora etc, each having their own-different city designs which is the best thing about it.
[*]All the different 50+ port cities and small-settlements with lots of lots of different characters with mostly being involved in a quest.
[*]200+ different caves and mini-dungeons to polish your skills against the outcasts and enemies and less-valued yet high in quantity loot items to establish your economy. For a starter this is the best place to take experience of Morrowind.
[*]100+ dungeons and enemy-group lairs with a series of tougher enemies and big loot in terms of value, like Ancient Dwarven Settlements, different Enemy Bases etc.
[*]If you are an explorer kind of person then Morrowind is best for you as you can travel all sorts of places with roads and pathways which are beautifully designed.
[*]A huge set of different armory for all different parts of body armor, be it helms (helmets), cuirasses, left and right gauntlets, greaves, boots, pauldrons, bracers. Also armory differ on the basis of heavyness - light armor, medium armor, heavy armor.
- Heavy Armor being the best armor, but took too much space due to which you might not able to store many things.
- Light Armor being the weakest sort of armor but took very less space so if you are a farming type or collector type of guy then you should use this type of armor as the additional space can be used to store or collect valuable or unique items.
- Medium Armor, mostly being used by NPCs, so all the unique items are available in Heavy (almost 60-70%) and Light (20-30%) with some exceptions being available in Medium (1-2%).
[*]A huge set of Weaponry for all type of gamers, 
- if you are a sword type person then you can use Long-Swords (One-Handed, Two-Handed), Short-Swords, 
- if you prefer ranged weapons you can go with Bows, Crossbows, Throwing-Knives, Throwing-Stars, Throwing-Darts etc,
- if you are a heavy weapon type guy you can go with Battleaxes and Blunt Weapons (Hammers, Maces, etc), 
- if you don't want to use any weapons then Morrowind features a Hand-to-Hand combat type as well.
[*]Morrowind also contains a huge amount of Flora and Fauna, though they are not very visually attractive. The beasts and animals can be skinned to make different items and gear for you, the flora can be used to make potions
[*]Potions and Intakes. Morrowind contains a huge variety of potions that gives you all different sort of abilities like levitation, invisibility, ranged damage abilities like fireballs, shockballs or lightning strikes etc. These potions are divided into different categories: Exclusive being the best of the class and Bargain being the most non-useful, why non-useful because their effects only lasts 5 seconds and exclusives effects lasted 60 seconds. There's another category - Spoiled, as the name suggests, it gives negative effect on the consumer.
[*]Enchantments and Magic. Morrowind contains different sort of Enchantments and Magical Abilities which are highly beneficial when facing a tough opponent or visiting some unknown place which is very hard to reach for example you can easily travel above the mountains and hard-to-cover terrains using levitation spells or abilities which you can either get using some magical spell, or some potion or some magical scroll or some enchanted item. Morrowind also features different types of magic initialization methods, 
- using scrolls and potions that can only be used 1-time only, so you might need multiple of them. And if you ran out of them at some important place then you either returns to some nearby settlement to buy some or find some other (super-hard) method to achieve whatever you are trying to achieve, 
- using enchanted items, these can be used unlimited times, given that you use them wisely, otherwise they will eventually ran-out of magic and thus needs time to regenerate the magical energy or you find a constant effect item (super-hard to find).
If you have an item which is not enchanted then you can convert that item into enchanted item as well given that your enchantment skill is very-high level or you can find the right NPC of which could provide you the enchantment service for your preferred ability.
[*]Skills. Skills in Morrowind is the most important thing, just like all the other games features. If you are trying to do something that lies under a specific skillset in which you are not good at then the possibility of it being successful is equals to the level that skill is for you. So for example if you are trying to attack using a Long-Sword and let's say your Long-Sword skill is at 50th level then there are 50-50 chances that your first sword attack will be a successful strike to enemy.
[*]Factions. Morrowind features a huge number of different Factions and Groups which you can join. Each of these groups have their own separate storyline which can easily took 1-2 weeks to complete. There are around 30+ different factions and groups in morrowind and around 20+ are joinable and the rest which you can't join, you will encounter them in different quests.
[*]Though Morrowind have comparatively a short storyline but if you are to join all the possible and joinable faction and groups, considering you don't f'ed up the concurrent-joining-conflicts and not mistakenly activate some random glitches your 95% time will be invested in completing or preparing for those quests and work exploration.
[*]Vast amount of Reading Material available for you to read. There are too many books, scrolls (non-magical), pages etc available to read by the player which provides all sort of information, historical aspects of Morrowind, stories, novels, plays (a certain quest, one of the best), some also providing reference to the past releases in the TES Franchise etc.
[*]BGM, one of the best game with the Background Music
[*] Different Sort of Useless yet Antique Material.
[/list]
[b]Expansions and DLCs[/b]
[list]
[*]A beautiful and vast city of Mournhold (included in Tribunal Expansion), with its visually appealing yet challenging sewer.
[*]A cold yet beautifully designed island of Solstheim (included in Bloodmoon Expansion), with a "certain" speciality type.
[/list]

The best part about Morrowind is it's story, when you reach the endgame and you got to know the truth for both Morrowind and Expansions, it's quite surprising for you. Though the story campaigns are quite small.
