Best Elder Scrolls game period you N'wah.

A classic and, in some ways, more dear to my heart than Oblivion or Skyrim. The realm of Morrowind in which this game takes place is truly unique and any true fantasy or RPG fan would appreciate the amount of care and detail put into the characters, lore, and plot of this game.

Sure, its graphics and combat system are now terribly dated. I recommend looking up one of the many overhaul mods to help give those aspects of the game a facelift (although some purists might even prefer the game unadorned).

Regardless, those of you who appreciate the type of things I mentioned above will not be disappointed. Hopefully, this game will continue to be remembered for all it did for the RPG genre in general and the Elder Scrolls series in particular well into the future. 10/10
Awesome game, especially considering its age! Modding it is addictive, but also improves gameplay and updates graphics.

Disclaimer: If you save too many times (in my case, 500 or more saves), the game may not let you save any more and might even crash on saves. If this problem occurs, simply browse local files, backup saves to an external folder, and leave only one or two of the most recent saves to continue with your game.

With that out of the way, the game itself is absolutely fantastic. I've played Oblivion and Skyrim (IV and V in the same franchise), and Morrowind has the best writing of the three games in my opinion. While it's not fully voice acted, the text-box version of the conversations held with NPCs means that you can scroll up and down to see previous dialogue instead of asking them to repeat something. And the journaling system means that you are able to find most of the dialogue even while you're away from an NPC by just scrolling through the alphabetized list of topics. The world is beautiful even for having 2002 graphics, and the music is amazing. If the gameplay gets to be too tough, there is a very forgiving difficulty slider option in the pause menu. Above all else, the class system is extremely customizable with things like unlimited training (not found in Oblivion or Skyrim) and spellmaking (found in Oblivion but not in Skyrim). The factions have ranks that actually mean something with more and more services becoming available and more and more equipment rewards. And even though fast travel is not an option, the Mark/Recall system paired with two kinds of Intervention (teleportation) allow for quick escape from a rough situation. And between cities, Mage Guild teleportation combined with boat and silt strider travel for a very low gold piece cost lets you avoid most hostile encounters that you'd find in the wilderness. It's not as accessible as Skyrim or even Oblivion, but Morrowind's complexity is quite beautiful once you learn all of its facets. And if you can master the mechanics, the protagonist of Morrowind will become even more powerful than the Hero of Kvatch or the Last Dragonborn.

Morrowind has potentially permanently ruined my intimate experiences and expectations for the rest of my life.

As many of you may know, Morrowind was released for the Xbox and PC on May 1st, 2002 (Wikipedia, 2023). Morrowind was a hit release - taking both the gaming and pleasure markets by storm. While the open-world RPG initially seemed innocent in its pursuit to give gamers a truly immersive and fun experience, free of the constraints of reality, I fear the long-term effects it could have on a healthy capitalist society were improperly studied at the time. 

Morrowind was known for many innovations in the world of virtual reality, including: A truly free open world that the player could leave their mark on, faction dynamics and high-emotional political situations, a new take on a mystical fantasy, and of course, the irresistible, curvey, high-definition NPC and player models - specifically, the character Dagoth Ur, the man who ruined my relationship with my wife.

Dagoth Ur is the overarching antagonist of Morrowind and many other Elder Scrolls titles. His goal in Morrowind was to take over the continent, by dominating, binding, enslaving and otherwise forcing the populous into submission (UESP 2023, "File:MW-creature-Dagoth-Ur"). His goals as a villain, however, have attracted the (often intimate) attention of many unknowing Morrowind players, including myself. Dagoth Ur promises, through dreams that your character experiences, a wedding, hot corpse erotica, your ascension to his ash-vampire status (and the perfect, sun-reflecting sparkly skin that comes with it), and the domination of your character. 

Believing his promises, I set out on a journey not to defeat Dagoth Ur, but to side with him, imagining that this game's truly unique and innovative open-world dynamics would allow me to do so. What I did not expect was to watch the most intense, passionate, fiery intercourse between Dagoth Ur and my player character that I have ever seen. This may seem relatively normal to the modern-day reader, however recent studies have been conducted into the effect that these fantasy relationships may have on one's performance in the bedroom. In my case, I was not prepared when I set out to meet my current wife, for a body completely devoid of the rough, low-rendered edges that I had come to expect. This has lead to much pain for both of us, as my I simply cannot seem to manage to stay "active" in the bedroom without such stimulation. At one point, I tried wearing a VR headset, to envision my wife in the glory of the sharmat Dagoth Ur, however even being deprived of his touch was enough to send me into a depressive spiral. 

In conclusion, Morrowind has ruined my life. My wife is filing for divorce due to my unrealistic expectations that were FORCED upon me by the 2001 title Morrowind. If any accurate Dagoth Ur cosplayers wish to contact me for further relations, my lawyer is on standby. 10/10 I love this game.

These are my first thoughts on Morrowind after spending nearly 20 hours playing it. If I finish it I will likely update this review and say more about it. In 20 hours of game time in Morrowind I feel like I have accomplished shockingly little. If I were to say one thing and only one thing about this game it is that it does NOT respect your time. There are so many mechanics in Morrowind that drag the experience down and slow the pacing of the game and I mean that literally. I usually wait until I have either finished a game or given up on it before writing a review but in this case I have to give my thoughts on it as soon as possible. The reason being I have never ever played a game like Morrowind before. A game that misses the mark so incredibly and so frequently.  I also do not wish to progress considerably further into the game only for my experience to suddenly get better and for my demeanour to change and potentially go easier on the game and some of the unforgivable gaming crimes it commits. What do I mean by that? Well, Morrowind lacks some of the most basic and fundamental quality of life features in a video game. This has got to be the most egregious example I've ever seen. If you are considering playing this, please do yourself a favour and skip this one OR look up guides on what classes to use and how to get the most overpowered build and gear early on in the game. Otherwise, you are going to have a REALLY rough time with this. I am one such player. I have never played this before and decided to go in more or less completely blind. I wish I didn't. This game without any exaggeration does not tell you ANYTHING. It doesn't have a tutorial of any kind. It just plops you into the game world and expects you to figure everything out yourself. I know a lot of people may enjoy figuring things out for themselves but when that entails literal HOURS of walking around not knowing what the hell to do, it not only becomes incredibly frustrating but also boring. Depending on the race you choose, in my case being Altmer, your movement speed will vary. I was never expecting to choose a race and move at a snails pace but that's what you get and that is my biggest problem with the game by far. Even above the RNG combat. The walk and "run" speed is so awful and wastes SO MUCH time. Of the 10 or so quests I've done (yes, in 20 hours I've only managed to complete around 10 of the quests in the game) most of them seem to be fetch quests and the writing is incredibly bland not to mention the fact that there is little to no dialogue in the game itself. The first 2 characters do have dialogue but these fuckers were so lazy that all "dialogue" is just text box after text box that you have to read yourself. The quests aren't particularly interesting. Combat is a godawful mess and is the worst I've ever seen because it isn't buggy or broken or anything. The clunky aspect is how they WANTED it to play out. Either way, I'm very unimpressed by Morrowind and its lacklustre mechanics, awful pacing due to how slow you move, completely RNG based combat and lack of any guide on where to go, what to do, where each location is and so on. Stay away. I hope I can update this review and say something more positive in 50 - 100 more hours of playtime, but just know that if you are like me and plan on playing through this dumpster fire blindly then you are going to be left with a feeling of suicide by the end of each and every play session. Seriously, if you want to play this, look anything that's even slightly unfamiliar up.
UPDATE: 
Almost 10 extra hours and to be honest things haven't gotten much better for me. I've reached an area called Vivec which is so large and complicated that it honestly has me asking whether I can even be asked to go through the trouble of trying to remember the layout. I've hardly been doing any combat as I've just been trying to figure out where to go and whilst the game does have a sort of quest tracker it is very unintuitive. So many quests have required me to steal something whilst I don't have adequate points into the sneak skill so stealing things fails more or less 100% of the time. So at least 6 or so quests I just flat out can't complete and I've even given up on doing it blind, looked it up and there really are no other solutions. Certain quests are bugged and won't progress for example a quest where I have to convince or force an Argonian to stop providing magical services without being a part of the mages guild and when I talk to him there is out right no way to progress as his dialogue just awkwardly stops and has no way of furthering the quest. Two quests involved me having to escort someone somewhere and they wouldn't stop following me until I finished their quests. Now the world being too large and obviously no quest marker I had no idea where to take them and they followed me around and would engage enemies in combat and one of them died to the enemies and the other I accidentally attacked during combat with another enemy (in case you can't tell the combat is VERY awkward) and then he became aggressive towards me forcing me to kill him. The worst part is that after this his quest didn't fail, or complete or disappear. It's still in my quest "journal" without anyway of getting rid of it and acts like he is still alive and following me. Honestly, there are so many other problems I could list but I'd need to talk for hours to list them all. The only thing to really consider is that this game is ultimately a waste of your time and for the amount of time you do play it, you will get nothing done. Now, I am uncertain what I am going to do going forward. Either 1. I keep playing and trudging through it and MAYBE it gets better (very unlikely to do this) or 2. I mod the shit out of it or use console commands to make myself not only move a lot faster and combat to be a joke at least to see the story and DLC (I may do this to at least get my moneys worth) or 3. I move on to Oblivion which I have played a tiny bit before and was a much better experience than this horseshit. In the end, Morrowind is a fucking crapsack of awful, blatantly disrespectful design decisions that not even a sadistic serial killer would put into a video game. I get it, it's old but when people say things like "oh, people back then were built different" and "oh, git gud, you're such a casual" I ask myself whether people "back then" seasoned their soup with stomach acids or that they made milkshakes with their own fecal matter. Did "people back then" just enjoy pain, are they all masochists? I fail to understand how standards were so different back then that rancid dogshit like Morrowind was given a pass and is still somehow seen as one of the best games ever made. Are there some good aspects to this game? No. Is it fun? No. Does it respect your time. FUCK NO. Fuck this game, 2/10. I want my money back.

[i](TL;DR - It's a good open world RPG, if you like TES games and haven't played this then get it, get it if it looks good too. Yup.)[/i]

	What to say... Well I could start by saying its possibly my favorite Elder Scrolls game. For those of you not in the know of what the Elder Scrolls series is, it's an RPG series started in March 1994 with The Elder Scrolls I: Arena.

	What you do in the  game is your choice, whether you want to be an assassin who's good with heavy armor, a straight up tank, a noble adventuring mage, etc.. The goal of the series is to make you feel immersed in another universe, play another life. Now the series started to go downhill with their spin-offs falling flat. and it wasn't looking good for Bethesda. So they put  ol' Todd Howard in the lead for the development of Morrowind. Now Toddy boy, he figured if it might be their last game they might as well go out with a bang or try to revive the series (at least that's what I think) and had the team work on Morrowind and put their all into it. Of course, this worked tremendously.

	Now enough history, lets get back into the review shall we? Hmmm... where was I? Oh yes! I remember now, favorite elder scrolls game blah blah blah no one cares. Now let me tell why this is.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]	[b]1. Quests.[/b] The game is rich with quests that could take you weeks or more to complete and lots of detail and places that can take you months to see. The amount of NPCs is astonishing (even though the dialog might not always be too interesting or unique), and all of them are individually named with the exception of the re-spawning guards or creatures, which is awesome and immersive.

[*]	[b]2. Openess.[/b] The openess is impressive even with today's standards. You can go to any part of the map, whether it's in the ocean, or some mountain, or castle, or whatever, you can go there at any point in the game (though it's easier to do with a levitate potion or spell). You can start a new character and right after you finish the quick character creation/tutorial bit you can go where ever you want! No need for the  main quest when you've got exploring to do!

[*]	[b]3. Map.[/b] The map size is huge (though not the biggest by any means, it's 16 km2 or 6.17 m2), it will take some time for you to fill your map. You could be walking for an hour thinking you've made a lot of progress, but when you look at your map you see you only discovered a small percentage of the world. Better walk a few more hours huh?

[*]	[b]4. Lore.[/b] This game has a lot of lore, from abandoned fortresses, to extinct races, to gods, to a guide about the Fishy Stick, and much more. Since this is in the TES series, if there's a part of the lore you can't find any information to, odds are there's something about it on the wikis. It's full of history, and you're also, in a sense, creating some of it by being the [spoiler]reincarnation of the Nerevarine[/spoiler]. Wanna learn some of the lore? You can either read one of the many books, talk to NPCs, go questing, stumble on it by accident, or by discovering and learning it by some other means.
[/list]
	Now I could keep going with this review praising this game but there really is no point. There are very few cons, but I'll name a couple and they won't be of much significance I can assure you.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*]	[b]1. Learning curve.[/b] Steep learning curve for new players, trust me. If you're transitioning from a game like Skyrim then you're in for a surprise. Welcome to The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind - Prepare to Die Edition! But don't worry, you'll learn sooner or later, just keep practicing and you'll get it.

[*]	[b]2. Lack of dialog.[/b] You could talk to 20 NPCs with the same things to say. This can get a little boring looking for quests or an overall interesting NPC. It's not really a big deal, it's just a minor thing. Although you can just download the LGNPCs (Less Generic NPCs) mod, though it's still in development. 
[i](The [url=http://lgnpc.org/home]LGNPC[/url] homepage.)[/i]

[*]	[b]3. View distance.[/b] The view distance is terrible. Now I know this game came out in 2002 but the game is made to put the entire view distance rendering on the CPU. Now I'm going to be honest, I'm not sure if most games from that time period do that but I doubt it. Bethesda just didn't optimize it very well. Though it does help make the map seem larger than it is, so perhaps some people like the view distance. Whatever I guess, it's realistic right? Seriously, who can see more then 50 feet ahead of themselves?
[i](Use [url=https://sourceforge.net/projects/morrgraphext/]MGE[/url] to increase view distance.)[/i]
[/list]
[h1]Final[/h1]

	Anyway, this game is amazing, and I don't know what it is about it but its more open than the newer Elder Scrolls (at least it feels that way to me). While it may be difficult to get into or just difficult, odds are it's going to be that way for a while with new players. But after some hard work, perseverance, and maybe a little help from the UESP, you will find the game becomes a bit easier and you will be rewarded for your efforts in one way or another. It's filled with lore, easter eggs, and many quests, you won't be discovering everything anytime soon.

	Also, if you'd like a more stable, cross platform experience for this game, I would highly recommend [url=https://openmw.org/]OpenMW[/url]. OpenMW is an open source engine that can be used to play Morrowind instead of the vanilla engine. It's very simple and easy to use, continually receiving support and updates, is open source, cross platform, and just overall a better experience than playing with the vanilla Morrowind game engine. It also enables an increased view distance, and if your computer is powerful enough, you could even set the view distance high enough to see the entire map. It doesn't contain any of the game files (of course), so you will need to download Morrowind. Seriously, highly recommended.

	I guess that will conclude this "short" review. And to all you new comers, have a Fishy Stick! I know you would like to keep reading this "amazing" review but I gotta go. This is me signing off, see ya!

	-Myself

With over 100 hours invested in Morrowind and the main quest still untouched, I find myself in the midst of an extraordinary adventure that defies convention. Bethesda's magnum opus, released in 2002, continues to capture my imagination with its sprawling world, intricate lore, and non-linear storytelling that have kept me enthralled from day one.

Vvardenfell, the game's setting, is a fantastical land brimming with wonder and mystery. The towering mushroom forests, ash-covered plains, and otherworldly architecture create a sense of place that feels both alien and strangely alluring. Over countless hours, I've embarked on endless expeditions, from the bustling streets of Balmora to the serene shores of Seyda Neen, unearthing hidden stories and secret corners that speak to the game's meticulous attention to detail.

What's truly remarkable is how Morrowind thrives on player agency, allowing me to shape my own destiny. While the main quest looms in the distance, I've been captivated by the wealth of side quests, guilds, and factions that beckon me in every direction. With each decision I make and each path I choose, the game evolves, ensuring that my experience is uniquely my own.

Character progression in Morrowind is a gratifying exercise in patience and strategy. The leveling system, which rewards practice and usage, has encouraged me to hone my skills organically, making each step of my character's journey a testament to my dedication. This personalized growth has imbued a strong sense of attachment to my virtual alter ego.

The lore of Morrowind is like a treasure trove waiting to be discovered. Conversations with NPCs, in-game books, and environmental details contribute to a rich tapestry of history, mythology, and politics that add depth to the experience. The main quest, while intriguing, is only a small part of the broader narrative that unfurls around me, and I revel in the opportunity to unravel its layers at my own pace.

Combat and challenges have been a source of both frustration and gratification. Morrowind's combat system is not for the faint of heart, demanding tactical thinking and perseverance. Yet, every victory, every hard-earned level-up, has brought an unparalleled sense of accomplishment, as if I'm truly growing into the role of a capable adventurer.

The fact that I've spent over 100 hours in Morrowind without completing the main quest is a testament to its grandeur and complexity. The world of Vvardenfell is an intricate web of stories, interactions, and choices that have woven together to create a deeply personal narrative. As I continue to lose myself in this immersive odyssey, I can't help but appreciate the lasting impact Morrowind has had on the RPG genre and my own gaming journey.

In conclusion, Morrowind is not just a game—it's a boundless realm of discovery and self-expression that welcomes players to explore, experiment, and immerse themselves in a world unlike any other. With over 100 hours invested and the main quest still ahead, I'm a testament to the game's capacity to captivate and inspire, offering an experience that transcends time and leaves an indelible mark on those who dare to venture into its depths.

Morrowind is the third game of The Elder Scrolls saga and in my opinion the best one.
The game is set in the Third Era and chronologically precedes the Oblivion saga. The game has been launched in 2002 but after 20 years, it does not feel the age. It perfectly represents the essence of an open world and perfectly adapts RPG mechanics to a single player experience that you can play in the way you like. This is in fact the motto of Bethesda and The Elders Scrolls. The game itself can be seen as a container (not to be mistaken for a sandbox) with quests, NPCs, guilds and factions each one interconnected with the others in a different way. To play the game and finish it you do not have any obligation to follow any predetermined path. You can simply explore the world, adventure, become stronger and finally defeat the big enemy (if you are able to understand who he/she is 😊 ) or you can follow one of the multiple questline you have available to forge your destiny.
The total freedom that Morrowind gives you can easily be seen also in the implemented class system. Your character will evolve and level up by practicing the main skills that are specific to your class but you are totally free to improve any other skill that you feel interested in. Skills improve with utilization, so if you want your character to improve in a specific area you simply have to continue using that skill.
On RPG side, Morrowind is in my opinion by far the one that better captures the essence of a pen & paper role playing game. Belonging to a generation where the quest indicator had not yet been invented, you will have to note down all the information about a place to reach it. This means that you will have to pay attention to landmarks while adventuring to find where to go. 
The concept of quest giver itself can be quite different if you are used to modern RPG. In Morrowind you have two kind of quests: the ones that can be formally obtained by a quest giver and those that you’ll discover overhearing conversations and rumors. These quests, as in traditional p&p RPGs, won’t be immediately added to your quest journal since it will be up to you to: understand if the quest is real, decide if you want to deep dive into that mystery and complete it. Once you will begin progressing in the “overheard quests” and you will have verified that the rumor you heard is real then, you will see the entry on the quest journal.  
Playing Morrowind is therefore highly recommended if you are looking for a true RPG with a lot of lore, a lot to discover and infinite possibilities.
Just a warning, if you have never played to end of nineties or first years of 2000 RPG, in order to enjoy it you have to keep in mind some things:
1)	Do as you like. Do not restrain yourself from doing anything. Just face the consequences of your actions. As in every RPG, whatever you do will modify the context and the environment but there is always a way to move on and continue. Try to avoid reloading if you inadvertently killed someone important, you will surely find another way to proceed and will be much much fun.
2)	The concept of build and gear is not applicable to this game as you would expect in a modern RPG. You do not play to grind equipment, there are no XXX run (you replace XXX with gold, farm, etc..). You equip your character according to your feelings and your playstyle.
3)	Morrowind is axed on exploration, Lore, and discovery of the environment. Sometimes the biggest reward of a quest is not the final prize but all the fragments of history that you learn doing it. 
4)	Read, read, read. Read everything, read books, and lose yourself in the lore.
5)	Take notes: Morrowind belongs to old school RPG where you were supposed to take some notes on the side to remember important facts, riddles, etc.
6)	Solving quests will not make you level by itself. You will have to use your favorite skills to progress.
Since the game has more than 20 years I recommend to play it using at least the OpenMW (you can google for it) engine. This engine is a user friendly tool that will help you to run this beautiful game on modern machines without compatibility issues.
To conclude, I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to have a taste of what could be considered one of the best RPG of all times.

Grab yourself the Morrowind Code Patch and Graphics Extender, and enjoy this classic Elder Scrolls adventure.

I always loved the way your stat progression made such a large difference. That was my favorite aspect, which wasn't quite as prevalent in future Elder Scrolls games. I always loved leaping across Belmora in two hops after getting my acrobatics maxed out.
Well, in that time, games and technology have changed quite a bit, and some functions and limitations feel clumsy. And that's why I recommend grabbing those two mods. They will make the whole experience so much smoother, and allow you to relive the nostalgia without having it ruined by out of date controls and limited graphics settings (primarily resolution and aspect ratio).

I'm a newcomer to this title, I remember it being around when I was a kid, but didn't have the time or patience to figure it out. 

Now, in 2023, playing this game for the very first time, I understand why the Elder Scrolls has the legacy it does, and why people still play this game and make memes about it 20+ years later. 

This is one of the single deepest RPGs I have ever played, with a mind blowing amount of detail (for the time). It's a little slow to get into at first, easy for new players to use weapons they didn't major and minor in, make a slow character who misses all the time etc---but honestly, new RPGs are missing this level of D&D style stat systems. I know I am in the niche minority here, but this game has been so fantastic and immersive, I fully intend to play it for hundreds of hours. Don't be afraid of the game's age. The payoff is huge.

My love for this game prompted me to BEG for an Xbox 360 so that I could buy ES4: Oblivion. I played that game non-stop during a family camping trip that occurred at the same time. It must have been truly bizarre. I credit this game for my eventual adoration of most of the games that would go on to grace the 360's lineup. Morrowind walked so that Oblivion could fly and Skyrim could soar. Btdubs, buy this DRM free if you're interested in modding. It's just easier that way.

Despite the mechanics being severely dated by modern standards, Morrowind's attention to worldbuilding, story, and the characters in it puts its sequels to shame in most respects. It's the little things like making the player question the motives of various faction members without outwardly spelling it out for you, which impacts other factions and the Nerevarine in a believable way. Some quests in Oblivion (especially the Dark Brotherhood questline) do this well too, but Morrowind's base game consistently does this across most factions. 

Another thing that I loved was just how well-written Vivec and and Dagoth-Ur were. They felt so believable, and even relatable, even in Dagoth-Ur's case. Both of them felt like genuine, multifaceted statesmen that had well-thought out intentions, plans, and motives, instead of the one-dimensional antagonists and supporting characters we usually see in the sequels. 

Unfortunately, Bloodmoon and Tribunal do not share the same level of quality that the base game's writing and world has. Bloodmoon has very uninspired dungeon designs compared to the base game, and is significantly more linear and predictable, though it isn't bad by any means. It just doesn't hold up to the passion project that was the base game. 

Tribunal, on the other hand, felt like an entirely different Bethesda game; virtually all of the quests were a slog to go though due to the painfully boring and large dungeon areas (especially the sewer systems, but also the end game area which I don't want to spoil the nature of), and the enemies being so high-level and unvaried made it even more tedious. The writing and voice acting for Tribunal was also a far cry from the quality of the rest of the game, and genuinely felt like the weaker parts of Oblivion or Skyrim. On top of all that, Tribunal feels very empty, being so large, yet having so few people in it, as opposed to the city of Vivec. This entire expansion feels so rushed, which is unfortunate given how important Mournhold is to Morrowind's story.

Despite the jankiness of Morrowind and the flaws of its expansions, the majority of it is a flawed masterpiece, and is well worth the price. If you can get past the clunkiness of the game, it is well worth the money, as it arguably the best game Bethesda has ever developed in terms of story and worldbuilding.

I have had all the add-ons since they became available nearly 2 decades ago, so I cannot speak to the base game. I immediately re-acquired them here, too. The game runs well. Periodically, it doesn't start-up correctly. Close it and re-open it. Also, do not try to optimize performance by opening the task manager. It will crash. I've not had any other issues with the game. I'm running Win 8.1. 

The game is a lot of fun and has a flexibility that other games of the era do not, and yet not having a proper class system feels like it limits it in other ways. You create a character. You are a prisoner to start with, but soon freed. You will choose your sex, race, birth-sign, and whatnot at that point. These will effect various aspects of the game. Well, your sex won't, but the rest do. 

After that, it's a free-play system. You aren't required to do one thing after the other after the other. You can even run around exploring. You will level-up when enough of your abilities have increased. At that point, you will choose to increase your attributes, such as personality, strength, intelligence, etc. There is an xn next to some of them. This means 1 point times n. If you continue raising your skills, you increase the bonus for the associated attribute, HOWEVER, the bonus applies to the upcoming level-up, not the next one. You will shorten the amount of skill increases that you need to attain the next level. 

So, for example, if you can level-up, but you continue to increase your Axe skill, when you level-up, you will have an increased strength bonus. However, you will need to increase less skills for the next level-up, thus depriving yourself of bonuses at that point.

There are a variety of cool weapons and armor to acquire. The armor rating increases with your stats. Your level is by and large irrelevant. You have a reputation, which will increase as you advance in either one of the guilds or one of the 3 Great Houses. They correspond roughly to the three classes. There is a mod available to allow you to join all 3 Houses. Your House will eventually let you build a stronghold. There are also mods available to buy houses. You will likely enjoy acquiring things and decorating your home, although decoration in Morrowind is a pain-in-the-rumproast.

Be carerful who you kill. Do not kill people or attack them, unless they attack you. Or do, then you can experience going back to prison. You are let out quickly and often must pay a fine, but I believe your reputation takes a hit. Your reputation, race, and affiliations determine the starting attitude of NPCs toward your character. 

You can focus on being a fighter, thief, or mage, but you can combine whatever abilities you find to be advantageous. If you lack too many skills from any class among your major and minor abilities, it can hinder your advancement in the corresponding guild. 

This is many hours of gaming fun. The controls take getting used to. Right click opens your inventory, or closes your inventory or open dialogs. E is jump. F is ready weapon. R is ready spell-casting. Q is constant walking. WASD are the directional movement controls. Shift is run. CTRL is sneak. Left click is attack. SPACE opens doors, chests, and initiates dialogue with NPCs, as well as closing dialogs from open chests and dialogs that contain dialogue initiated with NPCs. CAPS is constant run.

Note that the settings do not write to the .ini file in this version, so you will have to re-choose them every time you play. That was not the case with the original game. Trust me. I played it so much, the disc exploded in my drive and I had to buy a new one. Bwahahahaha!!!!

So there isn't anything I can say about this game that hasn't already been said. This game is the transition between old school dice rolls, skill checks, and systems that were put in place reminiscent of D&D. It is one of the last times in Elder Scrolls where you truly start as a nobody. Heck even when you become the "chosen one" it's because you force yourself to fit the description of the chosen one. If you choose to try Morrowind, try to enjoy it for what it is, a product of its time. Find a good guide on how to get started effectively so your time playing isn't painful. While some things are matched to your level, you can easily find places that don't care what level you are and will wreck you. Don't bother with min/maxing until you have played for a while and can enjoy it. My recommendation for the most enjoyment is go pure warrior/fighting class with the stats to match. It is the easiest to get started and probably the most fun. Magic is great in this game but takes a lot of patience (since magic doesn't regenerate over time in this game). I don't know. Just have fun and enjoy the game. It's good. (P.S. Stealth is so janky in this game its next to impossible to use without mods or cheating)

Morrowind is one of the last RPGs from an era where they were closer to modern survival games than the modern "dialogue tree with a combat system" games that are predominant now.

It's not an easy game to get into, it plays awkwardly, it doesn't explain much, and there's no shame in using the wiki (seriously, that guy who claims he relies exclusively on the quest journal and people's directions is a lying bastard). 

The strength of Morrowind lies in its freedom in character building, and deeper dialogue, the lack of voice acting may be a turn off to some, but this allows the NPCs to say much more than they can in later games where storage limitations of audio keep dialogue length down. In Morrowind, the game will rarely outright tell you "no" when you try something cheesy. The spell building system is really only limited by your cash and your Mana. You can use the potion system to leap across huge swathes of the map. You can smack enemies so hard with your sword that they fly across the battlefield. 

The main turn offs for most people in Morrowind are the slow start, and lack of unlimited fast travel. To clarify the latter, there is fast travel, but only from set hubs to other set hubs, usually for a small fee. You aren't made to walk literally everywhere, this is a misconception. Secondly, you do start slow, but as you power up, moving around becomes easier and easier, and eventually you'll be faster than you could ever been in Oblivion or Skyrim.

Morrowind is not everyone's cup of tea, but it's one of mine, and I quite enjoy it.

I bought Morrowind after seeing my friend play it. I fell in love with this game again after a years-long break. The story and variety it offers are the best parts, and the music fills me with nostalgia. Some gameplay mechanics and graphics feel outdated or complex. One of the reasons for my long break was that I felt optimization of stats and skill-ups and custom classes felt like a must to be effective. I like numbers-go-up and stats but in a story-oriented role-playing-game constantly keeping tabs on my skill-ups and training a lot of skills outside of my chosen class killed the fun for me, especially when I'm not planning to create a munchkin. I then decided to create more balanced characters such as a warrior who has a birthsign with healing spell and may use a summoning scroll or an area damage scroll if the situation is dire. This made playing the game so much more enjoyable. I'll still keep tabs on my most important skills and attributes but I don't need to count everything. This made me value the game's variety: you can optimize if that's how you like the game or you can have a more relaxed gameplay. If you try out the game for the first time, take your time, try different ways you could handle tricky situations and enjoy.

As a lifelong Oblivion lover and Skyrim hater, this game is SO GODDAMN GOOD! It's INSANE! The world building. The lore. The conflict between cultures. Low energy and low skill will net you less successful hits. Magicka not regenerating in battle is great. dice rolls on casting spells is great. It's so rewarding when you have raised your skill in a weapon or type of spell and can cast it with greater success. This game has everything. The soul. the possibilities. the mechanics. the story.
I would of course recommend playing with OpenMW engine and OpenMW-Modding graphics overhaul mod list whilst not opting for the blood mod or heads mod and instead installing upscalled vanilla heads but none of that has anything to do with all the stuff i just raved on about. This is a brilliant AMAZING game and i can see why Morrowind players thought Oblivion was goofy. Its because it is goofy(And i still love it!). There is nothing goofy about Morrowind. Its a very serious story, with serious people, that have serious stories to tell. the terrain is serious and ash storms are harsh. It's everything they tried to make Skyrim into as an apology for Oblivion but this time its a success. This game is just toooooooo good. you can wear more separate items so you can enchant more things. you can just do more stuff in the core gameplay that was absolutely dumbed down or removed in Oblivion and then even further in Skyrim. The list of things that make this game EPIC is too long. Play it and you will see how good Elder Scrolls used to be for factions, lore, mechanics, and enthralling stories. Wealth beyond measure, outlander!

In my honest opinion, I would say that Morrowind is Bethesda's peak.

While not having the same stumbling-down-the-stairs drunk clusterfuck-y feeling that The Elder Scrolls II does when you boot it up for the first time, Morrowind does [b]NOT[/b] hold your hand. 
*  No inexplicable magic arrow to point at where you need to go as if you're a skull-dented toddler who looks at a map like it's ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics. This gives the player an actual sense of freedom, as well as actually making you pay attention to the dialogue and journal entries, coupled with the fact that you won't be able to just speedrun every quest you do your first time around. 
*  There is no Teleport-Across-The-Entire-Fucking-Continent-Twelve-Times-Over button, you need to walk to the fast travel points around the map. You actually get to walk around and experience the world Morrowind has to offer you, instead of just mindlessly sprinting up to a spot to fill the color in on a black icon that you can then teleport to at any moment.
*  You actually have to play the character you build, and can't just pick up a completely foreign weapon to your character and wield it like my father wields shattered bottles on a Saturday night.

The dialogue is amazing. While there is very little voice acting, this actually does the game a favor, allowing the developers to add a plethora of dialogue to every single character in the game, save for a few generic paupers. [i]There is a lot of dialogue in this game.[/i]

While the game is great no matter how you play it (except for the Xbox version lol), it's a Bethesda game, and as such is full of bugs and best experienced modded. Morrowind Script Extender and Morrowind Code Patch make this game an even greater experience than it already is, as well as the many graphical overhauls and QoL mods that are a mere 5 clicks away for anyone with half a brain and the ability to utilize their wrist muscles and index finger simultaneously. I personally have so much graphical shit installed and active that this 21-year-old piece of software uses ~80% of my RTX 3060 the moment I step outside (worth it though).

While Morrowind is hard to pick up for those who are more used to the overly streamlined sludge we're served nowadays (trust me, I had trouble getting into it myself, having experienced Oblivion and Skyrim first), it's definitely worth playing, and is a nice change of pace from what some RPGs have become today. It gets a solid 8.5/10 from me.

After spending >200h on Oblivion and Skyrim each, I was ready for Morrowind. Although, looking back, I truly wished I had played Morrowind first... I hope Skywind releases soon. Maybe I'll have more patience and get back to it after some time, but for now I'm having a real hard time enjoying it.

I might not be the old classic player who played Morrowind, Oblivion or Skyrim back when they were released, but I consider that despite being that old, Morrowind holds up really well nowadays, or at least it doesn't age too poorly.

The main story of the game consists in stopping Dagoth Ur from conquering Morrowind. You start in Seyda Neen, liberated from an imperial prison boat. Your journey starts there.

I must say that the gameplay, despite being kind of archaic, it's not a pain. It feels weird to use the menus with right click, clunky combat and magic (or maybe I'm not used to it), but still, it's ok to play.

I can't blame graphics, since it's a 2002 game. You know, PS2 and Xbox's era. I say the enviroment is well done, but the characters models are just goofy.

But if something in this game is just timeless is the soundtrack. Voice acting and sound effects are meh, but the music is just wonderful and magestic. You know, Skyrim's music is epic, Oblivion's music is cool, but Morrowind's music is a blessing to our ears. 

The thing that annoys me the most is the price. Despite being a good game, Morrowind doesn't worth 15€ nowadays in my opinion. Yeah, it gives you many hours of gameplay, but come on, Bethesda... It was released in 2002, and if it was remastered or remade I would understand that price...

The story is some of the richest story to ever be developed in a video game, and they do not hold your hand. Tired of follow the map marker simulator? This game losely gives you directions once that are probably wrong, then never clarify. Get ready to become submerged in the best game ever, one warning though, once you play this game and start to get to level 15+ you will peak in gaming. The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is an immersive movement simulator deeply inspired by RPG name generators.

It's different everytime, sometimes you jump as a service, sometimes you run as to get away, sometimes you jump to sell, sometimes you sprint to find. Find what? Everything. Find Vivec, find a special specific person in Vivec, find the exit, find an item, find some dust. Move faster with that special sweet dust. Find out about more special things to find. Where?.. 
I'm not here to answer your every question!

The best feature, by far, is paying for transport and the worst feature, by far, is walking. 
The totally undigestible amount of content is a classic trademark, of the main Elder Scrolls Trilogy; Names, Books, Towns, Directions, Books.

You want to read some books? Yeah well, maybe at least some NPC's do.

Every bandit has a name. Ferlod Woris, with his buddies Mathos Luber and Therasa Suck are here to ruin your day. Deal with them your own way, you can even calm them down, if you want, they are probably very important so don't kill them. 

A good rule of thumb, and also a feature,  is that if you heard someone mention something specific, or sometimes, totally general, you will be able to ask anyone at any point of the game about it, and get the same NPC response. Why? 
Well what if the player wants to hear about "Dunmer" on the go? What if there is no one left? As long as there is one person still alive in the slums of Balmora, you will be able to hear about "Dunmer" at least one more time.  So knock yourself out!.. Ask the Arch-Mage about "Cave rat". Travel to the edge of civilisation and ask about "citizens of the Empire".  What about "Jobasha's Rare Books", that's a popular one in Vivec.

You are the perfect errand boy, an upstanding member of society where no one ever leaves their house. Except (most definitely not luckily) you! 
Use your house leaving abilities to gain power. Use your skills as well. Use some herbs to breathe in the canal water. 
But don't breathe in too much, you will hyperventilate. Speaking of hyperventilating, what about hyper jumping? You want to jump? Oh, they'll give you it. They will take away the game, and leave nothing except jumping in Vivec, you should go there and jump there yourself. Jump the short way, or take the scenic plunge, enjoy the comments as you spring by.  I will have you know I jumped for 2 and a half hours straight. I'm still at 70% of my Acrobatics potential. My legs are motionless as I bounce. The remaining 30% of Acrobatics is just more content, and by that definition, I still have a monumental amount of Athletics to get through. I can jump so high my spacebar is pressed only once a  second. There is a permanent tilted angle to my spacebar, that's how you know I went full morrowind. 

I totally disagree with the fact that jumping should be 100% successful every time, what are you doing Bethesda? You had it right with the weapons. You know? Miss me with that chance to hit! On the contrary, let ME use a wide selection of spells through my monotonously trained perspective. As I naturally come to the conclusion, that if you are playing the role of a knight, you are playing the game the *challenged* way.

I spent 20 minutes trying to think of what to say about this game that I've played since it came out when I was a kid. It's probably not possible to really capture what this game was to me as a kid. This truly alien landscape with an entire history to learn, characters that seemed (at the time, to a kid) almost alive. It's probably even less possible for me to give this game an honest review. Instead I will only say that it deserves to be considered one of the greatest RPGs of all time for it's world building, the attention to detail, the phenomenal story, and almost everything else. Yes it's infuriating when my club misses the giant rat in front of me 6 times in a row, and while not as bad as modern Bethesda games, it is buggy as hell unmodded. No game is perfect but, for all its flaws, this is one of the best games I've ever played. I've played it for 21 years across 2 consoles and the PC and thousands of hours, and I don't see myself putting it down any time soon. 

PS: Absolutely nothing but love to the modding community that has kept this game so fresh and incredible after 21 years.

One of the Fan Favorites in The Elder Scrolls where you enter the Land of Elves complete with Construction Set & its 2 Expansions, Bloodmoon & Tribunal as it had years of building up after Arena, Daggerfall, Battlespire & Redguard.
It was originally slated for a 1998 Release but was delayed to be polished up until its Release in 2002.

Throughout the game's introduction, you get to create your character in the game world itself. In Morrowind, you play as an Ex-Convict who is about to be released from incarceration but first you have to create a character and choose a class then deliver a package to a Neighboring Nation as part of your character's Release Forms when creating the character & then the game is open to you where you are free to proceed whatever you see fit to do so such as the Main Story, Side Quests or Go Adventuring on your own.

Like Final Fantasy 2 (The REAL Final Fantasy 2, NOT Final Fantasy 4) & Secret of Mana, your Skills will increase as you use them so that you can Jump Higher & Run Faster, just to name a few.

You can enter a world of Fantasy and live the life of an adventurer in anyway you want, such as joining a Guild, Adventuring Freestyle, live as a Hermit, a Magician Lord, a Knight and more as the possibilities are limitless. You can also purchase a House, Boat and more. Morrowind & Open Morrowind has been and will always be one of Bethesda's Greatest Hits as they Rose from the Ashes & to Towering Success.

Before I hear people say the classic "Morrowind/Oblivion/Skyrim is better" debate here, my first Elder Scrolls game was Oblivion. Now stating that, I have beaten Oblivion and Skyrim to completion before playing Morrowind so there is no nostalgia harking back to when this game was released for this reviewer.

With that being said, Morrowind is the best gem Bethesda has ever and will make to date. A game that you can get lost in, figuratively and in a general sense as well. When I start a new character I build a history around the race and gender of the character I am making. If that's an Orc Zerker that lost his home to the empire after being a prisoner for over fifty years or a High-Elf lesser-noble came to Morrowind to prove themselves and earn enough gold to come back as the wealthiest and most powerful house in the Imperial City next to the Emperor himself. 

A solid game worth playing today, recommended on every platform from someone that enjoys a great story, an alien and beautiful world, the play styles with melee and magic are fantastic and you have to earn how you swing that weapon or cast that healing spell that will save your life through practice or make sure you have the stamana to lift your arm to hit something and cast that spell needed (or learn to use the console commands). Highly detailed and has a high replay value for such an old game. 

Below I will talk about modding and my opinion of Todd Howard's ethics of making video games, read more if you dare or care too, if you aren't willing to read below that is fine, this is the end of the review.

(( RECOMMENDED ))

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-



 There are plenty of mods on Nexus that I have used over the years for graphical settings and a bigger world to be immersed in. I enjoyed my time with Tamriel Rebuilt and Morrowind Rebirth. Before moving forward about Todd, I wish to add something about the community that make these mods, back in the day some companies were okay with fans of there games to make mods while most sued their fans for copyright abuse. 

Bethesda didn't and was praised for this by their fans at the time. Which overall if we look at the gaming industry, that was a smart move. Though I don't like how today's Bethesda relies on them to fix their games even if they are doing it out of the love for the video game. Bethesda needs to learn to fix there games the time when they release them. But overall about modding, I have given money to some of these hard working people that make these mods and if you use them yourself for long periods of time, I would ask you to do the same. There are guides out there how to install mods. I wish you luck on installing them.

Now for the real reason I asked others that just wanted to see a review to not look at this is Todd Howard's opinion on game development. Which is that video games should allow everyone at anytime, be able to pick up and play any Bethesda game and have a fun time with it. I agree with this outlook on video games in general, what I don't agree is that every Elder Scrolls game after Morrowind doesn't feel like I'm in a RPG that gives a flying fuck about its world building. For example, interacting with NPCs that know anything useful, I enjoy to learn about the world from these NPCs, how they live, by what they wear I know if this is a noble, peasent, warrior/threat and so on. 

I enjoy the plot that they provide in Morrowind. Though when you take out these important events, characters and conversations that Oblivion as well as Skyrim does, the player character SHOULD be there or the very least a huge part of it. Its ether we just missed the conversation to an important event, missed the event entirely or just got there in the nick of time to hear a one liner or two. Let alone having NPCs ask questions on how you built a specific character and have conversations that can lead you into world shaking quests that have nothing to do with the main quest but can affect them in huge ways that are meaningful TO YOU and your playstyle! 

I have played what was the best in my eyes to what Bethesda has provided us, I don't think they will ever change their outlook to have a rich RPG-based world again that isn't reliant on GURPS. When I think Elder Scrolls, I shouldn't think "Its for the casual gamer" though, this is an opinion from someone that enjoys ADnD as well. I hope this review gave some outlook for you and I welcome you to comment. Thanks for reading, have a swell day.

genuinely so much more rewarding than the future games.  It takes some time to get used to, since your character actually has very limited capabilities early, that are entirely dependent on race and class.

Usually by level like 5 you'll have the game figured out and by 10 you'll be a walking god.

If you finish a faction quest line, you actually feel like a legendary powerful figure who has earned respect.
I will never forget the Telvanni quest line, by the end you are so magically powerful it's unreal you actually feel that you deserve to be the head of the faction. Unlike any of the future games, where you can be head of the mages guild before level 3.

Can't wait to make a new character, and do the appropriate factions.

This game remains my all-time favourite in the Elder Scrolls series, and given the current direction Bethesda is taking with the franchise, I highly doubt that sentiment will ever change.

What truly amazes me is the enduring passion of the modding community, which continues to breathe new life into the game even after two decades. With countless mods expanding the world and introducing fresh content, you'll never run out of things to discover, even if you think you've seen it all.

Admittedly, the graphics do show their age, given that the game is two decades old. However, if you're willing to overlook this aspect, it becomes an absolute must-have for any RPG enthusiast. The depth of gameplay, immersive world-building, and captivating storytelling make it an unforgettable experience that transcends the limitations of dated visuals.

Morrowind... is probably one of, if not THE best game I've played

+ Environment + 
"Alien, Unique, Weird"
Yea it is those things but it's also extremely well built and structured in a way where it feels lived-in and has genuine history and atmosphere, Vvardenfell to me is probably the best in-game world to truly get into and explore.

9/10
 
+ Story + 
Definitely lacking in some places, especially in the Imperial side of things, but other than that it's a great experience that doesn't feel over-the-top or feels like its going too far in places. It feels like you're an actual regular-ish person in the world trying to live a life and get by in any ways that you can.

8.5/10

+ Gameplay + 

Clunky, Slow, but otherwise very manageable.
This is definitely one of the places that you need to struggle with the most at first but also the one that yields some of the biggest rewards. Breaking the game in good and bad ways is very much possible, whether by accident or on purpose and there are ways to fix the issues in 3rd party programs.

8.5/10

+ Graphics +

Definitely aged a lot, but they still hold up really well at parts. Character and creature models are very well done and the weapons + armour look great. The various and well built designs of Vvardenfell's architecture are just as wonderfully bizarre as the flora and fauna

8/10

+ Overall +

Morrowind is a genuinely really great game that almost anyone can get immersed and sink hundreds of hours into. Probably the last great game Bethesda made before being watered down into generic fantasy action games with a pathetic fraction of the role-playing elements that this one has.

Very much recommended.

The base game in not very stable, but like with any Bethesda game, you can use mods to fix this!
In 2023 you can use OpenMW, which is just a f new game engine written from scratch, much, much more stable than what Bethesda did. It seems uncrashable. Mind. Blowing. And very easy to install.

Some tips/other stuff:
- if you find the game too hard, you clearly don't know how the game work yet, it's one of the easiest Elder Scrolls
    -> try to start any fight with a full fatigue bar. Fatigue impacts everything, even trading prices
    -> set at least one weapon skill as primary skill, and only use a weapon for it at the start, otherwise you won't hit anything
    -> you can get your attributes damaged permanently, until you restore them with potions/shrines/scrolls/spells (they'll appear in red)
    -> NPCs are not leveled, you might encounter something too powerful too soon, just come back later
- if you find the game too easy, try Morrowind Hardcore Mode. It's just excellent, reminds me of Requiem for Skyrim. This mod just made me love fighting in Morrowind, quite a feat.
- if you don't like a tedious aspect of the game use a mod
    -> don't like having to overoptimise your character levelling? Install madd leveler
    -> don't like having to rest to regain magicka? Install a magicka regain mod
    -> etc.

For anyone who's coming to this game after playing newer Elder Scrolls / other RPGs, it's a very daunting game with some of its archaic mechanics and controls, but if you like RPGs, you should absolutely try this. As I said the old mechanics can be a bit confusing or hard to get used to, but if you stick through it, it'll become very comfortable and easy. If you really can't get it, there are a plethora of mods to modernize it. The lack of quest markers and fast travel makes the game extremely fun to explore and really gives you a sense of accomplishment when you complete a quest or find a hidden location. While it hasn't aged too amazing, it is still an amazing game that I would recommend to anybody who likes RPGs.

What is Morrowind ?

This was my first contact with the Elder Scrolls series, I first played mororwind on my old pc like two decades ago and then went to play Skyrim and Oblivion in this exact order as I had to skip oblivion because my pc wasn't powerful enough and when Skyrim was out which was when I got a finally good pc I had my eyes already on it, but lets talk about Morrowind and my adventures on it.

Something I always disliked on morrowind was the combat, as a melee character It simply sucked having to hit and get no feedback because a specific skill wasnt leveled enougn and in order to level it you had to just keep swinging at something until it levels up, it doesnt make it any better, its a product of its time but playing as a melee character unmodded is true suffering, so when I played it the first time and then my return to it years late here on steam, I went with a mage build and there you dont actually need to keep hitting targets, its actually more immersive and fun to go to my dorm on a mages guild and train my skills there with the door closed, while everyone is minding their business on the guild I kept myself there training, conjuring stuff and more until I finally hit a high level and then I went to finally complete quests, every enemy being down in 2-3 spell shots, I felt strong and my efforts weren't wasted, with a mage build this system really shines and puts you in a immersive state that modern games don't have, a lot of stuff may feel dated, the controls, sluggish movement, ui and inventory systems but those you can get over with, the shitty combat system is the one you may not easily get over with unless like I said above you go as a mage.

Talking about story, its surely a good one, altho I think people overstimates how good it is, while its definitely better than the more modern rpgs we got in the last decade its not as good as people say it is, it does have some memorable characters but I guess being an older game the way quests are structure and a lack of set pieces doesnt make it something great to replay, what morrowind truly has going on for it is the worldbuilding, the locations are very creative and doesnt feel like just another generic medieval setting, exploration can be tricky tho especially at early game due to how sluggish the movement feels but as soon as you get immersed in this beautiful world, you will start to endure the game's flaws and learn to appreciate it. Also the soundtrack is very good, like in every other elder scrolls game.

While I never played the dlcs, I usually start getting tired near the end of the game, even this replay that I've done after years since my first playthrough, It was getting really draining at the end of the game and after finishing the main story and some guilds I had to put the game down, I may play both dlcs some day but I had enough with the main game, morrowind for hardcore rpg fans that have patience to older, dated gameplay may feel some fun and immersion here even today, but know what youre getting into, even with mods, its a dated, flawed experience, one that you need to get into a right type of mindset to appreciate, its a very good game that deserves a recommendation, its just not for everyone to play for the first time or replay today.

Solid game that gets passed over for being a certified jank fest. When you get immersed into the game, the controls and the graphics melt away and you're just an adventurer making their way in a hostile alien world.

Besides bugs, unfinished contents, and general quirkyness, this game is huge and was the first game I played in the Elder Scrolls series.

I have played old school games and even for old school games this game is dated. The combat is boring although not as bad as some put it. Your enjoyment of the game is inherently tied to your character creation at the start. This is as most of your major and minor skills are predefined and levelling up skills is a tedious process and I doubt you want to "practice" skills by spamming the same buttons over and over game like a mindless ape. In general if you do buy the game, just research what skills are broken,more easily exploitable or beneficial for whatever character archetype you want to play before hand so your experience in the early and mid game is more enjoyable. Furthermore, the first 2-3 hours of the game is incredibly boring as you walk around aimlessly exploring lifeless cities with like 20-30 npcs who all stand in the same spot. This makes resetting and starting from scratch unappealing. Guild and side quest are also poorly designed as for the most part they are all mostly just fetch quest of some sort. The map is basically a barren wasteland and if you are playing unmodded like I did even on the furthest Field of Vision you can barely see 50 metres in front of you.

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a classic role-playing game and it still holds up remarkably well even today.The game provides gamers with a very immersive world, complete with a great story and lots of exploration.The graphics may have aged but the world-building and the great characters still manage to draw in players.The combat system is still quite challenging and definitely stands the test of time.The music and sound effects are quite iconic and help to tell an epic story.The variety of armors, weapons and spells will keep you entertained for hours.Above all else, the game has tremendous replayability, thanks to its intricate mechanics and its large world to explore.All in all, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is an incredible game that still feels enjoyable even 21 years later.

This game, especially for a TES entry, has it all. 

Roleplayability: Check
Creativity: Check
In-depth Lore: Check
Worldbuilding: Check, Check, Check

All around, the most solid TES game, IMO. Oblivion is a slightly un-creative downgrade. Skyrim, on the other hand, needn't be mentioned due to it not holding up to either games. Other than superficially of course, whether that be graphics, gameplay, and so on. Or, in other words, everything that you'd expect from a modern-ish game. The downsides of Morrowind would be that: gameplay, graphics, etc. Otherwise, the quests, dungeons and roleplay potential are superb. 

Overall: 8/10

Brilliant game, would recommend to any RPG fan. 
I'll add that im a returning player, and know a lot of the "tricks" to make things easier (boots of blinding speed, enchanting constant strenght on items, a strong levitate spell), so playing through the main game was a LOT faster than its designed to be - That said, I still got almost 70 hours out of the main quest and factions, which is great value for money.
I was excited to play Tribunal, as I had never played the Morrowind Expansions, however Tribunal was very disappointing, and took about 90 mins to complete, including the optional quests. Glad I never paid for Tribunal seperately! 
That said, Bloodmoon is much more fun, and whilst I havent completed that expansion yet, so far it has been great and Im really looking forward to doing the rest of the quests and exploring the island.

My only real criticism (and this is my fault) is that the enemies are all trivial by this point, if you have gained power through your normal playthrough. I turned the difficulty up to max and still 2 hit most enemies in Bloodmoon, but I am level 56 with maxxed out Attributes (and 410 strength from constant effect enchants) so that's on me really - I'm sure if i started the expansions at a lower level it would be a lot more challenging, or indeed if I only had the normal 100 strength max, mobs may take a few more swipes to kill.

Overall, I would give Morrowind and the expansions 9/10 - It would be 9.5 if you removed Tribunal from the game entirely.

This game is only good if you're tripping on that nostalgia, trying to knock it off of the "must play" gamer hype, trying to fit in with everyone else who played it or says they played it but did not, enjoy minmaxing/metagaming your skills into oblivion (hah!), or like the Elder Scrolls lore. Beyond that, especially if you want to be immersed in the world, then I do not recommend you dig into it if you can't find the charm a few hours in. It's mostly empty filler material around a thin skeleton of relevant and interactable content. There isn't much to do outside the main questline and you will keep running into lifeless NPCs and towns that don't offer you anything to do and when they do you'll get a boring errand quest to fetch this item or deliver that note.

While an interesting alien world, it's mostly empty barren land with enemy creatures placed in expected locations with little variation. The towns vary slightly in that there are remote fishing villages, towns made out of giant mushrooms, out of giant crab creatures in a remote mountain, and so on but you will not feel any sense of character, uniqueness or depth to any of them because there isn't much to do outside of fetch/deliver sidequests and the main questline. They all feel bland and devoid of life. I'm someone who enjoys early 2000s graphics when they're done right and fleshed out, but this is not it.

The NPCs are also very lackluster and almost all of them respond to the same irrelevant prompts with the same exact responses. You have the option to ask them about something or someone in an unrelated and far-off town, but they'll respond with the exact same text as someone from that far-off town. This was especially surprising given that there's almost no voice acting which means that they could have added unique dialogues and provide new information ad nauseum. They didn't, so it's just the same filler content in each town.

The dungeons have the infamous early 2000s design relying on platforming and navigating the "difficult" thin land bridges all the while creating confusing layouts reminiscent of Daggerfall's atrocious dungeon designs.

The infamous guilds of the series are glorified fetch/delivery quest hubs. There's barely any substance or story going on except for the bits and pieces indicating there's some inter-guild drama going down. 

The melee combat system is atrocious. This is well known so I won't go too much into it, but fatigue is needed for combat and for running. In this game where fast travel at any time does not exist, you have to run everywhere which means when you encounter the inevitable randomly placed enemy, you won't have the fatigue necessary to fight it. So it becomes a slog of whiffs and misses.

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind  is without a doubt one of the best rpgs ever made and one of the best games ever made  IMO. This came out in 2002, so it is a little bit dated in some aspects. The graphics look a little rough and the combat is going to feel rather clunky until you understand how it works with primary stats and skill points. There are also no quest markers, and navigation is done by NPC instructions. This game does not hold your hand and makes you figure out most of the game mechanics for yourself, and once you do; an immersive, deep, lore rich world awaits for you. I heavily recommend giving this a try when it’s on sale, just for the atmosphere and story alone.

Welcome to Morrowind! The swamps are swampy, the grasslands are grassy, and the mountains? The mountains are well... ashy... Morrowind is an RPG that shows its age, poorly. The game was and is great, some would say damn near perfect. Perfect, even down to the most minute detail. Its combat is extremely dated and clunky, game-play uncaring of your feelings, Compass (what's that?), and the bugs the glorious glorious bugs. Even still, Morrowind sets itself apart by offering almost truly limitless choices, for example:

want to kill entire towns? Go for it!
Want boots that make you levitate? Make them!
Want to clear out a dungeon and make it your home? Absolutley, if you've got the skill!
Want to smuggle moon sugar in a cats stomach? You bet!
Want to kill a major character and ruin the main quest? damn right you do.

It's things like this that modern games seem to avoid for the sake of fun. In actuality removing them does the opposite. RPG's especially single player are meant to take you, the player, on a fantastic journey. A journey with interesting characters, perilous destinations, and the choice to do and play what you want how you want. Morrowind offers those things in spades, and its the reason it lives on in the hearts of players everywhere.

Morrowind provides a massive, interesting, and addictive open world to explore littered with possibly hundreds of shrines, tombs, towns, villages, and farms etc to discover with the best loot hidden in the most out of place locations.
With interesting and unique gameplay mechanics like command humanoid, levitate, and athletics and tons of skills to improve and play around with there is plenty to do and ways to play.
In addition to the main story and side quests from the base game, there are two full size DLCs to explore as well as years of mod content that improve both the visuals and add a variety of gameplay content and UI improvements.

This is one of the the best open world RPG experiences available even now in 2023.

My only complaint that comes to mind is The companion system is lacking in this game, as there are no opportunities I have found to get a companion in this game besides hiring someone in one of the DLCs or buying a slave that can't be equipped with gear as far as I know,

[h1]Playing this game unmodded showcases quite a few... surprises[/h1]
Let me be clear, I do not recommend against playing Morrowind, I simply want to say that you should not jump in expecting a clean experience if you're playing unmodded in 2023. The running speed is one example I have in mind, but there are many other aspects to this game that you can just feel are 20+ years old.

If you want a true, down-to-earth RPG experience where you're not the Dovahkiin/Superman/The One, and you can get over its decade-old, sometimes pointless, "gameplay mechanics", then this game is for you. I could maybe try this again with Skywind or mods, but for now this will stay a thumbs down.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I've started this game a few times over the years, but I never had the patience to stick with it for the whole main quest until now. I used the source port OpenMW (https://openmw.org) to play it, which is why Steam hasn't tracked my hours since I started a few months ago.

Anyways, this game is definitely still worth playing even as it's turned 21 years old this year. What really makes it work is that you're dropped into a very strange, alienating fantasy setting unlike any other, and you just have to figure things out about Dunmer society and culture for yourself while navigating the world, interacting with NPCs, doing quests, etc. You're essentially playing anthropologist, detective, and archaeologist just to make it in Vvardenfell. This uniquely intriguing setting which sparks the imagination and begs to be explored, combined with the lack of more modern convenience features such as quest markers (you navigate via following directions that NPCs give you) and instant fast travel (fast travel still exists, but through diegetic means such as Silt Striders, boats, Mages Guild teleporters, recall and intervention spells) really serves to immerse the player in the world presented here, even despite the dated technology. That's not even getting into the more RPG nerd stuff like character builds, player choices, and such, but there's definitely plenty of that here too, especially compared to Oblivion and Skyrim. You do have to pay attention to your build, since you need points in a skill to be effective with something, such as actually being able to hit your targets in combat. 

It's by no means perfect though. I found guild questlines to be quite underwhelming compared to the later Elder Scrolls games. There are too many goddamn cliffracers. I understand why the dice roll mechanics for combat exist, but it still can be frustrating at times. Also like every Bethesda game there's plenty of broken jank. Honestly this game's jank actually kind of adds to the fun, since you can abuse stacking potions indefinitely and certain spells to literally fly around the map at extremely high speeds while casting Kamehamehas from an effectively infinite magicka pool. At least, I was doing that by the end of my vanilla playthrough. It's not balanced by any means but it's fun that you're able to treat this game like a Super Saiyan simulator if you really know what you're doing.

I do recommend to play Morrowind if you're into RPGs, are a TES fan who hasn't gotten around to it yet, or just want to explore a fantasy world that isn't another derivative of medieval Europe. This game pioneered a lot of the open-ended, free form exploration that more recent games like Elden Ring and Breath of the Wild have been praised for. It's so easy to lose hours and hours at a time lost in such a mysterious, yet believable world.
