Damn, Morrowind is such a good game. It reminds me of playing old PS1 and PS2 games graphic wise and I love it. I also love how much better the story and immersion is. No quest markers might be confusing at first but then you talk to the people in towns and get more info and find your way around. The no quest marker thing also makes you want to explore things on your own more. I miss this so much from modern RPGs which just send you to a specific place and then you can fast travel back and get it done. 
I love how cool and unique each city is compared to Skyrim. 
I love how essential NPCs are killable but the game tells you that you created a doomed world. 
There's so much freedom. 
It's so sad that Skyrim abandoned the whole class, birthsign and attribute system. I know the start in Morrowind might be a bit hard coming from Skyrim but it actually makes for a unique RPG experience considering  the TES series was inspired by tabletop games like DnD. 
The only TES game I lightly modded with only the code patch (recommended to avoid some bugs) and the graphics extender.
I'd advise for the start to lower difficulty and read up some guides. 
If you're an Elder Scrolls fan coming from Skyrim like me and you also love old RPGs then I heartly recommend this game.
Just a great game. Definitely has a large learning curve, but it will be one of the most fulfilling games you'll play if you give it a chance.

Morrowind is possibly the best example I can think of for a game which simultaneously has so many cool elements and so many awful design decisions that it averages out to being passable overall. It took me many attempts to really get into it and im glad that I did, the game's strong areas are very rewarding. Morrowind is easily the most comprehensive RPG in the series. There is a large assortment of skills available, and many exclusive factions to join (or oppose). The world is super cool, the landscapes and architecture are very unique and interesting, and the regional lore is all superb, all combining to make the main quest probably the single best in the Elder Scrolls, among other things. 

However, the game is just as weak gameplay-wise as it is strong in the RP department. It tries to blend old school tabletop dice roll mechanics with real time control in a fully rendered 3D world which itself is fairly clunky, and the result is something highly frustrating (if not completely broken) in many areas. Your characters wont be able to hit anything in melee 9/10 swings until youve powerleveled to get your weapon skills and agility close to max, which entails hours and hours of grinding gold for training before you get to actually play the game; then even when melee combat does become at least usable its so clunky that its never fun. Stealth is basically completely unusable because the dice rolls break sneaking entirely, on top of not having poisons and other tools from the later games. Magic is the one archetype that is enjoyable at all, and there are no limits on it which means that magic based characters can end up being ridiculously overpowered, the complete opposite of the other two. Movement even with max speed is irritatingly slow for whatever reason, and the ability to jump might as well not even exist without using magic enhancements. Etc. Overall Morrowind's overly restrictive systems severely limit what kinds of characters you can even play despite the large assortment of skills and birthsigns and stuff, assuming you want to actually enjoy it, and the game feels like it's much more fun in theory than in practice at the end of the day. Morrowind is also one of the few games I feel needs a mod to be worth it; the default draw distance is absolutely awful and takes everything that's cool about the world away by only letting you see like 30 ft ahead of you, so the Morrowind graphics extender mod to push back the fog is a must imo.

TLDR, Morrowind is a game with some really amazing concepts that fails pretty badly at execution in a lot of places. I do recommend playing through at least once, but dont be afraid to look up guides to help build a character that will actually be fun to play and get them off to a good start so that you can sink more time into what you want to do. It can be a slog, but there are some things about the game that deserve to be appreciated and can be highly rewarding.

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind stands as a quintessential masterpiece of the RPG genre, renowned for its immersive and atmospheric world-building, deep and rewarding gameplay mechanics, and captivating storytelling.

At the heart of Morrowind lies its unparalleled ability to transport players to a fully-realized and meticulously crafted world. From the bustling city of Vivec to the treacherous Ashlands, every corner of the game world exudes a distinct sense of place and history, inviting players to delve deep into the game's rich lore and engage with the game's myriad inhabitants.

In terms of gameplay, Morrowind boasts an impressive depth of character customization options that allows players to truly tailor their experience to their liking. The combat system is both challenging and satisfying, rewarding players for mastering the game's intricacies. And with countless quests and side activities to engage in, players are sure to find themselves engrossed in the game's world for hours on end.

What truly sets Morrowind apart, however, is its unparalleled storytelling. The game is brimming with fascinating characters, intricate plotlines, and unexpected twists and turns, weaving a narrative tapestry that rivals even the most celebrated works of fantasy fiction. The main questline is an epic journey that takes players on a quest to uncover a long-lost prophecy and the fate of the world itself, while the game's side quests offer countless opportunities for moral ambiguity and difficult choices.

In short, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is an unequivocal masterpiece that deserves its place among the greatest games ever made. Whether you are a devoted fan of the RPG genre or simply in search of a truly immersive gaming experience, Morrowind is a game that simply cannot be missed.
Old school very well done classic fantasy RPG. Get some.

When I first reviewed this game, I had made it a negative review. I now realize that I didn't fully understand what Morrowind really was and how you're actually supposed to play it. Now, the game is old, and clunky at first. And maybe the graphics are a bit dated, but I highly implore that you keep the modding to a minimum to get the best experience. I only have some bug fix mods and a mod that improves the graphics but still keeps the vanilla "feel" of the game.

I know the combat is really bad and your character will most likely move really slow in your first playthrough. Eventually I just gave up in frustration and left a negative review warning other players not to play this game. I was wrong. I watched a couple Youtube videos on how to create an actually good character and how to enjoy the game. Then I read the manual that comes with the game. There is a ton of helpful information in there. Basically if you want to have fun in the game you have to be patient. You have to be willing to do some reading. A lot of reading. You're going to have to actually use your brain when you play this game.

And that's what makes this game unique to the newer Elder Scrolls titles. There's no hand-holding at all. You have to figure it out for yourself. But trust me. It's worth it. Once I figured out what I'm supposed to be doing, the game got a whole lot more fun. 

So I was playing it all wrong when I first got the game. I rushed into it without really learning anything and didn't have a good experience with the game. That's not how you should play Morrowind. Take your time. There's no rush. There's no pressure. Play the game at your own pace. Then you will really begin to appreciate the game for what it is. That's how you really play Morrowind.

I remember my younger sibling picked this up when it was new. We had a blast just goofing off, although I don't remember actually playing it seriously at all. It's high time I tried, and well, I can't say I regret it.
Keep in mind, I circled back to this game after having played through Skyrim. The game shows its age (which one? Yes. The answer is Yes.) but I find that at its heart, it's not bad. Just come ready to read and take a BOATLOAD OF NOTES and you'll be fine.

Well, let's kick this off with the pros:
+ More control over your character build, compared to Skyrim. You have stats instead of Health/Magicka/Stamina. It feels more in-tune with what I expect and enjoy in TTRPGs.
+ You level up by doing things. Practice makes perfect, as the old saying goes. It's a neat notion. Level up 10 skills to gain a character level and assign stats, and the key stats for those skills will get bonuses if you assign points to them on leveling up.
+ The scenery is cool. I mean, it's a little bit like "Fantasy Florida/Louisiana" in spots, but the somewhat unusual sensibilities in the architecture and the giant mushrooms get a smile out of me.
+ The soundtrack. "The Road Most Travelled" is a classic track for a reason.

Alrighty, now the cons:
- Unfortunately, you have to level up by doing things. Killing monsters and fighting your enemies will ultimately only net you XP for the weapons you use, the spells you cast, the armour you wear when you take hits, and if you use a shield then maybe you'll get XP for blocking, if you succeed in blocking any blows.
- Leveling up your skills is somewhat slow, particularly to start.
- Good gravy, that's a LOT of reading.
- Like holy cow, SO MUCH READING.
- Some of the age shows. Things are a bit clunky, key mapping is a bit bothersome, and of course the right mouse button isn't bound to any secondary functions. It opens your inventory. There's no compass/objective radar on your HUD, which makes navigation a bit tricky.
- Ew, weapon and armour durability. Wish I had more insight, but unfortunately while this was a nifty idea on paper -- particularly back in 2002 -- it mostly just makes the idea of running around starkers and unarmed a lot more appealing.

Dopamine (DA, a contraction of 3,4-dihydroxyphenethylamine) is a neuromodulatory molecule that plays several important roles in cells. It is an organic chemical of the catecholamine and phenethylamine families. Dopamine constitutes about 80% of the catecholamine content in the brain. It is an amine synthesized by removing a carboxyl group from a molecule of its precursor chemical, L-DOPA, which is synthesized in the brain and kidneys. Dopamine is also synthesized in plants and most animals. In the brain, dopamine functions as a neurotransmitter—a chemical released by neurons (nerve cells) to send signals to other nerve cells. Neurotransmitters are synthesized in specific regions of the brain, but affect many regions systemically. The brain includes several distinct dopamine pathways, one of which plays a major role in the motivational component of reward-motivated behavior. The anticipation of most types of rewards increases the level of dopamine in the brain,[4] and many addictive drugs increase dopamine release or block its reuptake into neurons following release.[5] Other brain dopamine pathways are involved in motor control and in controlling the release of various hormones. These pathways and cell groups form a dopamine system which is neuromodulatory.[5]

TES III is (at least from my perspective) the one true RPG which can call itself "sandbox". As many others already said, you are free to do almost anything you like and if you just use one offensive skill plus alchemy obsessively enough you will become more godlike in the late game than the Tribunal and Dagoth Ur combined. This game offers an incredible amount of possibilities of how to build and play your character and the balancing of especially the alchemy skill lets you acquire ridiculously powerful potions in mid- and late-game. And did I already mention the magic system? You can craft your own spells and enchantments as you wish, with a shipload of effects which you are free to combine as you like (You want a spell which deals 100 damage to yourself and kills you instantly? No problem!).

But wait, there's more: Even apart from the incredibly diverse game mechanics the game offers a sh*tload of lore. There are a couple of dozen books in the game with up to ~50 pages which provide detailed background information about the world you are playing in and its lore.

In the early game, there is one thing you need though: patience. Morrowind has no fast travel, you are dependent on public transport like boats, silt-striders and the teleport service provided by the mage's guild. Additionally, there are NO quest markers, you actually need to listen to directions given by quest givers and such. In my personal opinion, this is one of the strengths of this game but it can get annoying at times (especially when I looted another ruin and became over-encumbered again) - in any case it makes this game one of the most immersive RPG experiences you are about to encounter!

Last point: it does have quite dated graphics, but that's actually not a problem because of the load of mods accessible via Nexusmods for example. All in all, the immersion, lore and sometimes even funny game mechanics make this game worth a try at least! Buy it outlander, you won't regret it.

This game is broken. Let me explain how you can make the most op character in the entire game

First of all, get a Telvanni cephalopod mask, which has the most enchanting points in the whole game, and only sells for 50 gold in Khuul, and whatever clothing armour and robes you can find. These are all different layers of clothing so you can put them on all at once. Also if you can find any non enchanted amulets use those too. Now once you get your Enchanting level high enough, you'll have an option to enchant an item with a constant effect, so as long as you have the item on, the effect is active. Enchant every piece of clothing you're wearing with Fortify Intelligence (you can get this by getting any fortify attribute spell, I just buy orc strength from the merchant in Ald-ruhn) and then check your magicka bar. It should be very high at this point. Now make the most broken spell you can think of, and make sure that it's below your magicka (depending on the clothing that you got and enchanted you should be either at or near the max limit) and there you go. You are now unstoppable. I tried this with fortify strength instead and managed to kill Dagoth Ur in one hit. (while he was still in "god form")

This game is a masterpiece that I would recommend to any elder scrolls fan. Just be sure to get the boots of blinding speed because this game is hell without those.

Regardless of the early graphics and the bugginess of some of the gameplay, this was one of the first games that offered up an in depth amount of environmental interaction and overall sandbox feel. I remember the feeling of triumph and pay-off as I stood on the top of my tower, in the complex of buildings that was my estate near Balmora, which I had decorated myself in detail (with an alchemy lab, a library, etc)....so anyway, I stood atop my tower and unleashed a fireball of epic radius and damage down the river, towards town, where it flared up throughout a large swath of Balmora. And cast one more for good measure. I stayed upon my tower and looked to the ground, nonplussed as what remained of the Balmora city guard rushed my estate, only to be hacked down mercilessly by my hireling/bodyguard (in full Daedric armor).

Despite its age this is still a very good game. It does not allow fast travel like those that came after it but it is still enjoyable. I would recommend playing it with openmw, which helps some with crashing.

[H1] the meat and bones [/H1]
Now I bet you are wondering, "why is there an asterisk there? Are they going to-" 
yes, the answer is yes I'm going to go on for a bit [spoiler] sorry not sorry [/spoiler]. The simple thing is: this game is old and it feels old. The graphics are more than dated and the combat is very RNG dependant  which makes it feel even more dated. If these things sound like they will put you off the game, it probably will. However, if you can get past this here are some of the big pros:

1.) Builds: if you've only played skyrim you may be surprised to find how many more skills and stats there are in morrowind. In skyrim you just have health magika and stamina. Conversely in morrowind you have Endurance, speed, strength, willpower, personality, luck, agility. Each does a different thing and building for one will change your experience massively. To compliment this Morrowind has so many skills.
To name just the ones that didn't make the cut to skyrim:
medium armour, spears, acrobatics, armourer, axe, blunt, long blade, short blade, athletics, mercantile, mysticism

2.) Spells. Ever want to fly around because walking is boring? learn the levitate and soar across the skies. Want to cripple a target  and make them unable to do anything learn drain attribute spells. 
"What if I want a spell and it doesn't exist?" you may ask, there is a system where you can mix spell effects and adjust all the important bits like duration or what it targets. Even enchantments have more depth. You can enchant with passive effects or active effects; want to have a set of cheap hide armour that summons a daedric armour when worn? You can do that. Want to have armour that causes a big boom when activated, it can be done.

3.) The world [spoiler] wait haven't I already made this joke?[/spoiler]: ...So do you know how half of the things canonically in Skyrim aren't in the game skyrim? Like the minotaurs, dreugh, flying whales, talking draugar, etc. well Everything in morrowind is in game. Want to see giant mushroom trees? Sure and there are mad anarchist wizards who grow them artificially to live in. Want to see Vivec city, city of Vivec where a the ruler holds up a giant meteorite (turned prison) with their divine powers? Well you can. 

Speaking of Vivec
Vivec pre-godhood was always struggling to find a self, they were born as both male and female and struggled to decide on which they wanted to be (which is something [via my own IRL biases] find very...relatable). Books use he and she showing how they never really could decide. With the power they gained they could change at will to one or the other and this instilled a determination for freedom in Vivec which informs their personality.  Vivec is just one character. Many characters are more interesting than in skyrim, some are evil but do good or do evil but for good reasons but in the end they feel less like cardboard cutouts stuck to quest vending machines.

4.) Player choice (see that faction, you can join it): Morrowind is very open almost to the point of being a sandbox. Every NPC can be killed or interacted with. Common bandits can be conversed with and you can kill the main villain without even doing a single quest. There are many factions who all bring something unique to the (proverbial) table.

The Telvanni are anarchist wizards who are less xenophobic than most in morrowind but do engage in slavery but do everything by "might is right". The telvanni argue that if you manage to murder your direct superior that you must be better suited to their job since you beat them.

Redoran are the honourable house. They fight with blades and well crafted armour, Despite their honour it is hard to rise in their ranks as a non dark elf especially a beast race due to entrenched xenophobes who will only let you rise up if you can eliminate them or prove they gain more from helping you

Hlallu are the profit based house. They are the house with the most N'wah (foreign people). They are generally quite open minded but there is an obvious problem of corruption. One of their leaders harasses anyone trying to get personal and intinate asking for a kiss and insisting you call him "uncle".

Then you have some of the more minor factions (who all have quest lines) such as the Imperial temple who want you to spread word of the divines (since the dark elves are more keen on worshipping other dark elves [the tribunal]) or how about the tribunal temple who want you to follow the words of the tribunal (mostly vivec). You can join the mages guild, fighters guild or even the Impeiral army. There is only one main faction that isn't available, the Sixth house (the antagonists), which is sad since their leader is quite the likeable guy (even if he does need to be stopped).

Additionally you can become a vampire or werewolf and these I have a mixed feeling on. On the one hand it's cool that NPCs acknowledge that you are clearly a monster of the night but on the other you can't really play the game as them since every NPC won't even talk to you. There are also three entirely different vampire clans with different outlooks and beliefs.

5.) Immersive quest log: this can be a pro or a con depending on how you see it but I think it is better than how it is in skyrim. Every quest has a full journal entry which tells you what you are doing. There are no quest markers and instead you are told where to go in your journal. This is a good thing since it is immersive and leads to less zombie-like wandering towards arrows with no brain function but it can be frustrating when it goes wrong.

6.) Equipment: This game has way more weapons and armour to use. There is light heavy and medium armour along with multiple clothing layers that can be mixed. You have the following slots to equip armour:
-Head
-Feet
-Shoulders
-Undershirt
-Torso
-gauntlets/gloves
-Trousers/greaves
-skirts
-sash/belt
-robes
Each has weight and lets you make your character look how you want. additionally there are more weapons, to name the types not in skyrim: spears, thrown, short blades (like katanas), (melee) staff

So some Cons:
-This game is not balanced. You either adapt or you get destroyed. You will accept a quest to kill three rats and will die over and over again trying to kill the three rats.
-There is no fast travel so expect to do a lot of walking
-Obtuse stats and quests are aplenty

what makes morrowind so unique is all of the depth. Dagoth Ur is the best villian I've seen in elder scrolls franchise and with miles better motivation and charisma then someone like Alduin or even Harkon. 
I fear the success of Skyrim might teach them the wrong lesson and they may make an even more one dimensional plot with none of the weirdness that makes the elder scrolls universe what it is and with near to no build variety

What Florida was like 1000 years ago

Morrowind did not age well... in the best way. Morrowind does not give you fast travel by map. You have to use public transpotation. Morrowind does not give you quest markers. You have to use *street directions*. Morrowind NPCs will send you on a journey and tell you to go east, take the road southeast towards Vivec City, then hang a right when you see a big rock and keep going until you reach the cave where you're going to get killed by mudcrabs because you were holding "run" the entire time and now you're too exhausted to fight. I remember there was a session of Morrowind where I got completely turned around looking for a wizard's tower and I ended up in a town I had no idea existed. I had to go into a bar and ask a dancer on stage where I was and how to get where I was going. Like a tourist. It was the most immersed I've ever been in a game world.

And that's the thing. This is the one with the best setting. Oblivion and Skyrim are great but they don't come close to Vvardenfell and its god-kingdom and its giant chitinous livestock and its ashlands and its Divine Disease. Years after I finished the main quest I still go back and read the in-game books and marvel at the secrets they contain. This is the game that gave us the Sermons of Vivec. This game is how we know to reach heaven by violence. I want you to play it.
I have many more hours in Morrowind than Steam says I do. I highly recommend using OpenMW to play the game, along with Tamriel Rebuilt.

If you are a fan of open-world RPGs and you have not played Morrowind, you are missing out.

The game's story is a deep and complex tale of politics, intrigue, and ancient prophecies. The main quest takes you on a journey through the land of Morrowind as you uncover the machinations of the dark god Dagoth Ur and his followers.

And speaking of Dagoth Ur, he is one of the most memorable villains in any RPG. The way he speaks, with his grandiose oratorical style, is absolutely mesmerizing. He is a true force to be reckoned with, and the final battle with him is a pretty sick moment in gaming history.

Morrowind is more than just its story. The world is massive, with countless side quests and hidden secrets waiting to be discovered. And the level of freedom you have as a player is unparalleled. Want to be a master thief? A powerful mage? A brutal warrior? It is all up to you.

Of course, Morrowind is not without its flaws. The combat system can be clunky at times, and the graphics have not aged particularly well. These are minor quibbles in the grand scheme of things.

Come Nerevar, friend or traitor, come. Come and look upon the Heart and Akulakahn, and bring Wraithguard, I have need of it. Come to the Heart chamber, I wait for you there, where we last met, countless ages ago. Come to me through fire and war, I welcome you! Welcome Moon-and-Star, I have prepared a place for you! Come, bring Wraithguard to the Heart chamber, together, let us free the cursed false gods! Welcome Nerevar, together we shall speak for the law and the land and drive the mongrel dogs of the Empire from Morrowind! Is this how you honor the 6th house and the tribe unmourned? Come to me openly, and not by stealth. Dagoth Ur welcomes you Nerevar, my old friend... but to this place where destiny is made, why have you come unprepared? Welcome, Moon-and-Star, to this place where YOUR destiny is made. What a fool you are, I'm a god! How can you kill a god? What a grand and intoxicating innocence! How could you be so naive? There is no escape, no recall or intervention can work in this place! Come! Lay down your weapons! It is not too late for my mercy...

Okay so I'll start off with some positives but first let me say.
Do not make this your first Elder Scrolls game, the amount of reading optional material this game expects you to do to get immersed in its world is pretty absurd.

TES: 3/Morrowind as far as fantasy worlds go felt very interesting, I really loved the setting.
With its combination of religion, cults, and grand factions such as houses and a foreign empire, combined with the island your on which is inhabited by all manner of beasts, such as weird jellyfish things that are somewhat lobotomised for public transport, or all the pterodactyls that fly around the place, Morrowind is artistically quite great.

And as far as antagonistic forces go, I really liked how they present Dagoth Ur.
He's a man who has a constant presence throughout the entire game and piecing together the narrative as ya go along was pretty neat.

But the reason why I don't recommend the game comes down to everything else.
To put it briefly, the jank from this being released in 2002 is the least of its issues, but I will get into those issues all the same.

When you start off, you move PAINFULLY slow, if you are not running, you are suffering.
Even as the game went on, I still moved way too slow. The way I obtained a reasonable amount of speed was by just bunny hopping everywhere, the amount of distance you can gain as you level up via jumping is just ridiculous.

The combat too, is also terrible.
The RNG system they have for whether or not your hits actually hit your enemies makes attacks feel lame and weightless, and if your stamina is depleted from running everywhere, your hit chance is reduced by a fair bit.

I may have complimented the setting and antagonists earlier, but the characters you encounter are dull and undefined as characters.
The reason for this is because of how dialogue works, you have a list of topics to ask people and they give you either the specific result you're after, or very copy/paste dialogue.

Sidequests are bad, even the guilds and houses.
A lot of them are boring fetch quests that offer no narrative substance, but the amount of backtracking all these questlines want you to do is just absurd, it's boring.
Then there's escort missions, which are the absolute worst.
The pathfinding of these guys is god awful, they're slow and the rewards you get are consistently bad, aside from a pair of boots which you may or may not be able to wear depending on your race.
Top it off with very uneventful stories for most of their runtime and I just can't recommend doing as many of these as ya can.

Exploration is also very ehhhhh.
A lot of areas feel very copy/paste, and if you find an item for a sidequests before you stat it, well then you better not lose track of where you left that item. It just feels unrewarding at a lot of points.

And finally the expansions really aren't that great.
The enemies here are very spongey in comparison to the rest of the game, and when you're starting the game, if you don't progress in Tribunal, which you won't be doing at the starting level, you can be assaulted while you try and rest to restore your health. It's annoying and just messes with ya hard early on.
Tribunal's also just lame in general.

So yeah there's definitely some cool stuff here, and there are ways I could've mitigated some of these issues, but things like the lack of worthwhile characters or wasting my time will always persist.
Get it if you want more Elder Scrolls or desperately want to relive the 2002 PC game experience, but there's better games out there, even from the time this came out.

The best word to describe this game, in my opinion, is "scuffed".

I mean it, however, in a positive and endearing way. After playing something like Skyrim, it feels nice to play something this "broken" and unpolished. With so many liberties given, there are so many ways to break the game, and it's incredibly fun to do so.

The start is painfully slow and tedious, due to the fact that your skills get stronger "exponentially". You can hardly even hit anything at first, cast any spells, lockpick the simplest locks, and attempting to raise someone's disposition will only make them hate you, especially if during character creation you didn't get any bonuses to these skills. And when I say "slow", it's slow in the most literal way, since with low athletics, acrobatics, and a low reserve of fatigue you can only move at a snail's pace.
This is what had made me drop the game several times when I tried playing it in the past, until I finally was motivated enough to pull through.

Once you start to get going, though, you really start to get going. Once you get your acrobatics maxxed after spamming the jump button every millisecond for hours, you just start flying 5 meters into the air, and jumping from one Vivec canton to the other. When you get my favourite item, Boots of Blinding Speed, and find a way to use them, which I'm not even sure whether the developers actually intended for you to be able  to use them or not, the game just changes completely. You start gliding and jumping through Vvanderfell at a million miles an hour, and this kind of thing you simply cannot get in Skyrim (even with the same item, it's not even close).
I won't go into detail. but there's many more ways to break the game, which, again, make playing this game fun in a way that you can't really get in more modern games of this kind.

My biggest critique would probably be that the levelling process for many skills has not been thought through very well, which makes it incredibly tedious for some, and trivial for others. Especially since you don't get any experience on failed skill uses, you go from failing 10 times in a row on lower levels before succeeding once to get a little bit of XP, to succeeding every time and levelling much faster, which does not really make sense for skills to be easier to level at later levels than earlier ones.
And some skills, even when succeeding every single attempt, are much too slow to level, so the best way to level becomes to simply farm tens of thousands of gold and look for a trainer.

Despite its flaws, and sometimes thanks to them, I strongly recommend playing this game at least once. It really is a great experience, and the game felt nostalgic without having played it in the past, simply because it represents an era of video games that is long gone.

Morrowind is a roleplaying game in the worst way: it is too realistic in all those areas where less is more. Here you are not some random hero facing the world. You are a loser, a weakling, a nobody. The game does not want you to have fun. The game wants you to suffer and you have to fight against it. This starts from character creation, where you basically need to study or at least look up a guide before you can hope to have a somewhat less unpleasant experience. There are so many factors to consider just by picking a race, sex, class and birthsign. This will affect your stats and skills and you really need to think this through. Morrowind does not ask you: What do you want to be good at? Morrowind asks you: Where do you not want to be completely helpless?

Let me illustrate this with the basic attributes of which most will be "too low".

Strength: If you have too little, you will barely be able to carry anything but the clothes on your back. You will also not do any damage with weapons and run out of fatigue in an instant.

Agility: If you have too little, you will get hit a lot and also barely hit anything yourself.

Endurance: If you have too little, you will be killed instantly. Also health per level up is dependant on this attribute, so you really don't want to be low on this one.

Speed: If you have too little, you will walk horribly slow. There are some fast travel options, but they are far apart. You will do a lot of walking, so slow speed just means lots of downtime between the fun bits. But it's not relevant for combat, so it's a safe option for "too little".

Intelligence: If you have too little, you will barely have any magicka to cast spells.

Willpower: If you have too little, you will barely succeed on casting any spell. Also you will run out of fatigue in an instant.

Personality: If you have too little, nobody likes you. But you're an outlander in Vvardenfell, so nobody likes you anyways. Safe option for "too little".

Now that you have determined in which ways you want to be crippled on a fundamental level, it's time to figure out in which ways you want to be crippled specifically. Namely you have 5 major and 5 minor skills. Major skills start at 30/100 and only require 75% of the default experience to increase. Minor skills start at 15 and require 100% experience. All skills you don't pick here will start at 5 and require 125% of the default experience.

Now how does that cripple you? Anyhting below 50 is basically trash. With racial boni you can get some major skills to be almost acceptable, whereas everything else is a pain. So you want to have the weapons, armor and spell schools you use the most as your major skills in order to even do anything. Also in Morrowind, you do not learn from failure. Everytime you miss a swing, you have learned nothing about wielding that weapon. Everytime you fail at lockpicking, you decrease the durability of your lockpick, but did not learn anything about lockpicking. Everytime you fail at a potion, you wasted the ingredients. Everytime you fail at a spell, you only wasted mana - which does not regenerate naturally. As the success chance of everything you do is based on your skill, your minor and even more so miscellaneous skills are very hard to increase without spending gold at a trainer. You only get to pick the skills where you want to be the least trash at.

Of course everything gets better, once you start levelling, right? Nope. You level by increasing any 10 of your major or minor skills. Each skill is linked to an attribute. The more skills per attribute you increase, the more the attribute increases at level up. You may only pick 3, though. Don't spread your activities out too much. However, to get the highest possible increase to an attribute, you need 10 skill upgrades there (including misc). That means to turn your loser into a little less of a loser, you should preferably increase twice as many of the hardly increasable misc skills -> get a lot of gold and spend it on trainers. Sure hope you're not a mage, otherwise you might lack the strength to even carry enough valuable loot back from your exploits.

Now that we have established that you are a loser, you will also find that you're horribly poor on stamina. If you move, you will lose fatigue. The lower your fatigue, the lower your chance of... well, anything. Don't do things when you are out of breath. So once you moved through the empty, boring world to the tomb or mine you have a quest at, make sure to just afk for a while. While it is realistic, it's just a massive waste of time. Just as the slow walking or the incredible amount of failures when trying to level any skill other than those you're already quite good at. Funny enough the best skill to level is your amor, because you will be very good at getting spanked. But don't forget to keep some repair hammers on you. Armor and weapons lose durability quite rapidly and the worse state they're in, the less will they protect you and the less will you hit anything with them.

To top it all of, the writing and sound design are a mess. Quests are boring and generic. Dialogue is copy pasted everywhere to the point that the attitude of one NPC can change completely within two related textboxes. And absolutely nothing beats the good feeling of an NPC telling you how thankful they are for your help in the textbox, while the voice line pretty much tells you to piss off, outlander.

Morrowind has not aged well. It's clunky, the dice based gameplay is boring, there are a multitude of factors on every single dice roll that you should all have an eye on. Your chances will automatically decrease unless you actively wait. It might be a great experience for those that enjoy wasting time with tedious, mundane tasks, but for anyone who values their time, it's a pass.

I have zero nostalgia for this game whatsoever as I first played it in 2017. My first impressions were: This game is slow, ugly, and boring. There was something almost charming about how much people praised this game so I constantly came back to try to understand why they love it so much. After a few failed characters, sometime in 2019 when I had a grand total of 10 hours, it just clicked. This game is super buggy, game mechanic heavy, and extremely broken in many ways, BUT that's what makes this game so good. You can do dumb stuff like hit enemies so hard that it breaks them and your weapon. It's extremely entertaining in the sense that you can really do whatever you want in this game. Wanna move really fast? Make a spell that negates 95 points of spells for a single second and equip the boots of blinding speed. What about that last 5 points? It makes the game a little darker, but being blind actually makes you more accurate. Wanna jump across the entire map? Go ahead just have levitate on standby. Everything is stamina based for success rate, but now that you have no stamina what can you do? Good time to repair equipment since the formula divides rather than multiplies.
It's so good in the sense that it never restricts you and knowing the ways it's broken somehow makes it more immersive?? I don't know why but it really does.
Even though I make fun of it a lot this is genuinely one of my favorite games. It's not for everyone, but if you want a buggy mess of a game, this is definitely worth your time.

Also the story and lore are actually good.

Man this game is freaking amazing for immersion and replay-ability. Definitely old on the graphics and combat but everything else is awesome. I grew up watching my sisters play this game so I get that nostalgia factor too lol

For these were the days of Resdaynia, when Chimer and Dwemer lived under the wise and benevolent rule of the ALMSIVI and their champion the Hortator, though the Dwemer had become foolish and challenged their masters.

Out of their fortresses they came with golden ballistae that walked and mighty atronachs and things that spat flame and things that made killing songs. Their king was Dumac Dwarf-Orc, but their high priest was Kagrenac the Blighter.

Under mountains and over them the war with the Dwemer was raged, and then came the northern men to help Kagrenac and they brought Ysmir again.

Leading the armies of the Chimer was the slave that would not perish, the Hortator Nerevar, who had traded his axe for the Ethos Knife. He slew Dumac at Red Mountain and saw the heart bone for the first time.

Men of brass destroyed the eleven gates of the Mourning Hold and behind them came the Dwemeri architects of tone. Ayem threw down her cloak and became the Face-Snaked Queen of the Three in One. Those that looked upon her were overcome by the meanings of the stars.

Under the sea, Seht stirred and brought the army he had been working on in the castles of glass and coral. Clockwork dreughs, mockeries of the Dwemeri war machines, rose up from the seas and took their counterparts back beneath, where they were swallowed forever by the sea.

Red Mountain exploded as the Hortator went too far inside, seeking the Sharmat.

Dwemeri high priest Kagrenac then revealed that which he had built in the image of Vivec. It was a walking star, which burnt the armies of the Triune and destroyed the heartland of Veloth, creating the Inner Sea.

Each of the aspects of the ALMSIVI then rose up together, combining as one, and showed the world the sixth path. Ayem took from the star its fire, Seht took from it its mystery, and Vehk took from it its feet, which had been constructed before the gift of Molag Bal and destroyed in the manner of truth: by a great hammering. When the soul of the Dwemer could walk no more, they were removed from this world.

Resdaynia was no more. It had been redeemed of all the iniquities of the foolish. The ALMSIVI drew nets from the Beginning Place and captured the ash of Red Mountain, which they knew was the Blight of the Dwemer and that would serve only to infect the whole of the middle world, and ate it. ALTADOON DUNMERI!

The beginning of the words is ALMSIVI. I give you this as Vivec.

I really tried to enjoy Morrowind as it is my first elder scrolls game but it was really difficult. I played through a good chunk of it, but ended up just feeling bored, lost, and unimmersed. I had some fun and I definitely would not call Morrowind a bad game, but it just felt sluggish. Essentially my two main issues boiled down to dialogue and movement. I like the idea of moving slowly and building up speed over the course of the game, but goddamn does it make me want to kill myself in practice, like holy shit it is agonizingly slow. Dialogue wise, I actually really like the unique dialogue options, but each NPC has like five hundred default dialogue options to the point where it feels impossible to find NPC's who have anything worth listening too. Some of this agonizing jank did honestly help immerse me more, realistically walking across a country would make you want to kill yourself, but while I was immersed I felt like I was immersed in swamp water and getting stuck in mud and weeds. Decent game, I just couldn't enjoy it.

I have the theory that is is likely the best game Bethesda ever did and everything that came afterwards its just a repeat of what they achieved here. The side content ranges from fetch quests to some okay and interesting stuff, but what tops it all is the main quest, there is a sense of discovery not only exploring wise, but in a narrative sense as well!

The story is also tied to the sense of progression and leveling up, you start as a prisoner who is sent to work as a spy by the emperor, and there is a mystery you have to unveil, since you are a spy, you have to make a cover identity on your own, and the game tells you to level up and do side content to get better at what you do, there is no weird sense of urgency like in Cyberpunk where you are dying and it just feels off when you want to explore, or like in Breath of the Wild where they say Ganon is about to break free and you are collecting dragonflies for a girl and her sister, Morrowind gives you the perfect mood to explore and it only gives you the information you need at the final of the quest when things are about to go wild, besides you can still play after beating the main quest when there is no imminent threat anymore, you can wander around aimlessly and make your own story! Live your own fantasy life!

Morrowind also features a more natural and realistic depiction of the chosen one narrative, since this time you have to convince people and go through several tests instead of being told you are the one and being believed as such by others as a matter of fact, you have to win it, you have to convince them with actions, mere words don't do, people are very apathetic about the prophecy because naturally they don't believe it and just want to see results from you, people in Morrowind are all about to see to believe, and weirdly enough, even when it reduces the power fantasy factor, it makes the story feel a lot more real.

The lore is amazing and everything you hear about the Disappearance of the Dwarves is just neat, it is the kind of cryptic stuff that scrambles my brain, the mystery about the real truth of the death of Nerevar, that weird wizard dude that clones his wives, the cult and the use of the Kagrenac tools by the tribunal and Dagoth Ur, it's just so good, it's all so good. It is one of those stories that makes you to compulsively play nonstop so you can find out the truth!

Also, no quest markers whatsoever. I first felt it was frustrating not knowing where to go, but Morrowind taught me about how rewarding the sense of exploration can be, and the sense of freedom that comes with it, no compass telling you where to go, its all about your own story, you get clues and get to discover things, beautiful things, scary things, unbelievable things. For my second playthrough I completely disabled the map because I just realized I love feeling lost, I love being lost so much, there is an inexplicable joy on me in not knowing where I am and being in a place for the first time. And while there are some procedurally generated games with no maps, having manually handcrafted locations make the exploration feel more special, because there will always be something interesting to discover, it is the story related content and dialogue based questa that other exploration games can't offer with procedurally generated quests.

Also, as most Bethesda games, it does have a huge modding community, there are mods that can even duplicate the size of the map, all with handcrafted locations!

The gameplay is fantastic too, there are just so many things you can use to achieve your goal, sure, the RNG combat is weird at first, the stamina use when walking is weird too, but the more you level up the more satisfying it becomes to hit more frequently, you can either specialize in long blades, or you can use stealth, the magic system is vast and full of possibilities. I was sad first when I used all my Icarian flight scrolls and I couldn't find any on the game, but then I learned you can do a spell to increase your jump and reduce your weight and boom, I was able to make a bootleg icarian flight spell myself, it is all about those little tricks and things you can do, the abilities, the possibilities that just add to the repeatability, the ability to levitate between cities, have you seen that wind bombing glitch people use on Breath of the Wild to jump really far way? You can do that on Morrowind, no exploits needed, all legitimately part of the gameplay! There is also using the voice of the emperor to charm others, command creatures, paralyze your enemies! Become a master alchemist and destroy everybody with the most dangerous motions known to man! It is just all so good, so so good!

Some of the lore was taken along with for the next games, but, I feel this is the only game for me worth exploring. I do like the nordic inspired landscapes of the next releases and I like Lord of the Rings until a certain measure that you find in the next two games, but I haven't felt the drive to explore them when its approach feels so soulless, and while Oblivion and Skyrim are the definition of what I would call generic fantasy, Morrowind's world is creepy and alien, it is scary and wonderful. The steampunk inspired Dwarf ruins, the construction in Sadrith Mora and the closer islands, the open maze that can be Vivec city, the houses made of stone and the manor district of Aldrun, the skeleton warrior filled castle of Firemoth, the altars in the Sixth House bases, the master index forts, that bonelord between the lava I found in a cave raiding one of my trials, it is all so good, so good!

While Daggerfall aimed at a sense of freedom and size with the procedurally generated world, Morrowind uses the manual approach and gives you locations that are all lovely handcrafted one by one without cramming up so many things in a small space, still giving you a big land to wander around and sight-see!

Maybe adding routines for the NPCs would have helped a lot to make the characters less static, but I tell you that what this game achieved is really really special! Morrowind is the joy of being lost and discovering a place for the first time, to discover something beautiful or incredible after hours of walking, to find a lost fella and help them along the way for then discover the witch that cursed him was actually in the right, Morrowind is about dying, about fight your way in, Morrowind is about having an adventure, and it is one of my favorite games right now.

Plus Dagoth Ur is a pretty hot monster husbando. His aura is unmatchable.

Well, I'm rewriting the review, because my viewpoint of the game changed, and I'll explain why, and also why this game initially sucks. It is related to the Skills system, and also the character walking speed.

First of all, the skills system is quite atrocious on how they influence your character. If you're making use of a weapon, your weapon skill level is literally the percentage chance of the attack hitting.
If your skill is level 30, 30% chance of the attack landing. If it's level 5 (the level non major and minor skills probably will be), 5% chance of hitting the attack. 
There's also the factor that the target may dodge the attack too but that's something else. Training low level skills on a trainer npc by paying gold helps ease this, by making so you can try grinding those skills other ways.

As for spells, they have something similar to the weapons hit rate, but in this case, it's the chance of the cast being successful.
Gladly, the chance is mostly related to how powerful the spell is, and the level of the skill that governs it, so you can grind the skill by spamming the spell while using a bed to rest, and maybe you can get it to 100% chance of success (depending on the spell).
Regardless of wether the spell you're using is weak or strong, it will always increase skill level progress the same way.

Also, there is no natural Health and Magicka regeneration in this game. If you need to restore your character health and magicka, you need to make your character rest.
The problem with this, is that there is a chance that your rest might be interrupted, but the biggest problem is when it's interrupted by a Dark Brotherhood Assassin.
Those guys appearing so early in the game is like the developers wanting to punish the player. But... If you manage to kill them, their loot give quite a good amount of coins.

The movement of the character is waaaaaay too slow. Running makes the character considerably faster, beside still being too slow on the lower levels. The character gets somewhat faster as you level up Speed and Athletics, though, but not that much.
Also, you will need to conserve stamina, since it will be necessary for several things, like interactions with npcs, fighting monsters, and even for chance of successfully casting a spell. You can even get your character knocked out if you try fighting someone without stamina, so beware.

Also speaking of combat, the hits have impact. You can feel that the target of your attacks is hit by the attacks, and you can see them being knocked back, or even falling on their knees upon being hit. That's amazing. I don't know why on the future games, the characters fights like rocks with weapons, but here, feels more like attacks are painful.

Rich in dialogue the game seems, but it's also a really confusing and laziness inducing dialogue system.
They made quite a lite version of the text wall World of Warcraft npcs give to you when you talk to them, but alongside that, there's a system where you can pick keywords your character know, and ask the npc about them to see what they have to say.
That can easily get overwhelming depending on the npc you're speaking to, and how many keywords you learned.
After some time of gameplay, I begun ignoring generic looking dialogues, and only investigating further dialogues that starts differently.

The world of the game doesn't really seems that big, but due to how slow your character moves, it will still be a journey. There's actually lots more to see while exploring the world map, than you see on Oblivion and Skyrim, since this game has also some minor villages and other points of interests.
Also, there's no fast travel other than by hiring from npcs to go to other cities.
Also, pay attention to signs, to see if you're going the right direction.

While playing this game, I also noticed the trend on Bethesda games, of making so some monsters begin appearing on the world after certain level. I don't actually like that, because feels very odd. Like, starting from level 3 or 5, you begin seeing Cliff Racers everywhere, when they didn't existed before.

The dungeons of the game are actually quite challenging, and I mean that mostly because you'll probably need to fight against the rng on your attacks to win. The loot itself is like the best of all Elder Scrolls games I've ever played. It feels rewarding to explore a dungeon. The only problem is that they don't respawn.

The game features quite a good number of equipments that aren't present on other games, like Spears, and their own skills. There's also equipments like Shoulder Guards and Gloves, but I have no idea why they split them between left and right.

And, also quite a good number of skills to make use of. I am able to make a naked khajiit character, and because there's skill for Unarmored in the game, leveling it up made my character a lot better at surviving.
Also, that skill doesn't affect only naked characters. If you want to make a warrior that only uses cloth armor, go ahead.

By the way... Little side comment but... Did Bethesda forget to make underwears for Khajiits and Argonians?
Seriously, they have literally no piece of clothing when naked. Even the Female ones doesn't have any clothing on their chest. Just commenting btw.

And, there's also the bad skills, like Sneak, which not only is nearly impossible to level up naturally, but also extremelly risky too.

There is a great number of spell effects here, with interesting effects too. There's even a spell effect that allow you to Levitate in the air. Yes, you can fly in this game with that spell. That felt so amazing when I tried out that spell. And the potions are quite useful aswell, but I think their effect could last longer.

Factions seems to take a major role here, with several factions you can join, and each of them having quests.
The most interesting fact is, the Fighters, Mages and Thieves guilds, have quests on all cities they have a base on, so if you get quests from Balmora FG, you can also get quests from Vivec FG. And the devs actually invested their time making those quests, so it's worth doing them, and rewarding aswell.

So far, the game itself is great, and I plan on playing more.
What is sad, is when I think of TES IV Oblivion and TES V Skyrim, and imagine the many cool things this game has, that those games didn't implemented. Even more TES V, since it dropped most of the features from earlier games, and turned into some action rpg, with rocks fighting each other.

If it wasn't for the problem with the Skills system and the Walking Speed, the game would be more accessible to new players.

It's a great read of an Elder Scrolls game, but don't go in expecting Skyrim's action or Oblivion's physical comedy. Morrowind's story is more grounded and slower-burning than an Oblivion or Dragon Crisis. The stakes are still huge by the end, but you work your way up from pathetic shrimpling to superpowered god-hero in a way that feels a little more believable. Take your time to understand the world of Morrowind before you try to rush through the main quest- the game tells you to do so. 

Exploration is probably its best in the series here IMO. Combat is generally monotonous and magic totally unfair. Embrace the BS and delete foes with rude enchantments that would seem to violate international law and conventions of warfare, because enemies will do the same to you.

Oh, good gods, where to begin with this review... Actually, I have a lot to say about this game. So here's the quick review: Get this game. Mod the ever-loving hell out of it. Enjoy it, because this game is one of the reasons we don't get games like this anymore.

Now that I've covered that, it's time for a deep dive. Morrowind is one of the most jam-packed clunky messes of a game that has ever been published in the history of time. Don't believe me? This hulking mass of story is nearing twenty years old and people are still discovering little secrets that they never noticed before. And that's saying something, because even Skyrim can't hold up to the layers of depth that this game has to offer. Mind you, that isn't to say that the execution is particularly stellar. This is a game of upmost patience over anything. It's ancient, it barely functions by modern standards, and it requires actual reading. You know, that thing you're doing now, only I haven't scattered my review across a countryside and handed you a quest to find them and assemble them into a cohesive narrative. And even when intense amount of reading isn't required to play through parts, there's still so much to uncover. You can literally take weeks scouring parts of the map and still not manage to find all the intricate (if pixelated) details that have been strewn about.

With all of that pontification out of the way, there's some serious flaws that need to be addressed, and that's really what my reviews are known for anyway.  First off, the biggest issue: Bethesda has made a disgustingly lucrative career out of making spaghetti-coded nightmares. I'd go so far as to cite this game as the beginning of the trend. Morrowind is a hot bed of trash in terms of how awful the bugs are. And there's no modern auto-save feature, so if you aren't diligent about saving (and having multiple saves), you can be completely stopped by a game-breaking error in coding that won't let you proceed further. Seriously, it's a disaster.

The second thing to note is that the overall game-play structure is a bit of a nightmare. Where the bugs don't kill you, the awkwardness of the game's structure might. There's no perceivable logic connecting the UI and the skills you have access to are... troublesome. If you aren't careful at character creation alone, you'll be against a wall of being hilariously bad at using a weapon. Or spells if that's your fancy. And on the other side of that, the spells and weapon damage become absolutely absurd once you've gotten skills up to a satisfying level. And before you ask, physics are insane here. You can force enemies to ragdoll off cliffs just like latter installments, and that's still wildly entertaining.

Now, the third and final note is that there are a lot of mods for this game. Don't hesitate to use them, as some of the quality-of-life mods that have been created by fans turn this clunky old title into a genuinely thrilling experience. Just be sure to follow the instructions for the mods you choose or you’ll be downloading files that do nothing. Given that the base game can run on some of the least updated of systems, there’s no reason not to see exactly how many mods your potato engine PC can handle without fully cooking some Au Gratin potatoes.

What? You’re still here? Go buy this ancient game and have fun messing with it already. Sheesh. You’d think that I didn’t just lay out enough reason with all that previously spattered information to convince you already.
I'm tired of the Imperials putting potions in the water that turn the friggin Guars gay!
I would LOVE to love this game. But if I need to juggle mods, sift through defunct gamefaqs guides, and save scum my way out, then I'll just wait for the eventual remake.

It might look like I only have 52 hours played at the time of this review, but this is a game that I played obssessively in my younger days. It was always a great memory, and after I moved on to Oblivion and Skyrim, I was a bit afraid of tarnishing that memory. A lot of people kept singing the praises of this game, but we all know how niche communities work: everything seems to be better in the olden days. So, while I was trying to mod Oblivion (again), I noticed just how nurtured the Morrowind modding community was. I knew about the overhauls and the total conversions, but the modding scene for the vanilla game was as extensive as in the other games. So, I started reading about it.

What I like the most about Morrowind mods is that, sure, you can go ham with them as with other Elder Scrolls games, but Morrowind is a game that was so perfectly yet precariously balanced atop a massive heap of interlocking systems, that adding much more of anything on top kinda ruins the experience.

You see, this is a game that lives and dies by its systems. Be it the spells system, where you can create your own spells tailoring how powerful and how lasting they are provided you have the coin and the magical charge, or the soft skill system, where everything is learned through practice (or trained if you have the coin), or the persuasion system, where characters will reveal their darkest secrets and give away their precious possessions if you're charming enough (or you have the coin for a bribe),,, Morrowind never compromises in how far the player can go with them.

You might notice all of them have the word "coin" somewhere. Because it's absolutely true. Gold will solve all your problems, pretty much as it should be. You can murder everything that stands in your way and sell the materials, weapons and armor of your foes, or you can slink about stores stealing everything that isn't nailed down, or you can craft insane potions and enchantements to sell at crazy prices... Everything can net you some drakes, and after you amass sufficient wealth, you can break the game.

And breaking the game is immensely fun. It's very clearly a game that knew how its systems could be exploited, but also knew how that is part of the fun, if not THE fun. Everytime you outwit a problem, an obstacle, or an inconvenience through the use of savvy game mechanics loopholes, you don't fell like your abusing or exploiting the game. You feel like Morrowind is excitedly telling you "Great! You found another solution! Awesome!". And it's so immensely rewarding to be able to play a game in your own terms and still have it be fun, that I feel all the fame this game has is totally warranted.

I didn't know it when I was a youngster, but now that I have a better way with words, I realize that's precisely what I love about this game. It's a game with no real artificial boundaries, just how far the systems can stretch. And they can stretch REALLY far. An absolutely unique experience.

Closing, the game has humongous amounts of content. 52 hours, I have on this Steam playthrough. And this is only Guild content and half one Noble House content. I haven't even made the Main Quest nor the DLCs. You WILL get your money's worth. The original combat is what has aged the worst, with your skill determining chance to hit, not damage, and that can make fights take forever and be rather frustrating. While I love everything else, combat has certainly aged like milk.

Luckily, there's a mod for that.

And speaking about mods, here's my list. Rather purist (except for combat), and the game looks and feels wonderfully:

- Morrowind Code Patch
- Morrowind Enhanced Textures 5.2
- Better Bodies
- Morrowind Comes Alive
- Real Signposts
- MGE XE
- Next Generation Combat

Generally this game gives me a bit of a mixed feelings. From one side I enjoyed the world of Morrowind and all the history, cities, and characters that I managed to meet along the way. The game has rich lore and we can see that the devs put in a lot of effort on this one.

The game play itself was good as well. I played the game on Steam Deck and in my opinion the game should be in the status of "Verified" rather than "Playable" as I had no problems with it, nor did I have to make any changes to the default control settings either in-game or for the Steam Deck. The game did freeze up on me once or twice during my playtime but the game is stable on Steam Deck.

The problem I have with this game is the progression blocker that might appear depending on how you build your initial character. During one of the story missions, you have to recover an artifact from an area that has ghost enemies in it. At no point does the game ever explain or highlight what do you need to do hurt those enemies so after searching the internet I discovered you either need an enchanted or a silver weapon.

The thing is that you can't use any silver weapon, it has to be one that specific to your build, so for example if you have low skill points in using long weapons your weapon won't hit the enemy (even if you can see the weapon going through the enemy's body) and since I wasn't going for the magic build/user I didn't have any of the Enchanting skills.

Overall, I would recommend the game, but be careful when building your character and where you place the skill points into as this is important at the start of the game.

Simply put THE best Elder Scrolls game there is. Once modded this game will live forever.

With mods, Morrowind can be brought back to life as a playable game. I had thought in the past that it had aged so poorly that it wasn't worth my time, even as a die-hard Elder Scrolls fan and someone who played Morrowind many years ago, but after finally revisiting it and figuring out how the combat worked, I found myself as absorbed in it as I had been with Oblivion and Skyrim.

However, that doesn't mean the base game aged well at all, and like I said, Morrowind requires mods to be considered even enjoyable to play.

This is a very unique game for a very specific kind of person, if you're like me with no nostalgia for old RPGs like this I just want to warn you that there is more reading and walking than anything else in this game and the combat consists of left clicking until the yellow bar depletes. But if you like the idea of a lot of reading, a lot of menuing, and a lot of using the wiki because you have no idea what to do a lot of the time, Id highly recommend it. This 50hrs was on my first play through btw.

There's very few games I can get totally get engrossed in, and this was one of them. Apart from the standard praise the Elder Scrolls series gets, Morrowind is the standout for me because of the [b]writing[/b]. 

If you take the time to read the dialogue, books, you find a rich, detailed world designed and written by people who have a deep understanding of politics, history, theology and philosophy. Very few RPGs give so much detail that the world feels totally plausible, but this is one of them. In terms of writing, very, very few games come close to Morrowind.

It has a compelling world, interesting and thoughtful characters, and so many stories to get lost in. Easily one  of, if not the best RPG ever made.

This is the game that revolutionized the open world genre in my humble opinion. It is also the most immersive and 'real' feeling  games in the Elder Scrolls series, as well as one of their last games to display their once trademark esoteric rpg elements. The main story and score are also masterful as well, and together all of these elements present a heartfully handcrafted world that reaches Tolkeinesque levels of detail. the combat is shite tho but it beats arx fatalis that's for sure

Ever feel like Skyrim is too simplistic, ever feel Oblivion and Fallout hold your hand too much with where to go or level up a little too linearly? Morrowind basically gives a journal and updates your progress on quests and where to go but never tells you where to look. This can result in very rewarding conclusions when you find your destination yourself, or frustrating moments getting lost when there's no fast travel, and some clunky combat where you're not sure if you're missing because your skill is low or the hitbox is wonky. Fights can be very basic but the weapons are varied like broadswords that work most any way you use them, spears that don't chop well so you're expected to move forward and back in a thrusting motion, or katanas that only work with chops and swings. Compared to Skyrim's barebones weapons where swords tend to swing quicker and hammers tend to do more damage generally. This also applies to birthsigns where you could have a free stun ability per day, a decent lock open, shrug off most magic attacks, or challenge yourself with a heal spell in exchange for vulnerability to fire.
Back to having to navigate the world yourself, Oblivion you mostly want to get to the next green field, meanwhile the volcanic landscape and Dunmer buildings feel so alien. Imagine having to walk across Skyrim except you come across deserts and mud cities and dwarven ruins. Again while the archaic travel system is annoying you're never somewhere not interesting. You walk into a mine where they gather eggs from these worms that are scattered across the place, just an alternative to thieves dens and crypts patrolled by bone walkers.
The game is far from balanced, it's famous for breaking if you get deep into enchanting and especially alchemy once you have a merchant who can always hand over fortify intelligence items. This is more of a bonus since there are plenty of ways to get powerful items and just explore at your own pace. Consider this, Skyrim will make quest characters immortal just so you can always finish the game, Morrowind just makes sure you know the main story is screwed if you murder someone important, you're free to make mistakes and use high level weapons to feel powerful, just like you can craft spells too powerful to ever use if you're not paying attention. The game can be difficult but if you play loose with stealing and learn where certain items are and understand what skills you'll need early when making your character you can roll through it easy. It's not for everyone and again exploitable to a fault, but if you can get into it there's some surprising depth that later Bethesda games are missing.

The Road Most Travelled

Elder Scrolls 3 from the original game developer, was the beginning of the decline of the elder scrolls series. There were decisions that changed the creative direction of the game. Those decisions that made a smaller more controlled world for better or worse, is what led to Morrowind. The game has many flaws, early game combat mechanics have not aged well. No one likes the flying assholes. That being said, you are doing yourself a huge disservice to not dive into this game headfirst and immerse. This is one of those games that TRULY sucks you in. You won't have quest pointers, but the decisions you make really craft a unique adventure. That itchy open world feeling you get after the intro scenes in oblivion and skyrim are far different from the quest you are given in Morrowind. The amount of guilds and factions are quite a bit more numerous than later entries, and there is a near endless supply of fun mysteries and dungeons to explore. Exploring Morrowind's story is just a reward, and I think if you've played any Elder Scrolls games, you owe it to yourself to complete this main quest storyline. Cheers.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
I decided to play Morrowind after hearing many positive reviews and being a fan of other Bethesda games like Skyrim and Fallout. Going into the game, I was expecting an immersive and expansive world with interesting characters and a rich narrative.

Morrowind is an open-world role-playing game developed by Bethesda Softworks and released in 2002. Set in the fictional island of Vvardenfell, the game tasks players with taking on the role of a prisoner who has been released into the world by the Emperor and must fulfill a prophecy in order to save the world from an impending disaster.


[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Morrowind features an open-world sandbox-style gameplay, allowing players to explore the island of Vvardenfell and complete quests in any order they choose. The game uses a point-and-click system for movement and combat, which can take some getting used to but ultimately feels responsive and intuitive. Players can choose from a variety of races and classes, each with their own unique abilities and skills. One of the standout features of the gameplay is the ability to use magic, which can be customized and combined in various ways to create powerful spells. I did encounter some bugs and glitches during my gameplay, but they were infrequent and did not significantly impact my experience.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
The story of Morrowind revolves around the player character fulfilling a prophecy to become the "Nerevarine," a savior figure who must stop the return of the demigod Dagoth Ur and prevent the destruction of the world. Along the way, players will encounter a variety of characters and factions, each with their own goals and agendas. The pacing of the story is fairly slow, but I found the world-building and character development to be well-done and engaging.

[h1]Graphics and Sound:[/h1]
Morrowind has a unique and distinctive visual style, with detailed character models and a vibrant color palette. However, the graphics are somewhat dated by modern standards and may not hold up well for players who are used to more realistic graphics. The sound design is solid, with a memorable soundtrack, although voice acting in this game is reserved for the important characters, most of the game is told through text.

[h1]Replay Value:[/h1]
Morrowind has high replay value due to its open-world sandbox gameplay and the ability to create multiple characters with different races and classes. There are also many side quests and hidden locations to discover, as well as multiple endings based on the player's choices. Overall, I would definitely recommend Morrowind to fans of open-world role-playing games and those looking for a challenging and immersive experience.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
In conclusion, Morrowind is a classic open-world role-playing game that offers a vast and detailed world to explore, interesting characters and a compelling story. While the graphics and gameplay mechanics may feel dated, the depth and replay value of the game more than make up for it. If you're a fan of Bethesda's other games or just enjoy open-world RPGs in general, Morrowind is definitely worth checking out.

After putting in some thought and a decent chunk of hours, I think overall I would recommend Morrowind to those who are either invested in the Elder Scrolls series or general hardcore rpg/lore enjoyers. I am not as high on some aspects of the game as other people may be, granted; it released in 2002 (features being incredibly aged, some downright unplayable to a lot of modern audiences). There are plenty of quests or locations not as poignant or expansive as a lot of people might claim, but I think this game is greater than the sum of its lesser parts. I think ultimately, Morrowind excels in its well-thought world-building, tremendous main story beats, and stand-out art direction. Despite its flaws, The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind has well earned its status as a Classic of its genre.

Overall I highly recommend this game and I really do think that Skyrim fans and Morrowind fans aren't a complete dichotomy.

Morrowind is a very special contribution to the Elder Scrolls Series, especially being the game that set the precedent for later games. The world feels alien and full of mystique, and even though the graphics are dated by today's standards there is still a lot of beauty to be found in the landscape. Each item and asset has its own unique style. There is something different about the world, It is obviously very much inspired by medieval times but it is fantastical and alien and not so stiffly rooted in reality. The map may be smaller than later games, but it feels vast due to the limitations on fast travel (I have 157 hours in the game and still have not traversed the entire map. But I also like to take my time). A very interesting choice was to have "fast travel" in the form of various transportation systems, which really keeps the immersion. You can pay a fare to travel by boat or silt strider, etc., and each method of travel has a specific route that they follow so oftentimes you must jump from port to port. With Morrowind, it feels like you are a PART of this world.

The gameplay is very unforgiving towards newcomers (much like the people), but once you level up it feels a lot more balanced. Morrowind very much leans into traditional roleplaying aspects, with many actions being "roll" and "chance" based. The lower your skill, the less chance you have of successfully performing an action (lockpicking, blocking, attacking). With each successful "roll", you gain skill. There are also no quest markers, which can be confusing but also greatly rewarding. You must pay close attention to your journal and to the directions that people give you, which sometimes may be a bit misleading. In this way you are not just checking off quest markers and blindly following it to the next location, you have to do a lot more problem solving and exploration in order to achieve your goal.

Overall, the atmosphere and world building of Morrowind is very good and makes the experience very fulfilling! I highly recommend it!
