Morrowind is one of my favorite games of all time. Despite that it's hard to recommend. It's just not very playable anymore. If you're a fan of the Elder Scrolls Series and are willing to put in the time to add a few mods, and tweak a few settings then I definitely recommend it. I just want to reiterate though that it isn't for everyone, I'd recommend watching a short video or two to get an idea of what to expect before you buy.

First thing to be said if you are looking to play a vanilla run of this game, play it using OpenMW! it makes a lot of changes that make the game stable, have modern resolution support, and comprehensive bug fixes. It is very easy to install and doesn't changes the core of the game so I'd recommend anyone looking to get into Morrowind to play it like this

That being said Morrowind is just one of those game that you will get lost into. The main draw is its world and nearly endless depth it has to offer from it mechanics, lore, geography, characters, and quest which all tie these things together into a singular experience.
As an open world game, the game shines as it provides alot of incentive to explore. The lack of quest markers make it so you will have to explore and learn the lay of the land to get around efficiently. There is a great variety in it landscape with many different biomes and different cities/ towns with their own culture that stand our from the rest. There are many different joinable factions that often have competing interest which naturally leads to inter faction conflict often not seen in other Elder Scrolls games. The rewards it has to offer are immense and the quests you go on to find such rewards often will be unique to you as the game does not hold your hand on where you go or how you choose to complete your objectives. I don't think I ever played another open world game with such intricate systems that ties so well together to make such a small world feel like a gigantic place with endless opportunity to have fun.

As a RPG, like the other elder scrolls games its very free form with how you build your character. Arguably the leveling is better than both of it successors as it allows for more free form build that due to the amount of skill that stress the traditional melee,magic, and stealth archetypes to where hybrid classes are very easy to create so every character you make feel unique. Since there is a fixed difficulty of the world, the game starts out pretty rough and you will die alot! However due to that fixed difficulty as you level you really feel like you character grows in power finding new weapons, armor, spells, etc feel like a genuine treat as it makes your journey that much easier and allows you to take on even more challenges. Morrowind is most beginner friendly to combat classes as it is relatively easier to level those skills. The games magic system is fantastic as there is so much freedom in how you can use magic to solve problems. Magic spells, enchanted items are an essential part of Morrowind and why it makes the game so special. Alchemy, enchanting and especially spell crafting are amazing tools that make nearly solve any problem if you are creative enough and it rewards players who pay attention to the games systems. Stealth on other other I would say is the only thing that isn't changed much from other elder scrolls games. I would not recommend going stealth in your first play through as I found it to be harder to get into for first timers. 

Overall Morrowind is a rabbit hole that I preface by saying !CAUTION! you might get completely lost down as you sink hundreds of hours exploring the world and exploring the all possible character builds in one of the greatest RPGs of all time and one of the greatest open world RPGs. The game has aged like wine, and provides an incredible contrast to many modern open world that sacrifice so much for convenience and streamlining that they lose something along the way. And that is a strong sense of almost childlike mystery to the world, begging to be explored and making you feel that  your adventures feel truly like that; an adventure, personal to you and not having your hand held like in other open world games that feel like a trip to Disneyland.

Morrowind is the last unfiltered Elder Scrolls experience. This game does so many things better than others in the series while requiring players to read and understand the world they're in to progress. I love each Elder Scrolls game for different reasons, but Morrowind is special. Quests are not guided by markers, instead you have a detailed journal which gets updated with automatic notes. These notes give a general path to proceed and require you to be engaged with the story. The inventory/spell/equipment menu is better and more responsive than any other Elder Scrolls game which in my opinion became clunkier slow (without the assistance of mods). You can open your map, inventory, spell menu, and equipment, all just by right clicking and everything is intractable and movable. 

Morrowind doesn't give care if you're the main character or on a quest. If you're exploring and piss off a Daedra by saying something they don't like one might cancel dialogue with you by saying "After I kill you, I will r*pe your corpse. Don't worry, I'll be gentle.", and then proceed to spawn a corpus beat and beating you in the face with a Daedric axe. 

The main story of Morrowind is intense. You are the Nerevarine, a subject of the local Ashlander prophecy which is destined to kill Dagoth Ur, who is corrupting the minds of the people in Morrowind. As you progress through the story more and more corrupted Dark Elves start getting afflicated. You are commission by a member of The Blades to stop this threat.

The biggest complaint, mostly due to it being the first problem everybody experiences, is attacks and hits missing. Even if you're standing right in front of an enemy, with a low skill your attacks might miss, which can be incredibly frustrating for a new player. This obviously gets better and better as you level up but I can completely understand why a new player might think the game is buggy or broken from this experience.

The coolest part of Morrowind is it is the only Elder Scrolls game to have truly 3D game play. This game features levitation which even becomes a requirement to complete the main quest. The Telvanni wizards live in tall fungi towers, and as they're wizards you can only explore the hallways by levitating up. This translates into the rest of the world through caves, dungeons, and other towns. After you master a levitation spell or have an enchanted item you can fly around a city or volcano to find your destination.

Morrowind GOTY includes two DLC's, Bloodmoon and Tribunal. Fans of Skyrim will recognize Bloodmoon as it's Solstheim (Dragonborn DLC). I won't detail too much, but you're able to build the city of Raven Rock which you visit in Skyrim with the assistance of the East Empire Trading Company. Both of the DLC's add a ton of value to the game and are full of interesting lore and decisions. I can't get into the details of Tribunal without spoiling too much, however you gain access to two cities which includes a intricate sewer system. You're able to engage with the Dark Brotherhood, Tribunal Temple, and Gods themselves.

The guilds in Morrowind are done perfectly. They require specific tasks relevant to the guild and in order to receive a promotion your skills in the related areas must be met. In Morrowind, you won't become the Archmage unless you are an actual master mage. This is the same for the Thieves & Fighter's Guild. A unique part of Morrowind is the Morag Tong. The Tong are an assassination guild which operate within the law of Morrowind as they have 'writs' which allow them to legally execute people. This guild is by far the most interesting because even if caught by a guard, displaying your writ allows you to freely walk away. Another unique group in Morrowind is the Temple.

Similar to Guilds, Morrowind features "Houses", which each have their own intricate story lines. Each House has their own style of operating, ranging from political warriors to homicidal rogue wizards who live in desolate fungus towers. You can choose whichever you wish to join and can gain rank and prestige. Each house also includes a compound you can build from the ground up which operates as a base.

Magic in Morrowind is better than any other game in the series. The amount of spells you can use is incredible. There's simple stuff like mark/recall, where you can instantly teleport back to any point in the game you set, and conjuration where you can summon a huge variety of creatures. This includes enchanting as well, as you can associate spells to items and utilize this same spell list. Every magic related mod I've found for Oblivion/Skyrim is just trying to achieve what vanilla Morrowind offered.

Equipment in Morrowind is once again the best of any Elder Scrolls game. You can wear layers of equipment which offers a huge array of loadouts. You can wear a shirt/pants, put armor on top of this, and then wear a robe over all of this. Armor is split into pieces: helmet, shoulders (left and right), hands (left and right), chest, waist, legs, boots (left/right). You can also wear two rings and a necklace. So in Morrowind you can wear 16 pieces of equipment at once, all with their own unique enchantments. This doesn't include weapons or shields. 

-----

Mod set-up for Morrowind in 2023: MOISE by ForgottenGlory is the best way to play Morrowind. With the creation of 'Wabbajack', installation of MOISE is incredibly easy and automated. This total overhaul does everything you need. It'll update graphics, fix bugs, and make the game stable and perform smoothly on a modern PC. It remains true to the vanilla experience.

- Wabbajack website: https://www.wabbajack.org/
- MOISE Mod Website: https://www.fgsmodlists.com/docs/moise/
- Installation instructions: https://www.fgsmodlists.com/docs/moise/installation-guide/readme/

Message me on Steam if you need help installing it.

Is this game dated? Yes. Does it look its age? Also yes. Is it the best Roleplaying Game made this century? Absolutely. Oblivion and Skyrim have nothing on the Morrowind experience. Unlike Skyrim, there are many, many ways to play this game (other than stealth archer). Unlike Oblivion, your choices actually matter. Joining one faction might actually lock you out of another.

Pros of this game compared to other Elder Scrolls games:
- 3 armor classes (light, medium, heavy)
- wear clothing underneath, robes over armor (so many equipment slots!)
- more than 3 weapon classes (blade, axe, blunt, marksman, and spear - yes, this game has *spears*, aka the most commonly used weapon across all of human history, across the globe)
- you can ascend to divine status in power (become literally unkillable or invest all your points in strength so that the moment you hit someone your sword actually breaks on their skull)

Cons of this game compared to other Elder Scrolls games:
- you need a brain to play it (no map markers, you actually have to *read* journal entries)
- cliff racers

Buy this game. Play this game. Fall in love with this game.

Mods are available.

This is one of my favorite games in the history of video games. It was the first of its kind, an expansive, entirely hand-crafted, open-world RPG, crammed full of lore, customization, and freedom. Vanilla edition is still playable, though those days are behind me. The modding community has kept this incomparable title relevant, with (much-appreciated) quality of life mods, extremely well-made expansion content, graphic upgrades, and tweaks or original content that make existing elements deeper and more immersive. 

I've had an excellent experience using NexusMods and Vortex to manage mods for Morrowind. The most essential mods for me include: Morrowind Script Extender; Perfect Placement;  MGE XE; Tamriel Rebuilt; a couple of code patches; Move or Take My Place; Graphic Herbalism; some original content expansions; and a good deal of cosmetic mods. If you search for the most popular mods of all time in NexusMods, it will be easy to see what the essentials are. Just be sure to read the instructions for each of them -- especialy MGE XE!

I'm not going to fawn over it like some fans do, I'll shoot it to you straight: This game is not for everyone. The combat is dated and clunky, even more so than Oblivion, The game does not tell you much: It has no quest markers; you have to look for clues yourself and think a little harder. If a quest tells you to go to a cave, your journal will say "Its so far north of Such and Such town, over to the bridge, turn southwest and head into the hills." And you'll have to go looking, which is only made more arduous because running (which isn't that fast to begin with) costs fatigue, which you need to save for a fight.

All in all though, if those are pains you think you can deal with, there is no better game for you than Morrowind. The world is more immersive and deep than any other Elder Scrolls title by far, and you will enjoy the time spent in this world, with the unique creatures, characters, and stories. Welcome to Vvardenfell!

Amazing game! I’ve played it for four years now and still haven’t done everything! (And I very rarely play other games in between) Some would say that the graphics and glitches ruin it, but if you save often and over multiple files, it’s not that bad. If you have a choice over buying the original game or the game of the year edition, I don’t care how much more the GotY costs, get it! It has so much more you can do! 

Edit: You DO NOT need mods. I’ve seen multiple people say that, but it honestly is not true it is quite easy enough without them. Yes, combat can be excessively frustrating and stupid at times, but all it takes is practice or money. (Which is easy to get if you have a few invisibility potions or the Moonshadow ability; use it and loot the treasuries in Vivec. You could also sell items to the museum, steal them back, and sell them again to the Mudcrab Merchant.) One of the early East Empire Company quests requires an unexpected skill in hand to hand. Most people seem to think that you have to spend thousands of septims to train this skill just to proceed with the quest. HOWEVER, most, if not all, factions have hand to hand trainers, and you only need about 20 skill level. Also, if you’re a vet and are just looking at these reviews for fun, try being a khajit with a hand to hand major skill. It’s quite fun. Even if you don’t like the genre, give it a shot! If you follow the main quest right off the bat, it gets boring fast. Try something else for a while, like the thieves guild, and save the main quest for later when you’ve got better gear. And start jump running. If you’re  stuck on a quest, try UESP or The Elder Scrolls Fandom

Morrowind is a game that I know is sh!t, but I love it anyway. It´s an opaque pile of clunk that wards away any potential enjoyers by carefully making all of its gameplay mechanics just barely ridiculous enough that they seem totally unfair and arbitrary.

Never being able to hit anyone even when they´re standing right in front of you? Having to walk (literally walk) everywhere? Getting your strength sapped until you just straight up permanently can´t move? Getting attacked by a guy with a dagger that paralyzes you for 5 seconds per hit? There´s plenty of bullshit in the game, but the true goal of Morrowind is this:

Don´t complain about the bullshit. Embrace the bullshit, learn how your enemy shamefully fucks you over, then copy their strategies, develop them, and learn the art of using a spell to permanently lock an enemy in place, stand 2 meters away from them and mercilessly poke them in the face with your spear while they swing their 1 meter long sword at you in vain. Embrace the subtle intricacies of stacking 5 different weaknesses onto one enemy and doing like 8000 damage in one hit. Study the ways of alcoholism to reach levels of power so great that you can hit an enemy so hard, both he and your weapon will explode.

Ultimately, the more you learn about the mechanics, the more you learn how to break them, and that is basically how to play Morrowind.

Some people would have you believe this game is for 150+ IQ gentlemen, but who it´s really for is persistent dumbasses who will keep trying until they learn how to absolutely bend the game over their knee one day.

In summary, this game is fun eventually.

Is it the best game of all time? Debatable. Nothing will ever feel as foreign, open, weird, unexpected, or original again. Skyrim's a better game, better combat, but nothing compares to Morrowind. 

The game isn't just buggy, it presents a different kind of ethical gameplay system in INTERPRETING it's bugs. Was this intentional? Did the developers mean for you to push this or that? Can you avoid the temptation to cheat when it's simply so easy? Interpreting the game's systems intent and trying to stay in the intended limits of the game is the most rewarding experience to me but even then, I'd love to lock Todd Howard in a room and ask him if they really wanted me to achieve 100% CE reflect armor, get variable but permanent strength bonuses, farm golden saint souls, have my merchantile LOWER the sell price yet make money trivial by simply buying and selling the same items. Did they mean for armorer hammers to restock on vendors based on how many I SOLD them, not how many they started with? 

The graphics can be brought up to roughly oblivion level (which to me means never wanting to play oblivion again) but you have to be real careful with your mods. What's a "fix" and what ruins some ingame system's possibilities is a fine line. Sometimes I feel the original experience is more valuable, sometimes I long for the massively expanded world of tamriel rebuilt (biggest game mod ever made for any game, no question). 

Maybe it's unapproachable, maybe it's beyond old, or maybe it's the best game ever made. At least try it and decide for yourself.

Oh Morrowind, where do I start...

No other game has managed to alienate and entice as much at the same time, coming from modern "RPG"s, the first 15 hours of the game feel purpose built to frustrate and alienate the inexperienced, in what other game are you expected to explore a vast over-world map with a "running" speed slower than cycling uphill? Or punished so brutally for a poor character build that countless would-be fans quit after dying to a Mudcrab right outside the starting zone, even once you've got your character built in order, and yet, those who make it past those tedious first hours and rewarded with one of the most immersive and richest role-playing games to date.

Being the first role-playing game I ever experienced, Oblivion holds a special place in my heart, and in many ways it's an inversion of Morrowind's mechanics and design philosophies, Morrowind doesn't have quest markers or particularly subversive narratives, because the game designers intended for the exploration to be part of each quest, Oblivion did away with hit failure chance and replaced it with damage (which scales with the difficulty slider) because the designers wanted even the worst builds to still stand a chance, Morrowind was set in the alien Vvardenfell and spent a great deal of its efforts on world building and it's thoroughly detailed factions, whereas Oblivion was set in the familiar Cyrodil and did away with the naunces for simpler, yet recognizable archetypes. The end result? Morrowind is a game that baffles newcomers but breeds obsession in veterans, Oblivion is a game that fascinates newcomers but is utterly idiotic to veterans. 

I think this is why so many Morrowind "elitists" exist, and so many embittered Oblivion/Skyrim fans fail to get into this game. I don't blame them, Morrowind is an enthralling game that is overshadowed by the mechanically absurd Oblivion, and completely shrouded by the laughably shallow Skyrim because at the end of the day, Morrowind just isn't fit for the modern RPG audience, and despite that, I don't think there is a single thing wrong with Morrowind's mechanics, hit chance, spell failure, no map markers, slow walking speed and no fast travel is genius once you figure out how it all fits together, and just how much was lost in the transition to Oblivion. 

Despite this, if you've tried and failed time and time again, then it's okay to use console commands to raise your speed attribute, and it's okay to occasionally use the wiki if you're lost, as your understanding of the game's mechanics improve, you'll eventually learn how to work these systems in your favour, and you'll be off to enjoying the greatest Elder Scrolls game that will ever be made.

I wish that as well as a thumbs up and down for steam reviews you could give a noncommittal, shaky wave. This game an absolutely repellent, frustrating, obtuse mess with dire gameplay (especially at the start), and it took me years and 4 attempted playthroughs to decide it was worth my time and commit to a full playthrough. When I did though, I got into it very much and I didn't realise I had put over 100 hours into it until today; it was like Stockholm syndrome. As much as I feel like the game hates me for having the audacity of playing it sometimes, it is very fun, and exploring the various areas and missions is interesting for the most part. The loot progression feels satisfying too, you can eventually become godlike to match your jesusy prophecy, especially if you abuse the alchemy system which is incredibly easy and something I absolutely did.

However it didn't even help that much towards the end and especially the DLCs which have horribly balanced enemies. Speaking of horribly balanced enemies! Every wizard you meet in this game, if they are an enemy, spawns a zombie at you immediately which has an attack that drains your strength, which effects your carry weight, and when you get hit enough you are essentially just pinned in place, and if you're not psychic enough to have brought potions of restore strength, you're fucked. You need to load a save. This is one of the most god fucking awful design choices I have ever seen in a game and if critics at the time had run into this then bethesda would not exist today, but I digress. I did have a great deal of fun with morrowind, and I beat it and its DLCs (why is solstheim just a huge flat plane with like 2 interesting things?) AND its thrown together guild quests (like the majority of the morag tong, fighter's guild, and temple quests are just "GO HERE - KILL HIM" deals, a thing people praise this game for but shit on fallout 4 for which I'll never understand). 

All in all I'd say this is a bad game with good qualities, it does not hold up to today's standards and you need to mod it a bit to get it to run on modern hardware properly, and when you do get it working the gameplay is 80% slowly trudging from place to place. If you're looking to get into the elder scrolls series and somehow haven't played skyrim yet, get that instead, it's objectively the better game in every aspect (as much as the weirdos that champion this game would try to convince you otherwise, they're blinkered by nostalgia, pay them no heed.) but do pick this up on a heavy sale when you can because once you get into it and I mean REALLY into it there's fun to be had, you just need to try and get blood from a stone, so to speak.

I've actually been using OpenMW to play Morrowind so the play time listed is probably inaccurate, closer to 100 hours+ in reality. This game, if you can get past the dice rolling for hits, is really fun and easy to cheese with things like blinding speed, but also immersive in a way Oblivion just wasn't for me. 

I'd say in the elder scrolls series Skyrim came closest to capturing just the feeling of immersion and escapism, because both Skyrim and Morrowind somewhat and especially for Morrowind depart from Oblivion's standard fantasy feel, though I will say that Oblivion is at the very least unintentionally funny, and its writing is definitely superior to Skyrim's, but its ambience just can't match that of Skyrim and Morrowind.

Overall personally a 10/10, not for everyone though there are mods that remove dice rolling for hits if you prefer modern combat, I'm personally fine with the dice rolls.

The province of Morrowind is one of the strangest and most alien-feeling places in gaming, while also being completely believable as a real place due to excellent execution.

The gameplay and progression are a complete circus where you can put paralysis on your weapon, which freezes your enemy in place, letting you hit them again and reapply it before it wears off. Or you can just use magic which deflects all physical attacks. The only catch being, the enemies can do all of that as well. I was once attacked by a low level bandit with a dagger which paralyzed me, so I could do nothing as he hit me again and again, reapplying the paralysis each time. It took him about a minute to kill me, and I couldn't do anything at all. When I reloaded my save, I managed to get the first hit in, so I could do this exact same thing to him. This is a good thing.

When I bought this game back in 2002, it was a frustrating experience and a disappointment for any TES fan who played Arena and Daggerfall.

Luckily, the game included a wonderful piece of software: The Elder Scroll Construction Set, thus within a few years of heavy modding, the game became playable.

If you are going to play TES III today, I would recommend at the very least the following mods:
- Morrowind Patch Project (MPP) - tons of bug fixes.
- Morrowind Code Patch (MCP) - unless you like your games to hang randomly.
- MGE XE - so you can play at 1920x1080 or higher resolutions.
- Living Cities of Vvanderfell - puts the "I" in "AI".
- Herbalism - makes resource gathering interesting.
- Speed and Stamina or Run Faster - the original walking/running speed is just too bloody slow.
- Better Dialogue Font - you want this if you use MCP/MGE XE.

So [i]after all the modding[/i], this is what you can expect:
[b]PROs:[/b]
[list]
[*]Open-ended: ignore the boring plot and do whatever you want! You can explore the world, join factions, be a mercenary, a burglar, an alchemist, a merchant, whatever really. Play the way you want.
[*]You can build your own class, mix and match skills, racial abilities and so on. Play the character you want.
[*]No hand-olding, no babysitting. Finally an RPG where you don't spend most of the time following a bloody arrow or looking for the guy with an icon over its head. The map isn't already explored for you, the journal is not a list of quests and objectives, but rather a list of notes and clues.
[*]With all mods and expansions, the world is really huge and varied. Jungles, rocky mountains, icy islands, misty forests and more!
[*]Dungeons are really well crafted.
[*]The athmospheric music keeps you in the right mood.
[*]Even though the graphics are dated, visuals are still pretty good.
[/list]
[b]CONs:[/b]
[list]
[*]Despite the mods, many NPCs still are unblinking statues who are either bolted down or walking in circles all the bloody time. This is a step backwards from Daggerfall, and especially annoying if you are playing a thief. Suppose you break into a shop in the dark of night, anticipating the riches you will find in all those locked, unattended chests and... instead you find the shopkeeper there at the counter. Motionless. Unblinking. Running his business 24/7 (better than a Tesco Extra!).
[*]The plot is trite and boring. You are the chosen one and must save the world. Again. The world just can't stay saved for a while. Do yourself a favour: ignore all that rubbish and go exploring, or join a faction, or anything else.
[/list]

an absolute gem of an RPG, gives you a LOT of freedom.
wanna make a nuke spell that deals 100 damage every second for 10 seconds? you can.
wanna utterly break the game by stacking potions? you can.
wanna kill every NPC in the game? you can, hell, you can complete the main quest if you kill most important NPCs except for one. i managed to become the leader of a house by killing the other members and proclaiming myself as the leader.
the game rewards you for exploring dangerous areas, you can get near end-game armor at level 1 if you rush to certain dungeons.
if you find a way to cheese an enemy without breaking the game you should do it, because the game won't hold back and if the enemy can, they WILL stunlock you with a sword of paralysis that lasts 10 seconds and keeps re-applying every hit.
this is the only game in TES games that made me want to read the books that were in libraries and sold in-game because the lore got me hooked.
now for the people who don't like the dice roll mechanic, there are mods that make every hit land(it kinda makes the game easy so try to adjust the difficulty a bit higher), i also recommend installing morrowind graphics extender too(not necessary if you use openmw), morrowind code patch and fair magicka regen.
other than that if you are a new player i advice you, read, if you want to not miss as much make sure your desired weapon/spell skill is leveled up fairly enough(40 is good, you can get this much in the character creation with by choosing it in major skills) and for pure melee players when you level up try to get +5 agility each level up and in no time you will barely miss any attacks, and last but not least, GET A RESTORE STRENGTH SPELL/STACK UP ON RESTORE STRENGTH POTIONS, you will know why when it happens, i don't want you to go through my pain.

I have played Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim and out of all three, I have always preferred Morrowind, by a longshot. It is older, and the graphics are not great, but the story is way better, and more satisfying on completion. Everything is more challenging and takes more time, and, no fast travel being present, (excepting boats, siltstriders and mage guilds) you may get bored of walking the same paths multiple times. 
However, as a whole, Morowind gives a great feeling of adventuring, a great feeling of character building and a great feeling of heroism!
I highly recommend it!
(I also recommend doing the two expansion quests, Bloodmoon and Tribunal, before doing the bulk of the main quest. You get better equipment and better skills and in the long run, makes things slightly easier).

I'm not going to pretend that nostalgia doesn't influence my rating. I remember going to Wal-mart as a teenager and buying this game from the $10 PC games section after my best friend showed it to me. Our home computer couldn't run it yet (didn't know that when I bought it) so my brother and I saved up for a new video card that would allow us to play. I was so excited when the video card showed up.

The world was massive and so much fun to explore. Discovering rare artifacts like "The Boots of the Apostle" or "The Sword of White Woe" was a highlight of my play experience.

Playing the game now, it feels very dated. But I still really enjoy it. My favorite way to play the game as an adult is to create a character and give myself rules for how that character would act. I'm currently playing an "honest" Nord that won't kill (unless provoked) or steal. It forces me to change up the way I normally "exploit" my own knowledge of the game when making a new character.

And the game can be easily exploited. It feels like cheating when you understand how the mechanics work and where to find all the good loot. Creating rules for myself as I play (to avoid exploiting the game a bunch) has helped me enjoy the game again. I've even discovered a love for questing (one I didn't have at all when I played it as a teenager).

I love this game in spite of its flaws and I think I always will.
still the best elder scrolls game.

Morrowind is an amazing game, but not the most welcoming one to new players. Below is a list of a few tips I've put together to help new players get the most out of the game.

1. [u] OpenMW  [/u]

OpenMW is an open source port of Morrowind that fixes game-breaking bugs, adds additional graphics options, and in general improves the stability of the game while being incredibly easy to set up and use. 

Whether you're playing vanilla (which you should for your first play through) or modded, there's not much reason not to use it unless you're a vanilla purist or something.

2. [u] Don't be afraid to experiment with making new characters. [/u]

Morrowinds tutorial can be finished in just a few minutes, so if you make a character and you're not enjoying the race or class you've chosen, you can quickly make a new one until you find something you enjoy.

I would also recommend not using any of the default classes and just making your own, don't put skills you're not going to use in your major skills, that's advice for experienced players to min-max.

Also, do NOT take the iron dagger unless you're going to sell it. It's a trap that makes people think the combat sucks when they put long blade in their major skills and wonder why they miss with a short blade. If you do make a short blade build, you can buy an iron short sword in the starting town store that outclasses it in every way.

3. [u] Beast Races. [/u]

Beast races work very differently in Morrowind than they do in Oblivion or Skyrim. They can't wear closed face helmets or any kind of footwear, and are naturally disliked by most of the other races. 

While these aren't issues late game players have to worry about, new players may want to avoid them as they can make the early game more difficult.

4. [u] Early on you will miss a lot of your attacks. [/u]

Hit chance in Morrowind is affected by primarily two things your characters skill with the weapon and your fatigue. You shouldn't run into a fight exhausted swinging a weapon your character has no knowledge of how to use, and wonder why you can't hit anything. 

Later on, when your skill with a weapon type gets in the 50 to 75 range, you'll be landing most of your hits at high stamina.

If you play a mage, you don't have to worry about hit chance, but instead spell cast chance. If you choose any of the magic schools for your major skills, you will start with a few basic spells related to that school of magic (alteration, for example, lets you start with water walking) with a near guaranteed chance to cast them.

5. [u] Learn to manage your fatigue. [/u]

Unlike Oblivion (where fatigue mainly influences melee damage) and Skyrim (where stamina is only used for power attacks and sprinting), fatigue in Morrowind affects basically everything you do. Such as your chance to cast spells, chance to hit, ability to talk to people, and even your jump height. 

Early game, you should always be careful to manage your fatigue while exploring if you think a fight might be coming up, and carry a few potions to restore it during fights. Late game players can create constant effect enchantments to restore fatigue even while running and jumping.

6. [u] There are a lot of ways to get around Vvardenfell. [/u]

If you've played the later Elder Scrolls games (or most other modern RPGs) you're probably familiar with fast travel systems, and you've probably also heard that Morrowind has no fast travel systems, which isn't entirely true. While the game has no map screen to point and click to where you want to instantly travel, there are a lot of other ways to get around. 

Silt Striders can take you to most of the major cities on the map; boats can take you to most of the islands around Vvardenfell, and the mages guild provides teleportation services to all of their guild halls.

Then there are the mark and recall spells that allow you to mark a location and teleport to it at will, and the spells and scrolls for Almsivi Intervention and Divine Intervention (both of which you can buy in the Seyda Neen general store early on) that instantly teleport you to the nearest Tribunal temple and Imperial chapel respectively.

7. [u] Getting lost isn't always a bad thing. [/u]

At some point in Morrowind every player will end up getting lost, whether it be due to the odd vague directions or just being stuck in the wilderness without an easy way back to a town. This can be frustrating, but most people can agree they've experienced the adventure that this usually brings. 

As an example, in my most recent playthrough I took a Fighters Guild job early on to help someone clear a Dwemer ruin in the Molag Mar region. I somehow got lost and ended up walking into a Dwemer ruin that was home to a powerful vampire clan. After lots of running away to rest, dying multiple times and barely managing to beat the vampires, I searched the ruins to find one of the two pairs of daedric boots, the best heavy armor in the game.

This is something I chose as an example of the game's systems working together to provide an honest adventure completely independent of the developers design. If this was Oblivion or Skyrim, I wouldn't have gotten lost because I always have a map marker pointing to exactly where I should go. I wouldn't have had to explore, and I wouldn't have mistakenly stumbled into that ruin.

8. [u] Don't be afraid to break the games balance. [/u]

Sometime near the end of the game you'll get to the point were you end up 2-shotting most enemies you come across and you won't be challenged by much apart from literal gods, a daedric prince, and the odd werewolf maze. But I don't see this as a flaw of the game that needed to be desperately fixed like it was in the later games. Besides, if you think it's getting too easy, you can always move the difficulty slider across a bit (even if it gives me PTSD because it reminds me of Oblivion's level scaling).

To me, Morrowind is almost asking for creative players to take advantage of all its systems in unpredictable ways to break the game in two. Like using a 1 second levitate on target spell to instantly make Cliff Racers fall to their death, or creating a 100-point fury spell that gives me the legal right to murder anyone I want for, you know, general use. 

My favorite is enchanting armor with constant effect shock damage on self, which I then sell to merchants who equip it because of its high value and instantly die, allowing me to take everything in their store.

[u] The End. [/u]

That's it. I was listening to Young Scrolls while writing this. I only really wrote all this because I adore Morrowind and wanted an excuse to give it a positive review.

I'll see you on the next Angry Joe show (does he still say that?)

imma start out by saying; this game is old, and shows its age. there are a lot of mechanics that exist because they were developed at a point before people knew how to make open-world RPGs, and some of them have aged poorly. despite that, morrowind is worth a try. In terms of world and quest design it's one of the best emulations of tabletop RPGs in a video game that has ever been done. the world is full of secrets and rewards you for exploring every nook and cranny. almost every location has something unique to offer if you fully explore it, and the world is so dense with locations that you don't have to go far to find something worthwhile.

my advice for being able to enjoy morrowind: before you start, go through the controls and change them to something more familiar, then install the unofficial code patch. once you start, make sure to pick a weapon type and stick with it. remember that your hit chance is tied to stamina, so always enter combat with a full bar and always keep stamina potions on you. that's all there is

Being a Skyrim player, my first experience playing Morrowind was quite sour, as you can imagine. But, upon really trying to learn the game and understand it's mechanics, I was shocked to find a vast, bountiful world, full of adventure and woe. Morrowind is a brilliantly written game, that awed me with just how well thought out the people, places, factions, and world as a whole is. The ideas in Morrowind feel real, unlike later games. "Now now" I hear you say "Morrowind is OLD, and BAD, and SLOW, SOOOOOO SLOW". And while I should tell you to lower your voice, instead I will say that Morrowind is an acquired taste, like club soda, or caviar. It can be a very unpleasant experience at first, but, if you really try to understand the game you will be entranced and enchanted by the charm and thought put into this game. If you are thinking about buying Morrowind, I would have to recommend it without a doubt. It my take you awhile to learn it, but o boy is it worth it. Hlaalu good, Redoran bad.

I love this game; modded, it's a blast. The "soul trap" glitch, i enjoy so much, that I'm by all means horrible at this game. But the "soul trap" glitch makes me so strong that I just do as I please with this game and i love it. It's called the soul trap glitch but in reality any 1 pt target spell without an area of affect will work. Basically, in the spellmaker, if you attach any spell to a 1 pt target spell (without area of affect,) and aim for either the ground, or a wall, the other spell besides the target spell will become a permanent effect. Just dont hit an NPC with it. With the fortify attributes spell you can fortify any attribute to the thousands, and effectively faceroll the entire game. 

This game feels like it made to be exploited. I'm sad openMW doesnt include the soul trap glitch, but I guess that makes sense: it's not an intended feature. 

You can also fortify skills. For a while I would fortify personality permanently to anything greater than 2,000, but that would cause hostile NPC's to not attack. So I decided to leave fortify personality (with the help of Morrowind Code Patch) to a single, fortify personality 2000 for 1 second spell, which allows me to control when I need that personality boost. But the same could be achieved by using the 'fortify skill' spell to fortify your mercantile to over 400, i believe.

The Morrowind Code Patch also allows you to make spells stronger than 100 magnitude, up to 500 magnitude. Making a 500 magnitude levitation spell allows me to zip across the map, at what feels like faster than sound.

Anyway, lots of fun to be had with this game. That's not to mention the modding, which i found simple to get into. This game has so much replayability, it's awesome! Alright, take care :)

people complaining about the "alchemy loop" are just idiots. make a few strong potions and keep them for later if you enchant (which you will eventually). people complain that enchanting fails repeatedly even at mid and high levels. the answer to this is to make at least 3 items enchanted with fortify intelligence 100 for 3, 4, or 5 seconds and (preferably) have a spell with fortify intelligence 100 for 2 seconds. cast all items, cast the spell last and then menu. most useful enchantments excluding constant effects will easily be done this way even with enchant skill ~35.

Ok, guys. It's hard to write a short review on Morrowind because the game is iconic, legendary and it's been so many years it was released.

Pros.:
- Interesting story. It has many details, names, characters. And the twist that the protagonist is becoming the prophetic figure. For the time, it was a very smart decision to justify why the protagonist is cool, getting stronger and finally fights the antagonist.
- The world. It looks dull and boring. But Morrowind has interesting backstory, many characters for interaction, nice locations.
- There is a variety of paths to play the game. Also, Tribunal may be interesting as well as Bloodmoon. They expand the story.
- Main theme is legendary.
- Memes based on the game are awesome.

Basically, the coolest thing of the game is the story and world building. 

Cons.:
- The game is VERY outdated. The pace is slow, too much grind, the game literally forces you to grind, finish many alternative quest lines to actually do something in the main one. The Fifth and Fourth trials are trash - all that running around with stupid quests and begging to be named Nerevarin...
- Upgrading and lvl systems are trash too - you start the game jumping all the time to boost the skill. You have an alternative of training but it is costly. Need more money from the quests. Main quest line money making is unreasonably low. So, you HAVE to go around and finish as much as you can do.
- No fast travel. People tell - you need to explore the island. Screw the island - the huge chunk of it is just dusty, ugly ashlands. Bethesda did right when switched to fast travel (that I highly criticized for years).
- Too many boring quests. Dumb bring-take.
- The character is very slow regardless of your 100 speed.

There are more cons. The game is just outdated with its expansions. Better to play Skywind (when and if it's released) which should be adapted for the modern standards. This game is AWESOME and it WAS awesome. But its time passed long time ago. And for those, who remember playing it being 14-16 - too late guys. Cant waste that much time for the game.
This game takes me back to be a young kid on my desktop playing for hours.

It has been said before, but Morrowind offers an experience unlike any other. The world-building is, in a word, genius. Its unworldly yet familiar atmosphere blends fantasy, sci-fi, and metaphysical mysticism into an utterly enthralling game world. The depth and complexity to its world are both unrivaled. 

As for RPG elements, Morrowind is still the supreme example across the RPG genre. The sense of progression and the reward of learning the game, both mechanically and literally, is just unrivaled anywhere else. Your growth feels organic and compelling: you arrive in Morrowind an ignorant and sluggish foreigner. It is difficult to even move around. However, after a hard learning process, you become intimately familiar with the land around you. You learn its geography, you move more gracefully, and you are able to utter divine mantras to teleport at will. 

The mystique and wonder of this game, the idea that anything could await you at the bottom of that tomb or dungeon, is possible because it truly was a labor of love. Rather than holding your hand, Morrowind explains how its game world works through NPC dialogue, in-game books, and subtextual story-telling. What you do with it determines what you get out of the game. The unleveled world and hand-placed loot and enemies keeps the world exciting and dangerous. 

You can be whatever you want to be in this game and it will take your mind to places you never imagined. It is slow to get into, but that's for a good reason. The failed incarnations of the Nerevarine who gave up or died are the players who were unable to meet the challenge Morrowind demanded from them. I will never forget the day I entered the cave of the Nerevarine and connected the dots: all of the bad reviews are one of the ghosts in that cave. They are players who failed and who will never understand.

In the Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, you play as Bethesda employee Michael Kirkbride as he attempts to keep himself awake for 2 weeks, in order to write all of the game’s lore. On your journey , you will:

- Fail to stab a worm
- Eventually succeed in stabbing a worm
- Move at the pace of said worm to your various destinations
- Meet Caius Brosades, the most attractive person on nirn since Lamae Beolfag (at least, according to Molag Bal)
- Take part in the Lego Movie’s funniest joke
- Rob a jewellery store of its cool space ring and defile some corpses (at the same time!)
- Create potions so powerful that you can vanquish any foe almost immediately
- Still get insulted by every man, mer and beast under the sun for being too weak.
- Perform sexual favours for your higher ups, in order to rise the ranks in your company. Based on real life Activision policy.
- Catch rabies from an elephant priest
- Usurp the godhead
- Not really that last one. it would be cool though, right?
- Achieve CHIM every time you die apparently
- Meet the God-King of Ukraine, Vivisection
- Have rape threats made against you. That is not a joke it can actually happen in game what the fuck.

It may be old, but it still maintains its charm 20 long years later. If you're more accustomed to newer-generation games, then there might be a few mods you'd have to install to play comfortably. Nothing drastic, just a few things to scale the graphics for modern screens, a few bug-fixing packs, and maybe something to improve FPS and increase the view distance.

The soundtrack is absolutely magical, and I feel like this is the core component that helps you travel to Vvardenfell and feel as though you're part of something, despite the not-so-immersive graphics. The music is truly soothing when it needs to be, and while the combat music isn't quite as good, can certainly pump you up when it needs to.

The graphics... well, it's a 20-year-old game. I need not go over the technological revolutions and progress that have taken place since then. That being said, it was a big leap forward for its time, and I believe the way the world is designed holds up to this very day.

The worldbuilding is something else. The quests, the NPCs, the story... I truly think this is the peak of the Elder Scrolls, and I say this as someone who discovered the series with Skyrim, played Oblivion next, and finally tried out Morrowind last. You will be doing a lot of reading since most NPC dialogues aren't voiced, but the lore and creative direction make it worth it.

My only piece of advice is: Enjoy this game for what it is. Jump in, and prepare to immerse yourself in one of the greatest open-world RPGs ever made.

After playing, and loving, Skyrim, and not really liking Oblivion... Morrowind is a very different experience, almost peaceful, in a way. Unlike Skyrim and Oblivion, Morrowind takes an approach to combat similar to tabletop RPGs, where it's random. The atmosphere is very barren, and it really makes you feel like an outcast in an unknown land, as you have to explore around to discover the map. This game is a must-try, at the least. It made me realize that I took many modern game mechanics, like fast travel, for granted.

The depth of role-playing and character building in Morrowind is unmatched by any other Elder Scrolls game. If it's your first time playing, I highly recommend using OpenMW. It's a more stable engine, with a few QoL upgrades (like saves being sorted by character), whilst keeping the original experience in-tact.

Also understand that you live and die by your build. Many first time players pick up that little iron dagger in the census office, and are baffled to why they can't hit anything, when in Oblivion and Skyrim you could pretty much pick up anything you found. If you don't have Short Blade as a Major Skill, you WILL NOT hit anything with Short Blades; this applies for everything in the game. Your skill level is a representation, in role-playing terms, how efficient your character is at utilizing that skill. If you've never done public speaking or don't understand Vvardenfell economics, how will you cut a great deal? That's represented by a default level of 5. But if you've studied or have knowledge regarding those topics, that's also represented in a higher skill level of around 40-50.

Weaknesses in your character build create interesting problems that require you to think outside the box. You won't be struggling for durability with a combat specialization, but it comes at the cost of the many allures magic brings with it. Magic and stealth builds typically won't struggle with opening locks or traversal, due to levitation, teleportation and speed amplification spells, but combat specs will need to think about the options available to them. They can lightly dip their toes into magic as a major skill, so they have a bit of utility, or they can purchase scrolls as a gold sink alongside training. On the other side of the coin, magic builds need to think about how they're going to survive the early game, as mages are usually made of paper, and alchemy is usually a staple of such builds for the purpose of making gold to afford training and spell-making (easily the best mechanic in Morrowind). You're always planning, prepping and building your character's adventure, from the moment you start character creation to the moment you're assaulting Red Mountain to defeat Dagoth Ur. And it is utterly enthralling.

The Elder Scrolls is a strange series of games, as each consecutive game in the franchise slowly loses and bleeds features and design philosophies with each release. Morrowind lost things that Daggerfall fans loved, Oblivion stripped concepts that Morrowind players kept coming back for, and Skyrim took it further by being so wholly unrecognizable to even die-hard Oblivion enthusiasts. And inevitably, if the trend continues, Elder Scrolls VI will alienate the Skyrim audience by further eradicating any semblance of "Role-playing" in an "RPG". None of these games are bad games by any stretch of the imagination. Dated, perhaps, but the philosophies are sound. But it just goes to show there's an untapped market for people craving a genuine sequel to Daggerfall, or Morrowind, or Oblivion, with the design elements refined, focused and improved in modern engines, instead of throwing out ideas from game to game.

Coming from someone who didn't play this when it came out, it did not age nearly as well as other games from the early 2000's. Pretty much everything feels tedious and unrewarding.

- You walk to a quest location since you can't fast travel quickly near it
- You choose to walk VERY slowly or sprint (also slowly), which depletes your stamina, now your character is useless since the chance to succeed on ANYTHING (hitting, casting, talking...) is governed by stamina (wtf)
- You fight enemies on the way, mana does not regen after you cast spells
- Now out of mana and stamina
- Try to walk away from enemies since you can't rest but also can't fight without mana or stamina
- Rest finally
- Attacked on rest
- Use stamina/mana fighting it
- Rest again
- Success, I can keep walking
- Go into bland dungeon
- Fetch item
- Walk back, repeating the whole process of walking here
- Return fetched item
- Reward is 1 potion
- I only levelled acrobatics/athletics on the way, which doesn't progress my character, this entire process took 3 hours but my character and their items are the exact same as before

When I first started this playthrough I was like "this game sucks", but after 35 hours I'm convinced it's the best elder scrolls. It does a lot of things that should be standard in a lot of modern games.

Honestly can't recommend this game unless you purely care about reading books of lore and enjoying the atmosphere of the very cool world they created.

What's also great about Morrowind is you have a ton of possibilities in making unique spells and enchantments and it doesn't hold your hand which makes quests engaging and rewarding as you really need to pay attention.
Also it allows you to be genuinely evil if one so chooses, something later games took away in large part. You can sell a slave to a rich guy and save them, accept payment and leave, or even kill them both if you so chose. So many RP possibilities.

Story is interesting but takes a while to get going and quests are often boring fetch type stuff with no payoff. Takes forever to progress as well.

I painstakingly modded this game to be a bug free graphically enhanced vanilla experience, but the game-play is still just awful and indoor spaces are extremely generic and empty of interesting things, also copy and paste NPCs with nothing interesting to say make it frustrating trying to find unique dialogues and quests that aren't there. I understand how the gameplay system works with saving stamina, just isn't fun for me and always annoying.

So I cannot recommend this game unless you're a very specific type of person who wishes more so to read lore books the whole time, doesn't mind spending a lot of wasted time in a game grinding, and who can entertain themselves by making their own story rather than rely on the flood of generic quests, empty indoor spaces, and hoardes of copy and paste NPCs with nothing unique to say.

This was my first entry into TES. I know that some might immediately say "oh nostalgia painted glasses" however hear me out. This is by far currently the best TES game. Yes you can remove essential NPC flags from Oblivion and Skyrim however you can kill all the main characters in Morrowind and still BEAT THE GAME without cheats. Yes you have so much freedom that you can strong arm your way to rolling credits there is even a entire different quest line for those that want to walk the lands kicking butt the whole way through. Oblivion was the start of the downturn of TES because they installed "the bumpers on the side of the bowling lane". There is no quest markers pointing a carrot in the direction of your next quest. When you get told to go somewhere in Morrowind they will tell you "North of this village pass another village, a fort, go through a ravine, pass another fort, then turn west across the river into the city" like you would be told directions IRL. This leads you into a whole new world of discovery. The magic and enchanting in Morrowind in comparison to Oblivion and Skyrim is so much better that i cannot even think of a comparison to give justice to how much they gutted and watered down the system. Want to make a spell that lets you fly through the sky, while launching custom crafted magic missiles that explode into a 50 foot radius of Fetus Deletus in the form of omni damage you can. It won't be a cheap spell but that doesn't matter what matters is you have the freedom to do it. The lore this game has written in books is enough to make the Barnes & Nobles dwellers blush. Yes the graphics are outdated, and the combat is old school so you need to adjust to it you are right it is a old game, however that is what makes it a gem this game does not play like the shareholder endorsed cookie cut no child left behind coated watered down garbage that we have grown accustomed to be spoon fed. This gem was made before a bunch of old out of touch non gamers entered the meeting room with the dev's and said "these games are too hard, they are not casual enough for everyone we need to add the equivalent of a airport landing strip's light markers towards objectives, and these mechanics are too complicated we need to gut it out and give them a system so simple a 7 year old could use it". 

TLDR: The game is dirt cheap, and is probably the closest you will ever get to a D&D campaign you can play solo without a DM. Give it a try if you want to see what games where like before EA pooped on the whole market making games trash.

P.S.~ Look up "Morrowind Graphics Guide" to make everything look much better

It's hard to explain what about this game makes people aflame in nostalgia and praise. The combat isn't great. The AI can be predictable and prone to error. The landscape can be dull and unimaginative. And obviously the graphics are nothing to write home about. But somewhere under the archaic structure lies a gaming experience that the later games failed to capture; the adventure. While I believe that Oblivion and Skyrim made huge strides in areas that Morrowind falls flat on, because of the advent of instant fast travel and objective markers, the game broken down to its core is reduced to getting a quest, quick traveling to the nearest city, going to the quest marker, killing enemies or getting an item, quick traveling back to the quest giver, get loot, then find the next quest; albeit in more interesting settings. But in Morrowind, you are a detective. There are no arrows point you to your destination, you need to do the research to discover your destinations. You need to talk to people and learn what they know, do jobs for them to gain their favor, or bribe them for information. They tell you what directions to go, or where you might find what you are looking for; but never does an omniscient red arrow hold your hand and take you to your destination, save a rarely provided mark on the over world map. Need to find an artifact in a dungeon? You have to explore the dungeon for it. Quest giver wants a specific book? You have to track down the bookseller who has a copy. A riddle that reveals your destination? You have to solve the riddle, or find someone who can help translate it for you. It is a beautiful ballet of social interaction and adventuring. The skills in Morrowind were more varied and customizable as well. You could create your own unique spells that do a range of different things. You could enchant items with numerous different abilities. Armor pieces were individual so you could mix and match different rare armors and enchants. It was a more analog approach to creativity. Unfortunately because of it's era, while these mechanics are interesting, they are not pushed to their full capabilities due to the constraints of technology at the time. If there were to be a recreation of this style of Elder Scrolls game, where you do the leg work, you talk to the different people and learn their customs, you decipher maps and riddles and ancient books, you get access to tons of skills to be able to really make your character uniquely you; it would be a beautiful and immersive world worth revisiting many times just as people look back at Morrowind and sing it's praises still.

Slow to get going, but there's a lot of stories when you get there. Morrowind has a fairly slow starting to the game if you aren't familiar with it, but there's so much to do in this game, most Elder Scrolls Games are like this. Morrowind was the first Elder Scrolls game I ever played. It does have some elements that make it feel a bit outdated to fan of the more modern games, such as weapons having a hit chance and the fairly rigid animations of the characters. But it still has an incredible visual appeal. In my opinion Morrowind is just behind oblivion when it comes to the visuals and environments, Skyrim is phenomenal don't get me wrong, but Morrowind and Oblivion are visually stunning and feel much more like a fantasy, when you look at the worldspace. I've only beaten the game one time, never felt like I needed to again, but I was only able to do that on one of my later characters. If you don't know what you're doing during character creation you can make a character that is incredibly difficult to play, experimentation is what I did until I was able to find a character build that worked well for me. Playing with a pre-made class is doable, but you can also make a custom class that suits your own playstyle.

Honestly one of my favorite games of all time and tied with skyrim as my favorite ES game, the amount of intresting story and gameplay within morrowind would make Tolkien cry.

Due to my computer being dogshit, I gotta use OpenMW to make the game run good and to fix a few bugs in the game, i would highly recommend using openmw as the base game is buggy as fuck, the usual with bethesda.

Morrowind was my 3rd ever elder scrolls game after Skyrim and Oblivion, and Morrowind always sticks out in terms of its mechanics. (not being able to hit anything.) and the level system doesn't feel too cheesy like in skyrim.

The only reason skyrim comes close to Morrowind in terms of personal enjoyment is its storytelling, while Morrowind has a deeper lore, skyrims is told much more fluidly 

Soundtrack is bopping like in other TES games with the main theme "Nerevar Rising" being the first main theme to use the iconic TES melody that has been used all the way up even into the teaser trailer for Elder Scrolls VI.
As it is the first rendition of the iconic melody, its not as grand and epic as skyrims orchestral army praising dovahkiin in dragontounge, but its simple and nostalgic, much like the game itself.

there's a stereotype that all morrowind fans are late 80s/early 90s kids who scoff at anyone who enjoys the modern equivalent of their favorite things, but morrowind actually predates me as a conscious person by a couple years. in my personal opinion, morrowboomers are too harsh on skyrim and skybabies are too reluctant to play morrowind.

If you're reading this review wondering whether or not you should buy morrowind, I urge you do. It may take you some time to get used to, especially if you've played Skyrim or Oblivion with its more simple mechanics. it took me about 4 new games before I actually got used to it but after you get into the groove, it becomes and enthralling experience.

Morrowind is a superb game, despite its age, it holds up in 2022 as one of bethesdas greatest.

I love this game. Morrowind is rough around the edges, sure, but it offers a unique experience that no other Elder Scrolls game, or RPG in general for that matter,  can offer. The character creation is amazing, offering a multitude of possibilities and options for role-playing, combat style, min-maxxing -- whatever gets you off you filthy N'wah -- and more. The combat is simple and outdated, however, breaking it is extremely easy, and part of the fun. The story is likely the biggest selling point in this game, and it lives up tot he expectations. The fantasy standard in writing is almost universally considered to be Tolkien, he was a master of writing heroes and heroic acts. Whoever wrote the Morrowind lore, however, is a master of writing villains, and villainous acts. I won't say any more as I don't want to spoil it for any potential players, but trust me, it's awesome. I just finished my first playthrough, and am excited to start my next!

Morrowind to me is pretty much the best TES game other than a heavily modded Oblivion or extremely modded Skyrim if you like old school RPGs.

Morrowind has an absurd amount of mods that increase the graphics to be more modern or add lots of content (Soltha Sil Expanded is [b]AMAZING[/b], there's mods that adds an entire new continents, etc), so you can make this game look beautiful or even better if you want to. Those who have played Oblivion or Skyrim know the deal here, but Morrowind has a lot of great content made for it since it's an older game.

It's only gotten better as the Morrowind Script Extender exists, and now people are doing things like proper Necromancy and such that weren't possible before.

The amount of freedom you have is pretty unrivaled. You can make spells that completely break the game, like make your character fly so fast the game crashes from loading too many cells at once (at least on older PCs, and I think there are mods to help fix this). It takes a long time, but you can do it.

That said, if you don't like old school mechanics like having to find stuff manually in the world based on directions and not having an arrow navigate you everywhere you'll hate this game.

The combat system is mechanically terrible, as unlike Oblivion & Skyrim it is based around hidden dice rolls. This can kill your vibe hard.

If you know you'd like this kind of game, I'd recommend it to anyone who knows that. But for most people, it's gonna be iffy. It's an old game, that does things in an old way. It does not hold your hand. Some may like that. Most won't, nowadays.

Verdict: SALE

I think that The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind would be a great RPG if it weren't riddled with so many fixable bugs that Bethesda refused to fix so I'll have to give it a failing grade for that alone.

EDIT:  I have finished everything in the game now (or at least anything that I've found that wasn't broken) and I would like to reiterate that I do not recommend the game solely for it's bugs and instability and not for anything else.  I like many of the old fashioned RPG mechanics of Morrowind over it's successors and for instance got by just fine without quest tracker by following the NPC's directions (except when they were occasionally too vague or just completely WRONG.)

Before I elaborate further, I would like to state that I rate the game AS IS and not after it's been (fan)patched/modded because I don't think that's really a fair assessment of the product.  If a game requires to be (fan)patched and modded to be "good" i.e. to become something different because it could not stand on its own legs, then it simply isn't.

I'd say the bugginess of Morrowind, like many of Bethesda's games, can sometimes be very comical if they weren't so often frustrating.  I know it's an old game by now but Bethesda hasn't really improved much since this release in terms of playtesting and fixing their buggy games.  If most of the bugs were fixed or at least not essential to the functioning of the game then I'd not only give it a recommendation but would rate it highly.  The bugs are so numerous and sometimes significant that you practically *must* patch the game yourself unless you are just a glutton for punishment or something or don't mind leaving things unfinished.


In short, I can recommend "Morrowind+" but not Morrowind on it's own.
It's a classic, nothing more to say.

It took me several tries to get into Morrowind. I played the beginning over and over on different characters, always giving the game a chance, because I was so in love with Oblivion and Skyrim back then. It took around 5 - 8 characters before the game finally clicked, and when it did, it easily became one of my top RPGs of all time.

The narrative is unlike what you are used to in RPGs, in a world that truly feels alien, yet recognizable. The world feels like its own, a place the player is unwelcome, but yet you are able to master it.

You can delve deeply into the lore of Vvardenfell and always hunger for more. This is what truly hooked me, the world and how unique it felt and how many different aspects of the culture was presented.

To have fun in morrowind, you have to set goals for yourself and assume the game will let you do things your way.
This game is adamant about letting you do things that most rpgs won't.
You can ask almost anyone for directions. You can cheat quest giving npcs. You can annoy an npc nonstop for hours until they snap and attack you, allowing you to beat them up under the guise of self defense. You can arrange pillows into a fort, or take over an abandoned house and keep it as your own.

You also have to minmax your character to hell and back as the developers seem to have intended. Don't be a jack of all trades under any circumstances.

The night of my 16th birthday my parent's car broke down on the way back from a states wide trip to visit family. I remember because they'd never missed a birthday of mine before, and as an already sentimental kid I was sad that they may not make it in time for my birthday, but I accepted it. At least they were okay and nothing bad happened to the car that it injured anyone or even put them in danger, which was news enough for me to breath a sigh of relief. They took a greyhound the rest of the way home and they got home just mere minutes before midnight, and they had a big gift to give me: An Xbox. With the Xbox was Morrowind, which I played on a brother in laws PC at the time and loved.

Since that time when we set it up and my parents insisted to celebrate my birthday past into midnight and marvel at this GIGANTIC system, I've always found time to come back to playing Morrowind no matter what platform I was on. Being able to do what you want in a crazy open world right after the tutorial area including thieving and messing with the locals with saving/loading was something so rare to me those days as a Nintendo kid. 

As a small 16yo (I'm an adult standing at 5 feet tall now so, yea), it was insane attempting to grip the giant Xbox Duke controller in my hands, learning to play the game on console. But it stands just as good back then as it does now. Sure, there were major improvements in games in the decade and a half to come in UI, storytelling, combat, and graphics. That to me doesn't change the fact that this game is filled with amazing stories, memorable moments, memorable places, hilarious quotes, and a near infinite amount of fun you can have playing different characters in completely different ways. 

Fast-forward all the way to today, and you can play it just as it was so many years ago or use mods to slap an AWESOME fresh coat of paint on it brought to you by some of the most dedicated fans to a series there have ever been for any games, let alone Action/RPGs. Can't stand the graphics? Covered. Think it's stupid you can miss when you clearly just hit that cliffracer visually? Covered. Granted the fans didn't make the original game, but they've more than made up for that with all of the independent time, effort, and heart that has gone into modding/fixing up Morrowind. 

Whether you got it back then when you were 16 and said, "This is friggin' awesome!" or you're 16 now and modding it to look like your newer games from today saying, "The game slaps!" the honest truth is you're going to experience something that practically every person has when first experiencing Morrowind. And that is this -

The game is SUPER fun. Also there is reading. SO much reading!

Daggerfall expanded but still wack AF with the same issues with controls and whatnot. What was kinda unique about Daggerfall was the detail into the backstory of Tamriel and Cyrodill and all the various provinces or places like Slyrim and the Black Marsh and it went into more detail of the story of the Septim bloodline which was cool; good lore! The oldest yet best of the mainline elder scrolls series (not counting the DOS era games). Properly immersive story telling, requiring you to gather directions and piece together how you're getting to your destination instead of simply following the arrow on your compass. Hit chance mechanics may not be everyone's cup of tea, but they definitely still hold some charm. The story is one of ancient rivalries and self actualization, one that has some proper themes and morals if you're willing to listen, while not being preachy about anything.

If you're looking for a new (to you) game to play, grab this one. It take a bit of learning to get into, but it's certainly a treat to come back to every time.

(Note: originally I'd had an abysmally written review that was full of innacuracies and "what the fuck is he saying?" sort of moments... to be fair I'd only had 93.7 hours in the game at the time, and I was like 13 years old. 9 years older and with 520 more hours of gameplay under my belt, I finally gave this masterpiece the review it deserved)

Morrowind is in my opinion, one of if not THE finest first person open world RPG ever made. The setting is wonderfully unique and strongly detailed with great writing and lore fleshing it out which I find to be the biggest factor as to why I love this game along with the legendary soundtrack. The combat is ok, very clunky but nowhere near as bad as many claim since the hit chance is relative to whether your character's class is skilled at said weapon type and/or magic, that being said it is more than valid that the combat is outdated cuz it really is although its also bearable, speaking of magic, while it is at its most diverse here on par with Daggerfall, it does have a bit of a learning curve to be skilled at using magic although its the most exploitable and can make the game significantly easier if you know what you're doing, I absolutely love how they handled magic in this game compared to others which I will say I'm big on playing as casters in most RPG's I play. While the graphics are definitely outdated as well, they have a strong charm to them and with how the landscape and creatures look in Morrowind, it somehow holds up since the land of Morrowind is quite surreal by nature although character models especially don't look good and no amount of mods will fix that honestly. One criticism I've seen mentioned very often besides graphics and gameplay is how there's very little voice acting (a lot of it is actually cut content if you wanna install mods to restore it but I personally haven't tried them) and how all dialogue has to be read with no voice over which is a criticism I don't find to be that valid since stories are usually supposed to be read, not told and even then the writing in this game is amazing to the point where you probably won't even care about the lack of voice acting the more you read the dialogue. Morrowind has a genuinely awesome main quest, if you simplify it, it is a "chosen one" type story but the twist on it is unique and very well done since it's not initially revealed to you and the main villain is iconic (not gonna spoil the story even though this is an old game but I'm gonna be assuming you haven't played it) and even the side quests are well detailed. Also there are no quest markers at all, you have to consult your journal for directions on where to go to complete quests which they do give you good information with directions for the most part but if you get lost just consult the UESP wiki. As with every Elder Scrolls game before Skyrim you can choose a class or create one giving you a good amount of replay-ability and there's the usual factions being Mages guild, Fighters guild, and Thieves guild along with the three Morrowind specific factions which each require a different playthrough being House Telvanni (my favorite of the three), House Redoran and House Hlaalu each with their own sets of rules and ideologies but the rest I won't go into detail. For a first playthrough at least install the Morrowind Code Patch and Morrowind Graphics Extender (known as MGEXE) to make the game more stable and look a bit better while keeping the game vanilla but that being said the modding community is still going strong for this old gem of a game, I also strongly recommend getting Tamriel Rebuilt since its adding the mainland of Morrowind into the game (the base game is set on an island of the province but its not the entirety of Morrowind) and the content of Tamriel Rebuilt is very much in line with the main game although far from finished but what is there is amazing. I beat this game for the first time in 2020 and its a superb game (as you can tell by my hours I absolutely love this game a lot) so if you like surreal fantasy settings and old school RPG's with the freedom of an open world, get Morrowind with some mods.
Fantasy done well. An amazing RPG from the time where Bethesda was on the brink of bankrupcy; alien, dense, interesting and magical. Y'all n'wahs need to play this game at least one in your lifetime.

Straight up masterpiece. Michael Kirkbride hitting me with some of the best lore I've seen in a game. Tamriel Rebuilt only makes the experience even better.

10/10
