The greatest "Western" RPG of all time. No voice acting, destination markers or fast travel. Spells have a high chance of failure. Melee attacks frequently miss. The game is unplayable without the Morrowind Code Patch and Morrowind Graphic Extender mods. "Patch for Purists" should also be downloaded and enabled in the Data files folder as well. Despite these eccentricities, this game is addictive. Although Morrowind is hard, because you can't skip easily over everything like in Skyrim or Oblivion, you become far more immersed in the game and the roleplaying. The game is built on this idea of "no shortcuts" and "no hand holding". Without using the wiki, good luck learning everything you will need to know. This is one of those games that you are going to have to study for like you are taking a test in school. Despite the additional effort though, I promise you Morrowind is worth it. Check out r/morrowind on reddit for more info on how to properly install the patches. For less than sixteen dollars on the Steam store, you can't do much better than this.

You start off as the weakest and most pathetic person imaginable, but as you progress through the world and game, you will become a literal god with no challenge in path. Unlike Oblivion and Skyrim, when you level up, you will actually notice the change from weak to powerful, and fights will become much easier. This game, despite looking dated, holds up insanely well, give it a try, and you won't regret it.
The best Elder Scrolls Game, one of the best roleplaying games of all time. Worth the price at retail

This might be my 4th try to get into the game. I made bad characters that missed every hit. I tried to make mages that got 1 shot in the training caves. But this time I made a redguard that casts bound longsword. The quest detail is amazing, as I can go from splunking caves to delivering slaves with in depth world building in seamless transitions. The magic system (once you learn about stamina and miscast) is awesome too. Once you learn a spell, you can craft any possible version of that spell. Basically Oblivion but better. I hear a lot of people complain about the lack of quest markers, but oringinal WoW didnt have quest markers. Everything is readable, and the journal/questlog hold all of that info with blue text that can be clicked on. Basically every quest location is described in detail so far. im about 20 hours in on my playthrough, and it's dope.

This game is fun, especially if you're a fan of other Bethesda RPGs, however it has admittedly not aged the best. A select few mods are needed to bring the game more up to date. Mostly just the Code Patch, MGE XE, Better Dialogue, and MET. These manage to fix some bugs and give the game a much needed facelift, but also maintain the game's heart and soul. This game is definitely far less casual than newer entries in TES series. But if you can manage to power past the outdated nature of the game it's quite good. A great deal of the game's appeal is the setting and lore. Morrowind has some fantastic storytelling behind it. It can be a bit of a slog, especially compared to newer RPG's and I would love to see it get a remaster to bring it up to date. But for TES fans or just RPG fans it is a must.

Graphics: 7/10 Taking into consideration the time period it was released, it's graphics where pretty standard.
Gameplay...
     Leveling Up: 9/10 In Morrowind, you need 10 subattribute levels from a player chosen governing attribute to Level up. Each skill has a "Governing Attribute", you can increase your governing attribute up to +5 times per level. To increase the G.A simply increase the subattributes levels ten times. (For instance, Destruction, Conjuration, Enchant and security are subattributes that come under Intelligence, the Governing Attribute)  

Fighting 8/10 So i might be a bit biased here, but I personally enjoy the old-school fighting mechanics. It needs to be said that many very much dislike Morrowinds "Hit chance" mechanic. The "Hit Chance" mechanic basically functions as a replacement for actually dodging at higher levels (if you focused on the skills which increase it, that is.) 
  The rest of the combat is much like that of future ES games. 

Story: 9/10 I wont spoil thr story for others!
Masterpiece

Yes, especially with Tamriel Rebuilt. I started off with Oblivion and played the other main series of Elder Scroll titles, but I like this ES the best and is one of my most favorite games to play. Vanilla mechanics are tough enough for many gamers nowadays, but having dated graphics and animations tend to discourage potential players from even trying in the first place.

If you're new and willing to learn to play a (likely) more difficult game than you're accustomed to, I recommend installing a few basic mods: Yuki's bugfixing mod(s) and some graphic replacers to modernize the look of your game. There are various tutorials on Youtube that demonstrate how. Afterwords, I suggest watching some of the videos in this playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLobdprIgcqJ82TKnySC6yIzP9CO9ixyz_ for a greater understanding of Morrowind's mechanics.

At the end, you'll have a game you enjoy looking at with increased stability and a handy dandy cheat sheet of videos to reference to understand why your 0 fatigue, 10 shortblade character can't kill a mudcrab with the handy dandy dagger presented at the beginning of the game. 

I know some peeps might recommend playing it with only the bugfixes for the atmosphere, but tbh if you prefer higher quality settings on other games you play then graphically overhauling this game is the same thing.

I've been playing Morrowind for almost 20 years. Even still I'm finding secrets and hidden goodies around the world. There are thousands of NPCs. More than Skyrim and Oblivion combined. By virtue of the text based dialogue system. And there are SO MANY QUESTS.

Morrowind doesn't hold your hand. It gives you a set of systems and lets you do whatever you want with it. If you want to make a spell that permanently increases your speed by the hundreds, you're perfectly free to. Heck, you can even summon a sprawling army of daedric monsters for yourself, if you become powerful enough.

The combat takes some getting used to. Keep your fatigue full, and don't engage enemies that are clearly more powerful than you, and you'll be alright. Using ingredients, spells, and potions to give yourself the advantage is very under rated. Use the things the game gives you!

The variety of enemies and encounters is really staggering. In any random cave you're going to encounter something different. Sometimes it's a troupe of dagger wielding cut-purses, the next one could be a wizards secret lair full of beast from the daedric realms.

The sheer amount of lore and world-building is top notch. There are hundreds of books to read, and every NPC will give you some detail about the world. So many of the books will increase your skill levels as well.

Making quests and dungeons for your friends to play is so easy with the creation tools. Todd Howard himself even released some tutorials on using them around 20 years ago.

The music and atmosphere are second to none. Lush forests, rolling green fields, lively swamps and mires, craggy badlands, snowy wastelands. Even magical mushroom forests. All accompanied by the most beautiful soundtrack you'll ever hear in your life.

The variety of ways to role-play is very inviting as well. You can be the merciless "murder hobo", or you can be quite regal and pacifistic. All ways to play are viable, and it only takes your skill and knowledge of the game to be who ever you want in Morrowind. You can eventually get a house and decorate it with your adventuring spoils.

The modding community is thriving. The dedicated discord server gives you the utilities to start making and sharing your own, and they have marathons and contests to participate in. Such a lovely community doing some great work.

Seriously, this is in my top 3 favorite games of all time. You'll be hooked on Morrowind for hundreds of hours. There's just so much to do and see, and with all of the incredible mods, there is another few hundred hours of stuff to explore.

Перевод:

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind — ролевой экшен с открытым миром, позволяющий перемещаться по всей глобальной карте, включая четыре крупных города, множество маленьких деревень, а также бескрайние просторы диких земель. Существует несколько способов перемещения по миру пешком и с помощью внутриигровых механик. Однако игровая механика предлагает ограниченный выбор маршрутов, и до некоторых локаций с их помощью добраться невозможно. Также игра богатая на квесты и в ней можно найти очень много миссий связанных со Скайримом. Так как Скайрим я прошёл ранее было интересно погрузиться в лор другой провинции Тамриэля.

For Morrowind, the only thing that time takes is mechanics. It is still there with its magnificent story, interesting characters and unique world.

This was the last good Elder Scrolls game, although it should be made clear that this game is where the downward spiral of casualising a once great CRPG series began. There was a massive amount of aspects found in Daggerfall that were gutted from Morrowind such as home ownership, which was restored in Oblivion. It's just that the amount of things that were removed to appeal to the lowest common denominator increased exponentially with Oblivion and Skyrim, which this game is utterly superior to. (TL;DR) It's a good game, but make no mistake, it is quite dated.

Graphics (6/10): I know at the time that these graphics were incredible. However now it's low-res, low-poly, and always has a dense fog around to help the game run on computers of that era. There are, however, mods that can fix most if not all graphical issues, making it much more pleasant to look at.

Controls (9/10): Pretty nice and responsive tbh. WASD controls for movement, right click to go into the menu, space to interact, left click to attack/cast, E to jump, even has customizable hotkeys like Oblivion and Skyrim.

Gameplay (7/10): Fun, but flawed in some regards. Combat is... weird... when you attack you first whittle down their "fatigue" (stamina) once you get through that, THEN you start to get to their health. Movement at the early game is [b] S L O W [/b] trying to walk between any two destinations is like running a marathon, especially since the fast travel doesn't work like it does in literally every other TES game. you can only fast travel using transportation such as boats or silt striders. That all being said it has some redeeming qualities, the fast travel at the very least IS immersive, and that's something they try very hard to do, they try to make the game very immersive, and I think they've succeeded mostly. Combat, if you can deal with not being able to hit the broad side of a barn for the first level or two, is pretty fun, and being able to construct your very own custom spells and equipment is amazing!

Music (10/10): This game has an amazing orchestral score that is honestly a joy to listen to. Do I prefer ambient music while I'm walking around? Yeah. But does the epic orchestral soundtrack make trekking through Morrowind more enjoyable? Most definitely.

Stability/Bugs (8/10): Oh Bethesda, how I love your many bugs and glitches... thankfully there's only one you'll really have to worry about, and that's from the "Tribunal" expansion. Essentially, despite the fact the assassins SHOULD only fight you at higher levels (>=5 level I think) after waking up from a rest, they can do so at any level. So if you're playing this, try disabling Tribunal for a while until you thing you're ready, or just save before each rest.

Overall (8/10): An overall solid early 2000s RPG, which has stuck true to it's D&D inspired roots. It can be clunky at times, and the visuals have aged poorly, but at least one of those I know can be fixed by mods.

I cannot state how fucking frustrating this game is to get running. IT IS A FUCKING NIGHTMARE, I've spent the past 3 hours just trying to make it so it can run on my computer without crashing whenever I alt-tab, having massive audio clipping/errors whenever I play for more than 30 minutes, and all the other wonky shit I have to try and figure out. I end up having to install several mods just so I can RUN the game, which is a incredibly frustrating process, because as I go from page to page trying to understand the tech speak the mod creators use while having literally no understanding of what they are saying, all I can think of is how FUCKING RIDICULOUS it is I even have to do this. For as great of a game it is, I genuinely don't think it's worth the hassle and frustration of getting it running. 

HOWEVER once you do get it running, it is one of the most indepth and incredible RPGs I have ever played, with an almost incredible amount of freedom, and feels incredibly fresh compared to all the quest markers I get in things like Oblivion and Skyrim. Don't get me wrong, I love those games, but when was the last time you decided to just explore Cyrodil? 

Also an incredibly interesting setting. Morrowind is a really hostile place, and it really feels like you are supposed to die here, you are the bottom of the food chain, but by the end of the game, you are the god damn food chain. Hell, you're BEYOND the food chain. You become a fucking GOD, and it feels incredible.

9/10 - Play it, but expect a rough start, both in getting it working and the game itself, but a blast when you get goin.

after getting hooked on Skyrim, i started exploring the Elder Scrolls's expansive lore, amusing characters, & countless stories via UESP & ES YouTube channels. i loved what i've learnt & decided to get Morrowind & Oblivion, looking forward mostly to play the 4th instalment. 

i figured i wouldn't like Morrowind much. starting the game i thought the UI took some time to get used to, the graphics were dated, combat was too difficult. nevertheless, i pushed myself knowing while i can just look up guides & watch playthroughs, i will miss out on insignificant quests & NPCs that are often not discussed yet are the very things that make open world games so special. 

i'm so glad i tried to keep on playing. TESIII, although set on an island and not a whole province, have so much to discover. i feel like there are so many more NPCs, & most if not all of them have more dialogs than any Skyrim character i can think of. to me, that is what makes Morrowind such a good game - the amount of lore you will have to read to progress through the game. [u]i'm actually slightly worried that i will constantly be wishing for such depth when i play IV & replay V.[/u]

also, from one n'wah to another:
[*] save your game like your life depends on it.
[*] don't hesitate to look up guides to help you figure out your way in the game. & if you're not a noob like me, then your journal helps.
[*] you will miss so much when fighting you will wonder if you're really using your weapons at all. each time you level up, it'll get slightly easier, & by endgame you'll walk in any dungeon absolutely plundering through it.
[*] get the spells [b]Mark[/b], [b]Recall[/b], [b]Divine Intervention[/b] & [b]Almsivi Intervention[/b] ASAP. 
[*] be nice & don't steal a merchant's stuff unless you don't plan to trade w/ them ever. 
[*] a friend of mine told me to not worry about getting the main questline done - it's an open world game after all. [i]he's right.[/i]
[*] [b]Solstheim?[/b] a terrible place, i've heard. there's a boat from Khuul, if you have any reason to go.

Of the fully 3D rendered Elder Scrolls games, Morrowind is the one where your stats actually matter, how you build your character matters. Oblivion ruined everything with the leveled world where every enemy gets stronger as you get stronger and ruined the leveling system. Skyrim threw Stats in the garbage entirely but I still find it more playable than Oblivion, which in my opinion has the worst RPG elements of the 3D rendered Elder Scrolls games (which is scary because Skyrim has barely to none RPG elements), but Oblivion is a fun setting and world and fun lore implications.

People who rate Morrowind poorly based on the combat have a poor imagination, but I can't really blame them. Your ability to land melee attacks is greatly dependent on your own stats as well as your enemy's -- when you miss point blank, that is simulating that perhaps your character isn't an expert swordsman or your enemy sidestepped the attack. The word "simulating" is very important because there is no physical dodge animation nor sound queue. In my ideal world, an Elder Scrolls 6 would throw the Skyrim perk trees in the garbage, reintroduce skills, classes, attributes and dicerolls, but add significantly more feedback to a missed attack or failed action. With the greater technology of today, surely they could figure out a good way to show that an attack was glancing or an enemy sidestepped. 

The diceroll combat like I say is greatly dependent on stats. You can almost look at your weapon skill as a percent chance to hit, but it is also affected by other factors such as your own attributes, an enemy's attributes and skills, and spell effects. This gives a really genuine sense of progression that I just do not feel in Skyrim or Oblivion. The potential for attacks to fail makes successful attacks more gratifying. As your character lands more attacks, you skills level up. As your skills level up, your character lands more attacks. It's a feedback cycle that simulates your character being a breathing being in the world who is actually progressively getting more skilled. It is much more satisfying than putting another perk point into my One Handed skill so I will deal 5% more damage with One Handed. 

Many reviewers say the combat is terrible. The combat is terrible in *all* of the 3D rendered Elder Scrolls games, including Skyrim. Dark Souls, Skyrim is not, and every character you make regardless of what race you pick feels exactly the same due to the lack of attributes and classes. Morrowind's replayability to me largely comes from the wide array of characters you can create when building a class, you can actually create varied characters, and the main story quest line has potential for ambiguity and player interpretation. 

Shipped from Cyrodiil a prisoner, the player has just been pardoned of their crimes and told to follow orders lest they be marked a treasonous deserter. They are recruited into the Emperor's service, the missions given to the player are steeped in mystery right from the beginning. No quest markers means you will have to use that big organ between your ears to decide where to go based on written directions from the natives. The player doesn't even know what their objective is for about a half dozen quests into the main story, and then when a trusty superior offers some explanation to the plot, it just thickens.

The island of Vvardenfell is diverse in regions from marshes to grasslands to dry ash and volcanic lava rivers. The landscape is covered in hillsides and dotted with abandoned ruins of the mysteriously vanished Dwemer, shrines to Daedra lords, caves which house bandits and monsters, and ancient Dunmer burial crypts defended by the spirits of the honored family dead. The creatures of the land are very alien looking, not your typical wolves and bears. The cities are huge for a 3D Elder Scrolls game that isn't Daggerfall, the people have interesting things to say (even if different people of the same profession have very similar things to say, I'll take it over non-important characters in the later games having literally 1 dialogue option). The land of Morrowind, to me, is so much more intriguing and creatively cared for than the medieval setting of oblivion or the viking setting of Skyrim. The warriors of Vvardenfell craft their armor from tough bug-hide instead of iron. Many Dunmer wizards magically coax giant mushrooms to grow into the shape of living quarters and grand lodges. A main source of food for the native Dunmer is eggs -- not chicken eggs -- but eggs laid in subterranean caves by ugly creatures that the menial "egg miners" depend upon.

All of this combined with the ability to create varied custom spells, a long list of spell effects either forgotten or "outlawed" in the future, a culture well defined and unique, a slew of wonderful in-game books detailing topics from history to rumor, some portrayed as fiction and some portrayed as non-fiction. The native religion has many books dedicated to it, often conflicting -- you will have to decide for yourself what to believe.

You will have to decide many things for yourself, but the signposts will point the way.

This is a game that unfortunately does NOT stand the test of time. I really tried to give this game a shot, I really did. But I just don't like it. Everything is too clunky and unpolished, it screams "This was a game made in the early era of 3D"! I imagine most of the enjoyment of this game comes from nostalgia. Which is not valid in a critique sense, but whatever. But I have never seen a game that managed to lose me so fast in the first two hours. Awkward slow janky movement, unintuitive menu interfaces, awful dated graphics. And don't tell me graphics don't matter! You know how much effort and skill goes into crafting graphics? If you did, you wouldn't say they don't matter. Plus, the bad graphics along with the janky maps, just made ridiculous trying to find where to even go. And within the first two hours of playing, I had several doors get permanently blocked off by NPC standing in front of them. Do not recommend. Would love to see this game get a modern makeover.

I'm more of a story enjoyer rather than a graphics fan. Combat, leveling, and character creation systems take some getting used to but it's rewarding. It's fun to be on one hand-- a pacifist who picks the prettiest flowers and decorates their homes with beautiful vases versus, an inhumane psychopath who likes stabbing as well as picking flowers and decorating their home with vases. All of the npc's insult you but some people are into that; I personally thought it was funny. I directly credit Morrowind to my passion of music as it contains some of the most beautiful melodies that have graced my ears. The character arc is probably one of the best of any game. you start as this nobody who can't even kill a rat or run move than 2 mph; but by the end you're this absolute god who is mountain hopping and defeating your foes with one blow. Great game.

It streamlined just enough from Daggerfall to be accessible enough to newcomers if they pay attention. It also doesn't have Oblivion's leveling. When you level up your combat skills, you see actual progress in how effective you are. Sure it's not as big as the game before(Arena's technically infinite so you can't really count it in the world sizes) or the ones after. But with mods, that can be changed. And there's plenty of mods to give new quests, upgrade the graphics and other Elder Scrolls staple mods. It's certainly more difficult than later titles in the series-in the beginning, anyway-but by level 5 or so you should be handling things well enough. By level 20 you'll be laughing at Dagoth Ur and by level 30 you'll be taking out pretty much anything.
So gather your soul gems, horde Tarhiel's stuff and make sure to loot Fargoth's stash. Welcome to Morrowind. Watch out for cliff racers!

If you're having trouble with this game, there are many great guides on the internet that can help with ideal character creation, tips for combat, mod lists if you're into modding and quest walkthroughs, I played it without mods for my first full playthrough and really enjoyed it, Morrowind is still a pretty good RPG by today's standards, I'd recommend looking at graphics mods or using OpenMW as the game does look pretty dated and making it look better does make it more enjoyable.

This is where I started my journey with The Elder Scrolls series and with Bethesda in general.
So today, I just finished Morrowind. It was my first experience in the world of Tamriel and I have to say - it truly exceeded my expectations. Believable, interesting, diverse world full of books, tales, stories, fractions, clans and so on and so forth. I never experienced such a complex world building from any video game before. 
It's completely wild how you can dig deeper and deeper in terms of lore and the world around you. It's just up to you. It's possible to spend even 200h in this 20 years old game just wandering around and learning about it.

Yet, I wouldn't recommend it to the younger or less patient players. This is not only an old game, but old minded as well. Very little voice acting, RNG based combat, outdated mechanics and graphics. All these things you have to keep in mind when giving Morrowind a try. There are some mods of course, a ton of them actually. I personally wanted to play vanilla Morrowind so I didn't take a look at them. I had a blast playing it even without any mods so it is also possible of course.
I absolutely adore this world and how strongly RPG based it actually is.

Game mechanics are very complex and flexible. With the proper tools you can make yourself jump across the entire map or 1-hit anyone in the game, all without any mods. Just alchemy, spell making, enchantments and mixing up all the different things together. It's not easy and obvious, but possible.
Unfortunately the game is not very polished at some aspects so you won't escape from using console commands from time to time, for example to remove an NPC blocking your way (simple, useful command "RA" resets NPC's position to their default places) or to force journal update when finishing some quests because the game didn't notice you actually finished it.
Luckly tho, those are well known issues, commands are easy to find on the internet and the availability of console ingame makes it difficult to actually get stuck somewhere.

The GOTY edition contains two expansions - Tribunal and Bloodmoon.
Tribunal is magnificent, it connects with the main plot, the Mournhold (fortified city which is the main place of action) is a very nice, cozy yet dangerous place, filled with useful or memorable NPC's and makes you wanna come back to it and explore it further and deeper (and there is much to explore!).
Bloodmoon on the other hand is... rather over the top. Looks like the development team wanted to raise the difficulty, but they did this in the most pitfull way - throwing at you tons of enemies everywhere, hit-sponges with no reward of fighting with them. Bloodmoon takes place on the island of Solstheim.  You are getting there at the end of the game (doesn't make any sense to go there earlier), your character is already packed with useful items and maxed-out skills, so being forced to fight tens and tens of large health pool enemies is just a chore at this point. But besides that it is something new and refreshing, it keeps you going even after spending 100h in Vvanderfell.

I was afraid of Morrowind. I thought it would overwhelm me with its sloppiness and outdated mechanics, but I truly had a lot of fun with it. It's a very unique game, definitely one of these games that can make you fall in love with it. There are just no games similar to Morrowind. Every RPG lover should give it a try!

Some of the best writing and plot right on the heels of storytelling giants like Planescape Torment. The gameplay is dated but as long as you approach all combat as a stat checks, it's rather digestible.

Is old, is gold. Not made for the wee babies of today. Made for the stronk manly men of yesteryear.

After three different playthroughs (2 vanilla and 1 with Tamriel Rebuilt installed) across 270+ hours of gameplay, I can safely say that Morrowind is a fantastic game and what most RPGs should strive to be. Hell, even the other Elder Scrolls games should strive to be as good as this. The systems are complex/complete, the writing is impeccable, the questines are great, the world is captivating, and THERE IS NO LEVELED LOOT/ENEMIES (STOP DOING THIS ITS BAD GAME DESIGN). However, there is one thing holding this game back, which is the age. Although, this can be "fixed" with a few downloadable patches such as MCP (Morrowind code patch) and MGE (Morrowind graphics extender).

I assure you that you will not regret spending the money on this game. And even after you've completed everything, there are a ton of fan-made mods like the incredible Tamriel Rebuilt I mentioned, which adds the Morrowind mainland, an area even larger than the vanilla game with tons of unique quests/dungeons.

Hello again, good friend! And welcome to my review of the Elder Scrolls third installment. Morrowind is certainly a game any fan of the series should try. While not offering the same feeling as "starting it all" that Arena offers, it does offer a similar feeling. That being the feeling of the change of the guards, holding aspects of the previous titles and cracking the door open to aspects of the newer titles. But, let face one matter upfront, the matter of direction. A common complaint seen from those coming from titles after Morrowind regards direction, or the seeming lack of it. Being that Morrowind offers no visible quest markers, some may find the written direction to be tiresome. It is simply a matter of opinion. Now, with that out of the way (and before this turns into more a Morrowind speech box), I'll leave you with the simple recommendation of: get it if you hold any interest, for it is truthfully worth the investment.
Level up your weapons skills and keep your stamina above empty.
Aged wonderfully, in a day where nothing has consequences and your games are generic like New Vegas knock-offs and Skyrim for the 5th time, the OG Todd Howard shows you a truly alien experience.
yes

I still remember my first playthrough of Morrowind, I had no idea how to get to Balmora and didn't want to take the silt strider, not realizing how cheap it actually was. I remember wandering for a bit, following the road signs and entering every cave and burial ground I passed, doing the quest for that woman outside of Pelagiad, and being in awe at the sight of Fort Moonmoth. Despite being maybe a 10 minute hike from Seyda Neen, it had taken me a couple hours to walk there and I was immersed for the entirety of it. I still got that same feeling towards the end of my playthrough when I was traveling through a region I hadn't explored before, to a town I had never heard of, with only vague directions. There's so much side content for you to find for yourself and the game needs only to nudge you in the right direction. I think its stuff like that, along with the diegetic fast travel, that makes Vvardenfell feel so much bigger than it actually is. I'm pretty sure Skyrim is technically bigger but the map feels tiny in comparison.

Even with all the time I spent playing this game, I can't recommend it. its simply too archaic.

Its combat system is horrible. Despite being first person it determines hits based on "dice roll" style random generation. in addition, most enemies have a huge pool of health, so at early levels it will take up to 20 minutes to kill even normal enemies. enemies attacks cause massive damage, so you'll die in only a couple hits, even at high levels. stamana and mana are also very limited even at high levels, and all attacks require quite a bit of either. if you encounter more than one enemy at low level, you are gaurenteed to die.

normally i don't judge the graphics of older games as long as they look good "for the time", but the character models and models for the levels are extremely archaic even for the year this game came out. for a comparison, by the time this game had come out, silent hill 2, metal gear solid 2 and final fantasy X had come out a year earlier. this game looked bad back then. to make it worse, the art direction is TERRIBLE. EVERYTHING is brown. brown dirt, brown buildings, brown mushrooms, brown animals. even the concept art shown on the loading screens is brown. the only things that aren't brown are the elves, they're a horrible shade of blue grey.

the main story isn't very good, its just a normal "destroy the demon king" quest, the kind you've seen a million times in better games like dragon quest, but without the charming characters and locations that those games have. some of the dialouge is good, but most of it is copy and pasted generic lines that every npc in the game spouts. some of the lore is interesting, (mostly because the lore writer literally locked himself in a room and got high for a week and wrote down everything he thought) but for obvious reasons most of it is nonsensical, has no impact on the lore of the later games in the series, and is misinterpreted by the fans. (they do things like say that a character, an elf named vivec, who only ever lies to your character and leads a cult is trustworthy when he talks about the setting and its history) really, you might be better off reading the lore off of a wiki, all the notes and characters that talk about interesting things are so spread out that it would take days just to get all the interesting parts of the story, even with as few as there are.

your character moves slow, even at the maximum natural speed, so it takes forever to go anywhere, and combined with the dice roll combat, means that it takes hours to do even the easiest of quests. I skipped most of the side quests, and only did the minimum nesissary to complete the base game and one of the expansions, and it still took over one hundred and sixty hours. in retrospect i should have given up when it got boring, but hindsight is 20/20 and I had heard so many good things said about the game that I wanted to see if it ever got as good as people said. it never got good. I wanted to like it because I liked the others in the series, but theres nothing really likable. I don't even hate the game, because when I look back on playing it all I remember is bordom.
that's why I have so much time in this game. because when I gave the game my time, the game didn't respect my time. Don't waste your time like I did, Don't buy this game.

A quick edit: I forgot to mention that this game has an incredibly toxic fanbase. Its the second worst group of fans I've ever had the misfortune of dealing with, after Fallout New Vegas.

Only started playing this old mess of a gem in 2020.  Got me through my freshman year of college and I still come back to play it occasionally. Really, really great game. But not for everyone. 

I bought it bc I was bored out of modern RPG handholding and was told this one is more challenging. And actually it really is. The journal system is like the perfect balance between the obscure FromSoft quest system and the babymode EA/Ubisoft system. It creates a feeling of immersion I wish more modern games would have. 

However, the stat-based combat system and sluggish pacing/exploring ruined the game for me. I really don't mind old graphics since it has its charm but the "game feel" of that one is teeeeeeedious. It should not bother you if you're into CRPG, or tabletop rpg inspired video game, but for me it quickly felt like a chore compared to ARPG I usually enjoy. 

That said, I must say that the gloomy, weird dark ambience is really neat. Same for all the ES lore this game provides, if you're into it this game is a goldmine. 

So TL:DR : Great RPG like we don't make anymore but still very outdated and tedious. Negative vote is only bc I did not "liked" the game, and steam binary system sucks to give me 2 choices.

The bad:  this game is old and very janky around the edges.  You see glitches with a fair degree of frequency (though nothing game-breaking) and the UI leaves a *lot* to be desired.

The good: despite everything I said above, this might be my favorite game I've ever played.  It gives you nearly unfettered freedom to play how you want to play, to explore and interact with the world however you see fit, and to exploit its systems for your own gain.  I can't imagine any two play-throughs of this game would be similar, and I find myself constantly wanting to play more and explore the world just a wee bit further.

If you have patience for older graphics, dated UIs, and not having your hand held by the developers, I cannot reccommend this game highly enough.

Morrowind was my introduction to the world of Elder Scrolls. I didn't manage to get properly acquainted with the game until several years after its release, I couldn't stop playing it after I did. I don't know if people will find the game as interesting by today's standards, but it still plays great. Different, but great.

Morrowind plays much like an old style action RPG game, where RNG plays a very prominent part. Combat is one of the areas in which this is very noticeable, as enemy and player attacks have a chance of missing for no visually justified reason. Early on, when your skills are low, you are very likely to miss most of your hits, but as your skills start improving, you will slowly see more and more of your hits connecting. For me, it took a little while of getting used to, but now I find it an endearing trait of a bygone era that adds to the unique flair of the game.

The game also encourages a more attentive mentality, as most of the dialogue and quest information is relayed in pure text. There's quite a bit of voice acting, but the vast majority of dialogue requires good ol' reading. There are also no map markers to aid you in where to go next. You have to stay smart and check the journal for your latest entries or ask around towns for more information, which I found to be very engaging.

I absolutely recommend this game, it has a certain charm about it that makes me come back to it and replay it every couple years.

My history with this game: I may only have 25 hours played on the Steam Version on this game at the time of this review, but I bought this game on DVD when it came out and I have actually played well over a thousand hours in this game. I really only bought the Steam version because I wanted to more easily access it should my disk suffer anymore wear and tear (it is getting old and is will used). I also just wanted to show my support for not just this franchise but this game in particular. With how much I have played this game, Bethesda has frankly earned my money more than once.

I have done everything, literally everything. Every area, every quest or task everything, multiple times. This game is not as approachable as the later games in the series, it's still loaded with the signature Bethesda bugs, although much less in this game than in Oblivion and Skyrim and there are MANY community made patched which can make the game nearly flawless and bugless.

Mods: On that note of community made content, the mod library for this game is MONSTEROUS and truly incredible. You can change the game in any way you want. Tweak the graphics and game play things you don't like, add content and characters and stories and entire islands if you want. Give yourself homes and powers and on and on and on. Modding this game is easy and awesome. 

Story: Which one? There are many of this in this game and many many of them are great. Side stories that are open and obvious or hidden and told through incredible environmental story telling. I love them all but this of all the Elderscrolls games has the best, in my opinion, main questline story. I won't say more but leave it to you to experience it yourself.

World: I wish more than anything would go back to their approach with this game with the others in the series. Morrowind is the most alien and unusal of all the lands of Tamriel. It's fascinating and interesting and every part of it has personality and it's own look. From the area within the great ghost fence to the noble homes of the noble houses, some which require spells like flight just to explore (and yes you can straight up fly in this game). There is so much to see and explore. Pick a direction and go and you will find something interesting in no time flat. Just be careful, this is one of a few games where they will let you break the game. Literally, you can get quest items before you get the quest and sell them or kill important NPC's. So, save often and keep a lot of old saves. It will warn you sometimes when you are about to break the game, but not always.

Skills/Abilities/Progression: This game uses a skills used based progression. The more you do something the better you get at it. Literally everything too. Want to be better at running, run more. Want to be better at jumping, then jump more. Want to be better at sneaking, spell casting, using clubs, using shields... you get the idea. You get skill points in each area eventually adding up to 100 and you can be a master of all. You level up and get base ability point, HP and MP increase every so often when you level your skills up enough and you can pick what abilities you wish to focus on by spending ability points when you level up with multipliers applied to the abilities if you upgraded associated skills. For example, use a sword a lot and you can increase your Strength by 3 instead of 1 for a single ability point. Lots of skills to pick from and you can even pay for training from trainers who are EVERYWHERE to give yourself a boost. Although the cost of buying higher level training is insane sometimes and higher level trainers can be harder to find.

Melee Combat: Ok.... so this is the games weakest point, it's kinda bland. There are mods that make it more interesting but by todays standards, it's nothing exceptional. It's good enough and won't in any way put you off the game, but it's not something to write home about. Basic directional attacks, charged up versions of those and some shield bashes... and that's really it. But this game is old, what do you want from me? It was good enough for its time.

Spell Casting: Basic and super dynamic all at the same time. Its as simple as click and cast. No charging or combining of spells like in Skyrim, BUT you can make your own spells that have an enormous amount of control over what they do and how they work and you that makes the spell selection nearly endless with the range of things you can do with those spells far out pacing any of the the Elder Scrolls games that came after it. With some light modding this spell system is the best the series has to offer.

Lore: Don't get me started.... 2nd to none. Period.

Characters: Really there aren't many main characters who are present start to finish aside from yourself and you are very much a blank slate. Be who you want to be. Tell your own story. Make up your own background and personality. It sounds basic but I actually wish more games took this approach. I love it. Makes you really feel like a wandering hero (or villian) who is on a massive quest through a huge alien world.

Summary: Just get it. You won't be let down. It's my #1 favourite game for a reason.

Another game I replayed on xbox game pass for PC and not on here.... where I own it. Not sure why I'm like that. Anyways... It's a great game! Even without mods(other than unofficial patch) it holds up to today's greats in my humble opinion. I might even add especially up against today's greats. Who are now all social media hubs that also wanna hold your hand, and where the studios spend all their time and energy on multiplayer instead of ironing out great story and conflict.
That having been said, Morrowind thrusts you in the world of the Dwemer province Morrowind where there is a prophecy of an Outlander who comes and is the Neravar. Able to overthrow all the woe that's plagued the land. The best part about that whole premise is that the inhabitants of Morrowind usually HATE Outlanders, especially the Camona Tong and their leader. It just makes the entire premise that much more amusing. A essentially you're the dirty transfer student rags-to-riches story where you do enough favours and grease enough palms to finally achieve something in this place. That's obviously nowhere near the whole story, but just the premise. It still has the typical "Daedra conflicts", "Fascist Pegging" and "Racist crap" that the franchise is known and loved for, lol.
If you've never played Morrowind and love ARPGs I'd give it a good go. AS long as you remember that it doesn't do much to hold your hand, and you need to read a lot to be able to understand the full majesty of it. So Grade 9 reading and comprehension level are a must.

A very detailed and immersive game, one has to keep in mind that this classic game was developed in a simpler time. Still extremely entertaining by to-days standards, the lack of advanced interfacing is glaringly noticeable, especially in the absence of fast-travel. Even though you can set teleport points in the world map, you have to walk to the points the first time to set them. However, I personally, am glad that the game was kept to its original form, and plays just like I remember. Take a walk down memory lane, and get this game. It is well worth it.

Be sure to get the Morrowind Code Patch, Patch for Purists, and MGE XE at the very least, and probably a few other quality of life mods like UI Expansion and Better Dialogue Font. Otherwise your game will be buggy, foggy, and have an annoying interface. Mods can fix just about all the annoying problems with this game's mechanics if you so wish, and there's even one that adds (at this moment) half of the mainland of Morrowind with inhabitants, cities, quests, and so on. 

This is one of the three good TES games (the others being Daggerfall and Skyrim), and it stands between those two games in terms of mechanics and style. It has a better story than its brothers, to be sure, and its world has a great amount of depth even compared to the rest of the series. However, it has aspects that honestly make me recommend it last in that list. Combat is frankly worse than Daggerfall despite being nearly mechanically identical, since you will constantly be staggering from enemy hits (which now stops attacks) and get the odd look of weapons missing a target they are clearly hitting in 3D because of RPG dice rolls. For the first few hours you will be painfully bad at hitting anything unless you are a mage...but on the other hand mages kinda suck in this game unless you min-max them. You see, magicka doesn't recharge unless you rest, and you will probably only have enough of it to attack a single enemy or maybe two in between day-long rests (which can only be done when there are no enemies around), and unless you are a Breton or an Altmer and have one of the birth signs that give you extra magicka, you will have such a pitiful amount of magicka that it is just not practical. So you become an all-rounder, except if you don't PLAN your skill levelling carefully from the beginning you will have a way worse character at higher levels than you could because your attributes in this game can be increased efficiently only by using particular skills you want for those attributes (and not too much of any either). It's just not fun to have to think about, and it's not fun to have to use a spear or medium/heavy armour at the beginning to level up your endurance so you have enough health to survive no matter your build. Some of the quests are also incredibly hard to complete because you won't know where some tiny object is, or who you're meant to talk to, but in general they allow for a better amount of role-playing in how you complete them than you find in the other TES games.

All that said, the magic effects in this game are wonderfully diverse and can be used however you wish within your character's abilities. Be sure to try jumping over hills and whole towns in a single leap (and use slowfall!) for efficient travel at least once.

[TL;DR at the bottom] 

It’s not a controversial opinion for someone’s favorite Bethesda RPG to be Morrowind. Having gone back to play it on a whim, and not having liked Oblivion nor Skyrim all that much – and definitely not having any love to give for the Fallout Franchise, I’m blown away as to how hooked I got playing Morrowind and ended up finishing my first, largely unmodded (MCP) playthrough at around 60-ish hours. This does include finishing Tribunal and Bloodmoon; As well as the entirety of the Mages, Telvanni and Temple Factions.

On the technical side, Morrowind, after applying the ‘Morrowind Code Patch’ ran fairly decently but did have a penchant to crashing when quitting the game, as well as on rare occasion during gameplay. Even then, this was not a big issue as the game tends to create a save right before crashing. I have no complaints about performance, nor did I encounter any blatantly broken quests. That being said, I did encounter a somewhat common recurring bug wherein upon jumping, I’d fall through the world only to be swiftly reset. With some more troubleshooting, I got the game to not crash even on exiting; Having since started another playthrough on OpenMW, I would consider it to be essential due to the raw quality of life it brings to running the game.

Gameplay isn’t quite as smooth. On a reasonably vanilla set-up (i.e. w/o OpenMW), the player struggles to not slide off even the softest slopes. NPC’s often get stuck and block your path. This is particularly bad with flying enemies, who seem to struggle lowering their altitude to attack the player, with the result being clown-cars of Cliff Racers behind me only to randomly swoop down to actually attack me.  I encountered invisible “walls” in certain dungeon architecture that I needed to console command through to progress. This seems to relate to your movement speed and/or the Levitate effect.

A big point of contention is the player progression and how the game handles combat from the start: Unlike newer entries like Skyrim, where the only factor of actually hitting the enemy, is your actual hitbox connecting, Morrowind functions more like a CRPG, in which each strike – even if it physically connects with an enemy model, still rolls a dice dependent on your skill and factors in your current fatigue. The same is true for any other skill in the game; Spell Failure, Bartering prices etc. - In the early game this can often result in weird moments where the player stands still for half-a-minute, just waiting for their fatigue to recharge to squeeze a little bit of power (or drakes) from their current situation. 

On the flip-side, despite a rough start where every encounter is incredibly dangerous; Travel is long and methodical; The game eventually switches to becoming an incredible power-fantasy. This is largely due to many mechanics being “broken”; Or maybe more aptly: Exploitable. It is incredibly easy to generate endless gold through merchant restocks; To create incredibly broken spell-combinations; Or to kill seemingly impossible enemies through the fact of stat buffs of consumables stacking infinitely. 

The game is, inherently, broken in so many ways that any player will sooner or later stumble across a way to become powerful. Brokenly so; Just by virtue of the raw numbers the game is dealing with. It’s stupid but also stupid fun that somehow still manages to feel largely ‘balanced’. For me, when I was going through the expansions of Tribunal and Bloodmoon, I started to get burned out by the trivial encounters only to get shredded during the final dungeon of Bloodmoon and having to fall back to pull exactly all these broken tricks I had learned, to figure out which was the appropriate way to get through it. And it kinda works. It allows you to focus, truly focus on whatever you want your character to be good at – to roleplay, and to support that playstyle through the myriad of peripheral systems that help make you powerful. 

I have fewer good things to say about the quest-design, which thins out substantially towards the latter half of the main quest; And more so during the expansions. Whereas in the early- and mid- game, where travel is not yet trivial, working with your journal to figure out where to go for your quests, and traversing Vvardenfell is an incredibly immersive experience, the game quickly devolves into what *feels* like filler quests. The best non-spoiler example is the obscene backtracking that is required during Tribunal and the apparent struggle of the game to anticipate the PC doing objectives out of order. I frequently had to backtrack to talk to an earlier NPC, just do trigger a quest-flag even when I had already figured out what I was supposed to do, or where I am supposed to go. 

Another good example is a series of late-game main story quests, that send you all throughout the different factions for a diplomacy plot – only for each of them to send you on varying levels of utterly petty sidequests, like finding a ‘dating partner’ – for a relevant NPC. This is a problem that is simply not avoidable. It is Oblivion’s Oblivion Gates. Or Skyrim’s Civil War. The part of the game that is supposed to give a feeling of grandeur, but is in effect just obnoxious fetch-questing. 

Quests, in terms of roleplay choices, tend to be rather straightforward – with the more sophisticated ones usually being a choice from siding with A or B in a given conflict. This is sufficient, as roleplay in Morrowind is better focused to your characters personal development, playstyle etc., but can at times be fairly sophisticated, such as two different factions’ storylines overlapping with one another and thus forcing the player to pick a side to avoid locking themselves out from the other; Or getting, once again, creative with the games’ systems. 

Naturally, as with most semi-modern Bethesda titles, Morrowind is extremely moddable – especially for graphics and sound-design. Furthermore, Morrowind’s modding community is extremely active and provides an incredibly amount of tools to make the process of modernizing Morrowind a surprisingly smooth endeavor. That being said, even out-of-the-box Morrowind has a decent look to it, helped by its unique setting. The music is among the best that I’ve heard, easily competing with entries like Daggerfall/Unity.


[u]TL;DR[/u]
+ Unique setting that is supported by sublime writing; Unafraid to tackle themes that would not be acceptable in modern games.
+ Incredible support of emergent game- and roleplay: Factions naturally competing with one another; Rewarding the player for engaging with peripheral gameplay systems (Spellcrafting, Alchemy etc.)
+ Thoroughly moddable; Thus offering an easily customizeable experience for any player.
+ Spears. Very important.

+/- Combat- and Interactions are closer to what may be expected from a CRPG: Any action is inherently tied to both dice rolls and your current fatigue which may hamstring your enjoyment until reaching higher proficiency in any skill.
+/- Extreme freedom: i.e. persistent plot-critical items, and all NPCs being non-essential, means that it is possible to softlock your progress.

- Recurring, albeit non-game-breaking glitches; Falling through map-architecture, getting stuck; Crashes under specific circumstances.
- Lackluster and repetitive quest design during the latter half of the main game and both expansions; No anticipation of the PC doing quest(-steps) out-of-order.

Morrowind is an amazing experience. If you can put up with its quirks; How the games’ combat works, it will provide you with the best synergy of Bethesda’s modern Open World design and an incredibly immersive setting. Despite feeling burned out myself by these same quirks, the raw charm keeps me having it installed and excited to play through it with a modded set-up, or a fresh character fantasy.
Even in modern times, this game holds up to standards, it takes a little getting user to, but I quite enjoy it

Easily one of the most engaging RPGs I've played. I had to get past the very poorly aged controls, graphics, and poorly aged mechanics, but this is a game that asks you to be paying attention and to actively learn about the world you're in, and the responsibility given helps sell the role you play in the story. The game is also broken but in the best ways possible, to help explore an absolutely massive world that I haven't seen more than half of yet.

The best Elder Scrolls game, one of the best RPG video games of all time, an immersive experience that is unlike any other I've seen, even at vanilla, something that is hard to say for Skyrim, for instance. I enjoy Skyrim, but vanilla is quite a bore unless you use a lot of imaginative role play and suspension of disbelief to achieve in your mind what the game doesn't allow.

I recommend that if it's your first time playing Morrowind, you play as close to vanilla as possible, use OpenMW to get better performance and stability, I've played for 5-6 hours straight without a crash, and I'm sure I could play for way longer without one. OpenMW is truly a work of love by fans.

When you get to play, take it slow, read the manual, maybe read a guide to understand how stats, leveling, and dice rolls work, once you do, you'll appreciate the gameplay a lot more and won't care to use a mod that makes you hit all the time like many people do nowadays to expedite their playthroughs (but if you do use such a mod, it's all right, just know that there's a deeper game in there that you'll be enchanted by if you take the leap). 

During your journey across Vvardenfell, use a physical notepad to take notes as if it were your game journal, rather than relying on the in-game one. A tablet with a pen works, or as a last resort, take notes in your smartphone or computer, but a physical notepad is just a much more involved and personal experience. Immerse yourself in the story, the mysteries, the detective quests, the unique setting, become your character as you think through your actions and start developing a story of your own, who knows, you might even write a book. 

Once you're done with vanilla, mod the heck out of OpenMW, there are some awesome mod lists, I personally recommend One Day Modernization from openmw-modding, it will take A LONG time to setup, but it is worth it if you are a fan of these experiences. Keep an eye on OpenMW's development, it is one of those fan projects that deserves all the support and admiration it can get, I wish Oblivion and Skyrim got a similar treatment just so I could play them for long stretches without getting that demotivating random crash.

Also, keep an eye on Tamriel Rebuilt, they're building the actual Morrowind map, the one you get in the game is actually the Vvardenfell district of Morrowind, the island surrounded by the Inner Sea. Morrowind mainland isn't in the game, and it's a bigger area, Tamriel Rebuilt has built more than half of it, and about a quarter is full of NPCs and quests, they say they might finish the entirety of Morrowind by 2030, optimistically, I'll be showing my kid that awesome work of love when it happens.

In my opinion, Morrowind is the best elder scrolls game. This game is a classic no matter which way you cut it, look it up and down, flip it upside down or stick a pair of magic boots on it to send it into the stratosphere. It took the original original Elder Scrolls games and gave us our first taste of what a 3D modelled world within this rich universe would look like, and though by today's standards you may look upon it as ageing like bread I would argue more like cheese. Yes it may stink in comparison to newer fantasy games, but that rich tasting lore and vibe you get with this classic is still delicious by today's standards....and that is not a cheesy nostalgia addiction talking! I mean, take the soundtrack for example, a banger of a tune! It makes those early fights against pesky skycranes where 90% of your attacks miss bearable! The lack of hand-holding and sense of going your own way is strong in this game, as an adventure epic should be. Don't get me wrong, there is a main quest to follow....but we both know you ain't following it until much later when you've explored almost everywhere else. So yeah, I recommend this game to anyone looking to fulfil a trip into what a classic open world fantasy RPG game standard used to be.

Morrowind is a game where I both love a lot of aspects while hating a bunch of others with a passion. To get out of the way, the worst aspect of this game is the combat; The combat is heavily based on your proficiency with that skill and so is your hit chances, so the higher your proficiency the higher the hit chance, this makes the early game extremely frustrating. Another aspect i dislike are some of the quests; the majority of the quests can get very tedious since a lot of the objectives are very similar to other quests, especially some of the guild quests, and due to lack of quest markers, you can get lost extremely easily.  Even though i ragged on the game for the majority of this review, I actually really enjoy Morrowind. I love the setting of the game, it has such a mysterious atmosphere from the lived-in cities of  and Balmora to the countless ruins of a dead civilization long gone to the the eerie 6th house shrines. I love learning about the lore of the Vvardenfell, especially of the great houses, the lost civilization of the Dwemer, and tribunal temple and the god Vivec. The magic feels so good to use and customize, especially levitation. Overall even though i dislike a lot of aspects of the game, there's still a lot i really enjoy; I personally recommend you tried only if you can stand the outdated mechanics and want to immerse yourself in the lore.

I like this game but, it may not be for everyone. For starters it isn't fully voice acted so you will have to read if you want to know what is going on in the game. The game could also be called less accessible to those who aren't big RPG fans. You have to chose and stick with a skill set for a character. This though does give the game more replayability especially since certain character classes are more suited for some factions than others. Also the factions you join will have an effect on how much NPCs like you. This is just some of the considerations that have to be made in game. Magic doesn't regenerate on it's own like in Oblivion or Skyrim so you have to be deliberate about what spells you cast (and remember to take into consideration your chance to successfully cast it.) 
This is getting a bit long so let me put it this way. The gameplay could use some polish in some areas and you need to develop a tolerance for the walking speed and cliff racers (they aren't too tough but there are a lot of them and they don't give up.) If none of these things are deal breakers it is a very good RPG that gives the player a lot of choices.

Morrowind is a hard game to play.

The gameplay is not hard at all, but the overwhelming understandment of the tabletop quirks and thinking is required. The game asks you to perform and use a lot of little things that bounce out of each other things. Having a low stamina means that you aren't able to connect your sword or run as fast as you could. Low stamina can even affect how well you perform at bartering or other tasks which the game doesn't explain during the gameplay. But once you know this, you start to pay more attention to it and keep that stamina bar full.

The quests are very basic and dated. No twists. Most of them being 'fetch this' or 'go kill this thing' type of quests. You make your choices on what kind of flavor of quest you want to make and to whom. Like the guilds and houses the Morrowind has, they give you buffs or nerfs on quests based on which one you decide to side with. In a way it's a good thing that you aren't master of all, but it makes it worse since you might get a quest that isn't something your character can do. ie. Playing a pure strength/endurance Swordsman and deciding to join House Telvanni or House Hlaalu.

This is why the game is hard of beginners or people who want to try this game out after Skyrim or Oblivion. but coming from Daggerfall this game feels somewhat lacking in elements which made Daggerfall more rich game. For example in Daggerfall you are able to climb anything or break down doors, meaning that rogue and fighter could still move forward without any investment to their class respected skills.

In Morrowind you are in a way forced to invest a small portion of your skill pool to security to get other side of the doors or chests. Same with levitation, it's very useful skill and progresses the game heavily once you learn how to use for 10 seconds. This also means that alchemy and enchanting are skills that you should be put in minor because of their usefulness in any class. So this means it's better to choose one main weapon, restoration, destruction, armor type and all the things above as minimum for decent character.

So as a final thought, pick this game on sale and play it, it's still a good game.

I think Nostalgia has a lot to do with my love of this game, but this is one of my favourites. From the soundtrack to the unique world it creates, Morrowind is a great game, although the questing system is not as easy as the other games and the combat has a lot to be desired. For the events in this game and the rose tinted goggles I have I'd give this an 8/10 and I've never finished the game ;)

I love this game. I have probably have a few hundred more hours on the Xbox version from back in the day.

Pros:
- For the most part, the writing is excellent. It feels like a realistic world wherein many of the quests are mundane, but not grindy.  It's a good balance that also lets the more fantastical main quest shine by comparison.
- They evidently didn't give a shit about balancing, which actually creates a nice feeling of accomplishment when you create a spell that positively breaks the game. As long as it works in a way that's predictable to the way the game systems were intentionally designed, I think the ability to game the game's systems is very charming.
- The set design is more unique than later entries in the series, and, honestly, most western RPGs
- The writing-heavy dialogue system, which allows things to be explained in a greater amount of detail. It also allows modders to create dialogue-heavy quests that fit in much better than they would in the later voice acted entries
- The dice-roll based combat system makes level progression obvious in terms of gamefeel
- The lack of fast travel allows for a lovely feeling of serendipity for when you happen to come across quest-givers in the middle of nowhere, which is pretty common in the early game
- Levitation

Cons:
- Standard Bethesda bullshit, you have to download an unofficial patch or (preferably) OpenMW to make absolute sure you have a stable experience. I know it was a bit of a hack-job because the company was about to go under, but they've had many successful years since then to fix their own damn game.
- The soundtrack is like half an hour long
- The writing-heavy dialogue system, if you really don't have the patience to do that much reading (or are dyslexic and just now picking it up for the first time)
- The dice-roll based combat system is going to frustrate you
- The lack of fast travel is going to frustrate you
- Vivec city

Recommendations for if you do decide to play this:
- Don't minmax your character, for the love of god. That's more for experienced players who like to suffer. Pick your class skills according to what you'll actually use, and then actually use the correct weapons, and your swing failure rate should be much lower, even right at the beginning of the game
- Having high fatigue is super important and strongly affects your failure rate for like, most actions
Do you like reading? Boy do I have the game for you.

The main quest is hugely enjoyable narratively, the Levitation spell is a Godsend that deserves to be in the other games for the joy it gives me. All in all widely recommend Morrowind, especially to any Elder Scrolls fans

Come to the Heart chamber, I wait for you there, where we last met, countless ages ago. Come to me through fire and war, I welcome you! Welcome Moon-and-Star, I have prepared a place for you! Come, bring Wraithguard to the Heart chamber, together, let us free the cursed false gods! Welcome Nerevar, together we shall speak for the law and the land and drive the mongrel dogs of the Empire from Morrowind! Is this how you honor the 6th house and the tribe unmourned? Come to me openly, and not by stealth. Dagoth Ur welcomes you Nerevar, my old friend... but to this place where destiny is made, why have you come unprepared? Welcome, Moon-and-Star, to this place where YOUR destiny is made. What a fool you are, I'm a god! How can you kill a god? What a grand and intoxicating innocence! How could you be so naive? There is no escape, no recall or intervention can work in this place! Come! Lay down your weapons! It is not too late for my mercy...

What can I even say about this game? Morrowind so abundantly obviously stands head-and-shoulders-and-a-full-step-ladder above the other entries in the Elder Scrolls series. The world design, the lore, the atmosphere. Those elements remain fresh and delightful far after the admittedly dated gameplay can tire a player. They draw the player into the strange forbidding world in spite of its hostility. These aspects have kept me coming back to it, time and time again, to experience a unique sense of wonder.

"Each Event is preceded by Prophecy. But without the hero, there is no Event." Thus the game's opening cinematic begins. In most other games, the game's events proceed to give meaning to such a statement: the player knows that they are the hero. In Morrowind, that is not the case. Not at first, at least. The player, a prisoner "born on a certain day to uncertain parents", is sent from the Imperial City in Cyrodiil, to the island of Vvanderfell. Released, you are given a package, some gold, and told to find your contact Caius Cosades in the city of Balmora. And just like that, you are let go. You walk outside, you find a quiet village. In the distance further down you see a giant bug with hollowed out shell. The native standing in front of it offers his services to you: in exchange for a few pieces of gold, ride the bug to several cities and villages around the island, including your destination. The world does not get any less weird from here.

In your journey, you will encounter secret cults, abandoned ruins whose inhabitants seem to have vanished suddenly without a trace (they [i]have[/i], in fact, vanished from reality), quiet hamlets, wizards in isolated towers who definitely do not want you there, living gods, feuding nobility, and beasts and monsters that look nothing you have ever seen before. In Morrowind, Bethesda manages to create a world so captivating, so unique, I have never seen anything like it before or since. They certainly have been unable to capture the magic they bottled here in any of their later entries in both the Elder Scrolls and Fallout series.

There's really too much to say about how good this game is. It will be difficult to get into and feel borderline boring at the start but as you get levels and slowly piece together how to play the game, it becomes extremely fun.

There aren't map markers but here's the thing; you don't need them. Not only because the NPC's give you directions themselves, also that Vardenfell is an extremely dense open world. It will feel massive as you explore it but you'll quickly come to now where everything is as you fill out your map. Before you're done with your first guild questline (of which there are around 8, I believe) you'll have a good grasp on where stuff is.

It's a learning experience and if you use the community for help, you'll pick it up quick. It's incredbily rewarding to do so though, as Morrowind has more nuance in it's questlines, their outcomes, and the choice and consequence of what you do in the world than Skyrim or Oblivion. This is mainly because of it's lack of voice acting, so you won't see this again likely. The world itself is also one of the most creative and conceptually interesting fantasy worlds I've ever experienced. It's totally alien, mysterious, and extremely cool to roleplay in.

Play it. Easy top ten for me no question.

Edit: In terms of mods if you're so inclined, Morrowind Code Patch and Morrowind Graphics Extender will modernize the game and give you many more options to tailor the visuals or fix up some gameplay issues.

Tamriel Rebuilt is working to restore the entire mainland of the province of Morrowind, as the base game only takes place in the middle of it. They're 1/3rd of the way there. The content in it is comparable in quality to the base game but less content dense imo. This project is around 20 years old

Project Tamriel was at one point trying to add all the other Elder Scrolls provinces, but currently is only seeking to add Skyrim and Cyrodiil within Morrowind's lore and world building. Meaning, their landscape will be totally different. There's a decent chunk of "Skyrim: Home of the Nords" available and an island for "Province: Cyrodiil"

All of these can be found on the Nexus for Morrowind and I'd personally suggest them.

I mostly play OpenMW but this game is pretty bomb. you have to get into it tho, if you don't get past the first 3-4 hours of gameplay this game will drive you off.

Tips for enjoying the game on a first playthrough;
  -  Atronach birthsign makes mages very difficult to play, save it for a second playthrough.
  -  Don't try to experience all content in the game with one character, mages shouldn't be doing thieves guild quests and such, it's made to discourage that behavior.
  -  Pick Mercantile as a Minor skill no matter what class you make.
  -  If the game has a seemingly impossible quest, it may be a trap.
  -  Clean your inventory regularly. NPCs will not do business with you if you have illegal materials (Skooma, Moon Sugar, Ebony)
  -  Use the transportation. if you have a printer, i recommend printing out a copy of the game map and making lines for the transportation available to you.
  -  Most importantly, USE OPENMW, this game engine is a little screwed in the head, and even modern computers may suffer performance issues without OpenMW, not to mention some major bugs that it patches, along with having a sister project which allows you to play multiplayer.

I’m also becoming unkillable. 
Nothing can hit me before I jab them with a fucking halberd.

Fuck ‘em. 
If they’re immortal, I want them to remember dying to a naked lizard.
I also can’t stop taking skooma. 
It controls me at this point. I just guzzle it and launch myself around like Superman.
I’ll just fly to the clouds and kill a cliff racer on the way down.

But my main goal of all is to kill Vivec. 
I haven’t started the story yet, but that motherfucker's dead when I'm done. 
I’ll use ‘em then kill ‘em while high off my ass.
A god dying to a drug addict.

Oh. And my house is a mess. 
I need to visit the mudcrab merchant soon.

Also, this game can get fucking spooky sometimes.

Oh yeah. I forgot to mention my guy kills people in public for literally no reason. 
I’ve done it so much that the game glitched and guards attack me despite having no bounty. I kill them in self-defense, so I’m good; but the world is slowly turning against me.
My own guild mates hate me because of all my conflicting guild memberships.
Fuck ‘em.
I do what I want.
And the Aedra still love me. I get free blessings all the time.
Basically I’ve made this game my bitch.
And I love it.
I haven’t felt this immersed in an RPG in a long time.

A big plan I have for later is robbing the vaults in Vivec.
I’m going to steal all the money and just give it to everyone who survives this Hell I’ve made.
I’ll kill all the Houses. We don’t need ‘em.
I’ll just let each town prosper and live in anarchy.
I don’t want to be a leader.
I want to be a dominator.
Having everything and literally giving it away is sheer bliss. I’ve got everything I need.
I’ll just die alone in a shack after a skooma binge.
And my soul will go on.
But my passion will rest here forever - in the land of Vvardenfell.

I have some disclaimers for this review because much of what I say is slightly bias.

1, I played Skyrim first
2, I grew up in the 90's
3, I have only played for 3 hours at this time.

I really really enjoy Morrowind. I understand the graphics are poor compared to games like Skyrim, but it is a lot of fun. Morrowind is honestly very immersive to me.

Here is a short list of why I feel Morrowind is so immersive:

1, Quest log is a journal (which is written in the first person)
2, No quest markers
3, Speech is actually useful. Befriending someone can get you more info!
4, No skill tree (which some may see as a bad thing).
5, The list of skills feels really in depth.
6, character skills upon creation of my character had depth.

CONS.

1, Lack of options for character appearance.
2, Lack of spoken character dialogue. 
3, Arrows from my bow feel like they shoot off to the left.

It starts a bit slow, but I love exploring. The armor/weapon system in this game is the best. It's so customizable. Sometimes I want mismatching pauldrons to create a unique look. Someday I may even do the main quest. Daggerfall may have been my first Elder Scroll game, but Morrowind made me love the series.

morrowind is about 20 years old, but i didn't even touch this game until june 2021, so this review is completely void of nostalgia goggles. 

i immediately loved that the world map is a lot smaller than basically every other elder scrolls game ever, but still has a ton of depth in it and is still pretty big overall. i also loved how you start out in the middle of nowhere in a small town that isn't really important in the grand scale of the game, and from there you are able to go wherever and do whatever. you always hear stories of how a new player leaves that first town and basically starts an epic adventure that began with talking to a random npc in a random town, and i really didn't understand until i played for myself. having now put in close to 400 hours, i can say i've seen just about everything there is to see in morrowind, and i can say that this is in my top ten favorite games of all time. it is definitely worth purchasing, especially when it and oblivion are bundled together in a sale for a few bucks.

I didn't think it would happen but despite all the great reviews, I personally couldn't get into this game. Don't get me wrong, it's probably a great game and it probably deserves the praise but I just couldn't get used to so many aspects of this game. The graphics are not my issue and after a while, the lack of voice acting was also not an issue. It's primarily the gameplay mechanics. The player is slow, the lack of map markers is a personal issue of mine since I prefer my hand being held a bit in games, and most of all, the fighting is atrocious. Almost all of my attacks would miss and that got annoying very quick. You could aim directly on someone and hit 50 times and you'd be lucky if 2 of them hit. I get there are mods to fix this so maybe I'll return to it someday. I'm sure it was an amazing experience for its time and I'm happy for those saying it's great. Overall, I personally just couldn't get into this game because of how dated it was. Considering my PC can only run so many games, most being old, I got used to dated visuals. It's really only a few games like the first Witcher game and Morrowind that aged poorly. It's a 3/10 from me because of all these factors but I do hope that one day when I'm finished the other games in my library, I can come back to this game and enjoy it just like everyone else.
