the game basically doesn't start till all of your stats are 100 and even then you are slower then doodoo and miss every as i like to call it "Attempt to hit" attack, so just use the Console to give yourself 200 speed that's about how fast a normal human moves, then go to nexus and get a mod for always hit when swinging a weapon at an enemy, now that you can finally play the game good luck having full armor and still being able to loot anything without getting over-encumbered so boost that strength up to 150 with the console again and then make sure you don't carry TOO MUCH because the game will start deleting your inventory if you have too much stuff. once you have taken all this under advisement open the Wiki for Morrowind (Quests) (never close this) every new quest you get cross reference the names and just use the wiki to know where to go. if you enjoy crouch walking through dungeon's your Pinky is gonna be sore and you'll probably end up letting go by mistake and have the whole dungeon on you. oh and F5 is quick save push that every 5 minutes or you'll be sorry when you kill someone by mistake who is Vital to the main quest or maybe you screw up a pickpocket and get the whole town attacking you. 10/10 would Trash this game if it got a real remaster or maybe skywind will finally come out.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.
Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Very hard to get into but once you learn how to level correctly and build your character this game is easy to get immersed in. Probably the most foreign and interesting setting in an Elder Scrolls game. Would recommend anyone to play this if they love RPGs and Elder Scrolls in general.

Luck is an important stat (increases chance to successfully cast spells, hit enemies, etc.).  Add 1 point of luck every time that you level up.  It helps you cast spells and increases chances to hit.  Or, you can cast spells on yourself to increase it, but that's kind of like cheating and makes the game too easy.

This game is amazing!  The sheer amount of lore that went into this game...wow.  The landscapes are beautiful, with or without the Morrowind Rebirth mod or whatever the newest mod out there is to change the scenery... I highly recommend that mod for the aesthetics.  You can visit Solstheim with the Bloodmoon DLC included in the GOTY edition, just like with TES: V Skyrim.  I personally don't care about Solstheim or werewolves in either game.  Vampirism is meh, but you are more resistant to normal weapons as a vampire...and there is that one "broken" vamp quest.  Don't forget to explore and get Gold/Elton Brand, Denstagmer's Ring, and a whole slew of other game-changing Aedric/Daedric artifacts.

While some people do enjoy the rustic vibe of this game, I think that Oblivion and up are the only playable Elder Scrolls. Not only does this game not give you any sense of direction for anything, but every quest is something along the lines of; "keep going northwest till you see the green house. Therefore it will be the house above the blue house to the left of the brown cat." The skills in this game are horrendous as well, as you have to upgrade your combat so your character doesn't miss with his sword. I don't get how you would keep missing, as all you have to do is just drop it on them even to hit them. It really puts your character in this regressed state, where they couldn't even get a blanket off if someone laid it on them. The areas seem pretty barren and empty, leaving you to just aimlessly wander around till you get killed in the swamps. All in all, I bet this was a cool game back in the day, where you could just sink hours into it getting lost going to the main story, but no one likes games like that nowadays. I want to actually know what I am doing, and be able to actually do something. If you want something to show you how great Oblivion or Skyrim is, I would say to get this game. The only redeeming qualities I see in this game, is how it was revolutionary for the time. I give my respects to the old games that walked so that games nowadays could run, but this game feels like torture if you aren't playing it like it's Fable. Even with mods, I would still rather play any of the other games that were produced after this. Also, there just aren't any achievements for the game? Doesn't even seem viable for players just going for perfect games.

I don't like debating with people about why I think Morrowind is better than Oblivion or Skyrim, it's my opinion and it's one built upon my own personal experience with the game, and as such YOUR MILEAGE MAY VERY.

This game will feel immensely different than Oblivion or Skyrim, and if you are determined to jump in, then keep an open mind for when this game came out. There are countless videos on YouTube going into the nitty gritty of Morrowind versus Oblivion/Skyrim (it's a meme-worthy comparison), but those who love it do so for good reason.

I openly acknowledge that, while much of my love for this game is nostalgic, I find myself returning to it at least once a year and enjoying it just as much as I did in the 2000's. The depth of the lore, the alien-nature of the landscape, the mythical heights of the story, these aspects are unparalleled in other Bethesda games.

The gameplay itself is antiquated by today's standards, given it's combat is largely a Dice Roll based chop/thrust/slash system akin to D&D (with hit-accuracy often becoming the bane of player's existence). The magic system can be easily broken, resulting in low-cost OP spells. And while much of this can be corrected or amended through extensive modding (a scene that is still alive and active), the game will never run like its successors. The lack of voice-acting may also alienate many players familiar with Bethesda's iconic dialogue.

Thus, my advice to any new players is to approach the game from a story/lore perspective first. If you commit to "reading the game" you will be rewarded with a world that feels fully fleshed out, a world-building that was given immense love and effort. Talk to everyone, read every book, explore every nook and cranny. If you give the game your attention, it will give you an experience unlike almost every RPG.

The game will forever have a place in my heart.

P.S. If you have a friend who is begging you to play this, ask them to help set up some mods to make it look nicer, it's the least they can do.

7/10 (Long story short) Morrowind is a beloved older Elder Scrolls game with aged graphics, buggy gameplay, frustrating combat, and some of the best world building and storylines seen in any game.

My takeaway: I understand that Morrowind is an older title but even then it can hold its weight compared to titles that have come out more recently. That being said it is an extraordinary game but has its flaws in gameplay that can’t be ignored. I restarted this game twice in hopes of getting into it but I just couldn’t. In my very short time playing this title I came across an extremely buggy and slow moving world, combat that didn’t make any sense, and bulky long dialogue. If I’m reading between the lines I see an amazingly structured and beautifully created game. The story is great and the world building is out of this world! I just couldn’t bring myself to look past the dated mechanics and graphics which is my own fault because I can tell I’m missing out on something special.

You can create your own character, build your own class, and essentially play whoever you want to in a rich story filled world; if you don’t mind the old graphics and dated mechanics I would tell anyone to give it a go!

[u]Pros[/u]
[list]
   [*] Easily one of the most groundbreaking games in its generation.
   [*] Exploring is a very well made focus in this game.
   [*] Your choices ACTUALLY matter! It’ll shape how people interact with you and how your story progresses.
   [*] Soundtrack is amazing.
   [*] Story and world building is unlike anything else.
   [*] Character creation!
   [*] Class creation!
 [/list]

[u]Cons[/u]
[list]
   [*] The combat! You swing and swing and swing and you’ll never be sure if you’re doing anything.
   [*] Tutorial could be way better; it really just throws you in.
   [*] Dialogue in this game is bulky and hard to read/comprehend.
   [*] Very easy to get lost and even easier to just flat out not understand what you’re doing.
   [*] Older game = older graphics.
   [*] Mechanics and gameplay itself is very clunky and takes getting used to.
   [*] No quest marker; just pages of paper you have to read through.
   [*] So slow. Very slow. Extremely slow pace.
   [*] Voice acting has to be some of the most repetitive and boring I’ve ever heard.
 [/list]

[spoiler] I really didn’t realize that the sweetrolls were a running joke until I played the other Elder Scrolls games. If you’re a fan of the franchise I highly recommend. [/spoiler]

This is an exceptional game, very imaginitive, the story and atmosphere are top notch. A couple things I disliked were the locked 4:3 resolution, lack of much music, and rather dated graphics. The first problem can be fixed easily by installing the morrowind code patch and morrowind graphics extended, which takes like 5 minutes total. The music and graphics ended up not being a big deal because they've grown on me as I played, and I usually play old games with graphics like that anyways. You can get HD texture mods though so I'd reccomend those if the graphics bother you. Also the Dark Brotherhood assassains are a part of the DLC that comes with this edition, and can become very annoying at lower levels, so it might be advantageous to get the delayed DB attacks mod.

Morrowind was a classic when it was brand new. It's still an incredibly fun game, even though the graphics and controls are a tad clunky by today's standards. However, there are MANY mods you can use to tune it up to a more modern experience, and once again enjoy exploring the island of Vvardenfell!

It's Morrowind. If you like reading, and don't mind dice rolls, there's no better RPG experience. World and story are great, there's tons of ambiguity, so don't expect a concrete answer to everything at the end. Also I'm not joking, you have to read a lot, so if that's going to tire you out, you're going to have a bad time.

Without quest markers, fast travel, and more visceral combat, it's a way slower game than TES IV and V, doesn't have that same dopamine rush of ticking off quests and scratching that itch for the next batch of loot. But, at it's much slower pace, the worldbuilding and immersion are second to none.

If you can get past the ancient graphics, no fast travel, no quest-markers and weird dice-roll combat where sometimes you just straight up miss until you're at least a journeyman combat/magic/sneaky boi this game is amazing. 
You can enjoy a lot of the things that are removed from later games and see that Skyrim was dumbed down from Oblivion and Oblivion was itself dumbed down from Morrowind. Gameplay wise.

Levitation was removed because Bethesda realized invisible walls = substantially less work.

So I just finished Morrowind the base game I didn't do the dlc so far not too bad felt much different  than the last one but it does have flaws like how your movement speed is a stat which can make it take a long time to get around in the beginning, speaking of stats there's weapon and magic skill stats if they're low you'll be missing alot even though you look like your hitting them, your base stats can be lowered by status affects the problem is you need to have a spell or potion for each base stat lowered, the roads are better than Arena and daggerfall but they still feel barren with a few mobs spread out and a npc standing there waiting for you to talk to them to start a sidequest, 
Then there's the cliff racers which look like small pterodactyl and they're everywhere on the open map they swarm you, you'll always end up fighting one your not even safe in towns or cities, the most annoying mob in morrowind you'll be glad when you're done playing because you don't have to fight them until you come back to morrowind,
There's little to no voiced dialog just idle chat that doesn't match 90% of time who you're talking to, there's voiced cutscenes far between, and some voiced dialog from the main villain, so from the most part you'll be reading alot unless you want to be lost since there's no quest markers so you'll be relying on your journal, the good thing is quest don't have deadlines and you actually have to try if you want to mess up your play session both with sidequest and main quest, 
this Steam version doesn't save your settings so you have to configure your in game settings everytime you boot up the game, the game can crash so get use to saving alot, and finally the window can crash and get stuck when exiting out after a long play session 
In general not that bad feels better than daggerfall but it definitely is dated nostalgia for many I'd give it a 8/10
It was awesome back in the day, it is still good today, just bookmark the Wiki, it does not hold your hand on much

Morrowind - wade through all the fanboys review...

There are so many review on Morrowind that I thought I'd share some tips for beginners instead, and adressing fanboy topics.

INITIAL REMARKS

I'd probably rate this game 8/10 or 9/10. Some parts has aged poorly, such as graphics and combat, but graphics can be improved. Combat is a simple hack and slash and use potions/magic like Diablo 1. Enemies gang up on you, the majority are closed range so just click that mouse button to your heart's content.

MYTHS FROM FANBOYS / TIPS FOR BEGINNERS

There are a couple of myths regarding Morrowind worth addressing. This is to prevent new players from being to deterred from playing the game.

- There is no fast travel
This is one of the most famous conceptions of Morrowind. Fast travel exist in Skyrim and Oblivion, but not in Morrowind, therefore it must be better and more immersive in Morrowind. NOTE: fast travel did exist in Daggerfall and Arena as well. The problem is that there sure is fast travel in Morrowind. Money is easy to come by, so the internal transportation system will never be too expensive. Quickly you'll learn to hop on over across the map to the major hotspots. You can travel by silt strider or ship, and even teleportation through the mages guild.
You always only have to travel one way. When you have completed your objective, simply recall spell back to the quest giver. This is well known, and just because you anchor yourself and then cast a spell, it is still very similar to fast travel.

- Magicka and health doesn't regenerate
Also not true. It is true in cities, but not in dungeons. When enemies are far away in a dungeon you can "rest until healed" to completely regain your magicka and health. The only place in the game I had a problem with this was in the Bloodmoon DLC in Hiricine's realm.
Because of this it is simple to cast recall when one is done with the quest their on.

- There are no map markers
"Here let me mark it on your map" is a common line in Morrowind. You might not have a straight compass arrow pointing you toward where you're going, but you get a yellow blob usually close by. After that it is a simple matter of East-West-North-South from that yellow marker.
I have never ever had any major difficulty in finding where I'm going. The terrain is devoid of trees, grass and is in general flat. Openings in mountains are usually very easy to find, daedric shrines and Dwemer ruins are huge and easy to spot.

- Directions are confusing and the NPC lie to you so it is super hard to find your way
Also not true. I've heard of only two instances where directions are wrong, but this is not the case in the Main Quest and the guilds.

- You are super slow, but will get faster as you progress
Kind of not true. Most people have heard of the Boots of Blinding Speed. You can get these boots at level 1 and then never ever look back on being slow. At this point the slow speed is just gatekeeping for beginners. Get the boots, look it up on YouTube or something and save yourself from a terrible experience.

- You'll never hit anything
This is mostly true in maybe level 1-5 of the game. As long as you level combat skills fast (use trainers if you have to) the problems quickly go away. This is also a gatekeeping mechanic in that most experienced players would never keep sucking since it is not fun, and it is also a mechanic reserved for the absolute beginning of the game.

- Using a guide is cheating
I don't understand why Morrowind fanboys calls you a cheater for using a guide like UESP. They think that if you ever read a guide and don't just play this game blind you're a filthy cheater and will be a filthy cheater forever until the end of times. I'd say use guides for things to make your life easier such as finding the Boots of Blinding Speed, but not for quest directions (they are quite simple). 
   They pretend that strategy guides never existed when a game like Morrowind surely had a guide - included in the GoG version for sure - which is 419 pages long. Morrowind would also be covered in PC magazines at the time. Just because YouTube didn't exist yet, doesn't mean there weren't guides.

TIPS

- Use graphics mods, look it up on YouTube. MGE XE makes the draw distance better among other things which is a must.

- Learn how to make some easy starting cash in the beginning (use a guide)

- Use trainers. Trainers are cheap and can be found all over the 2nd city you go to; Balmora. Levelling up normally takes too long or you'll have to use stupid exploits.

- Do a guild after you've met Caius. I recommend doing Imperial Legion since they give you armor and weapons for free.

- Get the Boots of Blinding Speed as soon as you can, this should be your #1 priority

- Use guides when stuck.
good game

Push past the grind, research character builds, have patience, and you will find that Morrowind is one of the most open and free RPGs to ever be made. Want to down a load of booze for super strength? You can. Want to fly to areas of the map you aren't meant to access without even using a glitch? You can. Want to steal a ridiculously valuable soul gem from under the mage guild's nose early game and sell it? With effort and knowing where Creeper is, you can. Want to make those soul gems yourself, in late game, you can. As a Gen Z myself, I urge you to put time and effort into this game, because the rewards are truly massive.

A true-to-heart RPG with an incredible modding scene to help iron out those Bethesda 'features'.

The story and setting are amazing, as long as you don't mind reading a lot. The gameplay can feel clunky at first, but once your character is higher level and you know the mechanics better, the freedom it grants you is sorely missed in modern RPGs.

As for bugs, there are quite a few, but not too many game breaking ones. And there's plenty of community-made patches that are easy to install, which fixes the more annoying ones and corrects some oversights in the code as well.

This game isn't the easiest to get into if you've only played Skyrim like I did before this one, but it's well worth your patience.  

If you're going to try this game, I highly suggest using OpenMW even if you don't plan to use mods because the game runs a lot better on Windows 10 with this program and it stopped crashing on me. 

It's also a good idea to play around with character creation for a bit to see what suits you.  I did look at character build guides for some ideas, but it's not necessary because you can still become powerful even with an inefficient build.  Having a decent build does help out a lot when you're starting, however, since it will be easier to survive and do damage.  A warrior with supportive magic like Mysticism and Restoration was the easiest start for me. 

The lore and the worldbuilding is fantastic. Morrowind ranks up there with Planescape: Torment as having the coolest environment to explore in any RPG I've experienced.  You have weird mushroom buildings owned by eccentric wizards, ash plains riddled with diseased undead and incredibly annoying cliff racers, and lush swamps filled with all kinds of plants to use in alchemy.  It's amazing how well Bethseda was able to create different atmospheres with the game's dated graphics.

The lore also a lot more interesting than Skyrim's.  Dunmer culture is very alien compared to that of the Nords and Imperials, but their behavior makes sense given the harsh environment they live in and the guidance they received from certain Daedric princes.  Joining one of the Dunmer factions like a Great House or the Tribunal Temple is a good way to learn more about the world.  

The main quest is also really good.  While Morrowind's story doesn't involve dynamic, apocalyptic events like Skyrim's dragons or Oblivion's gates, there is a sense of creeping doom as you encounter more and more people and creatures that have been touched by the evil affecting the land.  Also, the role of Dunmer Messiah isn't given to you right away.  You have to prove yourself through numerous trials, which is a lot more satisfying than doing a handful of quests and quickly becoming the leader of the faction. 

I love Morrowind very much, though there are some aspects to the game that I didn't like.  Movement speed is pretty terrible for awhile until you train Speed to high levels.  Granted, there are enchanted items and spells to mitigate this, but they aren't affordable for awhile unless you know where to find valuable stuff.  I spent my first ten levels out of stamina most of the time because I couldn't endure having to walk everywhere.  Also, the dice roll combat doesn't mesh well with FPS mechanics.  A turn-based game will usually show "miss" animations but in Morrowind it looks like you're hitting even if you failed the dice roll.  This can be frustrating at low levels.  Lastly, NPCs will block you A LOT in hallways. Waiting for an hour clears your path most of the time, but sometimes you have to use console commands to reset their positions.  This was an especially irritating problem with the stairwells at Fort Frostmouth in the Bloodmoon expansion.

I could go on and on about this game, but this review is getting too long as it is.  Morrowind is a joy to play and I highly recommend it.
Started with Skyrim when it first came out, played through Oblivion recently, just now getting to Morrowind in 2022. Excellent game if you have the patience for it.

Morrowind is incredibly close to my heart. While not my first game ever (that honor goes to Unreal (1998), it was still the first one that truly opened up my imagination and was the initial catalyst of my creative writing abilities that would later evolve into roleplaying on the likes of user-made maps on Starcraft and eventually various MMO's. I engage in creative writing and roleplaying to this day and it all dates back to Morrowind.

When my brother got back from an unsuccessful attempt in the Air Force, he came home with an Xbox and… this. My recently passed mother often referred to Morrowind as having the best music she’d ever heard, and often watched me play in the earlier days. So the importance of Morrowind to me cannot be understated.

I used to claim that it took fifteen or more years to finally feel dated, but I binged eight hours of it earlier today and it still holds up. I unfortunately have long since lost any sense of wonder and discovery, having the muscle memory and just general memory of knowing where some of the master trainers were, hidden caches of gems, and the specific mechanics of high level enemy respawns that allowed me to farm high value-to-weight ratio gear to sell and managed to swim in hundreds of thousands of gold to mass-train myself quickly into Godhood before doing five quests. (For those curious; when you get attacked by assassins, follow that questline to the Mournhold sewers, kill what you can handle, sell their gear in the Bazaar, rinse repeat).

So for the newcomers, this is a twenty year old fantasy RPG. Attacks will commonly miss until you train your weapon up because there’s just an invisible back end mechanic that changes your chances to hit. Thankfully the leveling curve can be pretty smooth (as long as you know how to run away). Keep swinging at those basic bandits and mudcrabs, once you get a weapon skill into the 40’s and 50’s it becomes a lot easier.

There’s no map markers or instant fast travel, but there are spells to help (Mark/Recall, the two Interventions) that can help land traversal be much less annoying. Instead there’s a robust journal where you can look up key words alphabetically, and in a later expansion (with this very version) they gave us a functional quest log to help keep track of what you’re doing. 

It still has the usual staples of inventory management, gear, damage types, and so on. Even recent gamers won’t find themselves too abandoned to ye olde wastelands. What really brought Morrowind to the forefront of millennial gamer’s minds was the inherent weirdness of the whole thing. Vvardnefell’s biome is strangely varied. A volcanic mass in the middle, blocked by a ghostly gate to keep a powerful disease at bay. The west, swamplands. The south, an ocean with a Venice-inspired water-based city. The east, fairly even grassy plains and hills. All over you’ll find imperialistic, Roman inspired stone buildings alongside carved-out mushrooms and resin-based buildings with crablike imagery. It’s a wild place to be, and I highly miss going door to door in every town and finding out what’s in there. Or noticing that a path diverges slightly, and I always knew there was something cute tucked away.

Story-wise, it’s a fairly old school chosen one style but with a general twist. The idea is that you are the reincarnation of a long lost hero, but it’s not as literal as you’d think. There’s no ghost that speaks to you, no mentor that guides you as a spirit. He’s just not there at all. Instead you are guided down a path through political means to the point where you’re simply taking up the mantle, and in doing so you unite Vvardenfell against an enemy that wants to spread a forged disease to kill or enslave the world. The fact is you’re not really the “chosen one”, you are a hero that took the steps to help save the landmass.

Or don’t. If you kill an important NPC you get a message telling you to reload or “continue in the doom world you have created”. You can lock out some questlines but nothing truly stops you from continuing to play. It would take hundreds of hours to explore every tomb, cave, and quest.

So clearly, I’d highly recommend this game. Modding it is fairly simple if you think that may help the graphical fidelity, and it runs fine on modern machines through some resolution tweaking. I just feel that Morrowind is a must play for anyone interested in where some genres got some of their ideas, because Elder Scrolls was one of the first.

I hate Morrowind. 

I hate it, not for the gameplay, the graphics, the story, etc. etc. but for the fact it ruined the magic of Oblivion & Skyrim for me. Morrowind is one of the best games of all time, plain & simple. For being nearly 20 years old, it's easily the most engaging open world game I've ever played. 

There are no quest markers holding your hand guiding you through the big scary dungeons, you have to pull on your big boy pants and explore them yourself. Hidden areas are legitimately hidden, you have to search for them & constantly check your local map. You'll find hidden tombs & barrows tucked away in rocky alcoves, not shoved right on the main road. Speaking of hidden things, Morrowind is absolutely crammed with hidden gear, It's completely worth checking over & under everything in dungeons since there might be a hidden sword or pair of boots stashed away. There are a huge amount of small/unmarked things, too. Everything from encountering a shrieking man falling from the sky, to helping a bloodthirsty orc meet his end, and meeting a friendly crab who's more than happy to buy all your junk for full price. Also, the DLCs are both amazing, Bloodmoon is a little backtrack heavy, but it's great & Tribunal is just perfect. There's so much more that this game offers that I can rave about, but I hate overly bloated reviews.

Is the combat that great? No, to be honest, it's horrid. Unless you download mods or mess around in the command window, you're probably going to be using 1, MAYBE 2, types of weapons and armor your whole playthrough. And onto the biggest gripe I have with this otherwise perfect game: the Hortator & Nerevarine quests. These quests are absolutely miserable. You have to walk around to every single tribal camp & Great House spread across the whole island just to get them to recognize you as Nerevar reincarnate. Some of the quests you have to do aren't bad, others are full of pointless backtracking & huge dialogue trees. Easily the worst part of the whole game. Also, the game's default controls are beyond archaic, but it's nothing 45 seconds in the menu won't fix.

TLDR: Buy Morrowind, you s'wit. Also, the 6th House, the Tribe Unmourned shall rise again!

tl;dr: I would recommend anyone who likes classic RPG's play Morrowind. 

Pros:
+Incredible world-building that lays the foundations for future installments.
+Varied quests and characters with interesting outcomes.
+Magic is much more open to customization than future titles. Making your own spells is required at some points.
+Character progression that feels very tangible. Feels like an actual power fantasy past the midpoint, and you start from a weak nobody before progressing to a god.

=Classic RPG mechanics. Everything plays out like a more traditional tabletop RPG for better and for worse. Combat is dice rolls which can be circumvented, but it's not friendly to new players or players whose only experience is Skyrim.
=Travelling from place to place isn't easy and there is no fast travel. This provides a challenge for an otherwise basic thing that most people don't think about. Once you've "solved" travelling late game it becomes another annoyance.

-Combat is not deep. Once you get consistent hits at a high enough skill level it's all about spamming your attacks. Magic is similar and you can only use one at a time very slowly. Using spells for combat feels weak unless you know what you're doing. Magicka doesn't naturally regenerate while walking around or waiting and you need to rest and it's not always easy to do so in the middle of an adventure.
-The DLC's are tedious. Bloodmoon is filled with too many enemies that all have some form of magical reflection, and they are damage sponges. Once your strength gets high enough your weapons break too fast and Solstheim has no easy way to get repair hammers. The quests are very rote "Go here, talk to person, kill thing, come back" stuff. Tribunal is even worse with this and has a gigantic sewer system that is easy to get lost in which the game constantly expects you to navigate for every major quest. During my playthrough of the game I got major burnout while forcing myself through these two campaigns.
-Glitches. Bethesda is known for their funny bugs, but Morrowind's were never interesting to me. Just annoying. Even with a very high quality fan patch I ran into bugs and oversights that required a wiki walk and console commands to fix. Quests would sometimes become impossible to complete or remove from the journal without the console. Speaking of quests...
-Some quests are evil. A quest where the ideal outcome only has a 65% chance to succeed and you can fail through no fault of your own. The lack of quest markers is generally a good thing, but if you don't ask the exact right questions or the developers forgot to give you the right details then it is incredibly easy to miss what to do next.
---CLIFFRACERS

Overall, I recommend Morrowind but I also recommend keeping the wiki open in the background. And use the Code Patch!
The depth of the quest-lines are insane!

While I'm not generally a fan of older games just for their own sake (I still remember people flipping the f out about Fallout 3 being first-person and not isometric and acting as though this was a HUGE BETRAYAL.  Pft.  People are [i]idiots[/i]) I did get a kick out of this one.

I first played it back in 2003 or 2004, got the game of the year edition at Best Buy, could NOT get into it. The color palate just didn't work for me. Dispiriting. Gross. Just couldn't play it for more than a few hours, though I enjoyed the game itself.

But I got in a MOOD after downloading Daggerfall, and decided I wanted to play 3-5 again, so here we are. All in all, kinda sad I missed out back in the day. It has the main thing I like (and hate) about games back then, which is that it's BROKEN. When they created this whole world and all the ways with which you could interact with it, certain mechanics worked in such a way that if you wanted, you could just utterly dominate the whole system. In THIS case, it's alchemy. (Enchanting could've been similar, but they made it so freakin' impossible to get a success on really GOOD enchantments even with 100 skill that getting started with it became more trouble than it was worth, compared to alchemy, which is a breeze.)

If you know what I mean, you know, and if you don't, Google exists, so I don't need to waste space here.

Point is that they created a sandbox and left these things in practically as a reward. "Want to get into our system and really play in this world? Then if you try, you can do THIS!" It has the feel of playing a game as kids where you make up the rules as you go, and if you wanna do LITERALLY ANYTHING, then you can, you just have to think of a reasonable justification within the framework of the loosely-designed game you've created to make it possible. It gives the feeling of an experience you're joining in on, and not so much a packaged product that's like "this time we've created very set, stringent boundaries to keep you WELL inside the box so you can't do that fun shit we accidentally let you do before." You know, like later games in the series.

They're not BAD. They're just not as fun, and DEFINITELY not as fun in the same way.

Another fun thing that I didn't even realize is that your journal (OK, the journal is terrible) but it's not entirely to be trusted. I finished (according to the journal) one questymission thing and the last thing that transpired made me go, "Huh. I bet this person I talked to earlier would wanna hear about that," so I went and talked to them on my own, the journal was uninvolved. And they were like, "Oh, ho! That IS weird! Actually, maybe this other thing is going on," and suddenly I was off on a new thing that was still a part of the old thing, but I'd never have known it if I hadn't just decided to go talk to them.

In that way, even if things are generally more old-school feeling, the world actually does seem more responsive and even kinda alive than newer entries.

Anyway, I played it without mods for the base experience, and I recommend it. Right up until I beat the game and used my hyper-speed levitation potion to uncover about 95% of the whole map, and then it just crashed with no warning, so I'm uninstalling it now. I'll struggle through a crash when I'm working to finish the game, but fuck it if I'm gonna redo my random post-game stuff when it's not playing along.

The best Elder Scrolls game in my opinion. More depth than the subsequent games while not being as impersonal as Daggerfall.
That's not to say it isn't without its faults. Mainly, the animations are very, very not good. At best, it's charming, like characters strutting around like they somehow have both the confidence of a god and a 10 pound load in their pants. At worst, it's the combat. Stiff with very little feedback, combat outside of spells is more based on how many potions you have. There are also some issues I have with the writing, more so the contents than the quality. These flaws don't hurt the game once you're into it, but getting into it is the hard part.
Overall, 7/10. Great game in my eyes.

Morrowind is one of if not the best open world games I've ever played. Don't let my hours deceive you, I got this game when I was 9 on the original xbox and played it for easily thousands of hours. My first play through was me going around slaughtering everyone and anyone in sight and ya know what's fun about that? The game let me! Morrowind is a game like no other and it's truly a modern marvel. You can quite literally do anything. Kill anyone, steal from anyone, levitate, punch someone until they're completely fatigued and loot their pockets! Make yourself completely invisible, enchant items and create potions that make you a borderline neigh unstoppable God! Get diseases, cry because you hear a cliff racer for the 849th time, join one of many, many factions and work your way up the ranks! Go on a quest and check your journal and realize it's really hard to find a cave in a bunch of hills with very vague directions or even with clear directions! I could actually keep going and listing all the cool things you'll be doing while playing Morrowind, but you could also buy it yourself and find out.

The combat system is a little odd at first and learning how it works is one of the harder aspects of the game as well as navigating the absolutely humongous map. I'm not evening talking about going to Mournhold or Solstheim which really give you almost too much to do. While I'm listing things that may be turn offs, check out mods that make the game a little more presentable and add decent QoL to the game because while it is a spectacular open world game, it has issues that will turn off most people due to it's age. [h1]i’m not saying that it’s a bad game, but compared to other rpgs from that time, morrowind is pretty overrated and aged relatively poorly.[/h1]

this is especially true for the grafics. with mods, you can still make this game look pretty decent by todays standards, but i always aim for that original experience in games and so i played it with completely vanilla grafics. morrowind was released the same year as gothic 2 and oh boy does that game kick morrowinds butt in the visual department (and basically in almost every other aspect as well, but that‘s just my opinion). 

morrowind‘s world is incredibly ugly and barren. for example, where you have lush vegetation, vibrant colors and very atmospheric world design with much care for detail in gothic 2, there are just flat fields with a rock and one or two trees or little flowers here or there in morrowind. In those areas that are especially flat and barren, there is a considerable amount of distance fog. Later there are some areas in the game that look rather atmospheric and interesting, and the interior sections are designed with a lot more care for detail than the outside world, but especially the opening areas of the game look just bland and outdated for the most part. the colorpalette basically consists of brown and dark green, any other color is barely existent in morrowind.  the artstyle is a pure matter of taste. since it plays on a vulcanic island, morrowind’s barren, insectoid aesthetics may be fitting, but i personally felt like i was walking over a giant ant hill most of the time. the worst thing by far are the blocky character models with animations so stiff that even the most primitive robot moves like a ballet dancing jellyfish in comparison. after about half a dozen hours your eyes start to get used to the dated grafics and then it starts looking not as bad anymore, but my first impression was a loud YUK! let’s face it: morrowind looks just ugly, even for 2002 standards and its world is muted and lifeless as hell. on top of it, changing the gamma setting doesn’t seem to do jack-sh*t and the game remains terribly dark in some areas to the point where you can barely see anything at all. the final nail in the coffin of its presentation is the music, which in itself is great but unfortunately drones on and on in an endless inappropriate loop that sometimes kills the whole atmosphere with unfitting musical background.

before you are able to settle in, you have to overcome at least 3 to 4 hours of the most inaccessible rpg gameplay i have ever experienced. the quest log is a jumbled mess that makes it barely possible to keep track of all your quests and kills any motivation for completing more than just the bare minimum to finish the main story. the npcs just crush you with literal walls of text (morrowind is one of the most reading intensive games i ever played) and the combat is the dullest, stiffest form of pure rpg numbercrunching and dice rolling without any actual strategy, skill or fun. The worst enemy however is the terrain. I constantly got stuck, especially in the narrow interior sections, and on the outside even the slightest bump is a chore to get over because of the floaty, almost completely useless jumping mechanic, which often doesn't let you climb the smallest rock or step. some of the locations are not only ugly but also incredibly confusing to navigate (Vivec!), and even if you know where to go it is most likely that your progress is impeded by the hundreds of times an npc blocks the corridor you have to go through or the buggy, sloppy world itself that gets you stuck in holes you can’t climb back out of or makes you fall through the floor. it doesn’t stop there with the technical problems though: after steam updated the game, it wouldn’t save my grafics-, audio-, control- and gameplay settings anymore, so I had to set them up again and again everytime i started the game. In addition, the game kept crashing repeatedly when i tried to reload my save-games. 
lastly, just like in oblivion and skyrim, the progession- and level-up system sounds good on paper but is a double-edged sword in practice: you improve your abilities not through spending skillpoints, but by just repeatedly executing the respective activities. what this leads to is that you end up constantly jumping everywhere instead of walking to increase your agility skill. you thought quake 3 arena was the king of bunnyhopping? think again.

now don’t get me wrong: even though Morrowind and I won't become best friends anymore, I can still see why so many hardcore rpg-fans absolutely love this game and think that it’s not only the best elder scrolls game, but also one of the greatest rpgs of all time. the freedom that morrowind gives you in how you want to approach it is basically unlimited and the underlying rpg mechanics are deeper than those of oblivion and skyrim combined plus the tons of lore in this game are a feast for those inclined to dig deep into it and read their a** off. what has aged severly on the other hand are its presentation, clunky controls and inventory and overall inaccessibility, that make morrowind appear much more dated than other contemporary rpgs of its time.
after a period of getting used to its gameplay I definitely had some fun with morrowind, so objectively it holds up decent enough as an rpg in 2021 i guess. however, for me personally, who really enjoys a good action-rpg now and then but overall spends more time with fast-paced fps games, it’s just not the right cup of tea in the end, and its two successors ended up much more enjoyable for me. Morrowind is radically different from Oblivion and Skyrim, so to anybody who expects an experience similar to those two: Consider yourself warned! 

Morrowind < Skyrim < Oblivion 
*runs away before getting hanged, drawn and quartered*
__________________________________________________________________________

I wish this was my first experience with the Elder Scrolls franchise. Although it's graphically dated and mechanically challenging at times, the gameplay is very fun and the story is awesome. I found myself getting considerably more engaged in the politics and people of Vvardenfell than I ever did with Skyrim or Cyrodil. The amount of systems in this game that are absent in the newer titles makes Morrowind feel like it's from an entirely separate franchise than the games that follow it. If you install graphics mods and patch some of the bugs, this is an incredibly fun experience with a compelling main story and some very interesting side stories.

Ignore my playtime - I played it on Linux using OpenMW which I didn't have connected to Steam so hours weren't recorded.  I've probably have about 40 - 50 hours in the game (not to mention numerous hours modding it when I realized I didn't care for the un-modded game).

My thought is the same as when I first played the game when it first came out.  I find the game pretty tedious.  I just don't find the story that interesting (though I did find it interesting that you might not actually be the Chosen one, but rather simply a person who did what the chosen one was supposed to do which was enough to be called the chosen one) so I was left with combat and exploration which wasn't that good.

Honestly, the biggest issue i have is that this is a game that does levels based on using skills which is nice in theory, but just makes the early game tedious (i.e. trying to hit anything with low weapon score or moving with low athleteics) and the game is tough at the start until you either grind or get enough to get over the hump where things get tediously easy.  Since you learned through doing things, you didn't get xp from killing monsters and completing quests.  I soon found no point in doing either and the game quickly became a (bad) walking simulator. when I want what people consider a great RPG.

Not even mods to change combat or anything made the game any more fun (I had more fund looking for and installing the mods).

Maybe, just maybe, it would've been a little more enjoyable if you could walk/swim without groups of cliffracers/slaugther fish spotting you from what seemed like miles away, aggroing on you , and following until you waste killing them (or early on dying to them).

Many things could be said of Morrowind, but I will try to keep this short. Simply put, it's the best game I've ever played. It requires more effort to learn the game systems compared to Oblivion and Skyrim. But the game is much richer. Richer in story & world building, character options, questlines, and so on. No other game has so successfully presented a unfamiliar and detailed world that's truly its own. For instance, Skyrim's world is largely inspired by vikings. Not too much actually feels unique. It's really difficult to even pick out what real-world cultures inspired Morrowind. It's its own world. And the gameplay makes you immersed in this world. No map markers. Your quests are written down in your journal. This means you need to pay attention to things to complete quests--talk to the NPC and follow their directions, navigating and searching for your destination. 

There are many mods to update the graphics and such, as well as lore-friendly additions to the game (Morrowind Rebirth is my favorite mod for this).

As with every Elder Scrolls Game, you need to mod it. If you are new to Morrowind then it will be a tough ride but most certainly a fun one, if you embrace it. If you're a returning adventurer and worried that the game might not be fun anymore because you already know of 99% of the exploits and epic gear locations then I can recommend setting limitations.
Playing a class foreign to you would also help.

- Do not buy gear, only use what you loot from adventures(not shops).
- Do not use ol'scampy boi or Mr Crabs
- Do not make cheese spells. Levitate 1pt on target included.
- Do not use crazy enchantments
- With every lvl you gain, add 2 to the dificulty slider in game options

For me, the game became way more enjoyable this way.

Great player freedom, great rpg mechanics, great story, even if the presentation is a tad dated, only having some of it voiced is a little jarring, great style, the game hits a major snag for me though with only 2 things which I feel need to be modded out to make the game enjoyable if it wasn't something you played as a kid and just kind of force yourself to defend out of nostalgia. 
  1, your speed at the start of the game is fucking atrocious, I know it gets better but good god you are slow, like so slow that it feels like you barely move. I understand this was a decision that was probably made to make you use the unique fast travel options, that I do like, but it still feels awful when you just want to explore around. It gets a lot better later in the game but it doesn't change that the early game exploration is going to be horrible because you move as fast as a quadriplegic.
  2, the combat is truly horrible, I get that it's mostly the lack of feedback but it still doesn't change the fact that seeing a sword phase through an enemy and do literally nothing is not fun, bows are even more egregious, you can hit someone with an arrow and the game just goes "lol nah you didn't hit them fuck you", I do love spell failure though, that is pretty cool and something I actually wish was in oblivion and skyrim.
  All in all if you're willing to suffer through the strange way the game has to be modded to fix the issues it has, I mean the game is like 20 years old it's gonna feel dated, I think this is actually pretty great.

This game is a great game, it delivers the same thing as Skyrim, just with a different style of gameplay - a little more delicate and also slower paced. The tone is more story book, rather than a realistic take on "medieval" Nordic warrior life like in Skyrim. Skyrim abounds in epic, dramatic and mysterious adventure while Morrowind is a bit more layed back, it is more sedentary and perhaps more introverted. Morrowind has a lot of subject matter though and those who play 5 to 10 hours into the game realise how much it has to offer. Another thing about Morrowind is the way it captures the time when it was made. There is a real early to mid 2000's feel about the game, bringing back a similar feel to the Lord of the Rings movie trilogy made then, bringing also a shadow of the 90's exhilaration, adventure and fantasy. Besides this, it also brings with it an early to mid 2000's map feel about it too. Walking down into the swampy forest westward towards Gnaar Mok (apologies if I got the spelling wrong) has a very similar sense about it to the Tree House level map in Far Cry, which was made about the same time (this is somewhat of a horrifying level, I unfortunately have a limited experience of games in terms of variety). I would play the game for relaxation or otherwise push forward to experience the game as much as possible in order to gain the best appreciation of the game. The time that has passed seems to increase the game play rather than decrease it.

My favorite game of all time.

PROS:

-Quests are engaging and there's over 400 of them.
-Main plot line is super interesting.
-Each faction has a unique quest line that impacts other quest lines, which ties into my next point;
-Your actions have a lasting effect on the world, so you have to think about what you do. Not many games nowadays are like that.
-Atmosphere is immersive and diverse.
-Character creation system allows for unlimited role play potential.

-Very low draw distance.
-Chance-to-hit combat.
-Slow run speed.
-No fast travel.

Buy this game. You'll love it.

I will say this - this game is amazing and I can see why people love it. The lore and quests are expansive and the world building in this game is fantastic. 

Here is where this game looses me personally though:
- dialogue is not spoken/voice acted 
- there are no quest markers/map updates when you take on quests
- the movement and combat in the game start off very clunky

I have tried on a few occasions to get into this game, I have put in the hours to level up weapon skills and experience some of the better quests in the game. But every time I speak to an NPC it feels like reading a wiki article rather than talking to someone. 

With quests in the game, I do need oblivion style markers for them, but it would be nice if the map revealed the location where they were referring to (like the city someone is in at they very least so I spend less time wandering aimlessly). Like I do not mind getting immersed into the world but when I wander for more than an hour and have not found the cave or the hall that the NPC I am looking for is located in it does where me down a bit. 

When it comes to be combat and the movement, I do not like how the stamina heavily affects everything you do. I feel as if I need to run all the time to make the game feel OK from the start. Running uses stamina, and if you have low stamina and get caught in a fight you're going to die. 

In the same vein, unless you level up your weapon/magic stats considerably you miss a lot of your strikes/magic attempts - which is very frustrating as well. 

For these reasons I usually default to oblivion or skyrim for my ES needs. Like I said, this game's world is amazing, the areas and quests are great, and I do recommend the game for RPG fans. But with the issues I mentioned it just falls short of playable for me personally.
I don't care what anyone says - this particular Elder Scrolls game was the last really good game of the series.

One of the greatest TES games made. A true RPG experience. A vast open world to explore and dungeons to delve into. Loot to dfind and quests to complete. This is also a game that is drastically different from the modern TES games. No compass. No quest markers. No quick fast travel. A game that really forces you to read your journal and listen to the dialogue to know where to go or what to do. A game where talking to teh NPCs to figure out who or where the person is you are looking for. A game that if you kill the wrong person. you may forever 'brick" your story because you can kill essential NPCs. All actions are based off dice rolls within the game engine. So especially early on, don't expect to kill anything easily. Expect to die. Expect to run away to live another day.

Customize you character and skills. Major and minor skills dictate your levels. You truly need to build your character and plan out your late game build. There is no "everyone becomes a sneak archer" in Morrowind. Equip L and R gloves, L and R pauldrons, Boots, Greaves, Chest, Head. Equip Clothes under your equipment. Equip a robe over everything else. Enchant these individual pieces for endless end game god like builds. There are tons fo clothing and armor to choose to even RP as or just decide to look fashionable.

Dated, yes. But it is an RPG all fans of RPGs should experience.
Consider using mods and/or OpenMW to enhance the experience and make running the game a bit more smooth.

Also the music is A++ nothing beats the nostalgia of that opening.

In a lot of ways, Morrowind has not aged well in terms of modern gaming. The menu UI is cumbersome and overwhelming, the fatigue system is outdated and often frustrating, and combat is typically an exercise in tedium. 

That said there's substantial charm to the world and it's characters, the atmosphere is gripping and strange, and there's an explorability to everything that constantly has me finding new things after years of playing (don't trust the Steam hour count, I've probably got a few thousand hours in TES III). And as always, Soule's OST is brilliant and lends a real weight to the setting. 

I love TES IV and V (Oblivion and Skyrim, respectively) to death, but in my opinion the series was never more interesting than it is with Morrowind. The world, the culture, the people... everything in Vvardenfell is WEIRD, but it works. The main plot is full of intrigue and mystery, and winds its way through other questlines in a way that was never really achieved in the next two sequels. Players are rewarded for their patience and their diligence in understanding the setting they've been thrust into.

Morrowind won't be for everyone, but if you're the kind of player that likes to take a game slowly and really dig into its DNA then it might be for you.

If you can get past the hump of the combat, you will be rewarded with systems that allow you to break the game over your knee like it's a dry twig. Skyrim was my first Elder Scrolls game, which I ended up loving. That led me to hear about how great Morrowind was. After starting and giving up the game about 10 times over the coarse of a year or so, I finally got myself to get through the initial learning curve required for someone used to modern games. I don't think everyone will enjoy Morrowind, but if you think you will, it will probably end up becoming your favorite Elder Scrolls game, as it has mine. Arena, Daggerfall, Redguard, Morrowind, and Skyrim down, Oblivion and ESO to go. And Morrowind will probably still reign supreme.

Pain. Never before have I experienced such anguish with a game in my life. The early game is ROUGH because of the less than ideal game design. Before I go into a long review of this game's flaws, I will state that this game isn't 100% awful. It's an elder scrolls game, and it has some cool features that others don't. I like the variety of weapons in the game (you've got maces, clubs, spears/halberds, various swords, throwing knives, throwing stars, bows, axes, etc.). I find the lockpicking sound effect very satisfying. I like being able to help free slaves and hold and actual candle or lantern for light. I think having doors and chests sometimes be trapped with magic spells is cool. The graphics are a bit scary and unpleasant (especially the way argonians and khajiit walk), but I can't fault such an old game for that.

LEVELING UP
God awful. For visuals, think of it as a logistic growth but the exponential portion of the graph is a lot more gradual. You level up by successfully perfoming skill related tasks such as: hitting enemies, being hit, persuading, using magic, etc. The problem is, when you're low level these things rarely happen because it's all RNG based and not skill based. So you're stuck in a position where you're stuck in low levels for an ungodly amount of time whilst not being able to do anything because you're low level but you need to do things to level up. I believe I was only level 3 after about 15 hours of playing. I understand some people see this kind of leveling system as "realistic" but when it's done to this degree it's just unfun.

COMBAT
Thoroughly unenjoyable and boring. It's layer upon layer of RNG, but not the fun kind like in Pokemon. What determines whether or not your hit lands and how much damage it does is a few different stats. First, your proficiency in the weapon type you're using, it's durability, and some of your general stats (like agility and endurance I believe) affect your odds of landing a hit. How much stamina you have left also affects these odds. What determines how much damage is done is which attack you perform with your weapon (which you have no control over). Early levels, which is a very notable portion of the game, is characterized by you furiously spamming your mouse button whilst practically kissing the enemy in front of you and whiffing 90% of your shots (and that's being generous). Also, every time you swing you lose stamina, which means the more you sit there and play mouse clicking simulator the less likely you are of actually hitting the bastard. On a more minor note, I mentioned how I loved the weapon variety in this game, but it's a shame I'll never be able to use any weapon type other than the one or two I'm proficient in because of this mechanic. I decided I wanted to branch out into the marksman skill so I took a bow and 40+ arrows and I deadass sat 1cm away from a low level creature and proceeded to not land a single arrow point blank. It was a relatively large creature too. 

NPCS
Meh. Just meh. Most of them recycle the same dialogue that everyone else says but, unlike Skyrim where you at least get to hear some decent voice acting, it's all written. For some reason they often sniff at you? Also unlike Skyrim (or Oblivion), don't bother running towards a guard and expecting their help if you're being overwhelmed by an enemy. They'll watch you die. To my knowledge, there's no available followers in the game outside of certain quests, in which case they're temporary. They're not horrible but the other elder scrolls games I've played are much better in that regard.

CAVES/AREAS
For how few and far between they've been for me, they're disappointingly small with little reward. In Skyrim, Dwemer ruins can be annoyingly large. In Morrowind, the Dwemer ruins I've found are smaller and have less enemies than the small/medium sized caves in Skyrim. They're not that fun for me. 

GENERAL MECHANICS
No fast travel, outside of some ships/creatures that can take you to nearby towns. Wouldn't be so bad if you weren't so goddam slow or if there were horses. Personally, I don't enjoy having half my gameplay be walking back and forth on empty paths.
No quest markers/The Journal. I understand the fun to be had in figuring out where to go for a quest via directions from NPCs, but sometimes they give shit directions. I take more issue with the quest log or jounral really. It's not a bad idea, honestly I think it's a little cool to have your quest related gameplay logged in your character's journal. What I don't like is having to flip through and scan 30 pages to try to find that one quest you put off for a bit because you didn't have time or were too low a level to complete. It's annoying.

Will I stop playing this game? I wanted to but I keep coming back. What can I say, I'm a Dead By Daylight player, putting up with unfun mechanics is in my blood. However, I would not recommend this game over Oblivion or Skyrim. Morrowind does have a few cool traits that I would like to see in future elder scrolls games, but the overall experience I've had in morrowinf vs skyrim and oblivion is just embarassingly unfun.

This review will be aimed at people like myself who would be playing this for the first time. To better understand the place I come from when making this review, let me give a brief overview of myself and gaming experience. I am 30 years old at this time, and I have spent 95% of my life playing video games (and tabletop RPGs). I am not new to crusty graphics, janky mechanics, or complex UI elements. I play a lot of RPGs with a lot of dialogue and/or downtime as well as a lot of unforgiving games. I have more patience than most people. I have pushed through many segments of games I didn't like or found tedious because the game itself interested me.

Within the context of when it came out, it was an ambitious game. This review is aimed at people who might be looking to try this for the first time, and likely with less patience than myself. My feelings are more nuanced than can be easily conveyed via a 'Pro' and 'Con' list, so I shall go into details about the primary aspects of the game. Disclosure: I used the Morrowind Code Patch and many visual mods. I made zero efforts to alter the base gameplay beyond default options checked in the MCP.

The base visuals of the game have a good, clear art direction. They are definitely aged. The overwhelming amount of mods available can make the game look very nice. Visuals are usually not something to judge a game negatively for unless the art style itself is distracting or otherwise not well done.

In terms of audio the game is fine. Audio quality on what few voices there are is good, and the sound effects do their job. The music will get repetitive very quickly. What music there is in the game is most certainly good. Not playlist-worthy, but it's good. With how repetitive it got I ended up playing my own music for large portions of the game.

Lore. Important in games, infinitely so for RPGs. Morrowind has a lot. Tons of dialogue to read, and countless books. For those interested in TES's world this is definitely an area that does not disappoint. The presentation leaves a lot to be desired. I am no stranger to reading. I do prefer voices NPCs and a voiceless PC in games, but I was not turned off by the lack of the games voice acting. I was put off by how a lot of the lore is conveyed. The dialogue system is cumbersome: You can choose from an ever-growing list of keywords to discuss with NPCs who will then give you information and more keywords. There are many cases where you can ask NPCs about topics that result in no new information at best, or weird character breaks at worst. The dialogue system makes it tedious to go through topics and makes conversations feel disjointed/unnatural. More importantly, for people that like important story elements conveyed in a more straightforward or condensed manner, and leaving the superfluous elements for books and the like, the lore will definitely be harder to digest. It is definitely something that can be dealt with, but the journey for lore tended to be tedious to the point I spent more time reading wiki entries than shuffling through various NPCs and books.

Gameplay. This is where the game aged the most. Melee/ranged is dice rolls based on stats. Even if you shoot an arrow at the enemy, and see it physically intersect with the character model, the dice determine if it hits or misses. At low levels you will miss most all attacks. By the end game for me, I missed rarely. In games like Xcom and Pathfinder it works for me. Here? It's jarring. and it detracted from the game. In Pathfinder (and Xcom and similar things such as positioning matter greatly in combat. You can use the terrain and abilities to supplement hit %. In Morrowind, other than potions/spells, there is no way to mitigate low %. Mid-end game melee and ranged combat is you standing in front of your enemy and left clicking until they're dead. Dodging isn't a thing. End game for me was taking every opportunity I could to skip enemies and having zero issue fighting anything I couldn't.

Magic combat is possibly better, but as someone that wanted to play melee with magic as a supplement I found it to also fall short. You can fail to cast a spell if your skill isn't high enough, and you rest to get back magicka. There was a MCP option to enable magicka regen and, while I wanted a mostly vanilla feel for my playthrough, [i] I regret that choice and would highly encourage using it even if you make no other changes. [/i] Even at the endgame with 100 in every stat I could cast so few spells that I never used magic. Potions are a thing, but carry weight is something I struggled with through the entire game. For the magic I wanted to use, no regen was awful. From a combat standpoint I have to assume it's better if you have a high chance to cast the spell, but at the end of the day the offensive spell variety is not great either. The supplementary spell variety is a lot better, but it feels like you must be built for it from the start.

You level up when you achieve 10 increases in your chosen Major or Minor skills. Based on how many times you leveled up in a Major, Minor, or Miscellaneous skill, you can apply three stat bonuses ranging from 1 to 5 to your primary stats that the skills are affected by. Leveling a skill(s) that only affects one or two stats means inefficient levelling, which means weaker character, and it simply becomes a very tedious, chore-like experience to improve your character.

Travel takes a long time. The world is big and you move very slow. There are cities which have fast travel services to other specific locations, but you will do a lot of travelling in between. Nothing interesting ever happens when do travel, too. NPCs don't have routines or scripting. They stay in the same spot forever until you kill them, they are used in an escort quest, or they are moved for a main quest very rarely. Once you've walked a path once that path is the same every time other than far, far too many enemies (especially the flying Cliff Racers which are more plentiful than stars in the sky).

So many quests in this game amount to travelling to a location, grabbing something, and then coming back. You can break a lot of games down to such simple terms, but games usually have engaging gameplay to make quests worth doing. Or fast travel to mitigate tedium. The fact that Morrowind has none of that turns a cool aspect into a slog: No quest markers. NPCs tell you directions. Sometimes, these directions take you far away. Despite the dialogue system implying the idea that you may be able to ask locals about the nearby cave, you can't. Morrowind is huge. A lot of terrain is very same-y. NPCs don't give good directions and for some quests you might even get no directions. An idea that I would love in a game where I loved the combat or could travel quickly. An idea I have actually enjoyed in other games. In Morrowind? By the second half of my playthrough I dreaded any quest that didn't explicitly tell me where to go. Worse when most places don't matter. Is it realistic to find a cave that only has a bandit and some boxes of dirt and bread in it? Sure. Is it fun? Not particularly. Especially not after the twentieth time. Most places have nothing of actual value or interest inside at all. It just wasn't worth it for me to explore halfway through. The magic system lets you create all sorts of cool items, but you will rarely find such items in the plethora of caves and ruins that pepper the landscape.

All in all, I enjoyed Morrowind enough that I finished it, but that is where my appreciation for it ended. I saw what it tried to do, and inspired, and I respect it greatly for that. But in this day and age, especially as an adult, I don't find the poor implementations and tedious nature of it's systems to warrant a playthrough for people with far less patience and time than myself. I agree it was a wonderful game for the time. Not so much for 2022.

One of the most immersive games i've played with a very long main questline. You'll get used to the graphics but the sheer variety of stuff you can do in this game is insane. In skyrim they took out like half the skills and spells and weapons which is a shame. SPELLMAKING IS SO GOOD. 

What is also interesting is that the world feels HUGE but it isn't. the actual map size is quite small compared to other rpg maps but because you walk almost everywhere it makes you feel immersed in it and makes everything so much bigger, on top of that you dont have markers like all these newer games, you actually have to LISTEN(or read lol) what people tell you.You will be given instructions on how to reach places for example head north of this place until you see a rock cairn and then head east until halfway between these two palces and then head north north east until you reach this big tree where the dungeon will be on your left. That't the level of instructions you get given it makes you feel like you are actually there cause you not just walking towards some marker thats floating in the sky after skipping through all of the npc's dialogue.

 Also this game makes you earn your title. skyrim you literally can sit in a tower and watch gaurds kill a dragon for you and BAM you the dragonborn and a thane of whiterun. In morrowind you try claiming you are special/chosen one and no one believes you until you do like 50 billion quests and then people still doubt you, the only time someone will say "oh its the neravine" (idk how to spell it) is once you have finished the entire main questline which took me 30 hours and keep in mind i got a daedric katana at level 1 and i only finished the main questline at level 20. and thats with me using console commands to teleport places after i finished the first 5 trials (cause horator and tribe stuff was kinda boring for me at least) but that second part makes it seem real and hilarious. The prophecy says the chosen one has to have fullfilled certain stuff but you havent yet so you go around bribing officials and earning their favour so you can be called the neravine which is very immersive and hilarious.

Ah, Morrowind. The third game in the Elder Scrolls series and one of the greatest RPGs of all-time. The island of Vvardenfell is quite the curious setting. Filled with lush mushrooms, volatile volcanic peaks, and a whole bunch of flying lizards. Vvarderfell is unlike anything you will see in any other Elder Scrolls game. The map is much smaller than Daggerfall but more packed with unique dungeons, cities, ruins, and such. You will find something new everytime and it's quite exciting. You start off as some lonely prisoner sent from Cyrodiil with the simple mission to deliver a package to some old man in Balmora, and end up tangled up in a prophecy where you become a powerful being to stop some ancient evil and his army of phallic-faced monsters from turning everyone else into said monsters. The journey is one of the best and it helps you encounter various wonderful characters throughout it. I love this game so much, and you will too.

Firstly, IGNORE MY LISTED PLAYTIME!!! i had this game before i had steam. I've probably spent literal THOUSANDS of hours on this game.  but tis in the past. i booted it up just so i could write this review out of sheer obligation.

I write this review with a lot of heart because this is the game i played growing up.  its the game that got me really playing other games.  IT ALL STARTED HERE, for me atleast.  this is also where my Bethesda obsession came from. Time has passed and the graphics arent as nice as some of the newer products around but this game will forever hold a special place in my heart.  now i know you might look at this and think skyrim or possibly oblivion, good titles, but they lack a special something i cant quite put my finger on that morrowind had, their classic orriginal.  sure the voiced dialogue is nice in skyrim and oblivion, but theres SO much less dialogue in whole...  Infact if you go chronilogically in time from morrowind to oblivion to skyrim you'll find that the dialogue only gets more and more scarce.  infact this dialogue scarcity is the biggest lore-breaker and almost ruins the later, newer games for me.  you could ask an npc about almost anything relevant and they had CUSTOM TAILORED dialogue to say to you based on your personal gameplay, in infinite ammounts.  Oblivion and skyrim just doesnt have that.

another thing i really enjoyed, but others might not; is that this game, unlike skyrim or oblivion, doesnt hold your hand.  some find it offsetting that theres no map marker, or that the game lets you kill essential characters, but i enjoy this.  such handholding is lorebreaking in my opinion.  This is a game built with AMAZING lore, one could say its its own little universe.  You are just dropped into this little world and explore. much like skyrim and oblivion (which i continue to compare this game to), the content overall is still so endless, you could get lost forever.  dont let the last generation graphics get to you.

If your a fan of the Elder Scrolls series just know that it all really started here.  gaming for me personally as i know it started here.  if your an Elder Scrolls fan and you dont mind old games with old graphics please get this.  if it goes on sale your insane not to, but i dont regret full price. especially at its 'current' full price these days 20 years later.

12 out of 10

UPDATE FOR COOL PEOPLE (MODDERS): i said id never come back but... i did.  HUGE TIP if you wanna play this game with better graphics, extremely far view distances, widescreen support, etc. then please consider downloading Mod Organizer 2 and looking at the Nexus modding community.  With due dilligence, patience, and determination you can make this game look INCREDIBLE once again in 2020.  I am shocked the morrowind modding community is still so alive and making NEW THINGS even now.  It will be exceptionally frustrating and time consuming, and take a few days depending on how ambitious you are.  you may want to cry by the time your almost done getting everything together, but t'will be only tears of joy when you see how wonderful 2020 Morrowind is.
