Part three of the absolutely fantastic Elder Scrolls franchise, this game has a wonderful OST, great story and customization options, a lot of variety on ways to play, and is just all around a great game for any fan of the elder scrolls games.

I know this game doesn't hold your hand like oblivion or Skyrim, but that's its brilliance as a hardcore DnD simulator. The number of skills, weapons, magic, and armor classes still blows oblivion and skyrim out of the water on variety, if you can get over how brutally mundane the success chance calculator each strike or spell cast has. if you're a nerd like me who demands a challenging game that doesnt hold your hand and you've gotten bored becoming a multi-class god in oblivion and skyrim, come take a step back to a simpler time in gaming history with Morrowind. The replayability alone on this game is reason to try it. there are so many secrets waiting to be found. you will actually be excited when you come across a piece of ebony or deadric armor/weaponry because its actually rare. the legendary weapons/items are actually worthwhile to carry around with you. you will likely struggle maintaining your health, stamina, and magicka levels without practicing alchemy. you can break the game with a combination of alchemy and enchantments, but will find you are going to have to play the game normally in order to achieve godhood eventually. in the meantime you will appreciate the difficulty of each encounter because there is no guarantee that your spell is going to cast, or your strike is going to hit. pay attention to your stamina levels. going into caves and fortresses are actually fun, because the items you can acquire you will actually use: alchemical components, magical components, etc. there arent boxes full of health and magicka potions before every "boss" battle; youre going to have to enchant and/or brew your own stat regeneration items yourself as there isnt a reliable source for such items. disease and blight will have a significant effect on you, and you will want to have the ability to readily cure yourself, unless youre fine dropping some items on the ground because your strength stats took a hit, and then you have to limp away to go to a shrine for cleansing. some enemies can permanently damage some of your stats and will leave you stranded in caves with 0 strength stats; you will learn which enemies to fight at a distance..... if you can. dont expect to be a super sneaky powerful 1 hitting assassin wonder, this isnt skyrim. if you're a mage class, you will be horribly squishy; levitating away from enemies and perching yourself in a nook will save you butt more times than you care to admit. 
I love this game; the first time i played it was back in 2004, and is easily the game i have spent the most time in. ive made tens of characters and im still not bored. i just came back to playing this after a 5 year hiatus and its even more fun since i found out about modding the game to look a little more pretty.
theres a mark and recall spell that functions as a neat form of fast travel; there are silt striders and boats that can take you certain places, but you may have to jump between the two to get to a certain place. the mages guild can also teleport you between guild locations, but other than that, youre going to have to hoof it with minimal waypoints on your map. actually paying attention to dialogue and your journal will be necessary in order to guide yourself to each destination. I love this game because of its hardcore elements. this isnt a game you can easily play on cruise control; youre going to have to work for it, and theres going to be a lot of encounters youre going to have to abandon and return to at a higher level with better equipment and more potions; youre not felling any dragons with a couple axe swings in this game, youre gonna probably die once or twice to a blighted cliff racer because you ran out of stamina and none of your strikes make contact. 25% of your outside battle encounters are probably going to be with these glitchy gliding critters, and you will hear their dumb little screech in your nightmares. Good luck!

I have been playing this using OpenMW, so my hours were not logged. I played this a lot when I was younger, I probably put 100s of hours in. But I hadn't touched it till now for the last 15 or so years. It's still really good. All of the issues with the game can be fixed with mods if you want to.

- Huge depth and freedom with a truly unique setting. Very easy to get sucked in and get lost in the game, whether you choose to follow main or faction quests, do your own thing, or even really delve into the game's mechanics.
- Really big enemy variety, huge well-crafted areas with nooks and crannies designed to test a range of character builds.

- The game is not voice acted so dialogue is implemented through trees. I think that allows a much bigger range of different options.
- Fast travel is limited in this game to transportation nodes. I think that really draws you into the world as you need to learn your way around, or navigate by landmarks.
- Both the above two things are major factors for players to consider. It might be a positive for some and a negative for others.

- There are some major flaws with this game though. The levelling system is confounding, the fatigue system is intensely frustrating and the game is still a little unstable if you're not using OpenMW. I think for new players, it may not be worth their investment to download and get that working if they're not sure whether they'll like the game or not.

I have far more than 9 hours in this game, I played this on the og Xbox when it first came out as a kid with my dad. I've loved this game for years, the memories I have made will last a life time. Yes the graphics and some of the game mechanics are dated, and it doesn't have some the quality of life improvements the newer games of the series have. But remember it is a 20 year old game at the time I wrote this so of course it's going to be a bit dated. Also when you play this, if you are a new player or gamer that never played the RPGs of yesteryear, you may have some trouble with how certain things work in the game like the quest journal being a bit vague. But once again Morrowind came out at a time were very few RPGs held your hand in anyway, they wanted you to explore the world, play the character that you wanted to be. This was a game that was basically a tabletop RPG session turned into a video game, also this game pretty much saved Bethesda from going bankrupt. I could go on and on about why I love this game, but this review is already getting long in the tooth, so to end it here. I would recommend anyone that loves RPGs both new and old to either play this game or to come back and revisit the land of Morrowind for this where many found their love of the Elder Scrolls and RPGs in general. This is also where my love of the Dunmer/Dark Elves came from. So give it a go and if you have trouble with something the community is still here to help as always. Until we meet again, may Azura's blessings be upon you Traveler.

I beat Morrowind the other day, and I'd like to write about how wonderful the experience was.
I started Morrowind around this time last year. I only ever played the one character I started with, so I bore witness to the beauty of this game's progression only once. Let's talk about it.
The start of Morrowind is purposefully very rough and limiting. You walk slow, you die in very few hits, most of your attacks don't even make contact with the enemies, your spells constantly fail, etc. There are universal systems in Morrowind that impact all living things in the game, including you, and at the start, you are at the very bottom of those systems. Everything is working against you, and even a single bandit is often too strong for you. This forces you to get creative. Those universal systems dragging you down effect the enemies too. Your fatigue is too low so you miss everything and fail spells? Drink a fatigue potion, and find a way to lower your opponent's fatigue so they fall over a bunch and miss you. Tired of getting stun-locked by paralysis enchantments enemies have? You can stun-lock them too. This concept extends to out-of-combat activities as well; creativity is rewarded above all else. Tired of the blind effect on the boots of blinding speed? Make a spell that resists 100% of magic for 1 second, then put on the boots during that 1 second. Blindness resisted and now you get to go fast all the time. Skill training too expensive? Make a potion to temporarily lower the skill you want to train to a very low level so it's cheaper to train up. 
This ideology of clever solutions being the key to victory is instilled into the player from the tutorial. There's a quest in the first town where you find the secret cash stash of a local wood elf, steal from it, then return to the questgiver and split the profits. But why would you want to split it? Just don't turn it in and you make 150 more gold.
Just outside of the first town, a mage falls from the sky, dies, and drops scrolls of icarian flight. These boost your acrobatics skill by 1000 points temporarily, and let you skip the early-game trek to Balmora, but you'll die of the fall damage. I won't spoil it here, but there's tons of clever solutions to subvert the fall damage. 
The game's progression is the most satisfying I've ever experienced, as you slowly but surely turn the systems that were plaguing you on their head and twist them into strengths, all from your own ingenuity alone. This progression and "breaking" the game is supported by the game's story and themes as well, but we'll get to that later.
The world of Morrowind is my 2nd favorite in all of fiction, behind Xenoblade of course. An issue that fantasy games often run into is a disconnect between the character and player, as the player knows exactly what to expect out of a fantasy setting, while the character is often experiencing the dragons, undead crypts, and corrupt kings for the first time. Morrowind fixes this problem by making the island of Vvardenfell truly alien. The majority of the island is volcanic ashlands, rocky coastlines, and fungus-infested wetlands. Ash is a weather in Vvardenfell. Giant jellyfish float throughout the sky, the main food supply is the eggs from 9-foot long subterranean insects called Kwamas, meaning mineshafts are the equivalent to farms on this island. Tree-sized mushrooms are more common than trees themselves, and pterodactyl-like cliff racers permeate the hills of the game. People make their homes and cities out of the fossils of long-dead giant crustaceans, creating a wholly unique architectural signature of the region. Instead of horses, transportation between cities is handled by 30 foot tall, 6-legged insects called Silt Striders, and the people of Vvardenfell burrow into their backs to create a place to sit. The world is truly alien to every fantasy setting the average RPG player is used to, and that fixes the problem of the disconnect between player and character. You're in this together. I'd compare it most to something like Spirited Away where both you and the main character are getting lost in this weird, scary, alien world together and both have no clue as to what lies around the next corner. You and your character are experiencing the weirdness as one. 
The game did the Breath of The Wild structure 15 years before it was popularized. At the center of the map is Red Mountain, and at any time you can go up to it and fight the final boss. It's entirely possible to beat the game in a single sitting if you want to. The main story and questline instead serves the purpose to build your strength and give context to the events happening. This structure means there is absolutely nothing the player does that is a waste of time. Every single action you take serves the purpose of preparing to storm Red Mountain, main story or otherwise. Morrowind is about gaining power and becoming the prophesized, godlike figure of the Nerevarine who will save Vvardenfell from the wrath of Dagoth Ur who lies at the heart of Red Mountain. There are two paths to godhood in Morrowind. The first is following the main story, uniting the ash tribes and great houses, etc. The second is the path that your items and stats will lead you to. The game respects your intelligence enough to let the player decide which path to follow, and both fit the game's themes perfectly. 
Morrowind is all about Gods and historical myths. Every piece of info you are told about the battle of Red Mountain thousands of years ago is contradicted by another version of the story told by someone else. Nobody has an exact idea of the events that set the game's plot into motion, and that's on purpose. People having different versions of the same historical story makes it more believable. The game's text-based dialogue system helps it tell such a complex story, as they don't have to pay voice actors to read the hundreds of paragraphs. You're supposed to piece together each bit of info you're given and find your own justification to storm Red Mountain. By doing so, are you defying fate, or are you abiding by it? That's up to you to decide. Are you the prophesized reincarnation of the Nerevarine, or are you a self-made hero breaking the circle of hatred set in motion thousands of years ago? That's also up to you to decide. It's only fitting that Morrowind has the biggest mid-late game powerup in Bethesda's history to make you really feel like a godly figure. Breaking the game is encouraged by the plot itself. God I fucking love this game.

It is not the absolute, definitive RPG experience, but by all means Morrowind is a game from an interesting period, where RPGs remained with one foot in their Table Top origins, and the other foot trying to find its place - this creates the interesting scenario, where Morrowind can be experienced in two ways: a game with no boundaries that the player can mess around with fully to their hearts content, or a collection of resources to craft one's own experience. It has its failings like any game (poor writing in an RPG is hardly acceptable), and the more Table Top inspired mechanics don't always translate well to PC, but overall it can be a fun and rewarding game that is definitely recommendable.

I've heard it referred to as one of the best novels ever presented in non-novel form, and I would have to agree.

Once you get used to it however, the gameplay has some pretty fantastic flexibility. The magic system in this game is ultimately the most varied and interesting that the Elder Scrolls universe has ever presented.
It is a very good game.

Morrowind is a spiritual journey and my favorite game. Morrowind tells a complex story of the Dunmer people, and the implications of their history on your fate.  Clothing and armor tell a story about the region they are from and attest to the role of cultural evolution that is missing in later releases. Morrowind has the worst first playthrough of modern TES games, but I have no qualms saying it has the most satisfying and emotionally fulfilling final playthrough. Enjoy getting lost in a world like no other!

I played Morrowind with Bloodmoon and Tribunal when I was younger and loved it. I played it again at age 30 and loved it even more!!! Skyrim is a visual masterpiece, however, Morrowind is the best Elder Scrolls game in my opinion. The main quest is amazing, and the side quests too especially dark brotherhood and thieves guild. Blood moon and Tribunal offer great vacations from the main island if you get a bit bored. There are some hilarious comments that any NPC can make if you linger in a room long enough. The giant mushrooms and imaginative animals make this a great fantasy story game. Highly recommend! I have put in hundreds of hours into Morrowind and always find myself coming back to it!

Morrowind is an easy Top 10 GOAT in my opinion. The amount of thought and care that went into crafting the world and the lore, and then diegetically tying them all together to make sense within the context of the world has not been done in a Bethesda game since. I first played this game as a child way back in 2004 on the original XBOX with no  idea what I was doing, but even then I knew the world was something special.

The gameplay is somewhat a product of its time, but the more "pure" RPG experience it provides allows you to genuinely feel your character progressing and getting better and more powerful. You'll have to put actual thought into how you choose your skills and attributes, and if you do it correctly you can become an unstoppable monster.

Play the game with some visual mods if you want, but I'd suggest keeping it as close to the original experience as intended. Avoid mods that alter things like hit chance, read up on some of the game mechanics such as alchemy, and enjoy one of the best RPGs ever made.

I do hope there is not another ESO and we can get back to the level of artistic expression that Morrowind was. I feel as if ES is trying to emulate Lord of the Rings - Tolkien works. Morrowind was completely original, or as it seemed tot me. From the Dumner religion to the landscape, including the flora and fauna.

Pros
1. The music. Especially the main theme and the game knows it. It will play it over and over and over again. And then it will play it one more time. And you'll end up humming along.
2. The setting is incredible, you have never seen a game like this before. Probably. 
3. The story and lore

Cons
1. Graphics are crappy.
2. Gameplay. Oh the gameplay. Playing this game is a patience exercise.  Fighting is like, well, if someone hides a rock inside one of their palms, you have more chances of guessing the palm right than landing a hit on your opponent. At least when beginning the game. No fast travel either. Want to go in the other side of the map? Just put a rock on your "walk forward" button and sleep for 5-10 minutes. What will happen is, you will probably be killed by a worm of some kind, and you'll have to start over. No tutorials either, with the only exception being, "here's 10 bucks and a toothbrush, now find out why the world needs saving and if you survive come tell me so I can send you away again to save it".

 

Summary
If you played it before and you are feeling nostalgic you will like it. If you are interested in the extremely unique setting and deep lore, story and characters and open world exploring but don't mind the horrible graphics and gameplay and the CRAPPIEST BATTLE SYSTEM MECHANICS EVER EXISTED then you will like this game. Just play it inside a sound proof room - maybe a music studio - if you have the option, so that other people can't hear you scream at your laptop.

Morrowind is the best Elder Scrolls game and one of the greatest games of all time in my opinion. Don’t let the graphics and dice based combat discourage you from playing it. Once you see past the minuscule flaws this game carries, you’ll see that it’s phenomenal. One of the biggest strengths this game has is its dialogue. The scattered books found throughout the world as well as some certain characters’ dialogue are incredibly well-written. The lore and characters in this game are another plus. I could spend hours discussing the history and politics of Vvardenfell and Morrowind as a whole. The villain and other important characters are captivating and intriguing. I think it’s fair to say that Morrowind also has the greatest villain. I don’t want to rant and spend an hour explaining why you should get this game, but I do recommend that you play it. It’s worth every penny.

To preface, my first ES was Skyrim which I loved and spent 100+ hours on, and my second ES was Oblivion, which I actually disliked immensely due to boring graphics and bad mechanics, bugs, and screwed up leveling system. 

Having said that, I thought I would hate this game and would either be bored, lost, and/or frustrated at the mechanics because of how Oblivion was.  None of that is true because this game is absolutely incredible! 
The graphics are better than I thought, and I actually like them better than Oblivion (albeit my PC is low/mid tier.) 
The combat isn't as bad as it's made out to be, especially after you have leveled your character into which style of combat you prefer. It's like old school Diablo but FPV. 
I haven't encountered many bugs other than getting stuck inside walls or floors which since downloading the unoffical patch I haven't had a problem with. 
There is no fast travel or quest markers which I think is an upgrade to Skyrim seeing as you have to engage and immerse yourself into the game more. You are given accurate directions and goals and the Silt Striders aren't too scarce so you actually don't have to travel on foot a ton. Part of the fun is searching for what to do next by having to investigate an area where you know you are suppose to be but need to find whatever it is you are tasked to do. 
The campaign is less cinematic like Skyrim, and more lore and dialogue based. Less voice acting means more text, but I feel this fleshes the world out a lot better than you can do with heavy voice acting. 

Overall (for the amount I've played so far) I rate Morrowind 8.5/10 and absolutely recommend it to any Elder Scroll fan looking to deep dive into the world more.

Wow. Morrowind is a fucking masterpiece of an RPG. Just holy shit. Take away the graphics and the outdated combat, and it's the best RPG. The Main Story had more quests and content than the modern writing of the recent Assassin's Creed games, Battlefield, COD & even Cyberpunk 2077. And then you have the 2 both great DLCs of the game. Bloodmoon and Tribunal. Just holy shit. I really liked Tribunal more than Bloodmoon because of the new weapons like Trueflame & Hopefire, just godly weapons for the Nerevarine. And more interesting and fun characters, even new Gods. I felt like I'm spiritually connected to the Neravarine and Morrowind as a whole. Just a blast. Bloodmoon was really great too but I didn't quite like the quests as it got quite repetitive throughout the game. Still an awesome story line and great characters though. And after you complete the main quest for Bloodmoon, the secret ring called "BlueDev's Ring of Viewing" was an awesome touch to the end of the DLC. And the fact that it can only be found after you've finished the main story and DLC, but it's hidden in a dead Cliffracer's mouth in the Skaal village. Just awesome. You don't find easter eggs like these in modern games anymore. The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is one of the most enjoyable fun classic RPGs out there. I recommend this game and as well as the other Elder Scrolls instalments for anyone wanting to play good RPG's FUCKING AWESOME!

The bottom line is that it's very hard to enjoy [I]Morrowind[/I] without mods, frequent consultation of online wikis, and a considerable investment in and patience for learning it. But when you find your groove you'll have an awe-inspiring, memorable, almost incredible RPG experience. Incredible because there's really no game quite as grand even 20 years later.

Its scope is both broad and deep. It simulates a large and long D&D-like campaign crammed with dungeons, towns, monsters, and intrigue. There are overlapping political story lines with hundreds of named NPCs, many with their own personal stories, and books brimming with lore. There are skill, weapon, magic, and alchemy systems that outdo the complexity of AD&D's Dungeon Master's Guide. And there's an impressively comprehensive UI to manage it all. All of that is packaged in a remarkably open-ended sandbox that engenders many opportunities for emergent gameplay. Go anywhere that interests you and see what happens. It will often be pretty cool and quite dangerous. Many quests offer little direction beyond giving you a goal, leaving a lot of room for creativity and cleverness. And it's impossible to complete them all in a single play-through, as your role-playing choices and sheer coincidence truly do determine your path. You do you.

That said, not all the content is wonderful. There's no dearth of dreary back-and-forth fetch quests that still plague the open-world genre to this day. Indeed, [I]Morrowind[/I] giveth with one hand and taketh with the other. Alas, it may very well demand more than it delivers, because it doesn't miss any opportunity to rain on your parade. At times it feels deliberately [I]anti-fun[/I]. The most glaring example is dialog: I've never experienced "conversations" with NPCs as tedious as they are here. They are just long, clickable lists of repeated topics with repeated answers. So, immediately a central component of the game is awful. Similarly, journal entries—which are how you keep track of quests—are logged in the order you discovered them and there's no way to search them. Sure, that's how "real" written journals work, but, seriously? In the late game you'll have hundreds of pages of practically unusable text. Online wikis are the reasonable, immersion-breaking workaround. And then there's combat: you can sometimes do the 1st-person dodge-attack dance, but more often than not the outcome of battle depends on the roll of the die and it's a boring clickfest. The Bloodmoon DLC is especially rife with repetitive random encounters.

When it comes down to it, [I]Morrowind[/I] plays as if the developers were so focused on the comprehensiveness of their world simulation that they left play-testing as an afterthought. Unless you thoroughly patch it, mod it, and use the debug console, [I]Morrowind[/I] is hilariously broken. For example, it's a very common occurrence for NPCs to block you from moving or not being where they're supposed to be. Your only recourse is to load a save or run the "ra" (reset actors) command in the console. And you can easily break a quest line by, say, killing an important NPC by mistake or selling a crucial item to a random merchant. Imagine being 50 hours into the game and having to go back to a save from 20 hours before. You can fix most things with the console, but is that "fun"? It's a miracle that this game passed any quality assurance at all. Oh, and no playtester complained about the unbearable slowness of walking? Really? Without the "Run Faster" mod I would have stopped playing after an hour. The core of the gameplay loop is walking to places. Back and forth. Again and again. A lot.

I did have many memorable emergent moments in my play-through, such as when I knew a powerful companion would betray me and so made sure to weaken him by purposely walking through a dangerous crypt where he would suffer a lot of damage. Then, when he turned on me, he was weak and beatable. That was fun. But, often such moments happened [I]in spite[/I] of game design. For example, enemies cannot follow you through level doors. So it's always possible to run away, rest and heal, and head back to the action. It's an anti-immersive mechanic. Multiply this example by one thousand and you'll understand how [I]Morrowind[/I] plays. Cheesing is inherent.

And so despite my thumbs up recommendation I suspect that [I]Morrowind[/I] is not for you. Its many flaws are, perhaps, fatal. But if you're patient and open to the workarounds then you will be rewarded in spades. It's a masterpiece buried under a mud flow.

I'm 200 hours in but have mostly spent my time playing around with characters and builds, doing some questing. I was someone who was never able to get into Morrowind, and I think it's unfortunately very clunky and outdated in many ways, the gameplay is very lacklustre by modern standards, but the gameworld is absolutely incredible and is more than enough reason to sink your teeth into this game. It will seriously suck you in - a home away from home. Think of it as a novel brought to life.

Honest thoughts:
[list]
[*] The biggest plus of Morrowind is how completely open-ended its systems are. The fact that you can simply do SO MUCH means you can experiment and break the game in any-which way you choose. Breaking the game is incredibly easy to do, so you'll probably come up with your own rules to decide what's fair or too broken to keep things fun. Experimenting with different classes and exploring different game mechanics will give you so much to keep your mind occupied if you're interested in approaching a game in different ways.
[*] The gameplay is extremely bland and outdated and will be a barrier for many new players. Now, I personally don't mind it, but it's undeniable that the biggest issue with this game is it simply feels boring to play if you just want to follow the quests. Navigating the world is extremely menial, and finding ways to keep the game fun will be your biggest challenge. If you just run through the game swinging at things, honestly I think this game is quite bad. Turn the difficulty up, experiment with enchanting/alchemy, play with limitations on your character. Create new characters and find fun ways to approach the game. Exploration is what makes this game good.
[*] Skills are a bit of a mess in this game. There are many skills in this game, some are very easy to level, and others are very hard. The issue is that most skills other than mercantile level up based on SUCCESSFUL attempts and does not consider magnitude. This means spamming a 1 magicka spell gives you he SAME EXP as casting a 70 magicka spell. The other flipside to this is that skills are actually HARDER to level at a low level than at a medium level, bc you are more likely to hit an enemy with a higher weapon skill. Experience does scale a bit, but level is actually the FASTEST between levels of about 40-70, and is slower outside those ranges. So, leveling is essentially completely broken and you can level up VERY fast or slow depending on the skills you choose. 
[*] Character creation & specilization. Even though the game gives you the option of class creation, honestly, I feel as though this game much more strongly favours specialization than hybridization. Pure characters are stronger early, will progress more easily, and will have no issues reaching the highest ranks of their respective factions. If you play hybrids, progression is much more difficult and less rewarding, and your character might not have the right skills to advance to the highest ranks of your faction. This can be overcome with gold & paying trainers but still, it feels like making 1 character for each archetype is the "intended" design.

[/list]
Conclusion? Morrowind is a Sandbox RPG. If you plan to just play the story and do quests, I think you will have a pretty bad time honestly. Morrowind is a game that FORCES you to explore its systems, it rewards a curious mind and you will have a GREAT time if you simply go on adventures looking to understand more about how the game works. Make broken potions, punch the shit out of everything and get 100 Hand-to-hand in like 2 hours. Create high magnitude jump spells and jump halfway across the map. Create spells you think are fun. Learn about enchanting and try to craft your own enchanted items. Questing and gameplay is not the main attraction of Morrowind - let yourself EXPLORE and get absorbed into the world, then you'll never want to leave.

TL;DR AT BOTTOM

Tired of trying to get immersed into a game through reading outside lore and listening to NPCs with only two lines of dialogue?

Morrowind is the game for you!

MAIN FEATURE TO ME IS MAGIC -- YOU CAN ACTUALLY MAKE ANY SPELL YOU WANT, SO LONG AS YOUR CHARACTER KNOWS HOW TO CAST IT (and you have the in-game moneys, or a spellmaker REALLY likes you)

It features:
*Very Thorough Character Creation, if you so choose. Also a standard questionnaire should you prefer.
*ACTUAL STATS -- you can level athletics, and MOVE faster, acrobatics and JUMP higher
*ACTUAL STATS PT 2 -- Unlike most games, leveling things actually changes stuff for you. Damage changes with skill, Persuasion changes with skill, movement speeds, regens, crafting/repair/enchantment is increased by SKILL not by some odd purchase system like the one Skyrim makes you use that is incredibly, frustratingly limited to essentially nothing (for magic users).
*Ridiculously story-rich NPCs (compared to today's standards.. which are.. incredibly lax)
*NPCs set in a world they belong in -- no more random -VERY- out of place characters. If they seem out of place, they've got a damn good reason for where they are.
*Some incredible bartering -- you can set your own price, and NPCs don't have to say yes to you
*NPC relationship statuses -- you can get people to like you through quests, favors, or simply manipulating them
*A much closer to realistic armor setup -- pauldrons, gauntlets, different kinds of plate, all sorts of leather and things
*WEAPONS -- Ever wondered why there are no SPEARS in any of the Bethesda games? ME TOO. They exist here, among other forgotten weapons
*If you get OpenMorrowind, the game runs MUCH better than anything I've played from Bethesda
*IT'S MULTIPLAYER (after OpenMorrowind, and a multiplayer addition. EZ)

ISSUES:
*Game runs on basically D&D but if your DM isn't forgiving on your checks. Starting is rough -- if your character can't use a weapon, it will take A LOT for them to figure out how.
*Graphics for pretty much anyone would be an issue I imagine. My response? Go to Nexus and get OpenMorrowind, grab whatever all updated skins you want for your own world to come closer to life. Also OpenMorrowind is a complete rewrite of the engine, so everything runs SO FRIGGIN GOOD
*You'll probably be alright when you first start, and then get SO INVESTED IN EVERYTHING THIS HAS TO OFFER YOU MAY LOSE TRACK OF TIME -- IN WEEK-LONG PERIODS

To elaborate on what was mentioned in the issues -- D&D with a rough-ish DM.
To deal damage
First you have to hit,
Then pass armor check,
THEN you can see how much you hit it for (Weapon Damage+Damage Types+Character Modifiers+any Buffs/other).

So if you're stabbing at a crab with the dull+rusty butter knife you (might have) found on the table at the beginning, you're going to have a hard time 
1 Puncturing its shell
2 Getting the knife in far enough to actually hurt it at all

If you're trying to slash at it... I really don't think you're getting through that shell unless you are just REALLY GOOD at slashing... or maybe you roll a D20, who knows.
(If it's the knife on the starting table, the knife does have a note asking someone to sharpen and clean it so ye it's gross)



TL;DR

The Good
Amazing game from a long-gone era. Plenty of updates to bring it almost completely up to speed. Base game is amazing, mods/updates only make it unfathomably good. Character creation is important for once AND OH MY GOODNESS THE MAGIC YOU CAN DO
Also Skills actually matter and change gameplay heavily

The Bad
Really, Really rough starting out if you don't pick a character and stick to it -- you want to be a spear wielder? GET A SPEAR, your character likely can't swing a sword/mace/etc very well.
Graphics suck without help (Get OpenMorrowind, seriously. Everything's better, as it's a complete engine rewrite).

This game is nearly 20 years old now as I'm typing this.  The combat game play is aids, the graphics is an eyesore, and the terrain traversal is an abomination.  And yet I keep coming back for more abuse.  The game does NOT hold your hand, so, read the dialogue carefully, and keep pressing 'J' to consult the journal, because you are not getting any map markers in this spousal abusive video game.  7/10 I'm a masochist.

I'm so happy playing Morrowind again. A true childhood favorite, and I used to have the Xbox version. I love the versatility of having it on PC. Haven't even dived into mods yet! While the combat is really frustrating, especially at the beginning, it finally "clicked" with me that this game is very based on tabletop RPGs. Think a certain combat level and then making dice rolls for whether you hit or not, and how much damage you do on that hit. The quests feel fall superior in complexity and honestly, difficulty, than those of Skyrim (I haven't played Oblivion yet so I can't speak to that one.) The world is enjoyable. I wish walking and running speed were a little faster, but you really get a lot out of the difficulty of the game and all the obstacles in your way at the beginning.

If you haven't played this game before, here are some things you need to know. This is the GOAT TES GAME. This is a culmination of hard work, commitment and by far the best character and quest writing the series has seen. This game doesn't hold your hand, it doesn't give you quest markers, you have to train and build a good character that suites your play style. If you don't read or don't like to, this game will require it. It will require a basic understanding of lore that is established in the game. If you read the lore books around the game and love to in a games lore you will have even more fun with this game. Understanding why you're the nerevarine and the consequences of your choices you make as such are very rewarding. The combat system is dice roll based meaning you can just swing and hit, you train by use so when you level up that skill you're more likely to hit, magic is wisdom based and intelligence is your magika pool. It is also dependent on skill in specific arts schools of magic. Everything about this game is super detailed and thought out. A few mod recommendations for first time players who want to give the game a face lift and fix some bugs that already exist in game. MWGXE (Enhances graphics and details of the game, extends script for other mods to use) Morrowind code patch (fixes bugs) Morrowind Purist Patch (restores some content to the game) That's it, very easy to install and run while keeping the game close to vanilla as possible. If you're a TES Fan or just starting the series, PLAY THIS MASTERPIECE.

First ill give a background. One of the few negatives of Morrowind would have to be the movement and combat.  They are very choppy and irritating at first but start to feel better after a little bit of playing.   The never quite match oblivion and fall somewhat short of Skyrim.
All in all i would recommend for players looking for a refreshing twist with its difficulty and lack of hand holding and direction.

One of the greatest and most immersive of the Elder Scrolls games.
Deep lore. Interesting cultures. Fun magic, enchanting & alchemy systems. Memorable characters. 
The good feeling of becoming stronger, getting better gear, and overcoming challenging enemies is immense. 
There's nothing like coming back to the mines by Seyda Neen and one-shot eviscerating the scribs that paralyzed and killed you at the beginning of the game (after you attacked them unprovoked...). 
Or going into some dank, dark cave and finding a hidden piece of loot tucked away in a place that has likely been seen by not many others.
There is also a huge amount of mods to alter the game to your liking - some even adding whole other provinces to the playable area!

Of course the game does have its flaws. A couple notable ones for me are:
Some of the mechanics are archaic (despite some gate keepers standing by them) - but if you don't like them, as mentioned there are a plethora of mods to change the game to your liking. 
And a lot of the faction quests end with [spoiler]the guild master challenging you to a duel for the top rank[/spoiler]. But lame promotions are pretty standard for the Elder Scrolls series.

All together, despite it's flaws of age, it is an amazing game worth experiencing if you can.

The GOAT.  While it may be frustrating to those looking for the game to play itself, no other game does as great a job world building and providing you the ability to play it however you want.  Also since it is old... use the graphical mods available.

Without question my favorite TES game, the atmosphere is the most unique of all released so far, and mechanics are the most interesting with as little watering down as possible.

I would have to preface that it's not an accessible game, a lot of stuff you can find to be rather obscure, and while I love the Journal, it could use a bit more work as well. The game is filled with dice rolls, instead of just bigger numbers over playtime, it's consistent, in line with a lot of classic RPGs, but it's sometimes to its detriment. Persuasion skills are greatly uninteresting to level up, but their usefulness is great, you won't get persuasion checks, the characters will grow more positive toward you, either permanently through admiring, or temporarily through intimidating, you can also legally kill someone by taunting them into attacking first. It's something that covers entire design behind morrowind, a lot of stuff is insanely practical and sandboxy, whether it activates funny adrenaline chemicals is secondary. The chance to hit being the diceroll in a fpp game is infamous, but it's just an obstacle as any other to work around, pay to/or train your weapon skill and agility, and you will be hitting over 90% of the time, or go for a mean hammer, that can stun an enemy once it hits, so hit chance is less of a concern, or go for magic and alchemy instead. Magic is the ABSOLUTE BEST element in morrowind, like with anything else, you level it up by use, increasing your spell success rate, progressively letting you use better stuff, sounds simple, but YOU CAN MAKE YOUR SPELLS, you can adjust target of the spell, duration, radius, strength etc.. You want to make a stupid strong jump spell that lets you fly through the map? Go ahead. Levitate? Be my guest. Invisible + strength buff? Freshly served. Alchemy works on very similar principle, but instead of gathering effects permanently by purchasing spells, you gather ingredients that are gone after you use them. If you go really in depth, you can catch monster's soul in a gem and enchant your items manually too. You can level up armor types effectiveness, or level up unarmored to become a monk that doesn't have to use repair tools for his own skin. You can level different weapons skills, or go unarmed, where your damage to enemy stamina is more important than initial damage to their health.
You want to be a brawler that pulls out a hammer to finish an exhausted enemy while they're on the ground? Nothing besides your patience is stopping you. There is also a lot of technical limitations since the game is so old, as well as bugs that are probably partly due to hardware being much better than the engine would anticipate. For me the most annoying is getting constantly stuck in geometry, I tried as hard as I can, but I never found a fix for that.

Graphically it was insane for its time, now I still think there is a lot to like, especially the atmosphere of the gritty marshlands and ash wastelands, lots of weapons and armors look really neat, even if they lack pixels and polygons. The worst looking part for me is definitely animations, lots of them are still and ugly, especially the first person ones. There are some mods that adjust animations (I really like the one that uses 3rd person anims in 1st person), but no massive overhaul to every animation the game has.

Sound is pretty good, a lot of sounds are very recognizable, though they do lack a lot of variety, you can hear it almost immediately, with how repetetive the footsteps sound. Something that didn't age a day is the music, I am not that surprised they remixed main theme of morrowind, in the Skyrim theme, as the melody really gets stuck in your head. A lot of exploration and battle themes sound beautiful too, after countless hours you might eventually get tired of them, but you might eventually want to get back to them too, they have really outdone themselves.

The story is also pretty nice, sure the prophecy of defeating ancient evil is nothing original, but all the stuff around it is so fresh and intriguing, the lore is so rich that I am still astounded to this day. The backstory behind the tribunal, the 6 houses, the ashlander clans, the clockwork city, ghostfence being built, dwemer ruins. The all kinds of weapon and armor artifacts, having their backstories not in item description, but in actual books on them, that you can find previously in the game.

All this combined is mixed into a game that is one of the absolute most immersive and addicting experiences I've had with games. It has a lot of gameplay shortcomings, but I can hardly think of any games that are as rich as this, besides maybe some mmos that were around and developed for years. I can't recommend this game to any average Joe really, the edges are so rough that it easily scares off a lot of people, but god is it one of the pretties diamonds underneath, that I've ever seen.

This game is awesome.  It's got the immersion of an MMORPG with out the MMO part.   Tons to do, tons to see, you can play it any way you want.  Great mods modernize if you want,  or you can kick it oldschool and play it like its 2k2.  

I really love the leveling system.  Just do want you want,  as you practice at things you get better at them.  If you don't like something,  You aren't forced to do it.   It gives you way more level's and power than you would ever need to complete the game (and both of it's expansions)  so you can just play away.

It does have some balance problems.  The first level or two just about anything can kill you.  Don't be afraid to run away.  Late game you are uber-powerful and nothing can touch you if you know what you are doing.  

But It's all really fun.  One of my favorite games.

Morrowind is one of the few games that will never go out of style, or never NOT be cool. As all these other titles from the early 2000s begin to age poorly, whose mechanics are junk, etc., Morrowind will always be an exceptional classic with incredible depth you can always go back to.

Vivec lay with Molag Bal for eighty days and eight, though headless. In that time, the Prince placed the warrior-poet's feet back and filled them with the blood of Daedra. In this way Vivec's giant-form remained forever harmless to good earth. The Pomegranate Banquet brought many spirits back from the dead so that the sons and daughters of the union had much to eat besides fruit.

The Duke of Scamps came while the banquet was still underway, and Molag Bal looked on the seven pennants with anger. The King of Rape had become necessary and therefore troubled for the rest of time. His legions and Kh-Utta's fell into open war, but the children of Molag Bal and Vivec were too elaborate in power and form.

The Duke of Scamps therefore became a lesser thing, as did all his own children. Molag Bal said to them: 'You are the sons of liars, dogs, and wolf-headed women.' They have been useless to summon ever since.

The holy one returned at last, Vehk, golden with wisdom. His head found its body had been tenderly used. He mentioned this to Molag Bal, who told him that he should thank the Barons of Move Like This, 'For I have yet to learn how to refine my rapture. My love is accidentally shaped like a spear.'

So Vivec, who had a grain of Ayem's mercy, set about to teach Molag Bal in the ways of belly-magic. They took their spears out and compared them. Vivec bit new words onto the King of Rape's so that it might give more than ruin to the uninitiated. This has since become a forbidden ritual, though people still practice it in secret.

Here is why: The Velothi and demons and monsters that were watching all took out their own spears. There was much biting and the earth became wet. And this was the last laugh of Molag Bal:

'Watch as the earth shall crack, heavy with so much power, that should have been forever unalike!'
Then that stretch of badlands that had been the site of the marriage fragmented and threw fire. And a race that is no more but that was terrible at the time to behold came forth. Born of the biters, that is all they did, and they ran amok across the lands of Veloth and even to the shores of Red Mountain.

But Vivec made of his spear a more terrible thing, from a secret he had bitten off from the King of Rape. And so he sent Molag Bal tumbling into the crack of the biters and swore forever that he would not deem the King beautiful ever again.

Vivec wept as he slew all those around him with his terrible new spear. He named it MUATRA, which is Milk Taker, and even the Chimeri mystics knew his fury. Anyone struck by Vivec at this time turned barren and withered into bone shapes. The path of bones became a sentence for the stars to read, and the heavens have never known children since. Vivec hunted down the biters one by one, and all their progeny, and he killed them all by means of the Nine Apertures, and the wise still hide theirs from Muatra.

The ending of the words is ALMSIVI.

This is one of the greatest, if not the greatest RPG, ever created. The depth is unparalleled and after 30 hours, I haven't even begun to scratch the surface. Morrowind is the pinnacle of the Elder Scrolls series. You have to actually pay attention to conversations with NPCs and read quest descriptions in order to do anything.

Skyrim will tell you "Go kill this person" and give you a quest marker showing you how to get to the target. Morrowind will tell you, "You have been hired by *insert weird name here* to kill *insert other weird name here*. Your target is in Tel Mora, go north until you reach the fallen tree that looks like the lovechild of a guar and a kwama, then go south-southeast for 11.5 minutes." 

No, the graphics haven't held up, but with a game this deep, graphics don't matter. If you want to wear a skirt, plate armor, and fire spells you created at enemies, you can go right ahead. That's right, spells you created. The spellmaking system alone is deeper than all of Skyrim's systems combined. (Don't get me wrong, I love Skyrim, but it pales in comparison to Morrowind). 

This is a must play for anyone that likes RPGs, weird fantasy worlds, and deep, rich lore. Just play the damn game.

I cannot in good faith recommend this game to the average person. The graphs? Dogshit. The gameplay? It leaves a lot to be desired. If you were to hand this game over to someone to play, their first opinion on this game would be that it is a piece of garbage. When you first start this game, you will have no idea what the hell is going on. You will be lost and will be frustrated by almost every enemy pushing you shit in. This game has some problems.

However, once you get past this games flaws, you will find an incredibly immersive world with an intriguing story. Many of the characters blend into the settings and you get a sense of some of the politics that go on in the world. These elements carry the game for me. This is my favorite and in my opinion the best game of the Elder Scrolls franchise.
Even after all these years I absolutely love this game. Easily one of the best games to get lost in. From the moment you get let out into the world it is entirely your oyster.

I've amassed tens of millions worth of drakes in assorted valuable items and jewels. Know how much I pay in taxes to the Empire? 
Not. a SINGLE. Drake. Dry assets versus wet assets, and that's Hlaalunomics, baby. The REAL magic in Morrowind.

So I played Morrowind in 2021-2022, after clearing Skyrim and Oblivion avidly. I finished the main quest today after 60h.

But it ended up being entertaining. I tried not to look for solutions online, I never lowered the difficulty and I never abused any kind of glitch or exploit.

It was great experience, especially as someone who works in game dev, to see the way Morrowind was designed and how it was meant to be beaten.

Lore wise, I loved it. Honestly, it is almost on par with Oblivion. Gameplay, well, it's not so great but it's ok.

Morrowind is a game whose vision vastly exceeds its reach. The result is a game riddled with bugs and flaws, that might well be the most enjoyable computer gaming experience I've yet had. 

This is what Morrowind is. A bundle of contradictions. A riddle wrapped in an enigma, in the form of a computer RPG. And while most of the time this would make the game a waste of time at best or an outright insult to the player at worst, with Morrowind the whole ends up being so much more than the sum of its parts.  

The graphics are laughably dated (though mods can greatly improve it) yet an impressive (especially for its time) shot at an immersive 3D world. You begin in this world as ludicrously weak, feeble and slow, yet can become almost Godlike in power long, long, LONG before that stage of the game where you're actually supposed to be Godlike in power. There is a main quest and a story line in there somewhere, but that's not really what Morrowind is about. 

Morrowind is really an RPG sandbox, and the real game lies in finding the numerous ways to work around how otherwise completely useless your character would otherwise be. There are many such tricks, and the effects of discovering them are dramatic. 

This might not sound like much of an asset, but Morrowind manages to get away with things that would be laughable and frustrating in most other games. This is the enigma of Morrowind. It's like your favourite old T.V show or movie in how its numerous flaws actually make it better rather than worse than it otherwise would be. 

I could throw a Ming vase off the Empire State Building, and the end result wouldn't be half as broken as Morrowind is. But is it ever FUN!

Morrowind is a game that offers something that only few modern games offer. It has complex RPG systems, exploration and game play that's engaging and requires you to think. While the combat can be hard to grow accustom to compared to modern games. It makes you take time when building your character and specialising. Quests and talking with NPC's does take quite a lot of reading but it makes you think about where to go for a quest instead of it straight up pointing to where you need to go. The lore is also incredible and will get you lost in its world (this applies to any elder scrolls game). Some of the game's more "classic" or "out-dated mechanics" may turn a lot of players off from this game but to me it's what makes the game so special.

I'll tell the truth and state that at the start I really disliked this game but I kept giving it another shot until eventually it clicked then I was having a blast going though it. The game feels very much like they went all in with the RPG side of Elder Scrolls making quests require exploration along with some trial and error; along with that they included a hefty list of different skills that allow for quite diverse characters. Also something I eventually noted was that while the graphics haven't aged well the world that uses them compliments them to the point that they feel "natural" rather than "Dated". Finally if some of the things stated don't sound like your cup of tea or you feel that a feature hasn't aged well in your eyes their is a decent modder community with this game. All in all it was a close one but this game won me over in the end.

A timeless classic and a must-play for any RPG fans out there. The game can be made even better with graphic and gameplay mods. One of the best if not the best RPG I've played! An alien world that calls you to explore and a great sense of freedom coupled with an amazing main questline. I recently tried out the "You're just an N'wah" modlist installed with Wabbajack and I've gotta say it's very good! Adding nicely implemented survival elements like hunger, thirst and the need to sleep as well as ton of other things ranging from making the world more alive and interactive to many quality of life things as well as graphics. Will be cool to replay this as I never completed the DLC's as a wee little teen.

This game has been talked about to death by everyone.

So all that I will say, is that this game is worth buying if it seems interesting to you. And even if it seems only kinda ok, know that there is a whole world of alternative content for you to try.  This game's modding community has been active since the game released - it is nearly 20 years old and a lot of the largest projects out there are tied up in this game.  It inspired tons of people to be creative and the results are nearly endless.

Even if you find the game to be fairly unenjoyable, if the play feels good to you/tolerable, then this world of things has a high likelihood of giving you some really good stuff.  

What is most interesting to me, is how the game's lore figured in to how all of this developed and continues to develop.  Players were inspired by its unique aesthetic and cantankerous nature, and some decided to take concept art and development materials and make them real.  This is a game that, in its own way, has not stopped development.

Currently, Tamriel Rebuilt exists as a project to recreate the mainland, which expands the game by several orders of magnitude, and it is actively being developed and even remastered at the same time.  It is expanding the game with careful attention paid to keeping up with it's aesthetic and grounding everything deeply in the already established lore. It is literally about three times more game at this point freely available to you.  

There are several other large scope projects like that, where you can download what's been made and expand the game.  OpenMW exists as a project to build a new engine from scratch, one which doesn't have the shortcomings Morrowind's engine did. It too is being actively developed and can be followed very closely.

In other words, this game in particular has a very unique additional aspect to it that warrants your attention even if the game itself is merely fine.  You may well find through the modding community, that this becomes one of your favorites because you really can customize it in just about any way you want.

The tools to create your own things, or edit the game itself are freely available.  So if you play and find a particular mechanic is troublesome, you can change it, and just flat out make your game more enjoyable.  You can go as deep as the devs did with it, and that is a rare and special thing.

I can't recommend the game enough, both because of everything I've said above, and because it genuinely is a unique and special sort of game.  It was made with care, by genuinely nerdy folk.  If you're into roleplaying, like actually playing a role and living it out, this game serves as the bedrock for what could be the most interesting and personally enjoyable experience you have ever had.  Because you can make it yours.

[h1]This game... just wow. Here's a personal anecdote as to how a normal mission in Morrowind plays out: [/h1]

Got lost trying to follow Mage's Guild's bad instructions to a dungeon. Found an escaping slave called [b]Reeh-Jah[/b] on the road, and the story I got to experience with this naked Argonian was legendary: 

We found a cult town and my friend [b]Reeh-Jah[/b] casually stunlocked their leader. After a tiresome swim in a river to avoid the same cult town's residence revenge, we finally found a town and I made a good profit, right after beating up a local slaver. In all the chaos I forgot to take the Sift Strider to the next village, so we had to walk past a vast Argonian slave farms we couldn't liberate, until we got to Vivec. 

One boat to Ebonheart and [b]Reeh-Jah[/b] and me already had to part ways. It was actually very sad moment, I grew to love this ex-enslaved gentleman. We fought so many random encounters, bandits and slavers along the way, but in the end we realized we couldn't liberate all the slaves of Morrowind together, and then... End of the line. Goodbye, [b]Reeh-Jah[/b]. Just as we evaded your slavers, you had evaded my heart.

He was placed exactly so that if I go through the most direct route, I will see all of this and get to experience an emergent story. Morrowind is seriously a different type of game than what came after.

This isn't an outlier case, either. Quests are laid out with the world in mind, it's intended to be this sprawling world, and it forces you to experience it. There's no fast travel, although you can pay for rides between towns. You have to discover all these dungeons yourself, with questionable directions that force you to find new places, and solve the issues that arise along the way, or sometimes run from your troubles with your new Argonian boyfriend. It's.. it's just good.

I played this when it first came out so many years ago. I enjoy the memories and not crashing when you use too many potions at once. The only problem I have with it is when closing the game, the screen freezes over my desktop and I have to log out and back in to be able to see my desktop again.

All the talk of no waypoints is frankly a bit much, I'm not some hardcore gamer who's been playing games for 20 years, it just simply takes a small amount of thought to understand where to go, always check the journal for directions. I'm saying this because this seems to be a reason why people are somewhat scared of the game but it's nowhere near as bad as you'd think and you can definitely get over it if you want to try (if you don't want to thats fine but it is really not that bad).
As well as this the combat problem of the attacks being a dice roll are not a big problem either, it can be a bit frustrating at the start but after a few hours you will have upgraded your attacking skill to a point where that is not a problem. Again, this seems to be something which scares many people, but once again it's not as bad as you'd think.
If you liked fallout 3 or FNV or skyrim, you'll like this if you want to get over both of these problems which you may experience at the start. All use bethesda's three cycles of exploration, combat and scavenging (I know FNV was made by obsidian but the use of the creation engine means these three cycles still remain) and while in all of bethesda's other games (meaning not FNV) those three cycles are the best part of those games, it's here and only here where bethesda's writing and quest design reaches a point of quality where it really is the best thing in the game (perhaps other than oblivion but I haven't played it yet). 
Morrowind is the peak of bethesda's capability to create stories and quests at a good and consistent level and this along with Bethesda's other trademarks; a brilliant world, Great Exploration, Great loot and Satisfying Progression means that it is one of the best RPGs ever and I definitely recommend it if you can get through those teething issues I discussed earlier.

I've got hundreds of hours playing Morrowind since when it came out and I've loved every moment of it. This game is absolutely a masterpiece and despite many attempts to remake it, it cannot be recreated or relived today.

I don't recommend this game because expectations have changed over the years and a lot of the mechanics in this game just don't make any sense to people who have played modern games. The interface is clunky by today's standards and it requires too much time investment to understand the game world.

That being said - this game allows so much freedom to the player character while keeping the world state plausible. You can kill the god everybody worships, or work alongside him - some people will hate you and others will love you. You can make mortal enemies with hundreds of people you've never met simply by joining a guild. There are longstanding racial grudges and a variety of religions that will either love you or try to kill you based on whether or not you progress their prophecies.

This game also has some broken mechanics. You can make potions that make you better at making potions that make you better at making potions. Then you can sell those potions for more money than all of the vendors in the game have combined. You can enchant your equipment to make you permanently invincible to physical attacks.

If you want a game that presents you with a world to interact with - where characters have opinions about everything and won't always tell you about them, where your choices actually matter in the game world, and you're willing to deal with a very dated engine, then I would recommend this to you.

Amazing classic RPG with amazing world building and quests and an epic story. Can be hard to understand mechanics at first because people don't read instructions, but once you're aware of how to improve skills and level up the game is a breeze. Every RPG lover has to play this game once in their lifetime.

Despite a certain level of jank (my high elf slides every damn time they jump, for about 5 seconds across the floor), amongst other things (I've unloaded the expansion packs, so dark brotherhood don't spank my booty from the start, so maybe it's the cause of the jank?), this is one of the last true great single player rpg's. I could describe this as feeling like a single player mmorpg.

No fast travel, no quest markers. Just a journal to read quest tips in, lots of people to talk with to get clues and travelling by foot, boat, teleportation or silt strider, make this feel like a truly large world, with epic scale.

It doesn't spoon feed you anything and makes you work for it. The combat is based on percentages, so yes a rat could beat you 1:1 if your rng rolls suck, but when you level your skills and come back for vengeance, it makes it all the sweeter.

The melee classes are easier, but once you finally start looking at using magic, making potions, gaining that understanding of the systems and overcoming that steep learning curve feels like it truly pays off.

This is a janky, graphically aged behemoth of a game and a fine example of what games seem to have been striving to move away from, in order to attract a larger player base, for better or worse.

If you feel like an epic adventure, don't mind putting in the work to understand the systems and then crafting goofy spells, where literally jumping between locations is much quicker than walking or taking transportation, this game is for you. Just don't expect it to spoon feed you (there are lots of guides/tutorials out there if you do need help!).

If you don't feel like putting the effort in and want fast travel, simplified systems, shiner graphics, less original world (they live in dang mushrooms and there's a floating moon rock over one city, which you can enter!) and want more help with quests, just buy Skyrim.

Morrowind today is a RPG legend and a standout title in the Elder Scrolls Series. For a game released in 2002 it looks reasonably good and can be improved through mods fairly easily. The soundtrack is timeless and was composed by the now legendary Jeremy Soule. The game can be punishingly difficult for new characters and players who are more familiar with now industry standard game mechanics of health and mana regeneration, and not understanding how strong of an impact the various stats in the game affect everything you do. It doesn't matter if you happen upon some legendary weapons and armor; If your skills are low, most of your attempts to swing a sword or fire an arrow will miss entirely, and your armor will provide very little protection. The game also does little to hold your hand. Don't expect quest indicators to point your way to the next objective or prevent you from breaking the story line, as it is entirely possible to kill characters that are vital to progress the story, effectively ending your playthrough of the story. At least it does notify you afterward that you have broken the story. The story is definitely worth experiencing. If you don't mind a challenge and some of the tedious actions of the game systems from that time (like no indicators saying a container is empty and individually dragging items stack by stack from your inventory to a container), it is worthwhile to visit Morrowind and experience some of the history and events that are later referenced in Oblivion and Skyrim. The large number of books in the game are worth reading as well if you haven't already read them in more recent Elder Scrolls games. You also can meet the quirky author of those scandalous books, "The Lusty Argonian Maid", Crassius Curio. If you are looking for a RPG with a wide range of customization (except character models, which are limited without mods), an interesting story, a great soundtrack, and difficulty that will keep you on your toes, why not give Morrowind a chance? You can't beat the price and the Wiki can help you understand the quirks and workings of the game systems. Best of luck, Outlander!

Morrowind removed many of the rpg systems from its predecessor, Daggerfall, but it is still leagues ahead of any of the games Bethesda has released since. This game is the origin of the warp in the west, because the developers didn't want to pick a canon ending for Daggerfall, or account for all of the branches that would be caused by allowing players to import saves, as well as a significant amount of the rest of the Elder Scrolls lore.

The combat relies on skill-based dice-rolls to determine whether you hit your opponent or not. This system was also present in the prior two games, Arena and Daggerfall, but unlike Morrowind they were sprite-based, so it wasn't jarring then. There are mods to change this so that the dice-rolls determine the amount of damage inflicted, as in later games, but I recommend you suffer through the vanilla experience at least once.

So... Morrowind. As you probably know, there's a large mod community for the game, which aims to fix most of its problems. But not everyone has the patience to sift through mod lists, read guides, and wrestle with loading conflicts. So how does Morrowind hold up without mods? Is it still worth playing?

Well, I'd say it is, if you can get over two things.

The first is the graphics. I mean, just look at the screenshots. They're very outdated. The texture are low resolution and low details, the characters, creatures and geography are sharp and angular. The color palette doesn't help either ; most of the environments are some combinations of dark green, light and dark browns, beige, and grays. Which is appropriate for the setting, but still contributes to a generally unnappealing look.

The second thing is the quirks that come with it being an old school RPG. You've probably heard about the combat system, which uses hit chances. This is a perfectly fine system for turn based or even top down RPGs, but for a first person one, where you can plainly see your weapon go through the enemy, it's very jarring when it doesn't do anything. Not to mention that, at the beginning of the game, you are going to miss [i]a lot[/i]. Especially since the game doesn't give you a lot of explanations (hint : fatigue matters a ton. Don't fight when you're tired).
It's not the only thing, though it's probably the most well known. Some skills are much more useful than others, some are surprisingly hard or long to train. It's difficult to be a mage without some prior game knowledge because the magic system is complex and at times confusing (and your magic reserves don't recharge naturally, you have to use potions or sleep). Sometimes, an NPC will wander into a doorway, and you'll have to wait until they decide to move again to be able to go through.  The map has squares to indicate locations, not different icons by types, so if you are looking for a city you can't tell at a glance what is a city and what is a ruin, you have to mouse over each one and check the name.
And so on. There aren't some huge problems (though some people understandably can't get over the fight system), but a bunch of little annoyances that are a symptom of the game being (nearly) 20 years old.

So what are Morrowind's strengths? Why do I say it's still worth playing, if you can get over my previous two points?

First off is the setting. We're all used to the typical high fantasy fare, your enchanted forests, great roiling plains, snowy mountains peaks, and the like. But Vvardenfell, where the game takes place, isn't like that. It's a volcanic island. There are marshes, ash-covered wastes, rocky cliffs, and coastal wetlands. Weird plants grow all over, some mushrooms are bigger than trees, some factions make their houses in the shells of long dead gigantic crabs while other literally grow their towns from mushrooms that they then hollow out and live in, not to mention the many ruins of other civilizations  dot the landscape and also look strange and distinct. The locals use giant insects as means of travels, and have "mines" dedicated to raise another species of insects for their eggs. Some fighters use equipment made of chitin, or bones, or shells.
Point is, despite the aged graphics, Morrowind gives you a setting that looks weird, exotic, and disorienting, and that makes you want to explore it.
Another strong point of the setting is that it's believable. The factions and the people interact with each other ; cities have very distinct styles depending on where they are ; people react to your actions ; and so on. Joined the Fighter's Guild? Well they and the Thieve's Guild have a beef, so if you want to be part of both it'll make things harder for you. Joined one of the Three Great Houses? Well the others will like you even less than before. You get the idea.

Then there is the freedom. Both from a gameplay and from a story standpoint, Morrowind is a game that lets you do whatever you want. There are many skills that cover a big range of weapons and magic, as well as mundane abilities like trading and talking, so you can build a character that fits your style. And the story never nags you, at least until toward the end. Heck, the first important character you meet on the main quest outright tells you to go out and explore the world, do some things and grow, before coming back. There might be consequences for going somewhere you're not supposed to be, but if you really want to go there, you can. Same with NPCs ; you can deal with them however you like.
The mortal-turned-god, who lives in the temple of the city that bears his name? In a modern RPG (like this game's sequels), you would have to wait until the associated quest progresses enough to meet him, and then you could only talk to him. In Morrowind, you can pick the lock to his temple and stab him to death if you feel like it. It's going to be hard, and the game will outright tell you you probably should reload a save because you just broke the main quest, but you [b]can[/] do it, and if you're fine with having a broken main quest, then the game won't insist.

And finally -and this one might not be an appeal for everyone, but for those it is, it's a big one- there's the power fantasy. At the beginning of the game, your character is weak. I distinctly remember my first time playing the game, where I was wandering about with no idea of what I was doing, and ended up being killed by a fish in the waters of the starting town. A [b]fish[/b]. (in my defence, I was weakened as I had just fought a crab). But as you progress, you become steadily more powerful. And eventually, you become [i]very[/i] powerful. Your skills improves, you hit more often and harder, you get better equipment. You learn new spells. You start destroying enemies that would have killed you before. And that feels GOOD.

And that's before you start messing with the game's system. Once you understand the game well, how stats interacts with each others, how magic works, and so on, you can break it apart. Fixed loot? That means you can get there at the start of the game and get an end-game weapon at level 1. Enchantment? You can completely destroy the game's balance with homemade stuff. Travelling? Who needs a boat when you can jump mountains. And so on. Again, this might not be appealing for everyone, but for some people (like me) there is a special satisfaction in poking at the game's rules and abusing them for your benefit.

So yes. I would recommend Morrowind. It's still a great game, even without mods.
Altough even if you don't want to mess with mods, I'll still recommend installing the unnoficial patch, at the very least. This is an old game, [i]and[/i] this is a Bethesda games. There are [b]bugs[/b].

An incredible RPG, just incredible. The average gamer of today will find it hard to get into this game no doubt, mainly because of the copious amounts of reading, exceedingly crappy combat and the worst of it all: lack of clear directions on where to go next. Perhaps people can move past many of Morrowind's archaic design choices but this last one is where you actually start to lose players.

No quest markers, just you, your map and your journal. It's a fantastic feeling when you successfully follow the directions NPCs give you, but the problem comes when they start to give you extremely vage directions. Most of the time you get detailed directions like "go west and when you find a signpost, turn left". That's manageable, but when it's crap like "Uhhh yeah, just go southeast bro. It might be in a different direction tho", yeah good luck with that.

For people that really want to get fully immersed, directions are not going to be a problem, you can just walk your days away and explore to your heart's content. But Bethesda knows that most gamers are busy people and have places to be, so it's no wonder that quest markers are a staple of all open world games these days, few people will choose immersion over convenience after all.

There's also no easy way to fast travel to previously visited locations, but this is just a small inconvenience in the early and mid game. It's only a matter of time for your character to go from lowly peasant to omnipotent god, happens in every single Bethesda game and Morrowind is no exception. My orc barbarian started with a humble pair of legs that were not particularly good at running and ended up being able to fly all over the map at high speeds. So yeah, travelling the land is not a big deal, in fact, is one of the best aspects of the game. Morrowind is such a vast and peculiar place, everything looks foreign, almost alien. Not your typical fantasy environment by any means, which can only elevate exploration.

Combat can be a little frustrating, your attacks are going to miss a lot until you raise your agility or your weapon skill,  not a big deal either but everyone that plays this game for the first time goes through this: you start the game, create your character after several minutes of careful consideration, try to kill your first mudcrab and stand there completely dumbfounded as you witness your character miss every single one of their attacks. And that's just the very beginning, don't even get me started on enemies that drain your atributes...

So ok, we managed to learn how the game works (not really), what's left? Well, thankfully, an stellar main quest that delivers a very interesting story. My one gripe with it is that becoming [spoiler]Hortator and Nerevarine[/spoiler] is a huge chore if you choose to go through with those quests but otherwise everything else is pretty good. The expansions, Tribunal and Bloodmoon, are mostly alright, but honestly not as good as the MQ. Still worth checking out though.

Overall a hard game to get into but extremely rewarding when you finally do, defined by a feeling of true freedom not many modern open world games are able to convey.
