MY HISTORY WITH MORROWIND:
I played The original version of Morrowind (bought at Walmart in 2002).  Modded it and created mods for it. Played it until the CD got errors.  Got the steam version.  Spent a good day doing modding and once again fell in.  Steam hours listed do not reflect the actual hours I have played.  I know it's over 1000 hours and could be much higher.  I currently use OPENMW (with lots of graphics mods) and those hours don't show on Steam.  

SOME GENERAL THOUGHTS:
The combat sucks when you start a new game. Your starting speed sucks, so learn to enjoy the scenery.  Alchemy is OP as is Enchanting.  Sneaking? not so much. There can be a grind but there are ways to avoid most of it. There are many guides, both written and on Youtube.  Graphics is dated but can be enhanced through mods.  The landmass is large, you will get lost.  The game WILL NOT hold your hand and you can freely walk into areas above your pay grade.  Save often.  There are more NPC's than in most games. That said, there is NO quest marker, and most dialog is not voice acted so you will be reading a lot of dialog. NPCs will lie or be mistaken in their directions and you will get lost. Save often.  The methods of making an optimum build are not obvious, or required.  While fast travel like in later games (from the map) is not implemented, the various water ships, guild teleports, stilt striders and other methods of movement are viable substitutes. 

WHY I RECOMMEND:
The main quest is a good story.  There are a lot of step and fetch it quests but there are some memorial quests, too.  The landscape is unlike any of the other Elder Scrolls games and captured my interest.  Mods are still being made although you MAY want to try your first play through plain vanilla.  If you played Oblivion and Skyrim, you owe it to yourself to try Morrowind for the lore, the experience, and perhaps the completionist in you.

Like many people, my first exposure to the Elder Scrolls was The Elder Scrolls VI: Skyrim. I had already put in around 3,000 hours in on my Nintendo Switch and I was ready to see what else this series had in store. I've played for about 91 hours and gotten a decent ways through the main quest at the point of writing this review and I have to conclude that Morrowind is the better of the Elder Scrolls series, character creation is far more thoughtful and deep than in Skyrim and not every quest ends in violence, unlike in Skyrim where nearly every quest involves delving into some dungeon, slaying a bunch of weak enemies, slaying the dungeon boss, and getting some amount of loot to either equip to your character or sell once you're back in town. Those kinds of quests still exist in Morrowind (And again, not every Skyrim quest ends in violence either), but with Morrowind, the amount of violence you engage in is mostly dictated by you, the player. Sure, some npcs have to die for the story to progress and some npcs have to be kept alive for the story to progress, but with the smaller quests, i.e. most of what you'll be doing, your hand is rarely, if ever, forced.
And at the end of the day, isn't that what a roleplaying game is about? Being in control of your character's actions? To play out the role you wish your character to have? I would think so.
*But then again, if you asked someone what characteristics make a roleplaying game they'll probably tell you it has something to do with numbers or something. Like I dunno, I just like Morrowind, leave me be.*

While heavily outdated in many aspects, most of which are fixed by the modding community, Morrowind manages to be the game in the Elder Scrolls franchise that means the most to me. It is the only game in the franchise where the main quest actually hooked me. Whereas Skyrim and Oblivion have upfront and frequently present threats to the fate of the world, Morrowind's main questline is much more of a slow burn, giving you plenty of time to ease into the plot, learn the political climate of Vvardenfell, and learn lore that directly pertains to the main plot. Most of the main quest avoids the typical Elder Scrolls dungeon crawling, instead asking you to travel to different cities or camps, meeting people and fulfilling a series of prophecies, which plays into Morrowind's somewhat archaic dialogue system. The faction quests always start out seeming like meaningless tasks, but end up forming a larger arc that carries a purpose in the larger world. Smaller side quests usually succeed in either leading you to something obscure but important, or are just entertaining.

In terms of issues, well, there's plenty. First and foremost is the vanilla combat. To modern gamers, the idea of swinging a sword at something and just missing is asinine. It's a system rooted in the concept of AC and saving throws in D&D, but doesn't translate well in this format. Luckily, there are mods that rebalance the game so that you can swing weapons and always hit with them, like later Elder Scrolls games. Second is the fast travel system. Most people exaggerate this issue. While you can't open a map anywhere to travel to wherever you want instantly, getting anywhere you want is never difficult, and you have a lot of options. The silt striders, boats, guild guides, and gondolas transport you for a small fee. Almsivi Intervention and Divine Intervention can transport you to a town instantly. Recall does the same but to wherever you last used the Mark spell. There's also a propylon system that is hard to use unless you've installed the master propylon plugin, but is still another option. The problem of having to memorize all these systems can be lessened by a mod that shows a transport map when you go to a transport NPC.

Overall, what I think really matters is how a game makes you feel. And for me, Morrowind was an invested experience. Fulfilling the Nerevarine prophecies made me feel powerful, even though I knew I was just following the story's script. There were interesting and memorable characters. There were hard times of exploring ash-ridden volcano slopes, and there were fun times of getting an extra-comfy pillow as a reward for finding a crashed ship full of pillows. I will always treasure this game despite its many flaws.

Surprisingly Morrowind was easy to get into, it is old-school but nothing to be scared of if you're interested to experience it for the first time and honestly it's worth playing maybe not for someone that isn't into RPG more than that but even so it's a really fantastic game despite its age.

The main quest is interesting and the lore surrounding it is well explained in dialog and some reading material mostly provided on the journey. The dialog isn't voiced but it has a topic system which provide a lot more possibilities to share information with the player instead of needing books all the time for detailed information. There is also a massive amount of quests it's over 400 which provide a lot of things to do, it's more than Oblivion and Skyrim. Guilds have a ranking system and requirements but also reside in multiple towns so it feels more organic to climb the ladder because it also comes with some benefits later down the road. Character progression is more complex than its successors but not by much to be overwhelming and everything is viable even on higher difficulty but it might take longer to kill something in rare cases obviously. The world is varied in tone and ambience with different environments so discovering the world is often interesting. The two expansions Tribunal and Bloodmoon are good their main quest was fun and for tribunal provide additional content somewhat attached to the main story of the game. 

While main quest is fun most of the rest of the numerous quests do tend to feel more on the errand side given that the topic system could be utilised a bit more in-depth when investigating for some quests. Additionally some quests give very little to go and sometimes the directions given are rather vague and you end up wandering around making up 75% of the time spent to find the location for the quest. It comes to the world map which won't mark every discovered locations but only what the game deemed most important so finding the way to unmarked locations can be tedious at times and it also doesn't help that it's really zoomed out and cannot be zoomed in at all. Another problem is most dungeons have an identical entrance to most others so it's always needed to go up to the door and verify because there is no compass like in Oblivion and Skyrim here. The problem with dungeons is how they are most of the time very short and repetitive, no unique enemies, no interesting loot, no particular interesting quest to go with it or anything really to make them stand out even a little and the different types are few so as much as I enjoy dungeon crawling this is more about quantity over quality. A lot of time is spent finding your way around and given the lack of points of interest and unhelpful tools to orient yourself I'm confident a sizeable portion of my playtime is going in circles to reach quest locations so I recommend looking at uesp interactive map to avoid that. The game is most probably more buggy than the other TES games I've played even with mods to patch things up I still had quest that couldn't be completed most of the time because I didn't do things in order or in a specific way so my usage of the console commands was much more frequent in Morrowind than Oblivion and Skyrim to debug my way out of problems. Pathfinding is some of the worst as well, doing escort missions was gruelling since they also walk very slowly and can easily not be able to walk the seemingly normal path you do so it takes patience for those. I had numerous crashes despite having only the bare minimum as mods but most were after 300 hours played so maybe it was something in my save.

In conclusion, it's a good game truly for anyone interested in RPGs or The Elder Scrolls games maybe not so much to someone that is not too deep into the genre but the old-school side isn't hard to deal with and I have a hard time playing 90s games these days just to give an idea. I strongly recommend getting at the very least the code patch and MGE XE on nexusmods just reading the instructions in the description should be enough to install them it's easy and quick to fix many problems even if only trying to seek a vanilla experience for a first time with the game. My personal score is 8/10 it actually took me 400+ hours to do everything I could in the game with a single character but I tend to take my time with video games.

Although I haven't got many hours on steam, I have played this game religiously since I was younger on both XBOX original and PC and it is an absolute masterpieces. No hand-holding, no simple and easy combat, no BS. A straight to the point decent open world RPG that truly lets you just do as you please. Need to go somewhere? Screw your modern day fast travel. Either get a stiltstrider, mages guild teleport or walk. Don't know where to go? Screw your modern day markers everywhere. Ask for directions and actually follow them. It is such a damn good game and it is the best elder scrolls period. I love oblivion and skyrim and I have played those loads too, and from what I have played of dagger fall and arena they are OK, but THIS game is where it is at. Absolute bargain 99% of the time too so do yourself a favour and grab it!

Don't let my playtime on steam fool you. I first started playing Morrowind in 2004, as a bright eyed and bushy tailed 10 year old homeschooler. I had no idea what an RPG was but I had heard about them on the news reports covering the war in the Middle East, so I felt pretty qualified to play this game. What unfolded was a love story that would span two copies of Morrowind GOTY (turns out when you play a game religiously on Xbox, the disc can die) and two annotated maps, and would shape my future disappointment with just about every RPG that I would play.

Morrowind is Elder Scrolls for crack addicts and people who wake up ready to be heart. It's brutal, unfair, beautiful, deep, rich and also, with a wave of a magic wand and a proper soul trap on target, completely broken. Imagine spending 200 hours fighting through Vvardenfell, fighting to rid the land of Dagoth Ur, to restore order to Solstheim and uncover a deep conspiracy in Mournhold, only to start a new game and realize you could become a God (how can you kill a god?). To accent the struggle and strife of getting one shotted by a werewolf with 600 speed and 1000 acrobatics is an opioid I hope to God you can ingest in your system. 

I don't know how Morrowind will hold up for you today. I grew up with it. It reminds me of simpler days, of mystery, excitement. I think if you buy this game and go into it looking at it as a time capsule of when game design was simplistic yet deep, rich and engrossing, you'll be blown away. If you go in hoping for a AAA title with beautiful graphics and your typical voice actors, you're going to rage and head back to Skyrim Anniversary Re-Release V2. This game changed my life, as cringe as that is to say. It opened my imagination and showed me how powerful games can be, and how they can inspire us artistically.

If you're on the fence, jump in. It'll be brutal at first but stick with it. Raise your agility and luck, train in your primary weapon skills so you're landing hits, and then read your journal to discover a land full of intrigue, danger and, most of all, beauty.

I've been a devout fan of Morrowind since it launched in 2002. I had the base game and both expansions on CD and wore through those things with countless playthroughs. This steam version runs perfect and I've yet to encounter a single issue with modding; including the Morrowind Code Patch, Morrow Graphics Extender, and the Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul v3.0. 

This is, in my humble opinion, the Elder Scrolls game that set the bar for RPGs. It's a world rich in lore and adventure, that is significantly more dangerous and less watered down than Oblivion and Skyrim. This game doesn't hold your hand, and actions have consequences. Be who you want to be, go where you want to go, and let the story of the Nerevarine and Morrowind unfold before you. If you've never played Morrowind, I urge you to buy this game and dive in to a truly open world RPG. The graphics are dated being from 2002, but there are plenty of mods out there to bring this stellar game in to the 2021.

addicting, just with a few things needed to make it better

Engine: when you first start of modding the game, you need to make a choice, a very important one, do you stick with the vanilla engine or go with openmw? Both are good ways of playing but the vanilla version with no setup is far worse than openmw, most people mod the base game so I will focus on that, you need at least 3 mods

Mods: vanilla morrowind is quite outdated and it doesn't take a genius to understand so, these mods will help with the frustration you may encounter at the 480p resolution, 5 feet/meter view distaance, or any other annoyances you may have

1. MGE XE allows modern resolution support, cool shaders, and more, it's what most people use, just run the GUI executable included and adjust the settings
Link: https://www.nexusmods.com/morrowind/mods/41102/

2. The Morrowind code patcher is required to make mge xe work, just run the executable included and tick/untick the options you want or don't want and then click "apply chosen patches"
Link: https://www.nexusmods.com/morrowind/mods/19510/

3. Patch for purists is a bug fixer, unzip the contents into the data files folder, it has an esm/esp, nuff said
Link: https://www.nexusmods.com/morrowind/mods/45096

This is what I use to play the game but openmw has an installer which makes a lot of these mods obsolete for openmw, that being said, openmw does not have compatibility with mwse lua mods although in the next version, they plan to add support for it in the next update, but it's in it's very, VERY early stages, so the choice comes down to what you want

Do you want an easy setup or are not interested into mods? go with openmw

Do you want better mod support for your needs? Unless you don't mind a weird setup, go with vanilla

P.S if you chose either, be prepared to stick to it as openmw does not support vanilla save and vice versa, my parting words on this review/guide, or are experiencing any issues, comments are allowed, and if you do buy the game, welcome to Vvardenfell

Its weird how these games got more simple and contained less content with each new release. I don't think there will ever be a day when I 100% this game. 40 hours in and I haven't even touched the main quest. There is something great about a game that tells you "You suck, get good." before even starting the main story. It makes you feel like you belong in this world and that the quest were not specifically made just for you the player. There is so much to take in this game and unlike the other elder scrolls, any sort of cheep advantage you can get over your enemy, you should use otherwise you might not make it. Don't expect to be a super powered MF'r until you put in the work. There is so much content in this game that never made it into the other elder scrolls. Not having fast travel is awesome albeit at the cost of a headache trying to find which strider and boat to ride on. But something about that makes it so much more immersive than pulling up your map and magically ending up where you want to be. Fret not though if you want to travel fast on foot, take a strong levitation spell and the boots of blinding speed and you will be flying across the map in magical fashion. Never in my life have I felt more like a wizard in a video game. And for those that can't stand the combat because you miss every hit, just train. If you actually listen to what quest givers tell you and pay attention, you will be rewarded with help and items. This game is not as unforgiving as it may seem, you just cant be lazy. The Journal can be a bitch but I never had any problems completing a quest as long as I took the time to read what they were saying and went through all dialog options. Just don't get too much on your plate at once. One quest at a time. Worst comes to worst there are so many great guides that I can't imagine anybody having a hard time with this game unless they have a single digit IQ. Highly recommend you download at least the Graphics Extender if playing on a modern system. Which brings me into mods. This game is 100x times easier to mod than Skyrim or Oblivion, and most mods work with each other well and will not crash the game. The community is still putting out new content on Nexus. That should tell you the longevity of this game. Truly a masterpeice. The world is so fleshed out and so alive it feels like a real place that just far away from here. Amazing easter-eggs and hidden stashes as well.

Clunky and Old but it has its charm. I played this for a very long time back on Xbox and I will say the PC version isn't as polished the great part about PC is that you can mod out most of those problems. It has an amazing story and a super cool world. It easily took my #1 spot back in 2017. Its not for everyone I can say that, coming from Skyrim I was used to playing games in autopilot...cant play morrowind like that. Morrowind makes you think a little bit but not so much to the point where it feels like a chore. 
10/10

What a fool I was. It's a masterpiece. How could I ignore a masterpiece? What a grand and intoxicating adventure. How naive I was waiting so long. There really was no escape. No excuse or hate can work against this legend. Come. Lay down your other games. It is not too late to play.

So when I first played Morrowind I didn't have the luxury of playing it at launch, in fact, back when it came out I wasn't very much into RPG's at all, I was a dumb 9 year old that played PS1/PS2 games all day. My first true elder scrolls experience was Skyrim back in 2011, and as much as I loved skyrim, I eventually started to crave more... So naturally I looked back at the older elder scrolls games. First I started with oblivion, while the atmosphere was amazing and the world felt very alive, it was marred by an incredibly broken level scaling system, that, when I initially complained about, I was told that I have to min-max to circumvent this and make sure I get a certain amount of endurance on a single level up, and put all the skills I actually planned on using as miscellaneous skills.

That was fucking dumb, and you bet your ass I didn't play it for very long.

Now moving on from oblivion I decided to try morrowind, originally I couldn't get into it, a lot of things put me off, but eventually I made a character build I was comfortable with and had a blast, I chose a preset class and went to town, she was an acrobat who could zip around all over the place jumping away from combat only to poke somebody in the face with a spear afterwards, Eventually I fought dagoth ur, killed him, and completed the main story quest, but I hadn't even begun to scratch the surface of what this game had to offer, so I made a new character... And eventually I made a character with a custom class.

That custom character utilized magic, and that's where an entire world of wonder was opened up to me, I chose magic specialization, made my character's strengths both intelligence and willpower, then proceeded to take all the magic based skills as majors and minors, with unarmored slapped in there also for the hell of it, took atronarch sign because alchemy is a thing and I could just craft magicka potions. What became of it was something truly amazing, the spell making system gave me the freedom to make whatever kind of spell I wanted, and eventually my mage got so damn powerful that I made a single spell that fortified my mercantile to 900 and was able to convince a merchant that a rock I found outside of balmora was worth the entirety of his stock. It's an incredibly system and one that I wish was included in the later installements, especially in skyrim where magic was gutted entirely and became progressively weak the higher your level went.

Despite having started with a game later in the franchise I was still so drawn to this because of the sheer amount of freedom that was offered to me at character creation, eventually I found myself pouring hundreds of hours into it, several hundred of those hours aren't even displayed on steam because I started using OpenMW, which I highly recommend you use if you plan on playing this game, sure you don't get access to script extender mods, but you really don't need them, the game holds out on it's own without adding unnecessary bloat to it, and you get a launcher that is 64 bit, supports modern hardware, and has an amazing level of stability that bethesda could only wish surpass.

The best Elder Scrolls game, and my favorite game of all time. I must have over a thousand hours or more between my original PC boxed copy, the Xbox version and most recently OpenMW. While it undoubtedly shows its age at this point, underneath the dated graphical exterior is a deep, engrossing RPG with real player choice and meaningful character customization.

 While the quests you're sent on often aren't much on their own, the context and overarching narrative of them primarily serves to make the player feel like a part of the world. And what a world it is. This is the Elder Scrolls before all the rough edges were sanded down, when the lore was weird and wild and deep and not everything was explained to the player. 

It truly feels like you're a stranger in a strange land, and while Vvardenfell may be smaller than previous Elder Scrolls games it's far, far more detailed and much more alien. With OpenMW's graphical enhancements this can still be a startlingly beautiful game, which is a credit to the strong art direction.

I could probably write another ten paragraphs about this game, but I'll spare you my rambling. It's a masterpiece and if you like deep, engrossing RPG's you absolutely must play it.

Morrowind is an old (2002) open world RPG. It is fully 3D, in either 1st or 3rd person, with a complex leveling system and rich story.

So I am the most biased person to write a review for this game. I have bought it three times (once on Xbox, once as a PC disk, and once here on steam). I love this game, and always will. No this game isn't perfect, it is old school in so many ways, but if you take the time to learn it, maybe watch a guide just to get you started, it is a rich and rewarding experience.

First, and foremost, this game has a lot of "annoying" things about it that modern games have done away with that you will need to get used to, or potentially mod out. Things such as a slow walking/running speed, magicka (mana) not regenerating over time require you to rest, weapons missing most of the time if your skill is low, stamina draining as you run, no fast travel other than through in game services such as boats, no quest markers, etc. etc. This will be an immediate turn off for many people. I play the game completely unmoded, but have found ways to deal with these problems in game (such as using the "Boots of Blinding Speed"). The modding community is great for this game so if you must you can mod it right away to make it more accessible.

But why would you go through this effort for this game? In my opinion there are 3 things this game does extraordinarily well that make it worthwhile to play even today. 

1. You are a stranger in a strange land. You don't fight dragons or trolls or other familiar creatures from fantasy. You fight nix hounds and dreugs. No rolling hills of english country side here, instead swamps with giant mushrooms and ash lands where people live in giant crab shells. It is a setting unlike any other. 

2. The world building and story. There is basically no voice acting in this game (except like one or two lines per race), its all done through text. And the writing is pretty good. It draws you into its strange world, the strange customs of the Dunmer, the history of the tribunal, and it doesn't beat you over the head with any of it. You explore and encounter it naturally, organically and the people act like it. The open world means you can explore many of the smaller niches of the game or go through the main story. I find the main story great.

 3. It doesn't hold you by the hand. I think this is a positive thing, as you learn not only the mechanics of the game but the world of Morrowind, it feels rewarding to get a handle on things, it feels rewarding to find secrets and learn. You have to struggle to understand, make an effort in a way games don't ask of their audience anymore, but they reward you for it.

So if you can get past, or even get invested, in the old school, don't hold you by the hand gameplay, there is plenty to love about this game and it is well worth it.

One of the best and most underrated gems of the RPG genre, Morrowind has its peculiar charm but is not certainly for everyone. Set in the desolate volcanic province of Morrowind within Tamriel, Morrowind’s intricate world-building is one of its greatest strengths. The open game world can be traversed freely and contains numerous settlements, unique flora and fauna and wastelands. There are different races, organisations, and even in-game books detailing the world’s history, religion and politics.

If you are looking for a game with HD graphics, then Morrowind might not be your cup of tea. It does have 3D graphics and an open world, but for modern tastes, the game is unpolished, ugly and rough around the egdes. More than once did I get stuck on a certain section of a dungeon and had to push myself repeatedly to get through. There were a few bugs with saving the game too, though I was able to fix them by deleting corrupted files and starting over with progress largely intact.

The leveling system and character skills allow for a wide variety of different playstyles, even if some are more practical than others. Personally, I find it to be one of the best in any video games I have played. Morrowind has 27 different skills, which are developed further by practicing the skill. While leveling up you increase your character’s fundamental attributes that are separate from your skills. This sophisticated system reminds me of tabletop RPGs, and is not the only area of the game obviously inspired by them.

Joinable guild questlines are more believable than in many other games (such as Skyrim), as you will slowly work your way up the organisation by first doing menial tasks and then proceeding to the more serious quests. This balance helps you feel that you’ve progressed further once you have gone further in the questline. 

Conversations are in the form of written dialogue, and while in a sense it takes from immersion, it also allows for more intricate dialogue in character interactions. Most NPCs are useless statists, but it also means settlements are more believable when having a larger number of inhabitants. But it is somewhat annoying that NPCs are walking encyclopedias and you need to scroll down a long list of conversation topics to find the proper one.

Albeit being composed of only a few tracks, the soundtrack to Morrowind is excellent and helps immersion.

A true no frills adventure game. I cannot highly recommend it enough. A few points to follow though -

1) Download mods. Please do not play this without them and expect a great experience. Don't turn yourself away from the game right away. It's nearly 20 years old at this point, the game could use all the help it can get.

2) Take it easy. There's no wrong way to play. There are certainly "sub-optimal" builds for your character, but that's the fun of the game. You want to swing a big ass mace and cast spells in light armor? Go for it.

3) Don't look everything up. The directions that the NPCs give you for a quest are given that way on purpose to encourage exploration and discovery. Taking the long way to your objective is infinitely more rewarding, both in material rewards as well as in the enjoyment you'll get from this carefully constructed world. That leads me to the next point.

4) Look up, look down, look all around. There's loot behind tapestries, under pillows, behind beds. EVERYWHERE. Most of it is a little gold or potions, but some of the best items the game has to offer are hidden in locations you'd never go to normally. Harking back to point number 3, explore. It's a vast open world out there and the island of Vvardenfel holds many secrets at the tops of towers and depths of the many caves.

5) Ask the community. Morrowind has a fan base stretching back 20 years now. If you need advice or just want to learn more about the game, we're here. If you have a second monitor, I usually watch Lyle Shnub's Morrowind Mondays playthrough while pitter pattering my way around Vivec.

With Skyrim getting yet another release, I feel like there's no better time to look to some of the older games and appreciate them for what they are and embrace that lost sense of storytelling Morrowind has to offer.

Good luck out there Outlander, and watch out for the Clffracers!

This is the definitive Elder Scrolls game. It set the tone, expectations and delivered on them before we even knew we wanted them some years later.

I'm not trying to sell you on old school, paper-and-pen mechanics. Many of Morrowind's design choices frustrate me such as chance to hit, fatigue, day-long magicka regen, an incredibly slow leveling system when done without exploits and virtually barren merchant gold for how many >50,000 gold items you'll end up collecting in your inventory. Which is compounded by low encumbrance and lack of a proper player home to store and display collected items. 

No, when I say it set the tone I mean the thematic consistency, the rock solid writing, the subtle hints as opposed to ham-fisted orders. The sincerity of the alien world despite its oddities and zany interactions. The explanation for basically everything. This was sorely missing in both Oblivion and Skyrim, and I fear for the future of TES if the Pavlovian formula of "don't ask questions, just loot and shoot" continues.

TL;DR 8/10, old but gold, stable 90% of 50% of the time.

Definitely a great game, but it can be a little jarring for some players coming from Skyrim - no fast travel beyond the Mages' Guild, much wordier NPCs with paragraphs of text, an almost entirely different shop system, and stats judging your speed and jumping. Those aside, there's some things that I'd say put it just a little above Skyrim - custom spells (but I'd say Oblivion does this better), custom class creation, and an NPC that lost his pants down by Gnisis. 
  Long story short, it's a great game, but if you're coming from a later game, it may take a bit to adjust. Expect some dumb stuff in the game, like the orc that only says "meow," lol.

Come Nerevar, friend or traitor, come. Come and look upon the Heart and Akulakahn, and bring Wraithguard, I have need of it. Come to the Heart chamber, I wait for you there, where we last met, countless ages ago. Come to me through fire and war, I welcome you! Welcome Moon-and-Star, I have prepared a place for you! Come, bring Wraithguard to the Heart chamber, together, let us free the cursed false gods! Welcome Nerevar, together we shall speak for the law and the land and drive the mongrel dogs of the Empire from Morrowind! Is this how you honor the 6th house and the tribe unmourned? Come to me openly, and not by stealth. Dagoth Ur welcomes you Nerevar, my old friend... but to this place where destiny is made, why have you come unprepared? Welcome, Moon-and-Star, to this place where YOUR destiny is made. What a fool you are, I'm a god! How can you kill a god? What a grand and intoxicating innocence! How could you be so naive? There is no escape, no recall or intervention can work in this place! Come! Lay down your weapons! It is not too late for my mercy...

Classic.

I tried my damnedest to enjoy the beauty of Morrowind (with modifications, of course), but there is something so unappealing about its primitive combat system and its hapless navigation system. The combat is like that of a game of chance, favoring whichever creature has the highest luck/agility rating. In the end, both parties just look like one of those boxing robot playsets.

On the other hand, I do not mind having to find my way to a point of interest without a waypoint or GPS system, yet the only thing the player is given is a name, look, and seldomly a direction; most of the time I found myself wandering empty spaces and locations inaccessible due to being locked by quests.

In conclusion, this game could only be loved by nostalgics and geographers.
This game is NOT for everyone, but it's an RPG experience that offers a ton of freedom, which I love.

I love this game. I have bought more copies of this game over the years than any other. I have played more hours on the original xbox version than any other. I bought this version with the plan to mod the heck out of it, but have yet to do that because I don't have as much time to play games as I did when I was a teen, and there are so many more games out now, and it is even easier to get them. So I tend to bounce around a lot between other games. Once when I had this game on Xbox I accidentally pushed the power button with my toe while it was saving, and it corrupted my save file. I didn't know how to fix it, or if it was even possible so I just made a new character. Definitely worth checking this out if. If you started playing these games with Oblivion or Skyrim then the combat will feel very dated, but if you can get past that there are a lot of great moments in this title.

My Morrowind Journey
Day 1- Downloaded the game.

Day 1 - Played the game and realized the resolution is set to the year 2002.

Day 1 - Downloaded a resolution fix mod.

Day 1 - Finally played the game.

Day 1 - Choose Dark Elf and begin my journey into the vast lands of Morrowind.

Day 1 - Spend an hour taking spoons and cups, made 40 to 50 gold coins off that. Feeling lucky I decided to do some missions after taking a break.

Day 1 - Launched the game 2 hrs later saw that there was no save file present in the game. Because I didn’t manually save my game last time I played. Screw you modern games with your auto-save system.

Day 2 - Installed the game again. Decided to play as a Red guard, if it’s not dark, then all in on black.

Day 2 - No mini-map or objective marker. Journal said I should head north to the city of balmora. I ended up in Ebonheart, which is a castle in the south.

Day 2 - Then I decided to go north but ended up getting gang-banged by group cliff racers. Turns out, the time I spent walking from one destination to another, I was collecting cliff racers over my head.

Day 2- Survived the battle with cliff racers, because one of the stolen cups was a bottle of cheap health potion. 

Day 3 - Found a cave, freed some slaves. Hit their master with my inexperienced Axe skill, I got rekt after two heavy blows to my head.

Day 3- Auto-save took me back to the entrance of the cave. I decided the noblest thing to do is - 
* Free the slaves 
* Not to be seen by their master.
If they get captured, it will be their fault for not finding a better hiding spot.

Day 4 - Encountered a rat, took me around 5 minutes to kill it. Out of 40 blows, only six landed. Googled, why is that? Turns out you can only use a weapon if you are good at it or every swing is a guaranteed miss.

Day 4 - Learned that my red guard has a long sword. I mean to have experience wielding a long sword.

Day 4- Now I can kill rats in 15 swings. And 8 of them will land.

Day 5 - Ended up in Balmora (20 hrs of running from cliff racers and killed by fish). The main mission was to head to a Dwemer ruin and steal a cube.

Day 5 - Made it to the ruins, stole the cube. Found a locked door but I lock-picked it. My red guard was also good at thief-ing.

Day 5 - Gave the cube to the guy and he gave me a key that can unlock a special door in the Dwemer cave.

Day 5- went back to the cave and spent the next hour looking for a door that could fit the key. Got annoyed and googled the location of the door. Turns out it was the same door I unlocked the last time. One of the comments on the forum said ‘Much of this game is about nothing’.

Day 5 - With the Seinfeld theme playing in my head, I decided to join the fighter guild. One of the missions was to kill a person in Balmora. So I did, after a while, I noticed that nobody was using that home.

Day 5- Now I am the owner of the town’s murder house. Once you dispose of the body, the home feels brand new.

Day 6- I am stuffing my new house with stolen cups and figuring out which way is west of my town.

This is somehow the most deep and yet least satisfying RPG experience due to a lack of voice acting during conversation with NPCs, for me. I still find Morrowind to be incredible and rich but that doesn't stop it from being yet another Bethesda game, it's one buggy mess.

If you can be bothered to play a game full of game breaking bugs and save scumming your way to victory then Morrowind is incredibly rewarding.

Few games drop you into a massive open world to explore from the get go the way that Morrowind does. You could spend hours upon hours without even touching the main quest. Don't let the dated graphics fool you. This is a game of epic proportions and is highly recommended to fans of RPGs.

Morrowind is the most alien and truly unique entry in the main series of Elder Scrolls, this game holds no hands while also rewarding player intuition and creativeness, you will become intimately familiar with the games systems and mechanics as you slowly turn into a walking god in this sandbox RPG.

Morrowind is designed with the player having full control over their actions, it allows you to absolutely break the world and destroy any chance of "fair play" should you decide to, while this game is almost 2 decades old and has some quite dated game designs (dice roll combat for example), it still provides what I'd argue the most open and fun world to explore. 

9/10 my personal favorite entry in the mainline story of the Elder Scrolls franchise! P.S. don't be afraid to look up builds and guides as the first 5 or so level-ups are arguably the hardest in this game or browse the wiki/UESP if you get stuck on a quest, its better to "spoil" yourself a little rather than forever write this game off as awful and never try it again

Morrowind opened up new concepts of what an open sandbox game could be. It became the stick which which all alike games are measured. The system can be intimidating at first, but it instantly becomes as immersive as the story. The replayability and customization is unparalleled for it's generation, and still holds up today.

At first I hated this game, but then I learned to love it. I'm talking about the freedom in the style of play. I was very enthusiastic about the variety of spells. The main story is an exciting adventure. After I stopped the game in between, it often felt like a cliffhanger. It was comparable to an exciting film. If you plan to play this game, you need patience, interest and external help. The external help for me was the internet site "UESPWiki" and it was very helpful when I got stuck. There is no shame in getting some help. In the future, when I have played through the two expansions "Tribunal" and "Bloodmoon", I will revise this review. But until then, have fun with your own adventure!

The most poorly aged game of all time, and that isn't even much of an exaggeration. I know critiquing this game is considered  boorish and crude within hardcore gaming circles, but it has to be said. You could take a quick glance at the gameplay on youtube, buy it, then play it only to find out your fears were amplified 10x. The world is lifeless and ugly, repetitive and confusing. Your character walks incredibly slowly, letting you soak in the environment's repetitive ugliness all the more. You'll get swarmed by polygon amalgams that dodge 90% of your attacks. When you return to the local town after the most tiresome fight of your life, the NPC's hurl essay-length textboxes filled with banal information only the most unjaded gamer could find interesting. While all this is happening, you've been googling so frequently on your phone that your hand show signs of cramping, and the phone's battery dies. Without google's guidance you doze off easier than anytime in your life. Probably the most boring and unrewarding game I've ever played.

If you don't have any nostalgia for Morrowind or earlier Elder Scrolls games, you won't enjoy it. This was made at a time when real-time RPGs were still a new concept, and so Morrowind contains a lot of Tabletop influence. For instance, you can visibly hit a Cliffracer with a Bow and Arrow. You can then miss due to an unseen dodge roll. Hitting those things with the damn arrow is hard enough as it is without having an arbitrary roll decide my fate.

I love this game, and I always will. But I'm fully aware that my nostalgia fuels all my love. This was a necessary step for what would become Oblivion and Skyrim. It's a step you might want to revisit if you have aspirations of becoming a game developer. However, I can't recommend it as something to spend your free time on. Really, if you're getting a hankering for Morrowind, just mod Skyrim.

One of the biggest sins many people commit on their journey of exploring great video games... is playing later installments in the series first. Morrowind is way too good, and most importantly, way too unique, too remarkable to be skipped in favor of Oblivion or Skyrim, and remains an extraordinary RPG to this day. Yet it definitely makes you appreciate the improvements that later games brought to the series more.

As most people agree, TES III gives us a rather weak game-in-itself, but also gives us an incredibly strong game world and even more incredibly strong lore for this world. That's what makes it so immersive and memorable, that's still what makes it stand out from most of the modern RPGs. Morrowind is deep, but very flawed: it is massive in scale, but technically limited to be visually and perceptually believable; its game systems are ambitiously designed, but its gameplay is not implemented well, which makes playing the game for dozens of hours tedious, repetitive and unrewarding. The world is inimitable, and the lore that gives so much life to this undynamic and barely inhabited terrain is still mostly unparalleled, but the main and side quests that should give us the motivation to explore and live in this world are not that engaging, with the word "well-written" reserved only for a dozen selected quests out of a hundred.

First acquaintance with the world, its strange look, its miriad of people to meet, books to read and systems to learn made it highly exciting. But the combination of weak gameplay and unsatisfactory quests made late-game exploring a chore, a tedium. In its purest, the Main Quest is written well, it really made you engage with the world, believe in what's happening within its realms, think deeply about political and philosophical implications that the lore makes. Aside the very best of the side content, however, only the start of the Tribunal expansion managed to revive this deep interest in me, with the quests being considerably more consistent in their quality this time around, and the gameplay becoming suprisingly challenging with the tougher enemies. Regretfully, Bloodmoon (except some of the attempts in making a few tough enemies that aimed to destroy even high-leveled characters) was mostly unsuccessful in engaging me with a new set of people, lands and quests: occasionally interesting and peculiar, but not engaging. Morrowind mods are great, for their time Morrowind mods were almost genre-defining... but I only used a few of them to enhance the look and fix some aspects of the gameplay, never to experience something different than the original game intended. I wouldn't like mixing the modded experience with the original playthrough experience: I would wish for the memories about this game to remain pure and unaltered.

If there is a single 10/10 element Morrowind, it is undoubtedly a masterpiece of a soundtrack by Jeremy Soule. Ironically enough, it might be the only decisive thing that made me finally play this game: I simply adored licensed Harry Potter video games OSTs, and in no way I could allow myself to miss listening to any of Jeremy Soule's works. Previously I thought Morrowind was too old, too obsolete, too ugly to play in a current day, I thought I could simply start my TES journey with Oblivion and listen to Morrowind's OST on Youtube instead... But with almost every soundtrack, the context in which the music is played greatly enhances the music itself, as well as the thing it accompanies. Without the music of Jeremy Soule, Morrowind's world is dead, static, uninhabited. But the music created the most unique bond between me and the game: it made me feel different every time I hear the sounds of  "The Road Most Travelled" or "Silt Sunrise", "Over the Next Hill" or "Caprice", "Shed Your Travails" or "Peaceful Waters", "Blessing of Vivec" or THE theme song to rule all the theme songs, "Nerevar Rising". Not a single exploration song is close to simply "listenable", "passable": every single mentioned song is fantastic, magnificent, enchanting.
As the game itself, the Morrowind OST is outstandingly unique: to an experienced ear, its composition sounds a bit.. raw, unrefined? The transition between instruments, between melodies sounds.. a bit unpolished, clumsy? Occasional melodies, the sound of some of the instruments might sound.. naive in their simplicity? So many instruments presenting so many melodical and harmonical levels - that's the magic of Jeremy Soule. Specifically, that's the magic of the early Jeremy Soule, when his music often sounded unexpected and strange, but thematically coherent and smartly arranged, beatifully ambient, but overwhelmingly powerful and dynamic.

Regrettably, Bethesda had little experience in handling game soundtracks at this point, so the OST was treated as a short list of randomized tracks on repeat. For such a long journey, for hundreds of hours of gameplay, it's simply impossible to not turn the music off at some point, just to save yourself from getting too accustomed to it, from overplaying it to death. It's a mistery why for Morrowind OST Jeremy Soule came up with more of an album of amazing songs, rather than an extended soundtrack that supports and accompanies you throughout the long hours of the game; why there are as many battle tracks as there are exploration tracks, when in reality only 1% of the game you are engaged in a battle, while 99% of the game you are engaged in exploration. Most likely, it's the inadequacy in Bethesda's requests for what a video game soundtrack they "envision", because clearly, at that point, they never heard of extending a track to fit into a long segment of exploration, or categorization to play different tracks in different areas of the world to create a different thematic feeling of these areas (the only thing they managed to accomplish is cueing battle track playlist when an enemy is engaged). What's more to say: originally, "The Road Most Travelled" was simply called "Main Theme", which is what it definitely sounds like, with its build-up and clearly defined leitmotiff which is then built upon, and which is definitely why it is one of the most memorable tracks in the OST. And "Caprice" was originally "Ending Theme", which is what, again, it definitely sounds like, and why it sounds a bit out of place in exploration tracks.
Jeremy Soule is without a doubt capable of making a long extended soundtrack that supports and accompanies the game, in creating themes for different areas and locations of the game world: he already accomplished that on noticeably long Harry Potter OSTs (time to finish the game was 10-20 hours compared to a 100+ of Morrowind hours, but they still have bigger soundtracks with more individual themes and pieces), and he would keep accomplishing this later with Oblivion and Skyrim. He even envisioned the original purpose for many of the tracks, which he integrated into the compositions and arrangements... But Bethesda was ignorant, blind and deaf to be able to make it work any differently than a randomized playlist on repeat that plays inside and outside, in settlements and in caves alike.

I can't overstate how much the music enchances this game, I can't praise enough Jeremy Soule for the feelings it invokes in me. I can't believe so few people discuss and analyze the soundtrack by Jeremy Soule; the most that people accomplish is comment on how "heartwarming" it is, how "very nostalgic" it makes them. Thankfully, Morrowind's OST was never a simple nostalgia to me, I see it for what it is: an astounding achievement for game soundtracks, an immense source for deep feelings, a masterpiece that put Jeremy Soule on a map as possibly the greatest auteur of the video game soundtracks. Similarly, Morrowind itself is not a nostalgia game, it's not just a game that made some design features that later games shamefully ommited: a one-of-a-kind RPG with an unmatched depth of lore... which I wish more games tried to match.

In the name of Dagoth Ur, the Ash Vampires of the netherworld have come to claim the land of Morrowind.

The dark lord has joined himself to a Divine Spark, buried deep beneath the Red Mountain.

Under the guise of salvation, the Sixth-House now spreads his blight;

Deeming mortals so fallen a creature, Dagoth Ur plans to save the realm by consuming the people.

Only the battle-weary Tribunes and the scattered elven tribes stand in his way.

As the ash-blight settles on the land, Dagoth Ur's domination seems inevitable,

But an ancient prophecy foretold the rebirth of an elven champion to fight for their souls and destroy this looming evil.

Now, their fate has fallen into the hands of an outlander...

The game is great for elder scrolls fans, the story is great, the lore is great, and the added perspective it gives on Talos, Shor and dunmer society is great. Unfortunately it has not aged well. The graphics are really bad, gameplay mechanics are bad, and quality of life features are absent. There is not a reliable fast travel system, and the map is very poor. This makes getting around frustrating. On the upside you can use magic to fly, so while that isn't great for exploration it does allow for one to safely move around the map if you can get the levitation effect to last. 

The game has much to do outside the main story, with numerous factions, and decisions that create new opportunities while cutting off others. So there is also replay value. 

The game has numerous aedric and daedric artifacts. Many of which are not obtained through daedric quests and are obtained by killing or robbing the current owners. 

You can obtain legendary weapons only mentioned in the later games such as scourge, stendar's hammer (yes the god of mercy's hammer). So if you like collecting aedric and daedric artifacts then the game offers more than skyrim.

Morrowind is a favorite of mine and a classic that is still fun to play today, but unfortunately I can't recommend it to someone who hasn't played before unless you're willing to dive into guides before starting the game. 

The biggest stumbling block isn't the graphics, but how obscure yet important certain stats are in the game that can lead to an experienced player to become a God within the first few hours of the game, or lead a new person to founder hopelessly against the mud crabs around Seyda Neen. Combat can feel terrible if you don't dump starting points into agility and use a major skill for a specific weapon. Movement is slow without a high speed stat or a small handful of items in specific locations. Spells constantly fizzling out because you barely have any points in willpower, and then magicka doesn't regenerate without resting, etc etc.

This isn't to say that Morrowind is a bad game. Far from it; it has a fantastic setting, lots of interesting people, a great main plot to get invested in, and the world is littered with huge power ups that are a delight to find, especially since they will retain their effectiveness throughout the game and aren't tuned to your level just to be discarded for a random trash weapon 5 levels from now.

If you want to give it a go and don't know anything about Morrowind, I highly recommend reading a few guides for how to build out a character and some locations to go for equipment and quests to make the first few hours smooth. The start can be rough, but the journey is absolutely amazing and still stands as one of my favorite games to experience.

Morrowind is as old as dirt, it's true.  The graphics may look a bit dated, but don't be fooled; you're looking at RPG gold right here.  In fact, the game has many advantages over Bethesda's more recent titles that I'll summarize for you quickly here.  To get the most out of this review, you must be at least slightly familiar with Bethesda's more modern offerings, so consider yourself warned.

1. Weapon Skills Make Sense - In Oblivion, the only melee weapon skills available are blade or blunt.  That's right, your shifty rogue is inexplicably just as skilled with a massive claymore as he is his tiny daggers.  Or get this: Skyrim "improved" on that system by making it just one handed or two handed weapons.  Now your dagger is functionally equivalent to a mace.  Morrowind didn't screw around with all that nonsense.  Weapon skills are divided into sensible groups that don't give you a migraine when you stare at them too long.

2. More Weapon Varieties - I won't even go into detail about how the later titles have watered down the weapon selection.  Just know that Morrowind will let you use crossbows, halberds, glaives, shurikens and the like with no problems.

3.  More Armor Variety and Skills - In hindsight, probably should have mashed the last two categories together, but hakuna matata.  Bethesda's latest stance on armor is that there are just two options: heavy or light.  Morrowind offers a medium armor category for those who want the best of both worlds.  There's even an unarmored skill that protects you without any armor at all, for all of you Chuck Norris wannabes out there.

4. Murder Hobos Rejoice - In Morrowind, feel free to shank anyone at any time, for any reason (or no reason at all).  The later titles make "quest NPCs" unkillable for some infuriatingly annoying reason.  Morrowind will give you a warning message that you may have just screwed up a questline in case you want to reload an earlier save, but ultimately doesn't stand in your way of killing your bosses, guildmasters, or the gods themselves.

5. Get Lost - After Morrowind, all Bethesda titles feature an onscreen compass with waypoints.  This admittedly makes completing quests faster, but sadly, also more boring.  To get things done on Vvardenfell, you actually have to pay attention to directions.  I know, I know.  It sounds dangerously similar to using your brain, but trust me; climbing Red Mountain through the ash wastes and turning west when you see the Ancestral Tomb is a lot more fulfilling than "follow the arrow until you bump your nose on the objective".

6. Magic is Magical - I'm the first to admit that I love the visuals on Skyrim's flame spell, but... the entire magic system just seems so lacking!  Morrowind's magic allows you to levitate through the air, detect the where the keys to your cage are hidden, teleport across the world, and so much more!

Rare stuff is Actually Rare - Level up high enough in Oblivion, and pretty soon every bandit and his grandma are sporting supposedly super rare glass armor, to the point that it quickly become pointless to pick up.  Not so in Morrowind.  If you want the best gear, finding it in the first place may become a quest in and of itself.

Just Realized that I Quit Numbering my Points - Diseases are terrifying in Morrowind.  Sure you can get rockjoint just as you can in Oblivion and Skyrim, but on Vvardenfell, this is just a lowly common disease.  Adventurers also have to worry about the much more deadly and difficult to cure blight diseases, and the incurable "Corpus" disease that turns honest folk into undead abominations haunts everyone's darkest nightmares.  That vampires and werewolves lurk in the hills is just a given.

10 or something - There is precious little mollycoddling in Morrowind.  Frankly, there are many quests that you simply can't handle at low levels.  Later titles scale a lot with your level to basically make it safe for you to go anywhere, but carelessness will quickly get you an early grave in this Bethesda title.  If you hear that there are Golden Saints guarding a daedric shrine, you'd better D*MN sure you're ready before you go skipping in that hellhole.

Anyway, I'm tired of typing.  There's a ton more redeeming qualities that can make this the crown jewel of your collection, but honestly, aren't you sick of reading when you could be adventuring?  Quit stalling n'wah!  Don your ringmail, pick up your spear, and seek out the nearest silt strider.  Join the throngs of desparate souls who seek to still the howling winds of the blight storms, heal the rift between shattered factions, and maybe even bring back a measure of sanity to their own increasingly compelling nightmares.  Remember... Many fall, but one remains.

This game is a beauty to the Fantasy RPG genre, even with its flaws. 

Morrowind will be unforgiving to new players who don't know entirely what's going on, and there's some things that should've been adjusted, but there's plenty to love.

One thing is the environment, some may take issue with the fact that it's so unique and that there's no typical fantasy environment in it, but in the end, that's what every other elder scrolls game takes care of. There is plenty of depth to the story, and lore included in this game alone, and its many quirks may discourage some, but learning to love them will lead to hours of time lost playing this game. 

However, I do not find it to be without flaw, you absolutely need to know what your build will be before you even make it, which will hit first-time comers the hardest, because they probably won't know the difference between long blade and short blade, they don't care about mysticism, they just want a cool story, and a fun game, and there's nothing wrong with that. The whole chance-to-hit system may work for some (I just deal with it whilst playing), but it certainly makes early game harder, and your fatigue lowering chance-to-hit with the lower it is can hurt hard when you're travelling across Vvardenfell. Another thing is that there's no quest markers, you'll have to remember directions, or look a lot of things up. I also want to say that not every location has a spot on the map, so you'll need to be available to go around a lot.

In the end, the story, environment, and absolute immersion make this game amazing, it's just playing it that hurts. However, for every mechanic you don't like, there's three mods that fix it, and the same probably goes for story. The intense modding community makes this game truly beautiful, and I do suggest everyone who owns this game download the Morrowind Overhaul mod, it really is worth it.

Many people have written many reviews about Morrowind, but the shortest way I could write why I love it is because it drops you and your character into a world as a foreigner, where you have to learn as you go, struggle as you learn, and cannot rely on decades of assumptions of how a fantasy world usually operates. There are no horses. There are no apples. This is not the 10,000th reiteration of western European fantasy that Elder Scrolls 4 and Elder Scrolls 5 both tediously churned out. This is Michael Kirkbride's weird little kwamahole of lore, setting, and CHIM that truly stands out about the rest.

Morrowind is the only game that I dedicated every bit of 2 months of my life to.

It was early 2004...I had just taken a permanent lunch break from my crappy job, I was living with a slob of a roommate, we ate ramen, I was using a credit card to get by and I was bummed out. I heard about Morrowind from a friend, who sold me when he said "It's kinda like GTA in a fantasy setting" (he was so dumb), I bought it used for about 10 bucks that day, popped it in my Xbox as soon as I got home and began my journey...

The addiction took hold immediately, "fuck the job search" I said to myself, as I also skipped some showers and meals. My routine was as follows: Wake up at about noon, play Morrowind for about 14 hours, sleep, repeat, with a few quick breaks in between of course. I was hooked.   

Morrowind amazed me to say the least and took me away from the BS that was life. Sure, some could say I was a "loser" during those 2 months but I didn't care and I don't regret it one bit, Morrowind was the greatest experience I've ever had with any form of art or media. It took 3 long years before I found near the level of enjoyment from a video game-(there was Fable in late 04 but it was short lived)-that I had in Morrowind, which was Runescape (believe it or not), but nothing has came close to the love I had for Morrowind. 

I persevered through the game freezes (losing hours of game play), starting over with different characters because I couldn't make up my mind which race I wanted to be, playing entirely in the 3rd person view, and that huge and incredibly annoyingly hard to navigate city (Vivec) while the characters, the level progression system (the sense of getting better with every step), the huge open world, the graphics (often moving the camera towards the sky at ingame night to look at the stars),.and the incredible music, sucked me in. 

The possibilities seemed endless with this game, as I could do whatever I wanted (ohhh shiny! I'll take that!) and there were surprises around every corner...I'm just casually walking along and all of a sudden someone falls from the sky and plops on the ground, "what the hell just happened?", I search their body, find a journal, then find out that now deceased character has a bit of back story as to why they ended up falling from the sky. Later, I jump up-(no climbing in Elder Scrolls!)-a mountain only to find a lone orc on top wearing badass armor I so desperatly want to have. "Can I take him?" was the question I was asking myself. It was these types of discoveries that made Morrowind so different.   

Most of the time I would ignore the quests and just roam the world to see who or what would pop up. Silt Striders were for "wussies", I thought, as I spent hours traveling the land on foot, making sure to occasionally jump or swim to level those acrobat and athletic skills. Often I was ever so swiftly r a p e d by a blighted Cliff Racer.      

Something this fun had to eventually come to an end, I couldn't stay in Morrowind forever.

After 2 months, the journey...was finally over...It happened on a Friday night...I finally decided to go out with a few friends, after they begged and had somewhat of an intervention for me. I finally became unglued from the game for a few hours. I ended up having an awesome night, hung out with friends I considered brothers, met a pretty chick, and it was then I realized living in the real world wasn't so bad and that it was time to make it better for myself.

It's almost as if Morrowind played a part in my transition into full blown adulthood, something I didn't want to face yet, even though I was of age. It was time to let go of the carefree days of being a kid with little responsibility. Morrowind was the grand finale.

The rest is history. I got a new crappy job a few days later, moved soon after (minus the slob roommate), and began dating the girl I met that night. I revisited Morrowind about 4 years later (PC physical copy) and sunk another 80 hours into it, but it didn't hold me as it did before, so that was it, I was done, I walked away never beating the game. It felt like it already served it's purpose back in "04".

Although sometimes I deeply miss the characters (Fargoth), the world, the music, and 2004, I can say that I am, for the most part, done with the game, a closed chapter of my life, but I'll always have extremely fond memories of Morrowind. I enjoyed Oblivion and am currently playing Skyrim SE & ESO, but they can't compare. Nothing can compare to Morrowind.

I look forward to Skywind and I watch the Morrowind store trailer once every few years for that nostalgic trip, and just hearing the main theme song damn near brings a tear to my eye. Like most people who have experienced a most joyous event, my time with Morrowind in "04" evokes pure happiness. 

Even if it meant that my character's end game was to be deleted from existence after being brutally fisted by a lowly scamp (of all things), I would still relive those 2 months in a heart beat.

After typing all of this, I feel the urge to play it, but I'm spolied now with Skyrim's improved engine, and I know the experience can never be the same...2004, unemployed, young with my whole life ahead of me...Those days are long gone...but I'm thankful to have had such an incredible experience.

Always has a special place in my heart just after Oblivion. This game is fantastic if you want more lore on what happens not too long before the Oblivion crisis, and has a unique dice roll play style in it's mechanics.

I actually got my start in the Elder Scrolls series with Skyrim, and when I first got in, I was convinced that was the pinnacle of what Elder Scrolls could offer. But I was always curious about those other games out there and decided to slowly move back. And the one thing I've found is that the further back I go, the more and more I enjoy the games.

Morrowind feels special and alive in ways I never thought a game of its age could pull off. Yeah, its absolutely filled with flaws, but the world felt so alive and unique that I wanted nothing more than to fight past those flaws and master the game, flaws and all. It felt great to improve at the game and to figure out how to bend its weirdness and nuances to finally work in my favour. I actually bought this game originally on Xbox, but decided to rebuy it here on Steam because I heard the PC version is more stable.

Yes, it is. And boy am I happy I can finally experience Morrowind without the issues I had on the system I previously owned it on. If you're a fan of just Skyrim like I was, I wholly recommend Morrowind. This world is amazing and feels special in a unique way other Elder Scrolls games just can't quite reach. I adore everything about this game and I look forward to prying into every single secret it has and immersing myself in the lore even more than I already have.

Based on the information provided, can you guess what game this review is for? What's it about? What kind of game is it?

Point is, these reviews are completely interchangeable. I bet if you took this exact review, and copy and pasted it to every game in your library, you'd get the top review for half of the games you put it on, even if you didn't change the check marks to fit each individual game.

In my opinion, the Steam community should stop encouraging this format and instead downvote them all into oblivion. Maybe it's just me, and I guess it's not THAT big a deal, but for someone that puts at least some effort into the reviews they write, it is a little disheartening that the steam community prefers lazy checklists that ultimately don't say anything specific about the games in question. Plus I don't see how they could ever actually influence someone's decision to purchase a game or not when so little information is given.

Anyone agree or am I the only one that wants to read legitimately helpful reviews for games I might be interested in?

I don't have a load of hours on Morrowind but I did play Skyrim and Oblivion and I think it's true to say that Morrowind was way ahead of it's time, even more than Skyrim, it's true Skyrim's modding has alot more of potential but Morrowind as a vanilla state can and probably will have alot more freedom than Skyrim, in terms of story, you get loose from jail and off you go in Vvardenfell, do w/e you want, ain't no one gonna search for you in that sink hole of an island.
In terms of mechanics, if you pick a weapon that, according to the stats you picked, are proficient with, you shouldn't have lots of troubles in the early game and if you are consistent with the weapon choice, no problem at all, with the magic, alchemy and enchanting, do w/e you want, literally, brew a speed potion so strong that you break the speed of sound or a strength potion so strong that you one shot the end boss with a daedric sword and break it in the process.
I think it safe to say that the sky is the limit, or atleast the game's engine.

One of the greatest games ever made. I played well over 3K hours on this back in they day, and probably spend at least half that amount of time messing with the Construction Set.

Fair warning though, if you come into this game with modern gaming sensibilities, you will HATE it. You will not have your hand held, the game won't even give you a glowing red marker to follow for quests. Reading is fundamental, and you'll be reading everything. The game absolutely will simulate you being terrible at things. And also cliffracers.

But my god is it good. It's a damn shame BethSoft has streamlined the RPG out of the RPG.....
Great game. Nuff said.

First the cons: The graphics sucks, and the mechanics are obtuse. Very little voice dialog.

Now for the pros: Unique setting, out of all of the modern Elderscrolls games, this one actually has a properly defined setting that isn't generic fantasy England. Without much voice acting, the NPC's are free to give you as much detail as the writers felt like doing. This might seem like a con for those who don't like it read, but the wealth of knowledge available in this compared to the other games cannot be overstated. The atmosphere, the visuals, and the culture... There hasn't been anything like it since Morrowind.

Come indulge and feel like you're truly foreign as you're pulled into this truly alien setting.

An incredible RPG, and hands-down my favourite in the Elder Scrolls series. I can't even put into words how good it is. The music, the world, the spells, the books, breaking the sound barrier with an enchanted ring of fortify speed and levitation - all of it. I love this game.

Editing this review. I made it when I had 50 hours. Now I have over 100 and would like to revise what I've said.

I'm still on my playthrough, just finished the main story and am now tackling the DLC. 

Now, what I will say is that I'll recommend this game PURELY for the magic alone. If you build your character well, you can literally become god. You can fly around, raining fire from above on your enemies. You can create your own spells, allowing you to damage enemies however you like, calm them to prevent them from attacking, command them, the list goes on. You can create nuke spells that cause an explosion of whatever spell you want in a maximum of a 50 feet radius. You can create Jump spells that allow you to jump super far and high. I've just scratched the surface of the magic system here.

Not only can you cast spells, you can enchant weapons, clothing (overpowered) and armour. You can create essentially rapid fire magic by enchanting rings with different spells and cycling through them. You can create constant effect spells and have your attributes go into the 100s. Your enchantments can let you run incredibly fast and jump incredibly far. Not only that, but alchemy is incredibly overpowered, allowing you to skyrocket your Intelligence into the tens of thousands, basically enabling infinite spellcasting. 

I don't have much to say on melee combat since I haven't exactly played as a melee character too much. Sorry.

I can comment on the story and the world itself though. I was never bored of the story or the lore of Elder Scrolls. It was really interesting throughout, and when I got to the final boss I was genuinely nervous. I like how the game doesn't end after defeating the main antagonist. The world changes and characters react to what you've done and the things that you've accomplished. 

I'm not a good reviewer by any stretch of the imagination. I've barely even covered anything with this review but I encourage you to buy this game if you're into role playing games. Its just fun. That's all I can say.

Morrowind is with mods still a great game 19 years after release and even better than Oblivion. Although it does not compare to the quality and immersive experience of Skyrim. 
The biggest negative issue is the missing voiced dialogues: If you want to catch some of the story, you will have to read a lot. Also, graphic quality and level design are pretty poor (especially compared to Gothic which actually released a year earlier).

This game is obviously structured differently, compared how Oblivion and Skyrim plays. Despite that, I still enjoy playing Morrowind in its primal attributes. It is a rough start to go through, especially when dealing with larvae and your attacks are weirdly based on D&D dice rolls. I think the game is still worth playing. For any newcomers, be mentally ready.

If you are the fan of the series, this one is a must. If you prefer mindless hack&slash (almost achieved by Skyrim), buy something else.

What is there to say? This game is a fantasy classic.

Still one of the greatest, if not the greatest game of all time. An Outlander arrives on the island of Vvardenfell. Are they a savior, or a just a random adventurer? With a story that is inspired by Frank Herbert's Dune, this masterpiece of a game pokes fun of the idea of a hero of prophecy.

The world of the game is HUGE. Different factions compete for power on the island, so if you join a faction, it might make you hostile towards other factions. Each faction has it's own quest line. You can choose to join 1 of 3 Great Houses, and at the end of the quest for your chosen house, you can build your own Stronghold, complete with vendors and guards. And of course there is the main quest and a slew of side quests.

While the main quest ends abruptly, the story continues in the Tribunal expansion (which is included). And in case THAT wasn't enough content, there is the wintery island of Solstheim to explore in the Bloodmoon expansion.

The combat is an older-style of D&D dice rolling. At the start of the game, you are very weak and will struggle to hit rats. The world feels lived-in. Powerful enemies hide in dungeons, ruins and caves all across the land. And if you try and fight them too soon, they will stomp you. The world is filled with the corpses of adventurers like you.

An absolute must-play for fans of the western open-world RPG genre. Stick with it. It's WORTH it, 100% guaranteed.

I don't want to be too hard on a game that is 20 years old.  But there are better games that are also 20 years old.  This game has too many "time wasters" built in, a common trait of online games.  The character walks very slowly.  They deliberately made many destinations hard to find or hard to get to without the Levitation spell.   You can't even use the cheat code because it only takes you to cities.   After 74 hours, I have yet to see any interesting plots that Bethesda is famous for now.  The quests are boring gathering, delivery, or escort quests.   There are many pitfalls - spells you buy then find you can't cast them.  Factions joined that turn out to be dead ends and you can't join a different one.  If you do buy this game, save often and read many guides first.  If you're looking for cheap but good fantasy games for a low power computer, Steam carries Quest for Glory series, Utlima series, Tex Murphy series, and Citizen Kabuto.

Do not come into this game expecting it to be like Oblivion or Skyrim. You have to earn every bit of info. There are no quest markers. You have to read your journal time and time again to figure out where to go. Even in combat, you have a CHANCE to hit your enemy, whether your attacks be from a sword, spear, axe, or even magic. This is an extremely rewarding game. They do not make games like these anymore :D
