Don't play this game. Just don't. It is not worth the headache. I keep trying to give it second third fourth fifth tries, thinking if I go into it with a fresh mind and dumb down the difficulty it will be more enjoyable. It is not. Morrowind is a game that deserves nowhere near what little praise it gets. Short form of my complaints:

-Pickpocketing is insanely broken and too many early quests require some form of it.
-Combat is tedious with continuous missing since it is probability base not skill based. This is true even at full energy bars.
-Quest tracking in this game is a nightmare. The journal is disorganized and haphazard.
-Trying to find anyone or anything is a nightmare. Asking for directions to a place can get you lost when east really means north and a tiny bit east.
-Traveling anywhere is painfully slow. Even when sprinting which you don't want to do since it takes your stamina bar so if you get attacked you'll miss more than normal.

Basically this game is several good ideas executed in the worst possible manner. Even if you understand the flaws and mechanics of the game it is more of a chore than entertainment to work around. If you do decide to play it, choose a class whose skills are easy to cheese to high levels and keep the wiki open for when you can't find out what to do.
A lot of effort can go into starting out in Morrowind, but it's definitely worth it. There's a lot of reasons I would put Morrowind above Skyrim. And this game is older than I am.

I played this in my teens, for hundreds of hours. I enjoyed it so much when I was younger, sitting with my original Xbox, when Halo 2 got boring, or nobody was online at 4 am. I have lived and breathed Vvardenfell, in many ways. Still to this day I have that intro memorized, and all of Sedya Neen's quests as well. I have fond memories of the things I've found, and I'm still finding things in game to this day, or exploring the odd cave I never did before to find relics and treasure... but the game is dated. It FEELS dated. It LOOKS dated.

Highly suggest if you DO play this, look up OpenMW, which updates the game's engine, and provides some modern functionality we are used to (like being able to delete saves actually inside the game, rather than opening up root folders), or toggle to sneak. It only allows Morrowind (that you already own) to play in a more updated fashion, and does not change any of the core mechanics. (It also takes a bit to customize.)

I say play it... especially if you have played it before. Get it for $5 and feel good about your younger years, or to understand where something like Skyrim started from. I'd also say understand that the mechanics (especially combat) are based on older ideas of dice roles to hit. You. Will. Miss. You will miss A LOT. 

If you have never played before, you are going to have useless skills. Combat is going to frustrate you if you just run at enemies expecting to be able to overpower them. You are going to have skills that accidentally over level you based on what they do, and how they work. You are going to find magic (especially if you are moving backwards from Skyim/Oblivion) to feel really bad at times, especially if your character build at level 1 didn't "allow" for magic. Early game is REALLY hard to get through. The "meat and potatoes" of the game doesn't really open up till, like, level 3-5, like, ya know, most dice dependent games (Pathfinder, D&D, etc), so try and keep that in mind when playing. Also keep in mind that you will EVENTUALLY feel like a god, and kill literal gods.

Be patient with grandpa Morrowind, he's old and senile.

Couple of graphics mods and you're playing one of the greatest RPGs of all time. Except when it comes to levelling alchemy. Levelling alchemy is the worst in this game.

The story is very intriguing, but this game was made before fully voice acted NPCs. The good thing about this is you get a lot more lore, and dialogue is a lot more engaging. You can follow up on leads and keywords, and it most of the dialogue actually flows quite naturally, and manages to avoid lore-dumps. 
There are some quest lines that have messy conclusions, but they're all mostly quite interesting and fun.

The gameplay is super involved. Elder Scrolls has, through it's evolution, seemed to devolve into a hack and slash action game. This is not that, this is under-the-hood dice rolls, D&D mechanics. It makes it difficult in the beginning, especially if you're not familiar with D20 type games and systems, you'll be wondering why nothing seems to work ever. The payoff is that once you've levelled up your desired skills, you pretty much become a demigod. P.S. Don't ever neglect fatigue (which really should've been called stamina). 

At this stage, running this game with the original graphics, while mind-blowing for 2002, looks very dated. So follow Nexus Mods' Morrowind Graphics guide and you'll make this game look ten years younger. 

The sound effects are quite basic, and some, like the magic sound effects, are downright corny. But the music is spectacular. I haven't looked at this game since its release, and i didn't realise that all the loveliest pieces of music from Skyrim were actually written for Morrowind (probably i'll soon find out they were actually as old as Arena)

Bottom line, if you're an Elder Scrolls, RPG, or D20 enthusiast, definitely play this game at least once the whole way through. Morrowind transcends merely being a historically significant video game, it is still a barrel of fun. 

TRIBUNAL DLC:
Absolute trash. It takes all the worst things about the base and puts them on steroids. 

You are confined to one (albeit quite large) city and it's sewer system. Most of this game takes place in a cave, so it's very boring. Most of the above ground parts take place in one complex or another, and they're quite laberinthian. I don't know who wanted more places like Vivec, but that's what this is. So there goes the open world. 

The main quest is on rails, it feels like you have no agency, there's only one way to complete anything, and all the hard earned respect you've earned from single-handedly fixing Vvardenfell is irrelevant. So there goes the role playing. 

A lot of the new enemies are damage sponges. This is the most boring way to make a game more difficult. It sucks the fun out of fighting, it just takes so long to kill things. So there go the intricate battle mechanics. 

This is the Elder Scrolls DLC version of kicking a not-yet-dead horse to death.

BLOOD MOON DLC:
A refreshing return to what Morrowind does best. Wide open expanses and being pestered to death by cannon-fodder critters. You've got a main quest, and a long subquest, both of which are branching, both of which are fun and have exciting story lines. There's also some lovely new music.

The only downside i can see in this expansion is that a lot of enemies are still bullet-sponges. This is wholly unnecessary as the they already pose new challenges with their differing fighting styles.

The most Immersive game I have ever played. You get sucked in right away, with your normal quest marker being replaced with a notebook, only your directional sense can help you. Yes, it can be tedious, but you feel like you actually accomplished something. The way this game handles world building is incredible. Highly Recommend this game.

The improvements are all thanks to a modding community that never stopped loving Bethesda's best ever RPG.

Worth playing for nostalgia, but if you missed Morrowind the first time around, I'm afraid you may not be able to appreciate it now.

One of the best games of all time. I played this on the original Xbox when it first came out, and have very fond childhood memories of it. I'm positive I've spent thousands of hours total on it, and I never get tired of it. It's very old now, of course, so there's lots of "missing features" that we take for granted nowadays. If you're new to the game, this can be off-putting. Things like very limited fast travel options, the fatigue system making you miss hits and fail spells, no compass markers, and vague journal entries. You also start the game incredibly weak, and the first enemy on the way to the first main quest location (veterans know who I mean) will murder you easily if you go there right away before leveling and gearing up. Hang in there though, seriously. Once you get past all of that and get used to the game's systems, it's such an incredible and extremely unique world to explore. There's about a million mods now if you want to improve the graphics or add features, but I prefer the original experience. Highly, highly recommend this game for anyone interested in the Elder Scrolls series or sandbox games.

Oh also, this version crashes pretty frequently. So save often!

So Morrowind is definitely an excellent game. But what i warn new players is that you can't play it expecting it to be Skyrim, because it definitely is not. My review will be mainly going through the pros and cons, and slight comparison towards Skyrim.
General Gameplay:
Its hard. of course you can adjust the difficulty, but even when its set at medium, it can be so frustrating. Which i think is great. you start the game off with your character you're so weak. While at first it can be an extreme put off, it is so rewarding being able to one hit cliff racers. and you get to feel unique with your character also. its extremely difficult to level all your skills, without exploits or other methods that aren't playing the game normally. Whereas in Skyrim, you could master everything with a lot more ease, making you feel strong from the get go. When you decide to be a thief in Morrowind, you actually feel like your skills are more attributed towards that sort of build.
Combat:
Its ok, its very frustrating at times. Every attack is based off your fatigue, even magic, so when you run out, you start chugging potions or just spam until you hit. The enemies themselves are cool, not cliff racers, but they can get old quickly. but either way, it was nice to see such unique creatures. Fighting them can be annoying, but once you build up your agility, strength, whatever, it can be really empowering. but it can grow quite dulling after a while. 
Quests:
Quests aren't the strongest i admit. for roleplay, they're really good. when im in any guild, i actually feel like im participating in that guild. But a lot of them seem to go "kill this person", "retrieve this" or a mixture of the two. the main quest, to me, is the only quest that feel "unique". While each quest can be unique in some fashion, a loot of them seem to fall into the previously mentioned categories. But it is really fun to play them without quest markers, it makes yous feel more like an explorer, but a lot of the time, the information needed isnt enough to find the location. And a lot of quests conflict it seems. i had to fix a few where i killed a certain person i wasnt supposed to, or even opened a container and it stuffs something up. I know a lot can be fixed with the MCP, but i didn't play with it. this is a review of the raw game.
Guilds:
i actually feel that the guild system is better than skyrim's. Having to actually have my skills at a certain level before i could make an advancement was really fun, and it made me feel like i actually earned the position. The quests aren't that exciting. at some points they actually seem interesting, but they mostly feel tedious. But instead of being the "chosen one of every guild" that skyrim makes you, Morrowind makes you feel like a regular member of the guild, which feels really nice for roleplaying. In some cases, the game forces you to stick with a guild, rather than join two that conflict, (thieves guild and fighters guild for example), but this can be worked around
NPCs:
arent that good. A lot of them feel like copy and paste, with no real unique personality. of course this happens in a lot of Skyrim npcs also, but it seems a lot more in Morrowind. There seems to be a repeating male and female voice for each npc, and you only hear it while they idle, or see you. The lack of voice when talking is understandable, but not exactly enjoyable. And it seems that even with a high disposition, a lot of "negative characters" will make mean remarks towards you, but once you enter a conversation it become "how's my favourite person on the planet doing?". and even when you've met a character, they make remarks that they dont know you. but there are some great unique characters, like uncle crassius or Ahnassi. Also obtaining a high disposition is too easy, and ruins the fun of relation building i suppose.
Skills:
each skill requires 100 points to level up, until 100 without enchanted gear, or other bonuses. so a lot of skills that a while to level without exploits, but it has a nice feel, sometimes. there are a variety of skills which help for roleplaying, and make your character feel unique. Choosing a main and minor skill helps towards this also.
Magic:
I love spells in this game. you can only cast really good ones when youre truely a master wizard. it feels a lot better than skyrim. especially how you can create spells, its really cool. however, creating spells (good ones) requires a bit of  gold, and you need to ability to cast them. which is a bit frustrating especially when youre leveling a magic skills, but you keep failing your spells.
General game mechanics:
everything works from either your fatigue or luck, and its quite frustrating. even if its more realistic, you have 3 oppotunities to fail a pickpocket. lockpicking, pickpocketing, and other skills seem to work heavily on luck, which is a bitch to level up. i can't say these mechanics are better than skyrim ones, pickpocketing is really similar to skyrims i guess, but i prefer lockpicking. sneaking is fine, i suppose, but i never felt any desire to sneak through a dungeon. enchanting and spellmaking early game arent that fun, but further on they become more worthwhile. Becoming op isnt that hard, i admit. some quests just give you some really good gear really quickly. or just finding it isnt too hard. talking with npcs is uncomfortable, especially when you have like 50 topics, and you dont even know if they have the one youre looking for. its quite messy. the journal log is fun to see this stuff added, but the way quests are situated aren't that neat, it takes you probably an hour before you realised youve just picked up a quest. the topics help, buuut they dont always include the information you want. looking for someone? asking everyone for their name, but they dont have it? too bad then. 
Conclusion:
Morrowind is definitely a development from Arena and Daggerfall. It is a really good roleplaying game. in terms of role playing, its 100x better than skyrim. but i don't exactly feel the same satisfaction from completing quests that i do in Skyrim. it doesnt exactly feel "fleshed out". i dont know how to explain it better. The graphics are from early 2000s, so i dont think theyre necessary to mention. However, it does feel like an elder scrolls game, with better aspects than skyrim. But in total, i feel Morrowind is better for role playing, and skyrim for story telling. I do recommend that you try it out. Downloading a couple of mods like MCP is worthwhile to enjoy less bugs. and try not to intimidated by the morrowind cult, yes you're allowed to enjoy skyrim, oblivion, whatever more than Morrowind. i prefer Skyrim, but i can definitely tell why people love this game. And i hope that many give it a try.

This game brings back my old memories. I used to play this game a lot in rainy summer days. Story rich game with many characters and locations.

This game should be in strong consideration for the GOAT of RPGs. I used to mod this game (AKA Stormwynd)  along with Dongle, Mykal, and several others. I have lost scores of mods that I was working on including a huge nature collaboration with Dongle. I recently purchased the Steam version and after 19 years, I am still in awe of this game. 

If you are looking for a game that even for its flaws is thought provoking, has great voice acting, and that old school RPG feel, look no further!

Morrowind isn't just a game. 20 years removed from its initial release, and it still has one of the most active modding and playing communities in the RPG genre. For many, Morrowind is THE game. But why is that? As someone who grew up on Oblivion, I never saw the appeal of the strange and sometimes archaic mechanics of Morrowind. That was until around 2015. 

Ah, 2015: Witcher 3 is dominating the review boards, Bloodborne has elevated From Soft to new heights and you’re in college unsure of what you’re doing with your life. (Maybe that last one was just me) Regardless, dead center in that "it isn't possibly going to take 10 years for another Elder Scrolls is it?" I found myself hungry for that ‘Elder Scrolls Experience.’ Having cut my teeth on Oblivion and Skyrim, Morrowind seemed...different. But I wanted different, so I gave it my honest try.

 It was a much harsher game than my modern mind was accustomed to. Filled with a lot more reading, less direction, and generally less hand holding than I had ever anticipated. I vaguely remember that first play through at all, but I can say that I remember leaving it torn. On the one hand I had genuinely enjoyed my time—though admittedly I missed huge swaths of content—but on the other the game didn't quite "do it" for me. Why that is, I couldn’t quite say. Maybe it was the lack of voice acting or the weird animations. Regardless, I went back to Skyrim and continued to do so every few years whenever I needed that Elder itch scratched. Oddly enough I've never gone back to Oblivion, but that's a story for another time. 

Fast forward to 2021. I'm in a lull between moving and finding work and need something to occupy my time. I go back to old reliable, Skyrim, only this time it's different. It all feels...shallow. This was strange. Granted, it had been roughly 2 years since I had last played the game and I had played MANY wonderful titles in that span. But still, I was confused. How could Skyrim feel this way? It seemed that no matter how many mods I installed I still wasn’t feeling ‘it.’ I was distraught, until I began looking online to find I wasn’t the only one who felt this way. 

Now you can call it maturity. Your mind hits 30 and suddenly the things you used to like don’t quite feel the same anymore. This isn’t true for everything but as I replayed Skyrim this year, I realized something. Skyrim, as an RPG, is one of the most barren experiences you can have. While a beautiful sandbox and playground, Skyrim doesn't give one the FEEL of an RPG. It doesn’t FEEL like anything you do matters. Nothing is really earned, and the world feels far too static for all the monumental changes you supposedly make to it. The story is shallow and the most memorable character, Ulfric, is an antagonistic racist with a tragic backstory. This is cool, but why is he the only one worth mentioning outside, maybe, Paarthunax? Where are the deep interesting characters? The engrossing story? I craved these most of all. I craved choices like those in Dragon Age Origins or Fallout New Vegas. (Although admittedly you won't find those in a Bethesda game outside of mods). Even still, I wanted to feel that what I was doing in the world mattered, but how?

Enter Morrowind. Remember it? That game with 20 years of tweaks, mods, and graphical enhancers to allow even a noob to the series an honest shot of enjoying it. Despite my initial reservations, I followed a few tutorials, watched a dozen videos, and booted up the world. To my amazement, I was in love. Almost instantly all those problems I had with Skryim were rectified. Instead of shallow quests I had deep pools of factions just waiting to be explored. All with deep lore and interconnectivity. The Great Houses ALONE are better than the entirety of Skyrim’s faction pool. Master Aryon, Uncle Crassus, and Arthyn Sarethi are each memorable in their own right but what about Divath Fyr or Vivec? The Last Dwemer or the re-awakened Dagoth Ur himself. Morrowind, if anything, has the best main story in the series. It’s worth it for those things alone. The game boasts over 10 factions and a main quest that  doesn’t force itself on you but instead rewards you for playing it. While there are tedious bits, by the end of it you genuinely feel like the reincarnation of an old hero. Countless dungeons, quests, and people to see and talk to along the way. The culture of Vvardenfell unfolding before you. 

That’s what it’s all about really. The world. The world FEELs like something. It feels alien. Fresh despite its age. Couple this with mod projects like Tamriel Rebuilt of Skyrim: Home of the Nords, and it can be an almost overwhelming amount of content. Something comparable only to the Mount and Blade community (which I am also a huge fan and member of). As someone who has played games since 1996, Morrowind has immediately vaulted itself to the top of my 'Greatest of All Time' lists, something I never expected to happen. But how is this possible? Honestly, I’m not 100% sure.

Morrowind is not a perfect game, no matter the lore, story, tweaks, and bug fixes. There are CTD’s, graphical glitches, and quest chain breaking bugs.  Couple that with one of the worst combat systems in 'modern' gaming (which relies on dice throws that the game never even bothers explaining to you) and you have a recipe for unhappy gamers. Those who can look past the jank, will have a good time. As a veteran of games like Stalker, Cossacks and Mount and Blade, I am well familiar with these concepts. Those who are more accustomed to streamline/polished experiences may have a harder time. I’m not saying your miles won’t vary. In my most recent playthrough I had 3 crashes in roughly 70 hours. Not bad. A couple quest bugs but nothing console commands couldn’t fix. But it’s important to be aware of these things going into it. Remember: F5 is your friend. Use it often. 

I’m not really sure where this review was going, or where it went. Hopefully it gives you motivation to give Morrowind a try. If it steered you away, well, at least you were informed. I can’t promise a constant smooth experience. This is a Bethesda game after all. But I can promise that if you can accept the learning curve and walls of text then you will be welcomed by a wholly unique and fun experience. They really don’t make games like this anymore, and that includes Bethesda. Many of the people who worked on this game haven’t worked at Bethesda in years and once you play through Morrowind it’ll become all too apparent. Do yourself a favor and give it a go. It really is a relic of days gone. A reminder of what the series could have been and, in some ways, the first in a long line of modern 3D RPGs. A Classic worthy of it's laurels and its criticisms. 

But I’ve talked long enough. Now if you’ll excuse me, I have a scroll of Icarian flight with my name on it. *phwnnnnn* HRNNNNNNGHHHHH! AHHHHGHHHH! *crack*

Morrowind, once you get around the first few hours of trying to get it to run right, and then trying to understand how to even play it, is incredibly fun. I'm not sure why, I just really enjoy it. I recommend it to anyone who can deal with a few issues from old games

Some tips before you start playing:

*Fatigue! Fatigue in morrowind is more than just stamina, it effects your chance to attack, so don't make a fatigue and agility low build, because, like my first character, you'll find you can't even hit a rat.
*Another Important thing is Speed, as it literally controls the speed your character walks and runs at. I recommend having athletics being a minor skill, because it will both increase how long you can run, and, as it levels up, it will increase the amount at which your speed can be increased when you level up. When levelling up you can only increase 3 attributes, (like speed, strength, intelligence), and the amount you can increase them depends on how many skills that are governed by the attribute you increase. Sounds complicated, and the maths probably is, but once you start playing, it just means if you want to increase your strength, try using an axe, if you want to increase your endurance, try a spear (it tells you which skill is connected to which attribute in game).
*Before you mess with files, it is generally important to start the game first, maybe even make a character and see what the instantly noticeable issues are (at the normal resolution the game is off the screen for me, I still haven't used any mods, I just change the resolution).
*If the settings are reset after you reopen the game, you'll need to set the games .exe files to run in admin mode, this is done by: going to your morrowind folder and for both Morrowind.exe and Morrowind Launcher.exe, right clicking, going to properties, then the Compatibility tab, then ticking "Run this program as an administrator".
Once you've made it so your settings are saved, you can edit the controls to make it more like more recent games if you want (E is use, space is jump, so on), but generally the controls are pretty standard.
*If you open the game and in game nothing works but the mouse, but when tabbing out the keyboard still works, you just need to restart the computer, and you should be fine (its annoying, but there's nothing else you can do, as far as I know)

I hope these tips help! I'm still quite new to the game and I found getting it working quite annoying, but getting through that was worth it. That being said, I likely got some things wrong so I recommend watching a few videos and reading a few guides, and I'll allow comments for when someone with 10k+ hours sees these and goes "god, that is awful advice".

Thanks for reading, and have fun!

"Stand up... there you go. You were dreaming. What's your name?"

That was one of the first sentences I read when I played Morrowind for the first time several years ago. It was my first real exposure to the Elder Scrolls series (I had played the Daggerfall demo a long time ago but didn't have the chance to play the full version further at the time). I remember the feeling of awe, the sensation of freedom and perfect worldbuilding present in the game and the way its music, plot, characters and land hooked me in.

Morrowind is the third game in the main (numbered) series and in my opinion the best, but some of its gameplay aspects will be more difficult to be accepted by the modern audience of Skyrim and Witcher 3. Its combat is much closer to RPG rules, requiring die rolls to hit instead of always hitting - and the same for blocking. Magic is extremely slow but powerful if one has the time to prepare and the game can be easily broken if the player knows where to invest the character's build.

Whereas Oblivion had the standard fantasy land and Skyrim the nordic pastiche, Morrowind was something else entirely. Its peoples and cultures were and still are unique and none today have come close to building such an alien world in a mainstream open world RPG.

There are community-made add-ons called mods that greatly expand Morrowind for the returning player that wants something new or the new player that wants a more modernized experience (look it up) or play it vanilla as it should be, at least the first time around.

I played an enormous amount of games since finishing it a long time ago and have restarted it again and let me tell you, it still sits among the top pretty comfortably.

Interestingly, there is a reverse-engineered open-source port of the game done by fans that apply modern functionalities to the binary with minimal hassle (widescreen, filters, stability) called OpenMW. Be sure to check it out, but refer to its mod compatibility if you want to use any.

"Welcome, Moon-and-Star, to this place where destiny is made."

The Elder Scrolls 3 is mostly a "required play" because of the fact that it revolutionized RPGs, but that doesn't mean that it doesn't hold out well on its own as well. As a Bethsoft game, you should be fully aware that it is armed to the hilt with stupid glitches. But if you can get past those (or mod the majority of them out) and survive the outdated graphics, you will find some of the best lore and video game storytelling of all times.

Pros: STORY, Story, and story (and lore); Many spells, including the ability to levitate and make your own spells; Many quests and ways to define your playstyle.

Cons: Glitches; Graphics (they really haven't held up well); character customization (appearance wise);

Neutral: There is no fast travel, and there is no map with markers showing you where you are supposed to go. These are standard staples in today's massive world games, but I am not calling it a con, because it was part of the way it was meant to be played. I also am not calling it a pro, because I know not everyone will be happy about it.

At the end of the day, I strongly suggest a play through of Morrowind, especially if you enjoy its younger siblings Oblivion and Skyrim. It tells a better story than both of them combined, and sets the stages for a lot of what you see in the 2 games by fleshing out Nirn.

I'm (clearly) only a few hours in but, for it being as old as it is, this game is very fun! Yes, you do have to mod it a bit for it to have a coat of paint that looks at least on par with Oblivion, but it's very easy to mod. Just get MGE XE, the code patch, script extender, and then whatever mesh and texture mods you want. It's well worth it. The story feels like it was done with much love and care, while the game still has all of it's Bethesda-y, Scrolls-y charms. Not quite as silly as Oblivion, but still loving it. The first hour or two is going to make you feel like disintegrating from the difficulty curve, but once you're past that it's very good! Glad to see the specifically-tailored custom classes as well, that's something I really liked in Oblivion that I didn't realize I missed when I had played Skyrim as my first Scrolls game. You can even put a description for your class! It may seem just like a small thing, but little lore and roleplay details like that really make this more of an RPG. 

Overall, this is quite a great game so far, and I am looking forward to put 80+ more hours into it :) And if you're unsure about getting this game because of the recommendation you mod it, don't be! Modding Morrowind is very simple, and there's plenty of easy to follow tutorials online. Skyrim was my first game I modded ever, and I thought Morrowind was just as easy as Skyrim! Go for it, install those graphical update mods! Or don't, whatever you want and however you want to play!

When I was in high school, a little less than a year after Skyrim came out, I was talking to this girl about the game. Both of us were really into the Elder Scrolls and RPGs in general and we were talking for a few hours when she suggested that I come over to her house one day. I agreed and we set a date and time that weekend.
When I showed up to her house, her parents weren’t home and she answered the door in her swimsuit, which I thought was weird because she didn’t have a pool. I asked her why she was in a swimsuit to which she responded that she just felt like trying it on. “Okay.” I thought. So I went up to her room and pulled out my laptop, then proceeded to show her my Morrowind character for the next hour or so and tried to sell her on how great the game was.
Eventually she put her clothes back on and I went home disappointed that I didn't convince her to at least try the game, but hopefully this story can convince you.

morrowind is a great game. easy to run, great story and great scenery. there are a couple of things that might turn others away though but for an elder scrolls fan and someone who enjoys these older games this is right up your alley.

the problems

morrowind isn't a "hold you hand" game much. as soon as you get into morrowind your on your own. there is a guide at the start but its a small one and once your outside its "make your own way" deal. should also point out that there's no waypoint markers so you have to use directions and talk to npcs who know the way and use the map.

speaking of there's no fast travel in this game so there's a LOT of walking. you can make an alternative with strider's and intervention scrolls but be prepared to still walk a lot.

the only other thing i can think of is the combat. combat with weapons uses a dice roll mechanic so be prepared to miss a lot. there are ways to reduce it but it will always be there so prepare for fights carefully.

if there's more ill put them here otherwise its still a great game and worth playing. especially if your an elder scrolls fan.

fuck skyrim

The story and world building of this game is pretty good and I can understand why it was considered a masterpiece when it was released. Despite this, there are a lot of frustrating parts of the game that sour the experience terribly. The combat is infuriating and dreary rather than exciting and action packed. 

When you want to hit a target, you first have to aim, which makes sense. Whether you hit or miss is completely up to chance, even if you are completely on target. The amount of damage you do is also quite variable. The worst part is that there is no difference between the sound of you missing because you did not target the enemy properly and the sound of you missing because of chance. For the first couple of hours, I legitimately thought the game was broken. 

Even worse is the movement. I appreciate that their are limited ways to fast travel in this game, I think it is really cool. Walking on foot and exploring in Skyrim was an amazing experience. Walking around exploring in Morrowind is not an amazing experience. It is a slow, drudging, soul sucking experience. You move SO SLOW!!! Around 70% of my time in this game has probably been spent walking. The game does offer numerous fast travel options, but they are not available everywhere and you'll still need to walk at a snail's pace through dreary, generic wasteland to get to the next adventure.

This game has a lot of good things about it. It can be legitimately beautiful at times and the story is interesting and gripping. It has gotten me invested almost two decades after its release. The game really shows its age though. 

If you enjoy this game, I can see why. Honestly, I enjoy it too. I can not recommend it though.

Morrowind is a game that shows its age, despite the impact Elder Scrolls games have had on other RPG series, Morrowind itself almost feels a little unconventional even by the standards set by the more recent entries in the series. That being said I don’t have a huge amount of deep insight into Morrowind besides it having an impressive world to explore, as exploration was pretty much all I did in the game. Finding cities and towns and strange people in a vast fantasy world, I found myself completely uninterested in quests, or levelling, and only fought something when I couldn’t run away from it. As for whether or not I’d recommend it, I’d recommend playing Oblivion or Skyrim, but not Morrowind. Morrowind is far less user friendly, it demands much more from the player to complete quests, but even then, it has relics of older or more traditionally turn based styles of RPG’s such as miss chance, despite requiring you to attack in real time. If you’re ok having to navigate everywhere manually, and have attacks miss even though you physically hit the enemy, and don’t mind the occasional technical difficulty given the game’s age (first time playing I got stuck in a wall in less than a minute of being given control of my character), then maybe this is for you, but I couldn’t get myself fully engaged and feel that Oblivion and Skyrim have a lot more general appeal to offer.

Pros: 

-Okay-ish story. Characters are believable in their motives. 

- combat is arguably better than the newer installments. (It's like rolling in real-time)

-Magic is FUN. 

-Really good UI that let's you see all your status without clicking 20 menus. 

-Vvardenfell has multiple biomes to explore. 

-Cons     

Traveling sucks! Even late game speed and spells makes it boring that you have to go through the same empty areas full of Cliff Racers. Major cities are a maze. I don't know what happened here, but the starting area and the towns near it are so much better that the major ones. Even the NPCs joke that they get lost in them, it's not fun to go back and forth to do fetch quests when 90% of your time spent on the quests is traveling.  

-Directions suck, a NPC will tell you to go North, you go there and search for an hour and find nothing. This doesn't happen once, even the game's WIKI says the directions are wrong in-game.

-Guilds don't immediately make you leader when they meet you (*cough* Skyrim *cough*) and you actually have to rank up in them, too bad they're also 90% fetch quests till something fun happens. 

-Main story is "okay-ish" like I said, the thing why it's also in cons is it forces you to do what the game wants. Like you have the option to kill a character but you fail the entire main questline and there's no point in playing. If you persuade main quest characters they still force you to do their errands (unlike side quests).  

-DLC's were boooooring. (And even interfere with your game if it's your first time, since they drop super expensive items).    


-Nothing to spend money on, I ended my playthrough with 300k coins and never thought I wanted to go to a shop to upgrade, all my high level items were from just exploring. I stopped even looting late-game.  

Game becomes super easy after level 10, I can only think of 3 areas that were of any challenge late-game.  


Dungeons and shrines are copy-pasted (they have cool rewards in some of them, but it feels like a chore when you do them for the 50th time). 


-Game crashes every 20m and my keybinds randomly reset.
WHAT A GRAND AND INTOXICATING VIDEO GAME!
Game feels very outdated. It has mediocre combat and travelling takes a lot of time(your walkspeed is very very slow).
Worth trying, but wait for sale.

When I talk about Morrowind, I'm talking about the game that won my heart and gave me the love of the RPG genre!
I can say with confidence - after many 10-20 years of playing different RPGs - that Morrowind not only remained in my heart as a great and pure love, but also became the best RPG in the entire existence of this genre!


[h1]Plot:[/h1]
The success of a good RPG is storytelling! After all, the story that we see on the screen of our monitors, we read like a book, and because of how versatile and rich it will be, it will depend - whether we want to reread it again and again even after many years! I can really say that the plot of Morrowind is an amazing story that you will want to re-read many times and replay over and over again to find out all the possibilities, subtleties and trifles that we might not have noticed when we first read it - passing the game! Even after 15-20 years, we will remember the detective story, where we not only learned the secrets and arcana of this World and unraveled the tangle of intrigues, but also assumed the role of the savior of these Lands from the ancient cult and ancient Gods who wanted to destroy our World.

[h1]RPG system:[/h1]
Many games that call themselves RPG forget that this system must be quite large and to a certain extent difficult for the player, so that the study of this whole system is like learning mathematics from the multiplication table to matrices and other more level elements - algorithms that will add up to a single picture of the existence of this virtual world!
You will get the opportunity to make a character level 100, pump all skills to level 100, learn hundreds of new spells and abilities and create 1000 types of weapons, scrolls, potions, giving you the opportunity to create your own unique character leveling system and unique tactics of life and victory against evil!

I managed to get level 105 in one of my playthroughs, can you do the same? :)

[h1]Virtual world:[/h1]
I would like to separately note this wonderful romantic world in which you just want to live!
Even when you reach your maximum level in the game and complete all tasks: main and side quests.
There are very few games that have such a rich and saturated world, filled with many small details that fascinate you and imbue you with the magic that exists in our real world, but which we simply do not notice due to the fact that we rarely look at the stars above our heads!

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
When the game appeared, I was very delighted with this graphics, which I saw on the screen of my 17-inch monitor, and then on the screen of the 19-inch monitor, which I bought a little later (when I played the game for the second time). Even when I ran this game on the formats of the new 28 inch 4K monitor, I saw the same beautiful picture that I saw many years ago! At the same time, I understand that these are graphics - the game does not give a widescreen resolution, since it is old, like good wine, but over the years it gets better and is filled with a large bouquet of flavors, notes of nostalgia for my soul!

[h1]Music:[/h1]
This game has amazing gentle music that will caress your ear throughout the entire gameplay!
Even when you're done playing this game, you'll want to download the album of this music and use it as a divine serenade before bed!
When you have children (or maybe they already have), then you will want to put this music as a lullaby for them, so that they can feel the taste of beautiful and high art from childhood!

[h1]Bugs:[/h1]
This is the saddest part of all that I wrote above, but I can't help but write about it!
Yes, there are many bugs in the game, it's pointless to describe all of them, but I want to say that some of them add more hardcore to the passing of the game!
As an example - my favorite bug - there is a destroyed Daedra statue that asks you to restore it, and in return you can get a unique Golden Sword, the most powerful sword in the game!
The whole point is that from the beginning of the game, a timer starts, and if you do not have time to accumulate 5.000 gold in the first 2 weeks and still get a couple of rare elements (and this is very difficult to do), and then start restoring this statue with the help of a master sculptor , then you just risk not getting this wonderful sword!
That is, if you play this game and do not do everything quickly enough in 2 weeks, then, of course, you can restore this statue, it will talk to you, but it will not give you this sword! This is just a bug that was made by the developers and which, most likely, cannot be fixed, probably after tens of years. And there are a lot of such bugs in the game. Studying every bug and every subtlety of the game mechanics gives you more hardcore in terms of passing the game than any difficulty level that you will increase in the game!
 This is the unique game in which bugs make the game not worse, but better many times over, and therefore it becomes one of the best RPGs for a real hardcore RPG gamer!

10/10 Hardcore Love

On Steam I have 53 hours on record but in reality I've put at least a couple hundred hours into Morrowind, both vanilla and modded. I recommend anyone playing on PC today use the Morrowind Graphics Extender to enable distant terrain. There are also some texture and mesh replacers out there that are quite close to vanilla but look much better. I think after all these years these graphical mods are kind of necessary.

You will have to overlook some old and clunky designs, you will have to understand that your to hit percentage is based on skills, not on physically connecting, and until you hit like mid-level with your weapon skills a lot of your attacks will miss.

But it's worth putting up with all for the freedom this game gives you. Freedom in how you explore, which quests you do, which factions you back, freedom of play style, freedom to make your own spells, enchant your own gear (and there's more of it here than any other Elder Scrolls game). It's a big, alien world that I really enjoyed exploring. 

A lot of younger gamers will honestly just bounce off this game. But for people willing to put in a little time to learn the systems they will find a real classic gem of a game.
